This might be one of the best fighting games of the decade, the sheer popularity of the Dragon Ball franchise can't be denied and Arc System Works took that popularity and made an amazing game out of it.
This for all intents and purposes is the de facto Team Fighting Game nowadays, it features a great roster, a variety of characters with a variety of moves and playstyles, ease of play for begginer and a big enough challenge for veterans, jaw dropping graphics and animations and a hear warming soundtrack.
The roster is definitely pay to win, characters like Ultra Instinct Goku are broken to all hell, but even with the base roster you can build an amazing team full of top tiers, and with the game being at a state where you can play every character and have a chance to win, it makes for a great experience, with or without dlg.
The final veredict is that this game is amazing and deserves your 60 bucks, but I would advise you to buy it if you want to get into the competitive scene or even if you just want to play ranked at a comfortable level.
So pro tip: Use a Lan Cable please, the netcode is really bad and a stable Lan connection is vial to have a pleasant experience, thankfully a cable usually costs between 5 and 15 bucls.

First off, the PS4 version is better in nearly every way, mostly online play. I've logged about 300+ hrs on that version.

Now to main review, FighterZ is a new-player friendly 3v3 Fighting game and does a lot to try and be as streamlined and fun for anyone of all skill levels. I think that it's the best fighting game on the market as most of the specials and basic combos are all really easy to learn unlike something like street fighter, nearly every character has the same input for their basics with room to expirement for everything. However, while it is simple and easy to pick up, a player can explore the depth of characters and using combos that they find online or discover while playing. More often than not, The combos i learn are stuff I get hit with from opponents and then learn through expirementing, usually having my own way of doing it which feels easier on me. 

While i think its the best current fighting game out right now, there are 4 core issues with this game any person who plans to buy/play should know

1. ToDs, Touch of Death, are pretty well known tech that people practice. while most people don't seek out these in online, the Keyword is most. People who do can make an enjoyable online experience feel dreadful. Even more so if they have cost effective one. The game has systems in place to lower damage in combos to midigate this but seeing as it's cool to pull these off and share them, it might sour your expirence of the game watching a round start and you already iimidiately lose due to a character killing your entire team due to one mistake

2. Rushdown Characters. The entire game is fast paced and prioitizes rushdown characters and has system mechanics to make it easier to close in on enemies like superdash and vanish. In a small scale, its fine, but some characters get absolutely ruined because of this. Zoners, Grapplers, characters that need set ups, everything that doesn't rush down is less optimal. Because of this, your playstyle, if its not using rushdown characters, is less optimal than the game wants. While Most characters feel unique, most have the same game plan of just being in close range and keeping pressure on your opponent

3. Overtuned characters. Most characters feel fine, but then there are characters that feel over tuned like Ui Goku and Kid buu. Characters like these can be annoying but reactable offline, but online they completely dominate because of the Frame delay. If you encounter one of these characters, try and avoid getting close until the person starts superdashing or using moves to get close so you can use moves to punish

4. Net play. most fighting games online are bad. Matches take for ever to get and start if someone just doesnt outright just cancel a match request. PS4 has better match making but barely. Still usable just annoying

I've played a LOT of Extreme Butoden, the game that came out before Fighterz and was the game that this one took a lot of inspiration from, and had the same dev team. Fighterz is a highly polished and upgraded version of EB, with only a few downgrades, such as attacks having less feedback and oomph (mainly audio) when connecting with opponents, and modes being MUCH slower to access. In EB, there was a main menu that allowed you to access all of the game's modes with just a few clicks. In Fighterz, you have to walk around a hub area and talk to an npc to start them. Why? SO much easier to just have a main menu...

With a better story mode, an arcade mode, more characters, subtitles for Japanese dialogue, and MUCH better graphics, effects, and animations (mostly), Fighterz is what I'd consider a true successor to Extreme Butoden. If you have a 3DS and are curious, try EB out. You'll feel comfortable if you've played Fighterz, as they control very similarly barring the controls and certain mechanics being changed/removed/added. Solid 8-9/10 for this game.

Not a good fighting game. Exciting dbz epilepsy porn, but garbage fight system and bad overall game.

Defensive game is essentially mk2. For whatever reason outside of point blank range there is no guard-break option so people (yes all the way up the ranks) just defend until an opening. The only thing accessible at close range is a hugely telegraphed built-in auto option or using a very obvious jump-cancel. Stupid. Boring.

Offensive game is frustrating due to supremacy of defense to gain frame+. There are 3 attack buttons but I haven't the faintest clue why. Something about damage scaling but when your average high-level combo is between 60-100k bar damage who the frick cares? Again more needless complexity.

Balance is just utter trash and new heros are op every time and pretty blatant cash grabs.

Game is good for maybe around 200 matches then you understand the above and you're just like... why?

Probably the best looking 3D anime fighter out yet and the only other competitors are other games by ArcSys. All the in-game visuals are stunning, all the dramatic finishes reinterpreting the original fights like Gogeta vs Super Broly/Janemba, Goku & Frieza vs Jiren are a feast for the eyes. Every attack done by a character, down to the jabs, are references to scenes from the anime and manga.

On the more technical side, it's a rather simple fighting game compared to most others out there but there is still absolutely a lot of freedom when it comes to combos. Neutral is much more unique compared to other fighting games in that you can switch sides during combos or otherwise several times, and the in-game mechanics like superdash, vanish and such give the game's combo structures a unique flavour. And it can absolutely be technical like other fighting games (i.e. Roshi combos).

Overall, definitely one of the prettiest fighting games out there. And the fact that I can spend as many hours as I did, the majority of which was just practicing combos, should be a testament to how fun this game is.

P.S. Buff Goku Black, you cowards.

Honestly, this has been one of the better DB games I've played in years.  The last time I could get this immersed and into a DBZ game was DBZ: Budokai Tenkaichi 3 and the original Budokai games.  Raging Blast, Ultimate Tenkaichi, and Xenoverse just didn't do it for me.  This game runs smooth, I experience virtually no lag, it's graphically immaculate, and they clearly paid a great degree of attention in detail to each character.  I was initially hesitant to get this for well over a year because I'm more of a Mortal Kombat player, and I thought the controls to this game would be too much like Marvel vs Capcom, but it isn't.  It's better in my personal -opinion-.  I really don't have anything negative to say about this game, aside from 1 single thing, and it's from a long-term fan perspective.  I'm probably in the minority here, but my favorite character of all time is Raditz, and I'm brutally disappointed in only this specific area because I wanted to see how much justice this game could do him.  I'm not sure what's happened to the perception of Raditz's character in the DB community, but, it feels as though TFS had a heavy influence incidentally on a wide array of characters, even to the extent of receiving unofficial titles like "Raditz the runt" through DBZ: Kakarot.  From an Ocean Dub and Funimation depiction of Raditz, it's nigh-impossible to regard him as that.  I understand people are probably blinded by the existence of Gods and Angels in Super now, but for Raditz's time and what he stood for in DBZ originally is impeccable.  If you were growing up watching the show, and you started DBZ right after Dragon Ball directly, immediately seeing a conflicted but mostly evil Piccolo team up with Goku to contest an Alien force that far outweighed them in power was mind-blowing!  I'm not sure how you can even logically make sense of Vegeta and Nappa randomly wasting their time to go to Earth without the concept of Raditz being included.  It was only through Raditz's scouter that Vegeta and Nappa were aware of what transpired on Earth, if not for Raditz, we quite literally would have a different story altogether probably.  It's also Goku's older brother ... and I'm aware we're in 2020 and that relationship still holds no value.  I fear for the future of DBZ and especially Raditz as a whole based on recent years.  Just a concerned and always dedicated fan!  P.S. I would gladly pay 100$ just to have the chance of playing Raditz in an awesome game like this.

Pros:
-Art style and badass cinematics (it honestly looks better than the source material)
-Every character is viable
-Low execution barrier, high execution ceiling (check out clayton's videos if you don't yet believe the latter)
-Big roster that's still growing
-Strong set of fundamental mechanics universal across (most of) the cast
-Fun gameplay flow that has room for open-endedness

Cons:
-Character diversity, the characters all play pretty similarly
-Some mechanics kind of dumb down the game like superdash and autocombo correction
-The netcode is ass
-It can be hard to find a game, especially in lower ranks
-Balance patches are infrequent (and they don't always solve everything)

Despite the cons, it's a really fun casual fighting game. Just try to find a group of people with a good connection and just play with them, since ranked is a wasteland and this game still doesn't have rollback.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is an amazingly fun fighter and feels pretty manageable to the casual player - if you're like myself, who isn't particularly good at the genre, nor have played other similar titles like Marvel vs Capcom. 

The input execution for special moves is heavily simplified (involving only either quarter-circle-forward/backward motions) and jump cancel timing feels less tight compared to other anime fighters like BlazBlue. This is a good thing because long combo strings generally require chaining into air combo and they are relatively easier to execute here. For the record, I can never quite pull off long combo strings in BlazBlue regardless of how much I practice. But I can do pretty long combos in this game with lesser time spent in training mode and still feel I can get better.

There are also auto-combos (by mashing Light or Medium attacks) which are inherently part of the combo system - imo, I feel they are well-implemented. Auto-combos have certain properties like auto positioning closer to the opponent, making it easier to pull off air combo chains. For e.g. a basic ground-to-air combo like 2M, M, JC, L, M, JC, L, M, H can also be done as 2M, M, JC, L x2, JC, L x3. The latter will be easier to pull off, and that's not just because it requires fewer mixing of inputs but simply because of the auto-positioning itself. The great thing I feel about this is that even if an entry level player uses auto-combos as a crutch, he/she still needs to get into the habit of fairly precise inputs instead of just button mashing (since the latter combo requires hitting L the exact number of times). I think this is a good way to enable a new player to do something complex in a easier manner and condition them with the right habits at the same time.

If I have any complaints about the game, they would be:
- The story mode (which makes up the bulk of single-player content) and its plot are kinda meh.
- The tutorials are not really that useful.
- The OST is largely forgettable, though there are a few tracks that I fancy - like Bardock's and Android 16's themes.

The game is heavily discounted so you should get either the FighterZ or Ultimate Edition when on sale.
Both editions include only the FighterZ Pass 1 (8 additional characters) while the latter includes additional commentator and music tracks if you care about that. Personally, I got the FighterZ edition as the music tracks don't appeal to me. 

Strongly recommended!

I've given it several tries. I just can't push myself to like it. 

- Combat system: it takes investment to get used to it. The screen gets really overcrowded and flashy. This is personal, I know.
- The story mode: man, it is awful.
- The arcade mode: it is even worse than the story mode.
- The only real option to play Dragon Ball FighterZ is online against other humans. You'll often be matched to people who are really experts and will kick your ass no matter what. Matches will be you just watching the same animations again and again seldom touching your gamepad.
- Too many side contents that muddle the experience: you have to click through 90 screens to get a fight.  The lobby is horrible man, just horrible.
- Limited fighters availability if you don't constantly invest more money

Not a bad game by any means. From my perception, this was a game with unlimited potential impaired by the horrible practices of nowadays gaming: you just forget about solo gaming, everything is about the online stuff and getting additional money out of users pockets.

[h1] DRAGON DRAGON ROCK THE DRAGON [/h1]

The TLDR version is fantastic DBZ vs game. Fun at all levels of play wheather you're new to fighting games or a vet. There are quality of life issues with the online though like random disconnects and pretty much no way to communicate besides preset messages. 

[b] Pros [/b]

+++ It has English Dub (My ears thank you)
+++ The attention to detail is amazing, from the stage transitions, the shot by shot movesets to the destructive finishes and lore dynamic finishes.
++   Amazing OST that really compliments the high paced gameplay. 
+++ Game lobby system is this really cool overworld system. You can basically walk up to all the different game modes in server rooms that hold up to 64 players each.
++   Everthing besides future dlc characters can be unlocked via Z capsules (Pretty much exactly like GGXRD fishing)
++   Everything gives you zenny (The currency you need for Z capsules).
++   Rematches are very quick since the game doesn't need reload everytime. 
+     Controllers are well supported for me, but I don't know about arcade stick support.
+     The game is 5 freaking gigs. How is a mystery to me.
+     Fast load times
+     Global Online Tournaments finally added
++   Lobbies are very lively, you'll be able to good matches easily, wheater you're a beginner or vet.

[b] Cons [/b]

- - No voice chat or text chat, just preset messages. 
- - No region filter, only prefered bars
- - "dbfz UE4-RED game has crashed and will close" Hope you're not one of the poor souls getting this error
- - Delayed based netcode. Either make your own rollback netcode or use GGPO.
- - - No Crossplay
- - No way to send friend request in game. You can change your ingame name anytime, it's just if you wanna add anyone you played in ranked or something you better hope its the same name as their steam. lol
- People have 30 secs before they have to accept or deline their qued match. This either needs to be shorted to 10 secs or they need to let you cancel the que so you're not trapped waiting for them to do something. lol
- Performance its gotten worse from release. Especially after adding an unneeded EAC. It's not horrible but sad to see how well it ran on launch to now. That on top of the only mods people use is all visual stuff.
- Frames drop when searching ranked/casual matches. Hopefully this gets patched.
- Sound glitch that can happen at random just about anywhere in the game, seems like skipping lines in story causes it the most. It's like a half second of something loud. Probably a sound file playing when it's not intended to.

[b] Whats this game like is it like Mahvel or guilty gear!? [/b]

Basically it's a VS game that takes mechanics from GG and mahvel and puts a dbz like spin on it. A raw tag in this will result in your character superdashing in. Dragon rush's which are unblockable dash attacks are basically the normal grabs of the game. Instead of a pushblock or faultless denfense you have Z reflect, which deflect all attacks including supers and push the oppent back but lose to dragon rush. Sparking is like X factor and Burst fused together.

[b] Nit picks/Glitches [/b]

- Game soft locks if you're in a online lobby and in training mode for a certain amount of time, then change teams. It thinks you're afk but it doesn't try to kick you until you try to go back to the lobby. The game thinks you're going back when you change teams, then loads forever becuase it doesn't know what to do.

- I would love an online training mode to help me explain things to friends easier.

- So [url=https://youtu.be/e8AmR8IZ25M?t=21s] BEAM STRUGGLES [/url] ... where are they? I don't care if they can only be accesed through casuals I need them in this game.

[b] Request [/b]

Can I get a Brian drummond voice pack for Vegeta? I love me some Christopher Sabat,
 but [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TX20KuQWH7s] THIS VOICE [/url] deserves some spotlight.

If you've been hesitant because you're not good at fighting games don't be. Like even you just use the auto combos alone and you want to just smash your friends into mountains, I think you'll find more than enough entertainment with this game. Plus if you ever want to learn how to get better at fighting games you can always do that later.

The fact that you even got this far in the review tells me you're at least interested in the game. That or you're one of my friends who likes to read my reviews out load in the discord like I didn't know.

Honestly i love dragon ball and i love fighting games. Bringing the 2 together is a match made in heaven. The visuals are top notch and i could not imagine a more faithful recreation of the series. The fighting game elements are also well and fully realized. Sure some of the character balance  is a little wack but there are truly no unplayable characters and the ones that are good are not unbeatable. The tutorial elements do leave something to be desired but this is more than made up for by the games community. All this being said I love this game to bits and will probably put way more time into it in the future. Please buy it if your on the fence its a great game.

[h1] Anime fighting game done right! [/h1]

If you are looking for a solid Dragon Ball Z game, be it you are a casual fan or a hardcore competitive player, you certainly can't go wrong with this game. 
Graphics look the best there is with visuals that were carefully detailed to look like the iconic style from the martial arts manga and anime series. Gameplay is the most accessible yet the deepest in a 3 vs 3 fighting game to date. Character roster is still growing and developer Arc System Works has shown interest and respect for it's competitive community by frequently balancing the game even 2 years after it's release. Sound design is pretty good, not much more to say there. 
Story is long enough and there is a lot of character interaction so fans will find a lot to love there. 

Overall, Dragon Ball FighterZ is the game that with it's beautiful visuals, polished gameplay that well represents the source material sets a precedent in how anime fighting games with competitive appeal should be made.

Unless you have someone to teach you the game is terrible at teaching proper mechanics.

In the challenges and training examples the timing is not clearly defined. This for me makes it very hard to know what I am doing wrong and when I see on screen my character doing what I was told to do.

This is made worse by the story mode that is very long and teaches very bad tactics for pvp and higher levels of arcade fights. So having spent far too many hours getting each character, and learning how to get teams together, what you like from the story mode and who you don't like to play you have ingrained muscle memory that has to be unlearned before you can play against others.

This gets worse when you get to higher challenge levels as the difficulty spikes so fast because you haven't learnt what is good and bad to do in a situation.

I enjoy the game with friends and do not regret getting the game, but as a beginner it taught me terrible mechanics that only frustrate me as I try and go further. I still don't know how to close and because of that I dismiss entire characters as I don't see how I can engage with them.

In addition I understand it is trying to be next Vs game so this may be my frustration coming out, but I find myself in long combos that make me put down the controller and leave as I see no way out. Some form of combo break would be helpful so I don't feel like a passenger for sections of the game.

In conclusion, game needs to teach me the mechanics better so I don't just get angry and walk away in the middle of fights.

Gameplay feels solid, and it's easily accessible for new players, and rewarding for those willing to take the time to learn the more complex mechanics. FighterZ looks just like the anime. You can tell there was a lot of effort put into making this game.

Overall I'd recommend this game.  I think it's a particularly good game for someone who isn't very experienced with traditional fighting games.  There aren't many complicated inputs and the game has some extra mechanics to reduce complexity, but it's those mechanics that might cause frustration to more experienced players.

I'd go in with this warning though, everything except for straight vs. mode is pretty disappointing.  The story in particular is one of the worst story modes I've seen in a fighting game.  Still, this is a fighting game.  Vs. mode is the main selling point.

I think it's fun, maybe wait for a sale tho.  The game isn't getting any younger and there's a lot of DLC, so it's a big ask at full price.

Probably my favourite fighting game of all time and I've been playing this genre since SF2 Turbo. I play other fighting games but this game is always my 'go to' choice when I'm in between games.

-Pros
=Genuinely a simple but great fighting game
=3v3 format and a large roster (with DLC) means there is a lot of variety
=Another Arcsys 2D/3D stunner
=Fair amount to do outside fighting people online
=West City music track
=New strict anti-Rage quit penalties!

-Cons
=Buying all the DLC is pricey. There is no 'All in one' dlc bundle yet so if you do want to buy the game and want all the characters, buy it on sale.
=Fair amount of single player content but it's whatever.
=Even with the best  pc money can buy you can get annoying fps drops. You will need to tinker to get it running silky smooth, took me a fair bit of twiddling. (Nvidia friends turn Threaded Optimisation and DSR off)
=It's still a fighting game and you will get your ass handed to you online if you arn't willing to put some time in learning and using practice mode.

[h1] My POV [/h1] 
As a relatively good player, this game is definitely the go-to fighting game of choice, rounds aren't decided instantly and comebacks are very possible. Definitely one to purchase if you enjoy fighting games.

[h1] Combat [/h1]
It's Easy to learn but Hard to master, in terms of skill there are Auto-combos which are doable by simply pressing Light Light Light, same for Medium and Heavy respectively. I suggest picking your favourites and practicing with those until you become competent.

[h1] Nostalgia [/h1]
This will really get your memories flooding in, especially with destructive/dramatic finishes and unique voice lines between characters on both character intros and winning screens, not to mention seeing special attacks done justice, my personal favourite attack being Broly's Gigantic Meteor.

What do you get when you cross GGXrd style visuals courtesy of Arc System Works, gameplay reminiscent of UMvC3 and a certain beloved anime franchise featuring superpowered martial arts aliens? You get this.

'Dragon Ball FighterZ' may not be the greatest fighting game ever made, sure, but there's no denying that a lot of love was put not just into the visuals and gameplay, but also the various homages and references to the grand DBZ universe as well as other fighting games. Plus with constant updates and balance changes over the years, this game has continued to stay relatively fresh despite the competition.

Overall, one would be hard-pressed to find a better 'Dragon Ball' game than this; therefore I highly recommend 'Dragon Ball FighterZ' not just to DBZ fans, but also to fighting game fans in general.

[22.08.2020 Small update after 300+ hours in this game]

After 300+ hours in this game, plenty of games in ranked/casual and few playing buddies in the friends list, I have to say this game is really amazing. However... and listen to this however, because you will need it.

I'm old timer, who's reflexes are not as good as many other "youngsters" in the hood, but be prepared if you want to play online for plenty of horrible games. Current Netcode for FigterZ is real garbage and because everyone is using different PC to play, you will find out that not every game is fair for you. V-sync? Additional 1-2 frames, or more. Different graphic settings? Well, the same. You forgot to turn off something in Nvidia dashboard? RiP. Why are you losing guard in many spots? Well, thanks to 3-4 frame delay I guess...These are few things that makes me NOT want to play such game on my PC and use console instead. Saddly, I do only have PS3.

I would say, that I had been having fun for a long time, until I hit SS3/Majin rank and boy I have to say most people play like braindead zombies. I do understand that constant pressure, constant mashing of buttons IS a strategy, but if you try to compare such gameplay to "pro" players... it says a lot about such opponent. I'm trying my best to stay neutral in my fighting style, but when you have almost every opponent mashing every button, every millisecond of your match... I don't want to play this game anymore. Sometimes I do feel as if I'm losing my mind while playing some online games, so beware that FighterZ might break you in half, or just online players who you don't know at all. Higher ranks attracts more zombie mashers and that's a big deal, because it shoves off people from the game.

So if you have friends who want to play with you FigterZ, then play with them as much a possible, since Offline gameplay is what makes this game shine the most. I have also tried Remote Play with friend 400km from me and I would say having 4-5 frame delay in it is not as bad as I have thought. It works, but don't expect Unicorns out of nowhere.

This is the end for short update for my review. Take care and I GIVE VIDEL REFLECT, since Hercule will be next DLC character, after Roshi.

I was never a "fighting games" guy, but this game is literally what I've been searching for my whole life.

It's not just Dragon Ball game for fans, it's more and more than that. Dragon Ball FighterZ is next in Arc System Studios title, coming after Persona Arena, which already started implementing similar things to what we see in FighterZ. I used to play Persona Arena and Ultimax for a long time, but these games had some issues, and Internet fights were a mess. Since the characters had similar attacks to Fighterz, huge amount of people used to spam long range attacks and breaking whole balance to the fights. It was painful to play some of them. In case of FighterZ, it's completely different. Even if you enjoy spamming range attacks, you can always be punished for your actions, and because of it lose your game. Every character has your standard attacks like: light, medium, high and special. Additionally you will find special attacks, rushing systems, Sparking system, which boosts you, and vanishing attacks for sudde and painful backstabbing in the butt. 3vs3 fighting system is more enjoyable than what Marvel vs Capcom presented, so even if you are mediocre player, FighterZ still can teach you few tricks. 

Since the game features auto-combos, you don't need to learn huge charts from combo-list, unless you really want to. Also, you can try experimenting with combos and find something unique for you. Devs are still bringing more characters to the game and probably (I do really hopes so) they will reveal another season characters. So the game, even after two years after being released, still is being updated on.

This is my third buying playing this game (DLC included) and while I would say I'm biased to the Dragon Ball aspect I will also say how satisfying it is to have put triple-digit hours in on two other platforms and only be able to do, quote, "Evo shit" when the stars align and my three remaining braincells remember what a 2H is.

The story isn't much to scoff at but there was some effort put in to the actual characters. A21 is a welcome and surprisingly strong addition to DB's cast of waifus. She's not a personal main of mine but I know she has a place in the game's meta, which I'm glad for considering it's a Toriyama OC made just for the game.

I will say there is a SEVERE learning curve and spammers and braindead *cough* Z Broly *cough* strategies are INFURIATING to get caught in. Netcode rollback is also something the game needs but likely won't get until its sequel due to technical limitations of implementing something like that. But overall I'd say it's a great fighting game, especially if you like Arcsystemwork, especially-especially so if you're a Dragon Ball fan, and it's a must have if you can get a couple weeb friends to invest the time in to compete or do raids together.

The Good:
Solid mechanics, beautiful art, gorgeous animation and diverse fighting styles among the playable characters. Top tier fighting game and a damn good Dragon Ball game.

The Bad:
If it weren't for the fact that the non-Goku characters are actually relevant and viable, I would feel inclined to call this title Goku Time: The Game. Oddly enough, there are almost as many Vegetas. I'm personally not a big fan of 3v3 fighters and I really wish there was an actual competitive, working 1v1 variation. I understand that this game was specifically made with 3v3 in mind. I have my little nitpicks about it but there was clearly a LOT of love put into this game.

The Ugly:
Ranked made me realize I'm trash.

It is a decent fighter over all, if you like that much you'll enjoy this game. The not recommended is because of the imbalance of characters which pigeon hole you into a what is effectively meta. Again most people might actually enjoy the specific team comps that will net you that "W" but sadly for new players that "W" wont come if you are learning with characters not properly synergized for efficiency.

Graphics - Great nothing wrong here, anime games have come a long-long way.

Music - Most are simply too generic to remember but some are pretty good.

Gameplay - The game is mediocre difficulty to pick up and learn, you'll spend a lot of hours in practice mode since you wont learn much watching other players. The reason is because other players unless you are running top tier are probably running some formula of goku, vegita and kid buu with the occasional broly or bardock. There is nothing to learn from those characters and their variants aside from how to get your ass beat at every trade off. For example their lights or mediums will beat your lights and their heavies will lock you up in most situations. It's a nasty snow ball effect of just a superior character. Also the damage those characters (especially the goku and vegitas) can push out is silly. 

For example: Optimal combo for Andriod 21 will do about 40-55%, requires 3 bars without the 3 bars its about 40% damage, it also requires you have two assists and be in the corner. Base Vegita can do 55% from... anywhere requiring 2 bars one for the vanish.  It wouldn't be too bad if it was just a damage difference but combine that with the that those characters lights, mediums are faster and/or typically have better range then those guys have a better chance of getting in on you.

Beyond that balance problem which isn't normally a problem for arcade fighters that can't be updated, this game is actively updated for balance so it becomes then a problem because it could be solved if they saw it fit to fix it.

Those characters also feel more complete, they simply provide more options in more situations, it makes it so any predictability is based on you as a player. That's good, if someone likes to auto combo just deflect and neutral heavy them, but if they are half way decent they will correct that.

--------------

Also before anyone thinks that this is because I am no good at the game; I am not trying to say I am some professional at this game. I can however say that I have wiped the floor with dark and light green players so badly I decided to stop and review the game as a not recommended for new players who might not like being pigeon holed into playing a meta team combination to see success past red square.

Great Animation! Great Feel. Liquid smooth gameplay that'll have DBZ fans running for the nostalgia train. Standard combo transition combined with some Street Fighter-esque links for re-jump combos. It's an anime fighter, so expect their standards: over the top specials and supers, nods to certain events in the show, air mobility.

Pro's:
  Great netplay! You'll hear a lot of people complain about netplay, but it's the best I've seen for a top EVO fighter. With an excellent connection you'll see only 2-3 frames of delay. A good connection will land you somewhere between 4-7 frames of delays. I've played this game with download/upload speeds as low as 16 Mb/s or 2 MB/s.

Work in progress! Game is constantly being re-balanced to rectify the "NEW Character OP-ness."

Very responsive! Extremely responsive to the point where inputs have a slightly longer buffer time.

Tons of other modes for co-op gameplay with seasonal and random events.

Cons: 

Online gameplay is full of rage-quitters. If you have the upper hand, several players will "pull the plug" to conserve ranked points. This can somewhat be rectified by enabling the "High Completion Rate" filter in ranked matchmaking options.

The game will randomly crash! AND for no apparent reason. Around 5% of your launch time will be met with the game crashing and giving a "UE4-RED" error. This is sometimes rectified by ensuring Steam's cloud sync is enabled for this game and then deleting your local save data (Win+R, then type "%localappdata%," hit enter followed by deleting the entire Dragonball fighterz folder.)

New character launches present unbalanced characters. Normally with character launches, the new toon is either ridiculously OP/UP. It will normally take a month or so for the balancing patch. If you're a competitive player, this could mean unforeseen advantages/disadvantages for tournament play. Game breaking updates are corrected relatively fast. Usually a week or two.

A slight glitch (since day 1) From time to time, you'll notice the game returning you to your ring match lobby despite the rematch settings to continue on without changing your characters. If someone Alt+F4's from inside your lobby, this will likely happen to you. That or when all parties are returned to the lobby yet the game hangs and presents as if people are still in a match.

Pay for DLC! Although paying for minor additional content has become the norm, I still mark this as a con. The game itself is 60 bucks. With the release of new characters, you'll easily spend 3 times that for all characters bringing the actual game total flying into the upwards of 200 bucks in no time. Each character is around 5 bucks a piece, and a fighterz pass is around 25 bucks for 6 characters. Ultimately, the pass saves you 5 bucks for every 6 characters released, but this is no excuse for such inflated minor DLC prices. The game has a base of 24 characters (3 unlockable) with ~18 DLC characters as of 8/17/20.

-----All in all, this is a great game! Currently, I've logged around 2,000 hours in the game with no intention of stopping. Hours and hours of fun for you and your mates/friends. Hope this helps.

The best DBZ fighter ever made. Super easy to get in to, but hard to master. All the characters are interesting and varied. The assist/tag feature makes setting up combo's with different combinations, a blast.

The game is well designed and controls tightly, but it is not friendly to players new to fighting games. It barely explains the basics of attacking, blocking, combos, and assists, at which point it leaves you to your own devices. I've watched countless tutorials outside of the game to try to gain a better understanding, but still I find myself getting launched into a 70-hit combo with every online match I play. It doesn't explain the vast amount of nuance to every character in the game, as far as I can tell (For example: Broly's armor isn't mentioned, or Android 21's ability to copy other character's skills). After an investment of around 35 hours (both inside and outside the game), I feel as though I have not grown as a player, and that doesn't feel good. Additionally, the prices for additional characters is absolutely ridiculous. I understand companies have to make money, but the game already costs a base $60, and to ask $30 more for just another 6 characters is simply grubby. If you have the time to invest and are already familiar with fighting games, you may have a different experience, but as it stands I cannot recommend this game to people who are trying to break into fighting games.

This game has a fun combat system and I overall enjoy it so far despite some of the arguably annoying traits that the game has like the story mode. It's a pretty versatile, innovative, enjoyable, and strategic in a sense. Though, online play can be a bit weird with ranked I feel, some people are laggy beyond belief in pvp. Other than that, I believe I've wrapped my thoughts thus far on this game up, so I'll end it with a little disclaimer. All of this was my own opinion, that's it.

You know, say what you will about DBFZ, but this is a fighting game done right. 
Beautiful graphics, true to the original source, easy-to-play yet hard-to-master gameplay, singleplayer modes, online modes, z unions, tournaments, etc. 

For any MvC fans and/or Dragon Ball fans... I highly suggest picking this up until the next iteration comes out.
 
This overall was and still continues to be a job well done.

I don't feel encouraged to spend the time "getting good" at this just do do the same exact optimized combo over and over. What turns me off to a fighting game, more than anything, isn't winning or losing too much, but if whatever the result is boring to watch. No matter what the starting point is, every single combo path seems to fold into eachother somewhere along the line. It's not like I'm saying these people didn't practice to get good enough to be able to do it consistently every single time, but when every single mistake I make means I essentially get to put my controller down for 20 seconds I'm not sure I even want to go online. I've practiced in the training room plenty, but that doesn't help me adapt to doing the same combos within this game's garbage netcode.

Quite possibly the best Dragonball game ever made and easily one of the best FIGHTING games I have ever played.

This is a 2D 3v3  fighting game that has a combo system similar to games like BlazBlue, Tatsunoko vs Capcom, and Marvel vs Capcom 3 with the Tag and Assist system similar to Skullgirls and Marvel vs Capcom 3. The game has several universal mechanics (Super Dash, Vanish and Spark) that allow for counter-play and comebacks (not as egregious as X Factor or Dark Phoenix). Animation is incredible, voice acting (both English and Japanese) are practically spot on to the Anime, has an incredible original OST and also features some OST from the Anime, moves and animations for the characters come straight from the manga and anime. 

Very easy to pick up but hard to master for non-fighting game enthusiasts. 
FGC players/Fighting game enthusiasts will eventually find an issue with the meta, but the Devs have been great with balancing throughout the release of each Season. In it's current state the game is fairly balanced with the exception of Ultra Instinct Goku being slightly over-tuned (this issue will surely be addressed as the Season unfolds and the rest of the DLC characters release).

I am an older gamer and I feel that fighting games should require skill and knowing your opponent.

DBFZ is focused on memorization of "flashy" combinations which can be long and repetitive. I feel that it takes the fun out of the game when one side dominates an entire match after one hit because of juggling. 


I like being able to think on my feet, watching for patterns, adjusting my attack and exploiting a weakness.  

It gets fun and exciting to me when you don't know whats going to happen in a match. I enjoy it when both players stand up out of their chairs because it stopped being about "memorization" or combos and it became a literal boxing match and you have to think and react to whats going on. It is an Adrenaline Rush.   

You will never see a boxing match "IRL" where someone is able to hit another person 20 times in a row and the other person is just standing there taking the hits.   

Review the DBZ fight between Piccolo and Android 17 where both sides are slugging it out.

If you get the chance to play on older platforms, try playing fighting games like Eternal Champions, Killer Instinct Gold and Bushido Blade.

Dragon Ball FigherZ is an amazing game period, Let me tell you why, This game was a gamble for me, before playing this game I had little to no 2D figher experience but I bought it anyway after being blinded by the amazing visuals and Dragon Ball character roster. When I finally got my hands on FigherZ I was blown away this game is very beginner friendly and contains an incredible amount of depth for experienced 2D fighter players. Each and every character provides a different play style and moves with all of them having great variation, The visuals alone are enough to sell the game with Arc Systems Works portraying a beautiful anime aesthetic with 3D models and backgrounds. 

I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who has a love for either 2D fighter or Dragon Ball as this game appeals to both types of fans, prepared to be stunned by the beauty of this game and the love put into each and every characters move.

Really a good fighting game from Arc System Works.

Imagine this: It is 2018 and Dragon Ball Z fighting games were always very simple. 2 attack buttons, Ki button, and no command inputs. It was like that for a long time. That all changed when Arc System, mainly the Guilty Gear devs, came in and made this game. It completely changes Dragon Ball Z fighting games and makes it play like the older games, but let's not get ahead of ourselves, we will get there very soon. We just want to see if Bandai publishing this game was a good idea (it was).

Story: This game has a story, and I will use the story from the mode. In the 3 playable arcs, the main story is about a new Android named Android 21, who is a female android with the appearance of a Majin race. The 3 arcs are about the Z Fighters and new allies teaming up to fight this threat. Plus, clones are appearing and wreaking havok and energy waves are weakening the fighters, so links have to be made to regain strength. The script was written by Akira Toriyama himself, so there is some depth to it, but there are flaws, like how the arcs are not arcs, just different perspectives, and how gameplay and story is imbalanced, with lots of plot that can probably be simplified, but hey, it's not all bad, as there are plenty of character interactions that you can get and some pretty funny moments, but I still feel it could be improved, because honestly, the story mode sucks. Besides the interactions, all you do is mop the floor with the same clones that don't play differently from the regular characters. Yeah, there are skills, but most players will just overpower the skills the opponents use and end up getting skills that are much stronger, and there are some poorly written scenes, mainly the Android Arc with seemingly forced deaths. However, I won't spoil, but trust me, you can see the forced deaths when they happen, but feel free to DM me if you are confused about the deaths I am talking about.

Gameplay: Here we go. Forgoing the simple gameplay of previous fighting games, this game takes a lot form Guilty Gear: 3 attack buttons and a unique attack called "Special" (for simplicity I will call it the Ki button) and you can use command inputs like QCF for special moves, which is becoming worringly rare these days. The main fighting is set up in a 3v3 style, with the ability to call assists, both characters as well, making for some hectic games. Learning combos is very fun and simple, yet, challenging for the more dynamic combos, and while beginners can still have fun with the simple combos and auto-combo, more experienced players can make longer combos and take advantage of the auto-combo system which can get crazy. Have a character or 2 down? Use your Sparking, which buffs you in many ways as a sort of comeback mechanic, or you can get the Dragon Balls by doing combos or auto-combos, summon Shenron, and make a wish. That is crazy, and the hectic gameplay makes it fun!

Online: The main focus of this game is the online with all the modes. You have the standard ranked and casual, as well as ring matches to help play with friends, and Arena, which is just another Casual match. What is new is a party mode which allows up to 6 players at once in a fight in the 3v3 format. Teamwork is key.... or just carry the entire team, whatever works. There are also special boss events where 3 players can fight a boss character for rewards, and they can get pretty fun. Unfortunately, the netcode is terrible. Despite rollback being what all fighting games should go for, ArcSys stayed in the past and used delay based netcode, causing 7 frame delays to be a standard playing the game. Also, no crossplay either. 3 seasons in and ArcSys showed no interest in changing this. However, one thing that heavily damages online is the rage quitters. especially on PC. For some reason, Arc System just won't punish rage quitters, causing them to multiply! They even rage quit when you are not in ranked. Ouch. The only thing to not run into a rage quitter is through settings or checking their square, and the game tells you complete jack about the squares. Honestly they need to punish rage quitters, every other game does that. Smash Ultimate, Street Fighter V Arcade Edition, Marvel Vs. Capcom Infinite, and so much more. Get on it, Arc System!

Graphics and Presentation: Wow this game! This game uses a similar technique found in Guilty Gear, mainly the newer ones with animations and bone structures that emulate the animations of an anime, and they look great! They look so smooth and the cel-shading also looks great! There is even some battle damage implemented, but not too crazy. Just some scars, and armor cracks, but still a neat detail. I think more fighting games should have a battle damage feature. However, the backgrounds do not have this same style and look a little out of place, but they are destructible, so that makes up for it. You can also tell that Arc System were huge Dragon Ball fans through the character interactions through win quotes and even quotes mid match. They even include finishers called "Dramatic Finishes" activated by pressing Heavy (or Vanish if you use Freezer) which references moments in the show and a few what-is moments. And yes, you can Yamcha Yamcha.

Sound and Soundtrack: It's a broken record with Dragon Ball Z games and I won't have it any other way: Just use the sounds from the show. They sound great and fit well. You can't beat these sounds. Meanwhile, the OST is also pretty good in certain parts. It feels overpowered by the sound effects though, but what I heard is still good and catchy, even if Hit's theme is so unfitting.

Replayability: It's an online based game. 'Nuff said.

Final Thoughts: This game is great. Great gameplay, mostly great online, great graphics, awesome sounds, good music, it has it all. But what rating would I give it? My opinion, blah, I think this game gets an 8/10 with a side of Super Saiyan 4- oh that was retconned and people hated GT.... Well, the game is still good and I heavily recommend it. If you are more of a console gamer, the game is on PS4 (my OG place for playing the game), XBOX ONE, and Nintendo Switch (which came out later). If you are wondering about the Switch port, it is fantastic, it runs great, and features a unique resolution mechanic to help the Switch handle the game. Thanks open beta! Also, I am still waiting for them to add Master Roshi, I mean, come on, he trained Goku since the original Dragon Ball!

2020 Update: In Season 3, there were some substantial gameplay updates, like different Z Assists, changes to the meter and gameplay mechanics, alongside other neat changes
this game is realy fun but if you hate fighting games you probobly wont like this game

Note: I only just got the game on PC but my brother owns the Xbox copy so excuse the time played I have more on Xbox One.

Intro
Dragon Ball FighterZ is extremely well made compared to other new traditional fighters. The huge array of familiar and not characters from across the series, (cannon or not) always gives you something new to try. The tag-team element, (while not new) plays extremely well into the familiar fighting game setting we are used to seeing. The combat is smooth and like just about every fighting title has its split second strategies with combo's, guard breaks and just about anything you can think of. 

Characters
The game has a standard pricing to begin with and starts you with hefty amount of characters to begin with. The characters is the biggest downside though. Over 1 third of the character pool is locked behind DLC and while not completely game breaking, does limit your choice and variety, especially since the newer characters (especially fighters pass 3), seem to be a bit more powerful than others. No good game comes without balancing and Bandai Namco are doing so with every update, often dramatically shifting the meta each time. They just seem a tad slow with it. The game is easy to pick up and hard to master. You'll always find some new technique or move to try in your next battle. Especially since some characters get unique conditional moves. 

Detail and animation
The animation quality is beautiful. Everything is in the higher definition movie quality like DBS: Broly and it just makes the game look like you are playing a movie. The attention to detail is very filled as well. Pairing characters on certain maps will trigger stunning beginning and end cutscenes that leave ready for the fight to continue. Map changing after certain finishers is also a nice touch.

Hardware
The game for the most part is easy to run, though you may need to sacrifice some graphics for low end machines. I write this review on a school grade laptop with an intel i-9500 with 2.0 Ghz processor and it runs a stable 60 on minimum settings. Machines with 1080-TI's or higher will EASILY get the most out of the graphics and run smoothly. Online games do exist but servers do not exist in Oceana (Australia/New Zealand). The nearest being Singapore. There is still plenty to do offline. 

Overall, DB FighterZ is a solid modern fighter with plenty to do both on and offline where it's only drawback is price, setting you back a little over $210 AUD to get the ultimate edition + fighters pass 2 & 3. The requirements aren't fierce and will easily run on medium end machines on max settings.

I have been playing fighting games for over 20 years, competing in national tournaments when I was younger. These days, I'm more of a casual player, preferring Smash Bros over typical fighting games since typical fighting games are harder to get into (you need to spend a lot of time learning moves, practicing, etc.). I'm also a huge fan of Dragon Ball. I've been reading Dragon Ball since Goku and I were both just kids. I grew up with Dragon Ball and it has affected my life in positive ways.

As a fan of Dragon Ball and fighting games, I love this game.

As a fighting game, the game is fun and very easy to start. Even if you're new to fighting games, the training mode is very helpful for starters. The game's auto combos are also great for new players. Once you get familiar with the game and want more advanced tactics, there's plenty here to keep you interested. There's really no reason any Dragon Ball fan new to fighting games should be afraid to give this a start.

As a Dragon Ball game, this game is a love letter to Dragon Ball fans. Hardcore Dragon Ball fans will immediately recognize that many of the basic moves used by characters are actually taken straight from the series. One of Krillin's kicks is a kick he used against Goku during a tournament (when they were kids). Freeza's elbow attack is the one he used against Goku. Likewise, the elbow attack Goku uses is the one he used against Freeza. The game is loaded with these. :D While the story mode isn't great, it has many references to the series and has many interesting interactions between characters in a "what if" situation (like Nappa being upset with Vegeta for obvious reason). Watching these scenes made me all giddy.

Overall, this is an excellent Dragon Ball game that no fan of Dragon Ball should miss.

First of all, I love fighting games of any kind, I am a Mortal Kombat Fan from the beginnings, love the way Dragon Ball Super reanimated the series, but bro, this game got me off guard. 
I played the 2018 version of this game and it was like Meh another Budokai Tenkaichi wanna be. BUT when I buy it and play it full this year. GOD this game is the BEST FIGHTING GAME I've played. 

Pros:
-Epic Battles, every single one is Unique.
-Lots of characters (40 up to this date).
-Epic auto balancing feature that a few fighting games implemented, you can really win a fight that is already lost (1 vs 3 situation).
-Every character is balanced and unique, the moveset of any of those are full of references.
-Easy to catch a Fight for a newbie and Hard to master.
-Talking about moveset the way you can counter every single action in this game is insane, you can be very creative with your fight style.
-Ranked matchmaking (To improve your moves).
-Very active community.
-3 vs 3 fights with your friends is FUN. 

Cons:
-Lack of a good Netcode like GGPO(When I play brawlhalla I don't feel lag with my friends), but hey is not that bad only you can feel it with some friends, I can say like 1 of 10 Fights(every single one with a random) you will feel a little laggy.
-Lack of Alternative Costumes for every Character and more coop events with your friends.
-Lack of an easy way to host a Tournament on the Game with your friends. But you can fix this with discord and a Bracket Generator online.
-Some combos in the game are broken and you can kill another character with one fist. I wish this will be fix with some damage cap at 60% in one combo or something, because is very frustrating for some fights. 

if you want a number for me this game is a 10/10, no matter what.

Hope you like my review :3
Cheers!

As a lifelong DBZ fan its hard to say if i like this game or not. I'm not a huge fan of how the fighting mechanics work and couldn't care less for the DBS characters cause DBS is just as bad as GT. However the story mode for the game was surprisingly really fun. Seeing Goku and Frieza have a  casual conversation is priceless. I cant seem to get these dang rose tinted glasses of my face... oh well anyways, I have to say if you want a casual fighting game with lots of juggling and graphics so flashy you cant actually tell whats happening then this is for you. You want some dragon ball story that's fun and "original" then this is for you. You want deep and engaging fighting mechanics then move on cause you're in the wrong place. This game is DBZ fan service near its limits, just don't expect too much more than you get from any other anime game.

You will get bodied on online matches until you learn how to jump-cancel. Search it up, learn, and get gud.
As a game itself 10/10. For DBZ fans 11/10 + an ejaculation. Also DLC is a bit expensive, but at this time it's on sale so hurry up little childs. If you already have this game, then you're a cool kid. If not, then go play this beautiful game. No, like, for real go.

Excellent visuals, tight controls, relatively simple for beginners to pick up, and good game balance make this an excellent game to get into. Very faithful to the source material; it's obvious a lot of love and effort went into polishing this game. The DLC, while expensive, isn't necessary to build a strong competitive team, though the characters are actually worth the money if you enjoy those characters, but if you don't play them then there's no point unless you want to set up defending against them in training mode.But, there is an elephant in the room I have to address for anyone looking to get into it. The biggest downsides are the complete lack of crossplay and the delay based netcode which can make actually finding games frustrating and tedious, sometimes impossible depending on the times. Best if you have friends to play this with or you might have a tough time keeping on with it.

As beginners especially you'll probably have a really hard time with matchmaking at first because casual does not have any hidden MMR, so you'll likely get utterly curbstomped by people with hundreds to thousands of games played on your first couple rounds- ranked is actually better at matchmaking when you're a novice. You may have trouble with autocombo and superdash spammers too at first, but all you have to do is be patient and block until they do something unsafe, watch for their superdash and anti air them, and/or call an assist to lock them down and start your own offense. That alone should be enough to get you into the 400-500k BP range. 

Has a fairly active and chill community on the character discords so resources aren't too hard to find, usually. Overall recommended if you can get past the lack of crossplay, especially if you've got friends who play it too.

Dragon Ball FighterZ somehow fits all of my favorite Dragon Ball Characters within a singular fighting game, saying "no" to canon. These characters include Goku, a Saiyan who was sent from the planet Vegeta to Earth, Goku, a Saiyan who surpassed the limits of a normal Saiyan, Goku, a Saiyan that unlocked an ancient technique that separates the consciousness from the body, Goku, a Saiyan that unlocked an even stronger version of a divine form, and Yamcha.

The game manages to be simple while keeping the depth that is prominent in most fighting games.
If you don't understand what I mean by that, I'm saying the game has several tools that help people new to fighting games, including:

-Auto Combos
-Combos to be started off of pretty much any hit
-A Super Dash that makes you go through most projectiles while helping you approach
-Most characters having similar combo trees 
etc.

This allows for people to focus on working on mastering basic skills in a fighting game, like knowing when to throw an attack, or how to defend, or how to punish, or how to adapt, or whatever. For people who are wary of flat game without any long combos, you don't have to worry, as there are some mechanics that you can utilize to make your experience more fun, like the use of  assists, teleport cancels, and sparking to extend combos.

Going back to what I said before, the Dragon Ball FighterZ puts as much fanservice as possible, seen within the various supers that recreate entire scenes from the anime, or the interaction of certain characters in story mode that never actually met in the original manga/anime.



Now for an important question:
Is Dragon Ball FighterZ a good game?

Well, the answer to that question is:


Fuck no, the game runs on shitty-ass delay based netcode, makes me drop all my damn combos, I fucking hate this shit.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a team-based anime fighter, and I'm not really a fan of team-based or anime fighters. That aside, though, it's clearly a very solid piece of work, with presentation that's both faithful to the original anime and incredibly satisfying in-game, and gameplay that has enough touches for beginners to feel powerful while maintaining lots of depth for actual competitive play. The game's also bursting with content, including three story modes and an arcade mode. It's really got something for everyone; if you're a casual player who just wants to have fun with the Dragon Ball characters, I recommend buying it on sale, and if you're a hardcore player of anime fighting games, well...you probably already have this.

Dragonball FighterZ is an incredibly explosive and fun fighting game... bogged down by some stubbornness or lack of time on the developers' part regarding the online play.

This game is one of my favorite examples of how a fighting game can be accessible while managing to work as a competitive game. The auto combos is certainly too good on some characters BUT it is still well-integrated into the game as new players can use them as a stepping stone to learn more advanced combos. 

In contrast to other games where they're usually an "easy mode" function, in FighterZ high level players can integrate them as part of larger combos and setups. 

The roster is somewhat bogged down by how similar a lot of the characters play and how a lot of the more interesting characters are hidden behind DLC, but each character still has their own tech. Perhaps thanks to how similar the character are the characters are quite balanced right now, with the lower tiers only needing a few adjustments down the line to become good, and even now they're still playable. 

Matches are very high energy and chaotic, capturing the feel of the show even if it doesn't try to simulate the show's mechanics as much as other DBZ games. Though, still, if you don't like games where you're going to have to defend against long blockstrings or get hit combos that take massive chunks of your life, it might not be for you.

Story mode isn't anything to get excited about. It has some good moments and very fun character interactions but it just feels like a slog when you're going up against AIs who barely fight back and the story moves on at a crawl.

Online though is an important part of this game that has frustratingly enough not been improved for a long time now. It uses delay-based netcode which is not ideal in itself. However add this on top of DCing in the middle of a match carrying no penalty, and on the flipside no option to forfeit in case an emergency DOES comes up in the middle of a match, makes the online experience feel incomplete. With the Covid-19 situation, offline play is more limited than ever, so we'll have to see if they actually start implementing rollback netcode into this game or not. In general it just feels horrible right now when you get magneted into an auto combo because of lag.

I'd still say that Dragonball FighterZ is a fighting game that's fun at many levels, but you're going to wish the online was better.

I wanted to do an actual review off this game because I feel like I‚Äôve been with this game enough to truly capitalize on what it struggles in. This is also when EVO 2020 was completely cancelled, which I will mention that it‚Äôll have an impact on this game‚Äôs state

To get the positives over with, the game has amazing graphics. It‚Äôs easy to run. It‚Äôs beginner friendly(I‚Äôll mention this later), and it‚Äôs really fun labbing all sorts of possibilities with your team in training mode. In season 3, it‚Äôs amazing that there are now more opportunities opened up to change up your team, instead of reflecting off the meta(cough cough season 2). All in all, amazing if you‚Äôre a dragon ball fan and worth getting.

But it just ends there. My two biggest gripes about this game.

[Super Dash]: A universal button that has your character homing in on the enemy. This wouldn‚Äôt be a problem, if so many people just didn‚Äôt press it in scramble situations. Super dash beats almost every option in this game besides 2H(2H stands for down-heavy, and is the universal anti-air). That‚Äôs right, super dash is a better whiff punisher than many specials in this game that encourage some sort of approach. The game always has to favor the super dash instead of the legitimate approach. I shouldn‚Äôt be able to make a approach just by calling an assist and super dashing which apparently kills off a lot of options. A lot of people wonder why it‚Äôs a complaint from me, because they‚Äôll say ‚ÄúDude just punish it with 2H‚Äù. But that‚Äôs also part of the problem. You‚Äôre essentially punishing your opponent who pressed ONE BUTTON by you pressing ONE BUTTON. Neutral in this game essentially shouldn‚Äôt be like that. You have all these tools to yourself as a character and it‚Äôs up to you to win it, not just have two people push a single button. Essentially, a lot of potential was thrown out the window due to this.

[Online & The Community]: When you play the game online, it‚Äôs usually a very difficult path compared to playing at a local where you can easily learn from others. You have to deal w/ frame delay which will easily encourage mashing from both players. Not to mention, players who make a half-assed effort to win the game through something like superdash or turtling(2H only). You‚Äôll never truly improve facing these players, they act as some sort of roadblock(do you know this game enough to be punishing people who super dash too much?) before you get to actual good players who use a real legitimate strategy in order to win. Always go to a local, if you can. People play offline almost entirely differently and you will have an easier time learning the game. Unfortunately, I hardly went to any locals, but I‚Äôve sank too many hours into this game that it hardly even matters that I learn anymore. Take the opportunity I never had.

And lastly, this game falls into the exact same tech-trap that many other fighting games do, it‚Äôs tier lists. No matter what, people will absolutely disregard other characters because they are ‚Äúinferior‚Äù to the top tiers. This is simply untrue because every character brings something to the table in this game‚Äîeven when it seems that they don‚Äôt. You can make every character work in this game. A tier list doesn‚Äôt represent how good a character is, but their relevance in the meta and how much they are known.

It doesn‚Äôt matter where your favorite character is on a tier list. If you can work around their weaknesses and show off their strengths, people will reconsider placing them differently. You will have everyone‚Äôs respect when you bust out some amazing tech no one has seen before at a tournament. 

Blue Vegeta is seen as the season‚Äôs current bottom tier, but

It‚Äôs only a matter of time until someone takes him to a tournament and shows his true potential.

Over all if you are a fighting game fan, I would highly recommend this game. Especially if you love Dragonball.

There is a difference between this game and fighting games such as Street Fighter, Tekken, Mortal Kombat, Soul Caliber, etc.

The difference is that every character in this game has a backstory that spans 40 years. Established in 1986, Dragon Ball is a long running anime/manga series that really engrosses its audience. Not quite sci-fi, not-quite fantasy and not-quite a Kung Fu action series, Dragon Ball is a niche that nobody could have predicted to be so successful.

And now, we have the ultimate Dragon Ball fighting experience.

Honestly, I feel a lot more connected to the fighters in this game than in any other fighting game. Every move has a backstory. I remember the first time Krillin used his Destructo Disc or the Goku vs Frieza fight. Being able to physically perform these moves feels more satisfying than in any other fighting game.

The game has not one, but THREE different stories to play through.
The game has an online lobby where you can interact with other players and fight.
The game has unique characters with their own moves and dialogue (where you can switch between Japanese and English versions).
The game has an online tournament mode, an established esports scene and local tournaments in major cities around the world.

I'd been prompted by friends to get into Tekken but I was unable to. I'm not much of a fighting game enthusiast myself (although I had enjoyed them since I was about 5 years old). The questions that burned in my head were "why are these people fighting in the middle of the street with people cheering them on?" 

There was never an answer to that in games like Tekken. 
In Dragon Ball Fighterz, that question is always answered. 

The interaction between fighters is organic. There's a reason why they fight. There's a reason why YOU play (you're featured in the story of the game). There is a reason for everything in the game. 

If you watch the show, you'll be better equipped to understand what's going on. To a degree, it may be difficult for non-Dragon Ball fans to understand the plot. There are no spoilers for the show, yet you still need to understand who you're fighting to fully grasp WHY you're fighting.

This is a must-have fighting game for any enthusiast. If this game is not in your Steam library, you are missing out.

Went in blind with not much experience playing fighting games, nor having any skill in playing with a controller. Got to say, easily one of the best games I have played.

It has simple enough one button combos which would make you feel like you are doing fancy things, to in-depth combat which you learn as you play the game. The gorgeous visuals and choreography make the game a must play for anyone who likes fighting games. 

The best part though is the practice range, which has so much customisation that it makes life easier for training and practising new fancy combos and tricks. I have not tried the practice range on other fighting games to have a comparative talk on this, but from what I have seen in this game, it is really good. 

And last but not the least, the background music being upbeat, does its work really well as well.

It also has a story mode which many might not appreciate, especially since you need to beat that to get one of the characters playable. The story isn't anything to write home about, but for newbies to fighting games, it provides good practice before you get to delve into the actual game.

The most fun I've had with a fighting game in the past 5 years. Easy to pick up with universal inputs paired with deep, nuanced and strategy oriented gameplay. Gorgeous visuals, incredible music, tight presentation and a full and fun original story mode. Fluid structure and plenty of activities to break up and change routines. Netplay has been excellent with no lag or drops but only tested with friends in my city. Some menus are convoluted but are easy to figure out. Character and other DLC is pricey, season based but not predatory and worth it for the characters especially during a Steam Sale. No issues with installation or PC options. This game brings so much hype, fun, wow factor and is a must for for fans of Dragon Ball and fighting games.

[h1]The Perfect DBZ fighter[/h1]
The controls feels great and it's so easy to start cool looking combos. It's the perfect blend of a modern fighting game. You get the tag team action and super combos from MvC plus the sophisticated gameplay of Guilty Gears.

[h2]It's flashy[/h2]
Yup it has awesome 3D anime graphics! The game is noob friendly and is easy to pick up. After playing for a bit it looks like it has some harder to make combos. Although I suspect it may not be a in-depth as lets say Street fighter or a Guilty Gears game, but I could be wrong.   There are multiple game mode like an online hub, tournaments, story mode, VS just to name a few. 

[h2]Closing Words[/h2]
Most of all is that the game is super fun and feels exciting to play. The only downside I saw was the frequent loading screens. Besides that I would almost say it's a perfect game and that's coming from a Dragon ball fanboy. 

Highly Recommended

Its spectacular and a really fun game... in singleplayer. Multiplayer is a nightmare. The balance is all over the place. I dont even know why its 3 character system when you can master 1 dude and use the other 2 as cannon fodder you use to heal up. Strategy is simple, wait for a single mistake of the opponent and then dish out a combo which takes 80% of the opponents health. That would be fine, it takes a lot of skill to learn this but there is one major problem, there is no way to interrupt combos. Did they ever seen Killer Instinct? Thats how you balance a game like this, with combo breakers. Also, controls feel weird and unresponsive most of the time. You try to do a combo, nope, half a second too late or early on input. You cant even easily learn the timings if you want. Training mode provides you with a list of buttons to press but never when to press them. Its not even showing what are you pressing, which is a standard thing in fighting games training modes. Some combos are just rapid presses, other require a certain delay to wait for animations or enemy to be in a perfect position. Finding the sweet spot is just luck. At the end of the day, if you have lots of time and patience, when you master that one 85+ hit combo you can juggle newbies for days because when they make 1 mistake, its over, and they cant recover from this without a combo breaker mechanic. Entry point is high af. If you are a fan of the franchise you'll get some fun out of this no matter what but it might not last very long.

Dragon Ball FighterZ really takes me back to the DBZ Budokai 3 game era for the PS2. DragonballZ is known for it's fighting genre and many lovable characters to which iv'e grown up with and envied. They've made many Dragonball fighting games over the years but this one by far exceeded my expectations. I own this game here on Steam, on my Xbox, and on my Nintendo Switch because of how much I enjoy it (Got all 3 copies on sale for $15 each and only have all the DLC on switch because I play it on there more than Xbox or PC). I love to play this game and duke it out with my friends and I can't express how much I recommend DBFZ to people that are interested. Even if you've never played a Dragon Ball game before, you shouldn't have a problem with Dragon Ball FighterZ. I hope my review assists you on your decision to get this game. Take it easy out there!

It's obviously borrowed from Street Fighter 2 and later, but those games went on to borrow a lot from Dragon Ball Z; basically all the air combos and huge energy blasts. If the game gives you a Fatal Error UE4 RED when you try to launch the game, it's because it doesn't like the graphics settings.  For me, Windowed Fullscreen caused it to bug out, I have to use regular Fullscreen to have it work all the time.  To get back in the game though:

1) Right click on DBFZ game in Steam, then go to Properties, then Set Launch Options.
2) Type -fullscreen or -windowed to force game to boot different than what you had it set to.  
3) Start the game, go to Options and change your Resolution type and size to what you'd prefer, I recommend regular Fullscreen since tabbing out seems smooth anyways.  
4) Exit game, go back to Steam's Launch Options and remove the command you typed in.  
5) Launch game as normal again and everything should be back to normal.

Fixed it for me, hope this helps you!

Full review (originally for PS4 in 2018) here: https://dagondogs.com/2018/03/14/dragon-ball-fighterz-2018-in-depth-review

TL;DR
Dragon Ball FighterZ took some time for me to learn and took some time to really start enjoying. Once I got over the learning curve and the unhelpful design choices, however, I've really sunk my teeth into this game. It's the first tag-battle fighting game I've been excited to keep playing in a long time. It's stylish, fast-paced, and true to the source material that caters to the DBZ fan buried deep within me. The annoying design choices, lame lobby system, uninspired soundtrack, and the problematic netcode are all unfortunate detractors of the experience. But, if you can see your way around it, there's a lot of fun to be had with the first really good Dragon Ball fighting game.
