If you like dragonball and you like fighting games like marvel vs capcom or fighting games in general you will like this. The animation is top notch, even if you aren't that good the game makes you feel like you are and if you are good then thats a whole other level! No matter wether you are a pro or novice or have never played a fighting game before if you love dbz you'll love this game. Also the story isn't half bad either! No spoilers but its not the generic folliow the team through the series story its a brand new story just for this game (non cannon obviously just like the movies and dbx1 and 2) One thing I would say is wait for the fighter packs to go on sale if you are only new to buying the game, its just as fun without all the new fighters and its definitely not worth paying full price for the dlc when its on special throughout most of the steam sales! 

BUT if you can't wait some of the newer characters are very fun! just whatever you do buy the packs dont buy them individually unless you never ever plan on buying anymore otherwise you are just wasting your money.

Also one more thing to mention this game has in game curreny with heavy RNG, [b]BUT[/b] there is no way to buy that in game currency outside of the game you have to play to earn it, you are given some for some events and for having some dlc if I remember correctly could be completely wrong here, but you definitely cannot buy it outside of the game which is awesome cause this guys could be cashing in and they are not!
its all mavhel baby

I don't know what a Dragon Ball is, have any understanding of what is happening at any point during the narrative portions of the game, nor know why having bigger hair seems to be a source of power...and the game is still amazing. Easily one of the most incredible looking games I've ever seen.  I'm not even real sure how they're doing it; some sort of next level cell shading combined with...black magic?  You're watching a cartoon that you're also playing in.  There are a few other titles out there that try to achieve this effect, but they are nowhere even close.  I haven't seen anything this visually groundbreaking in over a decade.

I wouldn't call it a proper competitive fighter though.  The fighting is wildly chaotic, and it's often a bit hard to even figure out where your guy is with all the absurdly huge explosions.  Definitely more the madness of Smash Bros. than the refinement of Tekken.  It in no way detracts from the fun, but you wouldn't want to bet money on an outcome, as a good bit of button mashing will beat even the best technique.  The upside of that is also that it makes it very accessible to younger players or the inexperienced.

If you like Dragon Ball and fighting games, this is a must. I have to say, comming from other fighters such as SFIV and MVC2, it's nice to have a game that doesn't worry too much about complicated combo links and mechanics and rather pits you in with the good meat of every fighting game: The mind games.

I would say, it's an amazing entry title for newcomers, and also a very good title for veterans who enjoy team-fighters (like MVC, CVS, Skullgirls and such).

The bad?
The online experience is sub-par (as with pretty much every single fighting game out there). The online community is not as huge as the PS4 version. There are some tricky characters that you might think look cool, but are a pain to learn (still not as hard as with other games).

This game goes on sale all the time, wait for the sale and get the FighterZ edition so you can have, at least, the season 1 characters (that are super good), and you can take it from there.

If you do decide to get it, I hope you have a blast!

the single player of the game is solid though. character choices are cool, and with some worth dlc characters
to fight with as well. i would wait for fighters to go on sale to buy, and they frequently do. but they are worth the addition to the game. the AI can be tough and easy just depends on what you are playing and at what difficulty. overall on how you collect items for things in the room you go is pretty vast. there is also several single player modes to play.

overall the game is good. single player solid can become repeative, but the AI can teach you things you have never thought of lol. but online is just a nightmare unless you research combos with 3v3 and go practice you are not really gonna get anywhere. but the game does have friendly match system in reception area where you battle others with out having to que up if you can find a busy enough server to do that with.

The game feels fantastic and is a great gateway to fighting games. It has gorgeous visuals and has a pretty decent cannon story for dragon ball fans. The developers at arc system do take a while to make changes to the game through patches which is a genuine curse because if you don't like a certain meta you might as well just take a break. This also applies to DLC characters as some have been meta defining (destroying) and saw no action for most of the DLC's shelf life. It also has a visual issue occasionally as sometimes the game gets messy and its hard to see whats happening as well as my distaste toward the super dash mechanic but even with everything i have pointed out. The game is worth a play no matter if your new to the FGC or a veteran because this game is truly one of my favorite fighters to play especially with the season 3 changes.

This game overall is a masterpiece. Every animation, song, character, moveset, etc. calls back to the source material flawlessly, most of the time shot for shot remakes. Gameplay wise this is easily the best Dragonball fighting game. The basics are simplistic enough that anyone can jump in and hit the ground running, while still retaining a high skill ceiling to hold the attention of more experienced fighting game players. The issues I do have with the game are almost exclusively personal, and hardly even worth writing about, though there are two things that I believe most would agree with me on. The single player content is a bit lackluster, the story mode is a tedious, and the tutorials aren't altogether conducive to helping new players grow more accustomed to mid-high level play. Delay-based netcode is also less than ideal in any fighting game, and that's something I hope Bamco considers replacing in the future. If those issues are fixed in a future update I'd definitely give the game a 10/10 but for now I'll give it a 9.

Everything about this game is amazing. From the animation to the actual gameplay. Another masterpiece from Arcsys. 10/10.

WARNING: This only applies from A.) My experience and B.) Playing at a Middle-ish level of play

I love this game so goddamn much, and have played an ungodly amount of hours across all platforms, and for me is easily the best Versus style game out there, especially with the new additions from Season 3. However, even with this probably being my favorite fighting game ever, I absolutely cannot recommend it in its current state, especially to newcomers.

I want to start out with some positives. This game, in theory, is very friendly to newcomers. Combos have a very simple structure, letting new players easily learn the execution for higher level play, deemphasizing new players mashing auto-combos. All of the characters are well put together and stay true to the show and manga. This seal of quality is especially apparent in the DLC, paying brilliant homage to the characters in almost every move. Every character is well balanced, and while there is a very apparent meta, it is still very possible to win with the worst of the roster with Jiren, Krillin, and Videl being among them.  Figuring out combos and what your team can do is some of the most fun you can have in the game, making you feel like the smartest person in the world when you figure out some weird combo that only your team can do.

However it's not all sunshine and rainbows. I‚Äôll start with the least concerning problem first. This being a versus game it has the expected broken characters. Almost all of the Gokus are among the best in the game. While all of the assists can be utilized (except maybe Krillin‚Äôs A assist) there are assists that are way way way waaaaayyy better than the others. DBS Broly is a good example, his A and B assists are good, however his C assist is obviously the best as it doubles as a beam assist and standard C assist. This is to be expected as it is a versus game, however this can be very annoying especially to newcomers of versus games.

However, what is less forgivable is Bandai selling DLC characters that arguably should have been in the game since it first released back in 2018. base Goku and base Vegeta should have been in the game from the beginning, but no, we‚Äôll sell them for 5$ a piece. Other characters like Jiren and DBZ Broly also fall into this category. Now, I am an idiot consumer who will buy into this because I love this game, however this is a big turn off for many people I know, and Bandai and Arc Sys are potentially losing consumers, and a larger community because of this. Another problem with this is that the asking price for only 16, or all of the DLC characters is 80 DOLLARS. This is 20$ more than the asking price for the base game, which is pretty scummy if you ask me.

My last points will be on the biggest problem this game faces, and something that makes me want to quit playing my favorite fighting game ever, the online environment. This game‚Äôs community is either very helpful and nice, and will always rematch even if you're low rank, or is extremely toxic and will rage quit if you land two combos on them in a row (which is a problem with almost any fighting game, however I have noticed it in this game more which could easily because of my playtime across all platforms). All of the best characters are substantially better online thanks to some of the worst netcode in modern day AAA fighting games. What is even worse is that Arc Sys hasn‚Äôt done anything to fix it or even make it slightly better. And when indie devs are making better netcode in games like Skullgirls and Them's Fightin‚Äô Herds than you, a Triple A dev, somethings wrong. And hey, remember what I said about the game‚Äôs good simple combo structure deemphasizes new players mashing their face against the X button? Well I actually lied. In the online environment you will find high ranking players with Pink and Red squares playing Vegito and mashing their face against the controller. Now this is reactable, as you can block almost anything with enough practice, and they won‚Äôt be safe forever as they will lose their assists eventually, however my friends were immediately turned off by the terrible online, and feeling hopelessly outmatched thanks to a terrible matchmaking system.

I love this game so much for being the game that got me into fighting games, as an amazing homage to the original material, and having fantastic balance and really fun mechanics, however 2 years of putting up with this games bullshit, and 2 years of putting up with Arc Sys and Bandai making mistake after mistake, creating overpowered or disappointing characters and doing nothing about it has led me to now where I am actively being discouraged to play it. I hope a brighter future or sequel comes for this game, but for now I am constantly saddened by this game's competitive balance.

[code] Dragon Ball FighterZ is a 2D fighting game developed by Arc System Works and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment.[/code]

[table]
     [tr]
         [th]‚úîÔ∏è Pros[/th]
         [th]‚ùå Cons[/th]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td] ‚óè Beginners Friendly
               ‚óè Competitive + Esport Scene
               ‚óè Bonus Story Related to the Anime
               ‚óè Japanese Voice - Acting
               ‚óè Good Soundtrack[/td]
         [td] ‚óè Repetive Fights
               ‚óè Lack of New Players[/td]
     [/tr]
[/table]
             
        [h1] üìì Story  [/h1]

The game takes place sometime between "Universe 6" and "Future Trunks" arcs of Dragon Ball Super. The game's main antagonist, Android 21 (or later, her evil-half), was a normal human who eventually became an Android created by the Red Ribbon Army after her son became the model for Android 16. Once she awakens, she repairs 16 and uses the Dragon Balls to resurrect Frieza, Cell, Nappa, and the Ginyu Force, and seals away the powers and souls of all of Earth's strongest warriors. Wanting to control the hungry monster within her, she and 16 develop a linking system originally created by Dr. Gero in which a human soul (the player) can possess the warriors and provide them strength.

      ‚óèThere are 3 Arc's in Dragon Ball FighterZ
 
           ‚óè Super Warrior Arc

      This is the first Arc of the game, and in it we play the role of the ‚Äúplayer's soul.‚Äù After ‚Äúpossessing‚Äù Goku, we wake up to Bulma, according to whom Goku has amnesia. After a short further explanation of what is happening, you go in search of your comrades to create a strong team with which to defeat the main villain in this Arc - Android 21.

          ‚óè Enemy Warrior Arc

   In the second Arc you are given the opportunity to "possess" the body of an main villain from the anime. You play with it, form a team of villains, and then even make a joint team between villains and heroes to beat Android 21.

          ‚óè Android 21 Arc

This is the last arc, where everything will end once and for all. In it you have the opportunity to play on behalf of Android 18 and also on behalf of the main villain of the previous 2 arc's - Android 21. In it you finally understand many important things about the story and you are given the chance to see her good side. For me personally, she became one of my favorite characters in the game.

    https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2103826351       

        [h1] üïπÔ∏è Gameplay [/h1]

    ‚óè Mechanics    

 You choose 3 characters to fight with. An interesting mechanic in the game is that you can change the other 2 characters at any time, which opens up great opportunities for different combos. You can also call them for "assist" while fighting, and this also opens up other possibilities for combos. With all these combo capabilities, the opportunity for world stages and many competitions is actually alive. There is another special mechanic. It's called "Come on, Shenron!". To use it, you need to collect the 7 dragon balls, which you can collect through different combinations of strikes. Once activated, this option allows you to choose between several of your "wishes": increasing your fighter's strength, reviving a fallen ally, recovering a fighter's health or regenerating health for the rest of the match. Something i don't like is the mechanic for blocking. You can move backwards to block a punch and you have having 3 different types of blocking. The first is to block frontal attacks, the second is to block attacks focused on the bottom of your character, and the third type of blockade is for top attacks. They all come with key combinations involving backwards moving. 

    ‚óè Ai's
 
Let me explain to you how things are with AIs. When you launch the game and activate the story mode, you can start only with "normal" difficulty, which I find a bit boring. In the first arc, the AIs rarely make any punches, in the second they hit from time to time and in the third you can now feel the real feeling of the battle in the game, but not to the point where you need to execute flawless combos in order to defeat them.

    ‚óè Esport and ranked scene 

Above in pros and cons I noted that the game has a developed Esport scene, but there is also a lack of players. Let me explain these words of mine. The game already has a world championship, which is being held for 3 years in a row. There are other tournaments that I am not familiar with. You are probably wondering how there are world championships, but there are no players? I was also wondering that. From my personal observations I noticed that there are 20 people in the servers and they are all already developed players in this game. When you let matchmaking look for people of your caliber, you upload for an indescribably long time, and if you accidentally find someone for one game, then it happens that you play against both the next and the next round against him because are no other newbies. From these personal observations, I came to the conclusion that there is simply a lack of players and all that is left in the game are people who have already developed some higher skill level.


        [h1]üìä Difficulty [/h1]

     The game can be as difficult as you want. The game has many difficulty settings for the story and arcade modes, on top of fighting ranked online if you're looking for a bigger challenge.

       [h1] üéº Soundtrack [/h1]
       
     The music in Dragon Ball FighterZ was composed by:

          ‚óè Toshiyuki Kishi
          ‚óè Hiromi Mizutani
          ‚óè Kenji Katoh Reno

    The music is themed for fighting games. It fits well into the atmosphere and definitely moves the game. Each character in the game has a themed song and each arena has its own song. Separately, we have intro, main, lobby and loading songs, and to top it all off, Bandai offers you 2 anime song DLC's that you can buy, but not at the small price of $ 14.99 USD. (Note, gameplay recording will be blocked when these songs are playing due to copyright issues.)

       [h1] üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶ Target audience [/h1]

     The game focuses on people who like anime and mainly on Dragon Ball fans. It is also focused on people who love 2D fighting games with Esport scene.

     [h1]  üíØ Performance [/h1]

   The game is not very strenuous and can easily be played on machines that are not as strong. I think you can easily play it on maximum graphics with GEFORCE GTX 1060, not to mention weaker than that. I have not encountered any problems with FPS and I have not had any drops. I dare to say that the game is well optimized.

Tested with the following setup:

        [td]2x8GB[/td]
     [/tr]
     [/table]

      [h1] üíª Graphics / Art-style [/h1]

     Well, the game's graphics don't need RTX 2080 to see their full potential. As an anime-based game that has to stick to a certain visual, this game makes it great. The visuals definitely gives you that fighting game vibe and is aesthetically pleasing. There are great effects as well, which I was able to fully enjoy.
     
        https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2105188286      

      [h1]üìã Conclusion[/h1]
  
    I will definitely recommend you this game because it is actually worth it but since it's a game from 2018, just wait for a sale. She is getting a lot of big sales. 

      [h1]üìπ YouTube  [/h1]

Dragon Ball FighterZ is one of the best fighting games I've ever experienced, and by far the best Dragon Ball game I've experienced. It comes from a genuine love and appreciation of both fighting games and Dragon Ball as a whole, and it shows. Everything in the game is inspired, and if you're a Dragon Ball fan, you'd be hard-pressed to find to not find something to love about FighterZ. And even if you're not, it's still a damn good game, too. The story mode is really enticing, I loved the voice acting especially, and the animations were very smooth. The later fights can be a real drag if you're like me and not particularly great at fighting games, but still manageable.
Pick this game up if you've ever considered it. You'll find a lot to love here.

I hate fighting games and I'm not even a Dragonball fan but I like this game. The way the controls are and how easy it is to do damaging, cool looking combos with a little bit of practice makes me feel closer to actually getting good at a fighting game than I ever have felt in my 8 year love/hate, on again/off again casual experience with other fighting games from Street Fighter 2 to Tekken 7 and all the animes in between.
All the times where I get down on the genre as a whole and feel like I should just uninstall I always come back thinking, "just a little more practice with the universal bnb, or combo extension off a wall bounce/assist and I can get there!". Doing a good blockstring to eventually hit confirm into the universal bnb into three supers is a great feeling. Game is too much fun.

One of the only fighting games I care about playing and enjoy playing.
Dragonball FighterZ, Mortal Kombat 11, and Injustice 2 are the only games I particularly love.

Pros:
-The animation and graphics are absolutely gorgeous. Dragon ball has never looked better and incredible till now
-You do get to see some hilarious interactions and roasts from each character. Story mode has alternate scenes for each character on the field.
-Combat is fun, easy to understand, and fun to keep trying out
-3v3 battles with teammates assisting in the battle is crazy good.
-Lots of fan loved characters are in and look great. Gogeta, Vegito, UI Goku, Goku Black, Zamasu, GT Goku, etc.
-Each fighterz pass is worth it. I recommend getting FighterZ Edition then get the Zpass 3 and 2 if needed. 
-It is a new story. Not the same old Freiza arc, Cell Games arc, Androids arc, Buu arc, etc. 
-New Buu race character named Android 21 which seemed to be a favorite for a lot of people
-There are a good amount of mods available on dbfighterz mods site and they make up for the missing transformations or colors we want to see. You can even have SSB turn into MUI instead.

Cons:
-Would be great if there were more costumes and not recolors for characters
-More dramatic finishes would be insane and is lacking
-No SSG characters. Only SSB and SS3 and below. Also SS4 is included and UI Goku is here.
-Story is meh.
-Prices are still pretty steep. I got this on sale so wait till then.

WOW. Where to start... 

What I don't like about the game:
If you're new to fighting games then just give up if you don't no life games. The amount of smurfs at lower ranks makes it near impossible to learn. The tutorials in-game suck ass and barely teach you anything (including the new dojo training). All of the training is incredibly forgettable unless you write everything down. Since the training in-game is terrible, youtube is pretty much the only source of knowledge and even then, it's hard to grasp everything (idk maybe im just stupid). Trying to learn combos is incredibly hard if you don't know the "fighterz lingo" and it's ESPECIALLY difficult if you use a ps4 controller. I mean holy shit is it annoying to learn where the xbox controls are on the ps4 controller in-game. I know you can mod the game in order to get ps4 layout but I just didn't put in the time. The season pass and dlc fighters cost way to much. Not worth it in the slightest. I recommend buying one or two characters you like and just stick it out. Don't waste money on the season pass. 

What I like about the game:
The visuals look amazing at all times and the game is not hard to run at all. The moves are flashy, the supers are cinematic, and they knocked the voice lines out of the park. This game is honestly amazing on local play with friends. The amount of fan service they put into the game with all the abilities really is the only thing keeping me from quitting. If you choose to be a spectator rather than a player, this game is one of the most entertaining fighting games to watch in terms of competitive play. 

Summary: In my opinion, the cons outweigh the pros. The game is not newbie friendly because of the smurfs and the only reason you should even consider buying this game is because it's Dragon Ball.

Arc system works really nailed the essence of what it is to play as a DBZ character. As a long time fighting game follower as well as an avid DBZ fan, I can say that they have masterfully crafted a fighting game that feels as fast and explosive as the series it's based on. 

With each updated this game gets better and better. If you aren't familiar with the way that Arcysystem animates their games, it's truly unique. If you like fighting games this is one that should not be missing from your repertoire of games.

Still my favorite game currently out right now. I can't get enough of it. All the characters are fun to play and play against. The strengths and weaknesses of the characters are fairly balanced, especially since you have the option to mix and match different fighters to create a team to match your playstyle. 

A few people like to complain about the balance of the game, but it's just a coping mechanism to make them feel better about losing. In reality, from my experience of playing, I'd say the game is well balanced, especially with the recent patch allowing everyone to play their favorite characters and still compete online. Only thing that is stopping this game from becoming THE best fighting game at the moment is the lack of GGPO for rollback netplay to smoothen the online experience. But if you are playing this game on PC, the online experience is much better than the PS4 online experience. 

The overall gameplay and feel of the game is top notch . And if you are a Dragonball fan, you can easily spot many of the easter eggs and references to the show, which makes the game that much more enjoyable. If you want to play the game competitively, there is a world of resources online (youtube/twitter/twitch) that you can refer to in order to ameliorate your gameplay, the sky's the limit, and even till this day new aspects of the game are being discovered. New characters are still being added to the roster, I‚Äôm looking forward to the next DLC (Ultra Instinct Goku) next week. 

100/100 would recommend this game to anyone, especially if you‚Äôre trying to get into fighting games. It is very easy to get into but difficult to master.

The game itself is good and this is a mixed review. The fighting is awesome and the amount of content is pretty good. But, there's a few issues that make it not so fun. 

I ran into a bug in which you have to delete a certain file in order to fix this... EVERY. SINGLE. LAUNCH. 
It's a fatal error message that closes the game and many others run into the same issue so it just isn't me.

As for online play, from what I've gotten so far is disconnects left and right. I'll join a fight, and a few seconds in, get D/C'd. I thought it was only me, but no, just more bad Bandai server issues that many more people experience. 

Good for solo and co op content if you want to fix that stupid bug every time it launches.

The gameplay is fantastic, unfortunately the online is atrocious so finding online matches around your skill level with good connection takes ages. If you have friends or are willing to put up with massive queue times its worth it. But if not, grab this when its on sale.

[h1] The Short Version [/h1]

It's a solid fighting game with mechanics beginners can pick up really easily and very easy combos to learn.

[h1] The Biggie [/h1]

Dragon Ball FighterZ is my favorite Dragon Ball game ever, might be because I really love fighting games, might be because the game looks and feels amazing, but let's talk more.

The overall gameplay is very solid, from vanishes to dragon rushes, there's not a time when DBFZ becomes predictable, however, that does bring some issues.

Let's say you're playing the game, block a move then get hit by Bardock's B Assist, now you have to block for a full minute before your opponent allows you to play again. Now let me make this clear: There is absolutely nothing wrong with having flashy blockstrings you labbed for 30 hours, I just personally think it's really not fun having to sit through 3 cycles of the guy hitting you with assists and mixing you up. Fortunately I suck at blocking and get hit by anything so I generally don't have to sit through everything.

People complain about online a lot, I was born and raised in the 19 frames so it's whatever for me.

My main complaint is DLC prices, gotta hate them.

Overall, solid game, a tad overpriced, not without its issues.

Definetly recommend though.

I bought this game when it first came out, I will be reviewing its game in its current state (Currently we are on Season 3)
I may update this review in the future if there are more user-friendly features or a removal of user-friendlyness in this game.

This game is a fighting game, as such it will have game mechanics that don't inherently make sense and will cause you frustration.
With that out of the way, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game in its current state to anyone who either A) loves Dragon Ball or B) loves fighting games. This game's presentation is absolutely bonkers and does an excellent job recreating Dragon Ball in the Arc-Sys art style, while still retaining the look of Dragon Ball.
The mechanics that this game presents are complex, but the game has a specific mode called "FighterZ Dojo" which helps explain all of these mechanics, which makes it very easy for newcomers to learn the game by just playing it instead of watching Youtube videos.
The game also supports various types of playstyle, by allowing the player to pick from 3 assists per character on their team of three. If you want to pressure your opponent? you've got assists for that. Do you want to combo your opponent and deal a lot of damage? You've got assists for that. Do you want to hang back and try to react? We've got assists for that too. The many different types of assists and characters allow for any player to pick up this game and create a team that suits their playstyle.
[spoiler] Yes i understand there is a painful amount of Goku in this game but they all play different, also Dragon Ball's main protagonist is Goku so it makes sense that he is represented the most [/spoiler]

The game's storymode is mediocre, but the team interactions before a match starts are a great way to have genuine fanservice in the game by developing what-if dialogue to be played before a match in story mode starts.

Training mode in this game is very effective, it allows you to not only practice combos, but also practice reactions to the opponents actions by allowing you to record actions. Recording actions is very powerful and key if you want to develop strategies to either protecting yourself or to stay on offense.

Arcade mode is a mode, very simple. You fight enemy AI teams in rapid succession. i do not like the artificial damage increases that you experience when you progress in arcade mode

Tournament of Power mode in the FighterZ Dojo is a fantastic mode that doesn't feature artificial damage scaling, and you get rewarded for playing a variety of characters in that mode with "Titles" that are specific to that character. Titles appear on your player card before a match begins, they can say things like "First to Fighting" or "Nervous Around Girls". Some reference characters directly, like when Vegeta says "Heh! What Dirty Fireworks!". 

Online is a bit iffy, but if you have a wired connection and filter what connections you want to see when engaging in matchmaking, you should do well. The reported connection is not your opponent's quality of internet, but instead its the relationship between you and your opponents connection.

Overall, I rate this game a 8/10, it has its flaws and some of the game mechanics do not make sense (super dash is a good example), but if you can get over that, the game provides all the tools you need to have a great time. Online has some quirks too but they can be circumvented

Please be wary of the extensive DLC, there is a lot, and if you want to buy them, please check youtube videos featuring those characters to see if they are worth your dollar. I have bought all the DLC because i just would like as many possibilities as possible when playing, but you may not feel the same.

Don't get me wrong this game is really fun, but man can this game get on your nerves. And before we get into this "this guy didn't play enough to fully critic the game" stfu and sit down for a second. To get this out of the way, this game has janky hitboxes, a couple of examples is kid buu's down heavy, golden frieza's down heavy, and bardock's down heavy, all of these down heavies have unusual hitboxes that should not be there. Another hit box that seems to be weird as well is Zamasu's heavy, when his enemy is slightly above him no where near his leg, it somehow hits it. But I have good faith that these could be possibly patched. Aside from that the game is fun, I like how each character is different unlike in tenkaichi where all the characters where basically the same.  I do have a few questionable slots of why these characters are here, but this is about how the game plays. Story is alright i guess, it could have been improved. Gameplay is fun, stages are gorgeous looking along with the whole game, ranked and casual can be insanely hard but rewarding.  Overall, i give this game a solid 7/10. it could have gotten higher if the character line up was better and the hitboxes were better. other than that fun game.

Hands down the best fighting game in the world right now, Beautiful art direction, Mechanically sound, And jam packed with little things that fans will love,

Has a respectable base roster, and loads of DLC characters that are made with the same care and attention as the base characters if not more. You could go through a character's move list and find the moment they do that exact same move in the anime. You can tell its made by people who care.

The game itself is beautiful, the effects are spot on, and it feels like playing an anime, which is the part of the reason why people buy Dragon Ball games in the first place. Additionally, in matchups that happened in the series, there will be special dialogue, and in some cases full cutscenes after the fight or 'Dramatic Finishes'

The mechanics are all there, it never gets pretentious with how you input your controls, and it feels natural to play, not precise for the sake of being difficult like other games.  You can actually have a good time picking up the game, and getting better on your own by battling other people, instead of sitting in training mode trying to get consistent enough to do your inputs as well as the game arbitrarily thinks you should have to do them.

So yeah, the game is gorgeous, Dragon Ball fans love it, competitive players love it, casual players love it and I can wholly recommend it to people who think they dislike fighting games, people who are hardcore members of the FGC, Dragon Ball fans, casual players, or people who just want a cool game with cool moves because they want to do cool shit.

Balance has been thrown out of the window at that point, especially when you're clearly blocking attacks and they just decide to go through. A low kick? Blocking low won't help. A super dash? Pros - 

-Visually stunning. Looks almost exactly like the anime w/3D models. Props to Arc System Works for their art direction. 
-Solid cast of characters, especially with the 2 previous season passes + the current new one. 
-Fast paced, team based fighting game. Doesn't feel like a clone of any other 3v3 fighting game. Feels very much like its own thing. 
-Team composition making has improved since season 3. Each character gaining 3 assists allows for near endless team synergy. 
-Simple inputs. If you don't feel like learning a DP motion or charge motion, then all you have to worry about is quarter circles in this game. 
-PC community is fairly active for a fighting game. 
-No microtransactions outside of DLC characters and music. Colors and stages are all free. 
- 3V3 player mode is fun (despite the lag issues it has). 
-Boss battle modes are fun for people into them. Adds a layer of challenge.
- Easy to jump into compared to some fighting games, but hard to master, like most.

Cons
- Story mode is a grind and kinda sucks. Also the only way to unlock Android 21 IF you don't own the season 1 pass. 
- Online is delay based netcode. TLDR, it's not good. Likely will find some pretty laggy matches. 
- Some frustrating mechanics exist, such as superdash. These become even more frustrating when you play online with 3-4+ frames of delay. 
-The games optimization can be hit or miss. Sometimes the game hard crashed on me. There are ways to fix this with some configuration changes though.

To preface this review, I had never played a serious fighting game before. I was pretty terrible at them and could not figure out how to do anything cool.

With that said, I have had an absolute blast with this game. I love Dragonball Z and Super, so I was naturally hyped for this game (even though I did not play this type of game). I'll be honest, I was super bad when I first started playing and I did not have a good time while getting my butt handed to me again and again. I even took a 3 month break from the game because I was very frustrated. However, I took the time to find the enjoyment and as you can see at the time of this review (414 hours), I have played this game a lot.

It is a fantastic game when you figure out how to go about playing it. The tutorials have been improved since the game has come out with (with the latest system changes) and all the characters in the game are really good. Season 1 was the base game and you could say the fighters were pretty generic and similar to one another. Season 2 came out and they introduced some interesting gimmicks and characters with fun things to do. Season 3 looks to do more of the same. The tournaments are really good to watch (EVO, etc) and the top players really showcase what the game can do.

The most important thing I can say about this game is the rewarding feeling you get when you master a combo you have been grinding for the past however long. I have felt this many times with all the characters I have played and it feels amazing every time. Don't get me wrong, you have to practice to be good and competent at this game, but it rewards you when you put the time in.

All in all, this is a very solid game. The biggest downfall is the online (delay based). It can be rough at times on PC but is serviceable for the most part. If you like Dragonball, give this a try!

DBFZ has been out for 2 years now and in my opinion, it's in it's most fun state yet. With the recent addition of selectable assists, it's easier than ever to make your dream team work without just being lazy to resort to throwing SSJ Goku in the back for his beam assist or something. It still has loads of depth despite it's more simple control scheme compared to other ArcSys games (I'd argue one of their most deep games in general!) and of course, it looks absolutely gorgeous. The roster is bigger than ever now and it's pretty well balanced too. DBFZ is probably my favorite fighting game of the generation and I still play it almost every chance I get (though I only recently moved onto PC from PS4).

It's biggest downside is it's mediocre average Arcsys delay based netcode. Recently, Arcsys has been interested in putting in good rollback netcode in their upcoming game, GG Strive, but who knows if it'll be good and even if it is, it'll ever be patched in. That being said, it's not unplayable by any means and if you have no other way to train, it's nice to have. 

It's easier than ever to get into these days, especially with the abundance of tutorials online. Sure it's not an easy game, but I believe in you. I definitely recommend DBFZ for fighting game fans and DBZ fans alike!

I‚Äôm not usually a fighting-game person, but liking shorter games this has ended up as the game I have clocked the most hours into. And for the most part, I‚Äôve enjoyed it. It‚Äôs fun and challenging and is a good contrast to other games I like to chill out and play. Even though I‚Äôm a noob in fighting games, I wouldn‚Äôt call this necessarily beginner friendly. It does try really hard in some areas, it has auto-combos for beginners, and if I had to set a difficulty to it, I suppose it‚Äôs easy to learn/hard to master. ArcSys knows that a lot of people probably will try it out because it‚Äôs Dragon Ball, so they do try their best.

FighterZ has ran smoothly on my computer for about a year now. Since it‚Äôs been a while for me personally to have major issues, I‚Äôll still recommend this game to anyone who knows their computer can run it.

Tutorials: Season 3 has added a lot here, with the FighterZ Dojo and the Tournament of Power competition. It was bare bones before, and no real help for anything besides beginner knowledge. And I would call it useless doing it separately outside the Story Mode, which you‚Äôre stuck doing the basics for a while into it. Now, I‚Äôll say all the tutorials together are something substantial and having a character set to be your master is an interesting concept and incentive for someone to complete them. Not my cup of tea, but it‚Äôs cool for people who like it.

Training Mode in general: There‚Äôs enough variety in what you can look at plus controlling the settings where you can spend hours effectively trying to get better. If you know what you‚Äôre doing, this game gives you a lot here to find strategies and teams that work for you. The combo challenges are nice if only so you can get a feel to see what sort of moves go together well for what character.

Story: The story itself is fine, but the pacing for both the story and gameplay is awful. It‚Äôs nice that it has that gallery option if you just want to revisit fun interactions and dialogue between the characters. That‚Äôs the best part of story mode. Like I said for tutorials, until you unlock hard mode a huge chunk of story is just repeating tutorials and super easy fights. I would only recommend story for Android 21 unlock and zeni grinding, though the ToP challenges in the Dojo eclipse the latter now.

Arcade Mode: I was tired of the same sets of fights, so I almost gave this mode up until it introduced random. Now, I go through it if I want to practice a few matches with a team without deciding what CPU level and teams to fight against. Just fight what the game gives me and roll with it. Not too hard, and I don‚Äôt know what the difficulty curve is set to, but it works if I don‚Äôt feel like going online. 

Local Battle: I don‚Äôt have any friends who play this game, so I can‚Äôt comment on its usefulness there. Looks competent. If I do have a specific CPU level I want to try, or just a single character to practice without doing a whole 3v3 battle I use this mode for quick fights.

Online: I only do normal matches, so I can‚Äôt comment on the Party Matches or anything that isn‚Äôt simply being matched with someone for battle. I don‚Äôt know anyone else that plays the game, and I feel party and ring matches are best used among people you know and know your fighting style. I see people unhappy with what matches are offered to them, but for me the longer I‚Äôve had this game the better it is.

New chances: I can set my parameters to good internet connection, high completion rate, and someone around my skill level and have matches lined up. It‚Äôs not always great, but I‚Äôll accept a few poor nights of not much compared to my old luck. Old chances: Have to accept all kinds of challengers, with poor internet connection, possible rage-quitters and people way out of my skill level and sometimes still have nothing. Part of it may be that I‚Äôm not completely at the bottom of the barrel with skill level now and more people exist that are better at the game and matched with me, yet overall, it‚Äôs a huge difference to the first 6 months or so I had at the game.

I won‚Äôt discount people who say they have a horrible time finding a match, everyone‚Äôs connection story and luck will be different, but for me I haven‚Äôt had head-banging problems in a while.

DLC: I paid for all the passes (not including Ultimate), though the first season pass was on sale when I bought it with the game. Disclosure done, I think they‚Äôre all okay. I always have at least one DLC character on my team, if not two. I can‚Äôt say on what average tier they fall into, not knowledgeable enough on all of them or fighting games, but I can say that none really feel same-y to me, and that‚Äôs what I care about when putting extra money on something. Some have similar moves ‚Äì which is likely to happen with several variety of Saiyans including Goku, Vegeta, Broly and fusions ‚Äì yet they‚Äôre all mixed up in ways where none feel like they have the same exact play style.

Unless you feel it‚Äôs worth the investment, I‚Äôll look up videos on characters you‚Äôre interested in buying or just go for characters you like, no harm in that. I wouldn‚Äôt buy the newest season 3 pass with only [i]hopes[/i] that your favorite character will make it in. Wait until they are confirmed at least if that‚Äôs the only character you‚Äôre interested in.

UPDATE: My complaints about fuzzies and snapbacks have been resolved, I will leave them in the review anyhow but the updates to this game have treated it very well. Everything else is true, from the positive to the negative (non stop aggro wins against all). Still loving this game.


This is probably one of the best intro to fighting games you can get. The gameplay itself is great, beautiful and a lot to learn and they way auto combos are implemented lets casuals have their fun and let them dive deeper into the game. The attention to detail for the animations in this game are truly nuts and the characters in this will probably be the best they will ever look in any way. Yes, it most certainly does look better than the anime.

For people already into fighting games, this one is solid but not too deep. You aren't going to see many demanding execution heavy skills in the game but it doesn't detract from the gameplay. About 50% of the cast plays "the same" but that is just in combo structure. Normals, specials and such are all unique. The game rewards (slightly) mindless aggression over good neutral, and the lack of push block makes the aggression worse since once they are in they can stay in pretty easily. Also, to add to that, there are very little reversals in this game as well (That is if you don't want to burn meter). Also, once you get to higher levels you will see Snap Back abuse , which basically puts you in a 50/50 in the corner every single time forcing you to guess on what the mix will be with the only counter play being to spark which is a one time use. This also negates tall characters due to "fuzzies" (for example Broly, Cell, A16, basically anyone taller than Goku). Some people may like this sort of frantic gameplay but just for fair warning its probably the number one thing I hate about this game.

How I may have  kinda tore into this game a bit it doesn't take away from a single thing about me loving it. Its very satisfying to play fast, learn new tricks and it look stunning while doing it. If you love Dragon Ball and ever wanted to get your toes wet in a fighting game start here. I am sure you won't regret it.

And oh yeah, don't get this for single player content. All fully voiced (ENG/JP) but very boring . They could of added fun traits to fights like the games of the past (draining health, max ki all the time ect) but nope. Just some slight beefier stats and beat the crap out of sub par AI.

This fighting game just shows how low the bar has come for fighting games. Most of the characters play the same from each other, there's nothing really special about the game, it's vastly unbalanced, some characters are just clearly better than others, overall the game is a joke though. There's little that's impressive about it and it's just a combo based piece of trash.

The mixup game is the same, no matter who you play, the game always plays out the same, almost every character is the same thing, there's really no unique qualities about this fighting game. It's just a cash grab because it's a "real" fighting game made by Arc System Works despite the fact that the company has only focused on simplifying even their most complex games so drastically, they're not complex anymore. Basically, the bar was set very, very low for this game. So if you want a mediocre fighting game where almost everyone plays the same and there's very mild difference in how the game plays out, you've come to the right game.

After playing this game for 116 hours I discovered that this game is COVID-19 level of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  Even if this game was one dollar don't purchase it, because once you are done playing it you will be filled with regret in your soul that you even spent a minute wasting your valuable time.  

At first, you see the youtubers playing it, doing cool combos and your friends praising the game, fuck them.  

The game will seem fun at first to you but then realize you are playing against the same 3 op DLC characters that can hit you even if your blocking.  Oh yeah and blocking, forget about it, the net code of the game makes it so even if your blocking they can get through. So you get hit once and get to watch helplessly as your character flies around the screen until they are bloody dead.  Want to try an attack, well even if you put the command perfectly in your controller it will wiff and do an attack that leaves you wide open.

Match start > try to attack > game thinks you want to dragon rush > get hit once > comboed for 80 seconds = lose (over and over)

Please value your time, your money, and most importantly yourself.  As a Christain, I cannot recommend this game to my brothers. I pray for you to stay safe during these times. Thank you

[b]Summary:[/b] Buy it if you're a Dragon Ball fan and willing to put in several hours of practice. This blows every other Dragon Ball Z game out of the water. However, this game has less content than other fighters, so I must recommend getting this on sale.

[b]Notes:[/b] The roster size is a popular point of contention (24 chars + 14 DLC chars). Since this roster doesn't seem particularly small or big it's neither a pro or a con. 

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Treats license well, several references from source material
- Great soundtrack, funny English dub, and decent Japanese dub
- Character unlocks (instead of microtransactions)
- Simple, deep mechanics (though not unique)
- Story mode cut-scenes are ok
- Easy to learn for a fighter
- Runs surprisingly well
- Great Visuals

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Depending on what gamepad you have, you might end up dropping combos regardless of skill, even when using dpad to move.
- Strange lobby system that complicates playing with friends, occasional server disconnects, and outdated delay based netcode
- Weak Single Player: Story mode is padded with repetitive fights between cut-scenes, increasing the time it takes to unlock one of the chars. In addition, there's a lack of standard arcade endings. Devalues this game slightly below the full $60 for general audiences, especially with titles like mortal kombat or injustice in the market.

[b]Rating: 7/10[/b]

I just like going into practice and labbing as of recent, to be honest, but since we're in Season 3 and this is one of my favorite games, I guess I'm due for a review.
The visuals in this game are INCREDIBLE, personally I think this is gonna be the pinnacle DB game visually and ArcSys Work's magnum opus for a while (personally I like it more than GBF and GGS).
3v3 Tag Vs. styled gameplay is always a welcome.
Matches with friends are a blast, playing online matchmaking is a mixed bag because of netcode, I'll touch on that later.
The gameplay itself in the game is also fun, a much needed change in DB games, having an actual high level fighter is phenomenal.
The changes added in Season 3 really improved the game for the better, it's much more fresh now.
Incredibly fun to lab in this game, and finding ToD's is satisfying.
Mods are fun too, sucks that you can't play online unless someone else has mods enabled too.
Only downside is online is can be bad, netcode really isn't that great, bad even at some points.
Best DB game? Arguably.
My favorite DB game? Absolutely.
Cooler and DBS Broly are also in this game so automatic 10/10.

The gameplay is pretty good, but what's more important is the number of Gokus. 

If you look at the math, there's actually many more Gokus in this game than one might expect. Of course, we've got the three main Gokus, but there's also Vegito, who is 0.5 Gokus due to being a fusion with Vegeta. 

Then, we have Gohan, who is half Goku and half Chi-Chi, making him also 0.5 Gokus, so since we have two of him, this brings our current total to 4.5 Gokus. 

We've also got Gotenks. Gotenks is 0.25 Gokus, because he is both a child and a fusion. Now our total is 4.75.

There's also Goku Black. While he has the mind of Zamasu, his body is 100% Goku, making him count as one Goku nonetheless. Fused Zamasu is 50% Goku Black, making him also 0.5 Gokus.

Next, Bardock. Goku is 50% Bardock, which in turn means that Bardock is 200% Goku, making him two whole Gokus. This brings our total to 8.25 Gokus.

Perfect Cell and Android 21 are kinda weird, but according to a commenter Perfect Cell is 0.166 Gokus, and Android 21 is 0.151 Gokus, which brings us to a total of 8.567 Gokus.

With the FighterZ Pass 2 giving us GT Goku and Gogeta, we now have another one and a half Gokus, but the new pass also brings us the Great Saiyaman as part of Videl's moveset, which is another half Goku, bringing the current total number of Gokus to 10.567.

And with FighterZ Pass 3 we will be given yet another Goku, this time in his Ultra Instinct form, which will bring the total to 11.567.

Good game. Terrible online netcode. Buy for the single player or to play with nearby friends. Online is a rage-inducing experience due to the outdated delay-based netcode. Pretty much any game in the west uses some form of rollback netcode, which is why you get rubberbanding in FPS games. Japanese fighting games are the only games that refuse to update their games. Without it though, you basically freeze for half a second every few seconds unless your connection is perfect. Don't buy if you plan on mostly playing online. Especially don't buy if you're going to play on WiFi or if you have a mediocre connection. WiFi warriors are especially frowned upon because you're just going to ruin the match for everyone. It's a shame, the rest of the game is pretty good. The netcode is garbage.

Positives
This is the Dragonbal Fighting game we always wanted. It's as if the two favourite things from my teens came together, Dragonball and Marvel Vs Capcom 2. This game is insanley balanced for what it is and a lot of thought has gone into the combat flow. Combos chain amazingly...and I'm not even considerably good at this game. The character interations and cutscenes are often hilarious insights to the individual characters and how they feel about eachother. Also Android 21 is a good addition to the cast.

Negatives.
The actual plot of the story mode is trash. It's just drivel and everything in it is an excuse to make fights like Yamcha vs Cell an even match. I can't hate them for trying though.

WARNING FANRANT...
There IS a great selection of characters. But What would be great is if they gave certain characters some love. Tien, Although actually has an alright move set has kind of been crapped on (again) He has probably introduced more signiture movesto the series than most individual characters. Why is is one of the only characters that DON'T have the Solar flare?? He invented it! Why does Krillin get mor use out of the multiform...When Tien ALSO invented it! Tien can grow more limbs, did you know that? No? Only watched super? Only watched Z? Watch Dragonball, He has so much more to give...and don't get me started on his finisher. Well, okay, if you insist!!! Why is Ciaotsu killing himself and Tien having a three secon breakdown his ULTIMATE attack??? Even more so, once you have used ityou don't have a finished for him anymore! Waste of a great character. I love Yamcha...but why doesn even HE have better moves than Tien?

Could do with some more obscure characters rather than more versions of the same Saiyans.
Where's Roshi? Wheres Yajirobe? Chi Chi? (More female characters, please! There isn't many in Dragonball, but from what there is please put them in!) Mercenary Tao? Zarbon? Dodoria? Raditz? Ciaotsu would be fun to play as. Personal gripe, but if Krillin can go toe to toe with Janemba (Who isn't even canon either) then I don't see any reason not to include old school characters.
END OF FAN RANT

One last negative...there really isn't a scaling system in place. Every time i play someone online, 9/10 they are insanley good. Like, they have played this game a lot and there is no hope in hell of beating them. So I avoid the online mode like the plague, that place is on another level.

Overall incredible fighter. There is a lot of fan fluff, but when you are in the actual arena, ANYONE that's a fan of a brawler WILL enjoy this game.

Keeping this brief cuz I got off-track last time and idc if people want to bicker over specific bullet-points

Pros: 
-Great presentation
-Beginner-friendly, while still complex
-Dragon Ball fanservice extraordinaire
-Great overall game feel
[spoiler]
(Edit: to clarify, these Pros include things like "The story mode has great cutscenes" [strike]or "Matches feel great to play"[/strike] and as you can see by my playtime, they are very wholly and substantially good parts of the experience-- I'm not trying to downplay them with a small list but the cons absolutely get in my way, check my comment for details)
[/spoiler]

Cons:
-ABYSMAL netcode
-Terrible online infrastructure
-Very low playerbase and available matches any time other than patch-day because there's no crossplay
-Lacking and unengaging single-player content
-Awful AI
-Devs seemingly ignoring obvious features to add, like local (or even local/online mixed) Party Match, which is already available on the Switch version, mixed team sizes outside of Local Battle Vs, or even things like Story Mode 'Skills' in versus for example
-Unappealing DLC pricing and release schedules
-Long-standing balance issues that respected the nature of fighting game meta at first, but now just come across as extremely frustrating and disconcerting.  Our last balance patch was in March. It's now mid-October.  Certain characters have been awful since release, while others (mostly DLC) have been great since release.  GT Goku in particular, who released in May, has been the subject of serious talks for getting banned in-tournament, which obviously doesn't apply to modes like ranked.  Fun, right?
-Below 0 mod support, risking players to get banned/dropped from matches for undetermined amounts of time for even offline-only use of custom community content.  Even reinstalls and firewall settings (which are both recommended with mods) sometimes can't avoid you getting a stained account for no good reason. 

Currently, I don't recommend the game to new players, but it wouldn't take much for me to change that. 
The basic grind would be FAR more enjoyable and much more worth it with just a few things fixed at the top of my priority list; 
1- Rollback netcode (GGPO's SDK and license are free now, there is no excuse)
2- Crossplay, to offset low playercounts for PC.  Again, not too hard to do for any company in 2019 that isn't exceedingly stuck-up and willingly ignorant.
3- Easier access to modes and features already in the game, like Party Match and variable team size, so sessions with friends/randoms aren't prone to getting super boring and barebones-feeling

This game is one of the best fighting games to get into if you're new to the FGC. It starts out easy enough and many of the combos transfer to most of the cast. All the fighters are beautifully animated and similar enough control wise that it's not daunting to learn a team of 3. And at a high level I find this to be one of the most enjoyable fighting games to watch.  

My only issue with it is constant crashes. It's not enough to ruin the experience for me but definitely something to be aware of when getting into the game. if you have the option get it on PS4, otherwise the crashing is a nuisance but within 2 or 3 restarts I can usually get in.

Decide I'd make this review now at Season 3. The game has reach a new high this season. Whereas previous seasons of this game have had a meta defining character or team build ("shell", if you will), with the most recent update of the game it has allowed previous 'dead' characters to rise again or for the first time.

The game still has a steep learning curve if you wish to play the game at a high level, however, with the now diverse characters at your disposal, team building has never been more fun.

Story mode is a chore though.

This game is great, I have it on my Nintendo Switch and that is the primary place I play it just for the sheer convenience of playing around the house of on a hotspot on the go. But I originally had it on PC and that is really the best experience with a good internet connection. The gameplay is superb with easy to learn combo mechanics for beginners which means you can feel like a badass right out of the gate, but as you master a diverse and balanced cast of characters, the game gives you plenty of combos to learn and strategies to master. The 3 fighter system works great and plays a massive role in online play where your character loadout can make or break you. With Z assists becoming its own massive part in learning the combat system, each character has a special assist move that can be anything from a hard knockdown, a power blast, or a buff that helps your current character. But the real treasure in this game is the art style, its basically if you upgraded an anime into 3d and it totally works, the 3d models look exactly what your mind would render when you think "hey what does 3d Goku look like", and this takes the special moves to a whole new level as they are directly inspired by manga panels and feel super authentic. The only gripe I have with the game is the story, its kinda booty and I can never finish it because I would rather be playing online.

Great game, easy to pick up, easy to learn and with Season 3 all characters have a chance of being good. The DLC Is always good, well made characters (Except 17 and Jiren OOF) And it looks BEAUTIFUL on PC, you can mod the game (offline) and just enjoy it at any pace you want. 

I am top 100 in the UK on the leaderboard and I find matches almost instantly, the player base is thriving (Except for like 5am on a Sunday) And the game is just overall amazing to get into.

Ignore the idiots calling the netcode bad, they clearly play on a laptop on wifi, against people from my own region I get steady 1-2, I play with someone from the US, East Coast and I only get 5 frames of delay (Which honestly, ain't even that much. It's usually a steady 4 anyways)

The only annoying thing is every time there's an update, Fatal Errors seem to be abundant but that just stops after a few days.

The auto combo system is forgiving for newer players, but punishable by advanced players. So while using the auto combo system for a while is good as you come to grips with the game it eventually makes you want to learn more advanced combos as you progress.

so as someone that plays fighting games quite a lot, i'm going to review this game in my own biased way. 

this game is not an eyesore by any means. the graphics are colorful, bombastic, and services the game play very well
the music is pretty forgettable honestly. generic rock tracks can be kind of fun the first listen through, but i sort of wish Budokai 3's soundtrack was used more in recent games. 

the fighting in this fighting game is pretty fun honestly. if you don't play 2d fighters like i mostly do you'll find yourself mashing quite a lot, and this ultimately doesn't help because Fighterz rewards your opponents if you make one simple mistake. 

if you take the time to get your ass beat, you can learn from it and have a genuinely good time. i personally have been enjoying the characters of Hit and Frieza quite a lot, because they're good zoners with not bad up close game either. 
the new season 3 changes are awesome. being able to change your assists is huge, because it means people will actually use krillin for his assists now. 
all kidding aside, there are a few problems i do have

for starters, some characters have crouching attacks that are pretty indistinguishable from standing attacks, like DBS Broly and Cooler, and sometimes crouch blocking doesn't even work in DBS Broly's case. the stomp attack generally hits low, but sometimes you just get hit by it even if you block correctly. 

the online can be very frustrating. sometimes it'll run buttery smooth which is great, but then there will be matches that feel like they're playing in slo-motion.

i'm giving this a big recommend, because people that like fighting games will enjoy the Guilty Gear feel of this game, and even more so if they like Dragon Ball.

This game's core mechanics are absolutly fantastic, it borrows and improves on the 3v3 system used in the marvel vs capcom games (thats why this game is at evo 2018 and not mvcu xd) dispite having an auto combo system it still rewards veteran fighting game players by making the auto combos do much less damage than pulling those combos off manualy. even as someone who knows nothing about dragonball there is a ton of fun to be had with this game,the issue with the game so far is that the servers at the moment are complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• but there is still a metric ton of offline content if the servers are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the bed. everything you would expect from a modern fighting game is here, story mode, arcade, practice mode, are here all while looking absolutly stunning. the graphics in this game are as close as you are going to get to the tv show without the artists that work on the show animating the game by hand it is stunning to say the least. with all that being said im gona give this game a solid 8.5/10 when the servers improve this game will be a must buy for any fighting game fan or fan of dragonball

180 hours and 2 years later this game still holds up as one of if not the best fighting games of all time. the dlc improved the roster a ton and dispite how unbalanced gt goku was and still is, all of the dlc fighers were welcome additions and with the addition of new assists for every character, team diversity is at an all time high. the server problems mentioned in my old review have been completely fixed although the game dose crash much more frequently now. my final review for this game is an easy 10/10 but when im fighting gt goku or teen gohan that score goes down to a 1/10 garbage doo doo trash game

The perfect Dragon Ball game for true fans. While most anime games out there look kind of whack, this game looks even better than the show. The attention to detail in every single scene, for every single character is insane and pure fan service. The only negative is that it doesn't have the original soundtrack from the show.

EDIT: With the Season 3 update the game got SO MUCH better and it was awesome before. I can't stop playing because I'm enjoying it so much. They fixed all of the games small issues.

Good stuffs:
-Battle system is very enjoyable and flashy as befits Dragon Ball style
-You don't have to learn a whole bunch of complicated directional button combinations that fighting games usually have
-Very good anime style graphics just like in Storm series instead of the weird 3d models like in Jump Force (this is just my personal preference tho)
-Performance is good and consistent. No random frame drops, stutters or crashes throughout my entire playthrough

Bad stuffs:
-Story mode, both gameplay-wise and plot-wise
-Suffers from the greeDLC-syndrome like pretty much most fighting games these recent years and its also way overpriced imo

I recommend this game for the amount of fun it can give but would recommend you buying this only on super sale especially if you want to get all the "passes" as well.

Even though I kinda played other FGs on a really casual level, Dragon Ball FighterZ is the first FG that i decided to take seriously. So as an introduction to this genre, it's a great place to start.

You can basically do the same BnB with every character. However, once you start experimenting, and start using assists, etc. It can become quite fun. This new season has added a new layer of complexity to the game but without making it feel too bloated. 

Easy inputs, cool supers, and actually, a pretty well balanced roster.

Unfortunately, the game suffers from quite a few things. A really bad, long, and tedious story mode. Delay-based netcode, some mechanics like Super Dash or the built-in auto correction in auto combos are plain stupid and broken. But once you get past that, it's an incredibly fun game that I will keep playing, especially with Season 3 going at full throttle.

Arc System Works' best game, in my opinion, and I'm not saying that lightly. Gorgeous, true to the show graphics with flair and a real feel of impact with every hit. Tight controls that, while easy to understand, lend to seriously skill based gameplay that punishes mistakes hard and rewards great play. A soundtrack that is some of the best music in fighting games. Fairly priced DLC with great characters that refresh the game every few months with new play styles and a shifted meta. Easily one of the best fighting games on the market currently, dare I say, even possibly the best one.

A fun and very accessible fighting game, that still manages to have a lot of skill expression at the upper tiers.

Pros:
-The game allows for beginners to jump right in with only quarter-circle motions for special moves and supers.  Auto-combos are good enough on their own for beginners, but learning how to properly extend combos is required as you climb the ladder.

-The game looks really good, with flashy special moves, giant explosions, and attacks sending opponents flying.

-The latest patch for Season 3 brought a load of improvements.  The standouts include the ability to choose what attack your assists perform when you call them, and new changes around the Dragon Rush (the game's un-blockable attack common to all characters) mechanic making them easier to land.  The UI was also changed and a better (but still incomplete) training mode.

-Overall a good roster of characters (though there are a lot of Goku characters) that play differently enough to have distinct strategies and match-ups, but similar enough that picking up a new character doesn't take very long.

-The Dramatic and Destructive Finish moves are still not old 150 hours in.  Some of the level 3 super moves... might be a bit long to be happening mid-match.  They still look really cool, though.  I honestly feel like I'm watching an anime while playing this game.

Cons: 
-The single-player content is not very good.  While this is common for the genre, ArcSys usually makes games with loads of interesting content for those of us who don't necessarily want to bash our skulls against the ranked ladder.  The story mode is the biggest offender here.  The plot is boring and the gameplay consists of trivial fights against AI opponents that just stand there and let you beat them up.  In the Blazblue series, ArcSys seemed to understand that there need not be 80 - 90 fights in a single story route.  Here, they kind of went off the deep end...  All in all it took me about 6 - 7 hours to finish.

-The training mode is not very good for teaching anything except for the absolute basics of the game.  The newest patch does improve training mode, which is nice, but still your best bet is to take to YouTube and find some of the tutorials posted there.  For instance, in the Combo Challenge mode the final combo for Super Saiyan Goku is actually a very basic combo that most of the characters in the game can do.  The thing is, this combo does not feature in any of the other character's Combo Challenge so I figured it was character specific.  Later on I noticed other players performing the combo with other characters at which point I realized I was missing out on a lot of damage doing Auto-combos or down + heavy launchers instead.

All-in-all, this is a great anime fighting game that has a good trade-off for the hardcore audience vs. the filthy casuals like me.  It's the first fighting game in years that I've actually wanted to make an effort to learn some, and enjoy watching others play.

This is definitely one of the best, if not my favorite, fighting games I've played in a while. Arc System Works makes some top quality anime Fighting games like the recent Granblue Fantasy Versus, Guilty Gear, Under Night In-Birth, and BlazBlue. They do an amazing job at mimicking the Dragon Ball/Akira Toriyama style. Every single animation in this game was taken into account and they all look stunning. All of the characters play really well and feel amazing to control. Finding teams that synergize with each other is also nice thing because it makes you experiment with each of the unique characters and their play styles. The one side that this games falls a little short on is the campaign. It plays almost like the Dragon Ball Z: Budokai 2 story mode but at the same time a little different. While I will say that the cutscenes, alone, are fun to watch and seeing how everyone interacts with each other in the story is also nice, I just don't think it's something you NEED to play in this game, unless you're going for the Android 21 unlock. Other than the story this game is outstanding in the fighting game world and is must play if you are a fan of Dragon Ball, MvC, or Fighting games in general. Everything is filled with eye-candy here and I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone into Fighting games.

Overall Score : 9.5/10

After pouring hours into the closed and open beta on PS4 then more into the full release on PC, Switch and PS4, I find it hard to believe why people love this game so much. 

I mean, I CAN actually see why, but at the same time I really don't.

Pros:
+ Amazing, hand-drawn, effort-filled animations, art and graphics. Probably one of the biggest eye candy I've ever seen in any game
+ Controls and mechanics are optimized for controller
+ Character interactions, dramatic introductions and finishers, alongside character cast and moveset, are very faithful to Dragon Ball Z/Super and what makes the franchise loved.

Cons:
- Optimization broken beyond belief: One lag spike destroys connection with controller entirely, occasional lag spikes with an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 with fan boosting and laptop coolpad
- Bad netcode (but not SFV, Smash Bros Ultimate levels of piss-poor)
- Lack of stages
- Balancing: lack of updates (as to one of the reasons why GT Goku is piss-broken) and overly aggro-favored gameplay ruins the balancing factor of this game
- Gameplay itself reward too much aggro-gameplay; little to no defensive options. 
- No variety in assists; Yes, you can extend combos or use them for neutral but assists consist of one attack only, which either boosts or detriments a character badly. Thank f**k they're adding assist variants. 
- Abyssmally boring story mode; nonexistent writing and piss-poor AI 

Personal Grudge (that does not affect my ranking of the game as much as my views on the game):
- The DLC: The fact that Base Goku and Vegeta are DLC and their SSJ1 forms aren't, but even moreso the DLC pool lacking in ideas to the point where we need more Goku variants as DLC than in base game

There are factors I like about this game but many more that I suggest against buying this game. Wait for a sale. At least the community is alive, and even so that's LITERALLY because this game is Dragon Ball and everyone loves to kiss aggro-ass.

Most nutty, best looking, fastest paced fighting game out there. Literally stunning visuals and gameplay is just complex enough for it not to be too hard to get into, but deep and rewarding to really learn and experiment with your team.

A tough game at first, this game requires you to put time into it if you wanna win games online. Story mode is the worst part of the game, around the end it's fighting the same bots over and over again but the interactions of the main cast make up for that short coming. Though the story does help you learn how the game works, after that it's up to you on what you do next. With all the new updates and characters on the way, I can't recommend a better time to get this game, once you get good enough at the game you get an adrenaline rush and it just pushes you to keep getting better. Best part is if your not sure if you wanna get the game just see if any of your friends have it and ask to use steam's remote play feature so you can play with friends online who don't even own the game!

I have well over 1000 matches total across Xbox One, PS4 and PC. And I just want to get this out there:

This game is insanely well made, it's crazy. All characters are viable, obviously, some are better than others, but that's normal.

On top of all characters being viable, they are gonna get even more viable on February 26th, which is when the first Season 3 Patch releases and will introduce a new mechanic called "Z Assist Select." This mechanic will allow you to choose from 3 Assists when you pick a character, so characters that weren't being chosen that much due to not having a good/best assist will now have time to shine. I too, am guilty of this as my most played character is Goku(Super Saiyan) due to the fact that his beam assist, "Kamehameha," is the most versatile assist out there. Now I don't have to choose Goku(Super Saiyan) for his Beam Assist because other characters will also get beam assists/better assists.

This game is also visually stunning, in terms of graphics and the attention to detail in a character's moveset. I don't just mean "Goku did a Kamehameha in the show, so he has it in the game." or "Krillin did Solar Flare in the show, so he has it in the game." I mean everything from their Supers to their normal attacks (Light, Medium, Heavy, Special, etc.) If you truly want to see just how much effort they put into this game, [url=https://www.youtube.com/user/IKevinX] check out IKevenX's channel to see it for yourself. [/url] He takes stuff from the show and manga to show you just how much effort and references the devs put into the game.

One last thing, the game's balance is gonna be as balanced as ever on February 26th, with Kefla(Super Saiyan 2) dropping on February 28th and Goku(Ultra Instinct) dropping during Spring this year. Please pick up this masterpiece!
