Astonishing fighting game

The long short; It's Marvel v Capcom DBZ edition

Well balanced and fast paced, DBFZ presents a 3v3 fighter with plenty of avenues for player expression through the unique fist/ki fighting style and eclectic cast that has made the franchise famous. The cast consists of characters primarily from DragonBall-Z and DragonBall Super, offering a wide variety of move-sets to stylize your beatdown while maintaining enough common threads that make experimenting with other characters accessible and exciting when you've found your rhythm. 
That said, players should spend a good amount of time practicing combos in the practice room, character combo challenges, arcade (PvE), and testing their muscle online as the campaign does not enforce advanced fighting tactics and because of its length can become a repetitive mindless monster mash. The game could continue to introduce advanced tactics to widen the breadth of the player's five-knuckle vocabulary, but leaves a good handful of that duty to the player themselves. Much of the creativity and fun of the game can be lost through mindless mashing repetition, and many online battles can be lost just the same. 
Normally this wouldn't be a downside as it allows new fighters to build familiarity and confidence, but the campaign is just too drawn out to allow so much repetition without pushing the player forward in skill. Frieza even complains about the repetitiveness during the campaign!
DragonBall FighterZ is a great game if you're even a little bit of a fan of DBZ; it offers a beautiful presentation and faithful recreation of many characters and moments from the Z series, on top of being a tense fighter. The campaign is fun and will tickle many nostalgia nerves but feels a bit long for what it gives you in personal personnel punching progress.
FighterZ is the best fighting game with the DragonBall tag on it since planet Vegeta was death-starred to dust and is itself a fun frolic with apt depth for fighter enthusiasts. Jump in, pierce the heavens, and fly away!!

Fantastic game, most fun I've had with a fighter in years. It's similar in style to Marvel vs Capcom 3, but IMO, a better game. For Dragonball fans, this game plays like a love letter, very true to the source material and tons of fan service. For fighting game fans, there are deep mechanics and a ton to master. The battles are flashy, fast, tactical and insanely fun. The lobby system could be better, I would have preferred a traditional menu based matchmaking, but overall, they got so much right with this game.

Recommended to DBZ and fighting game fans, 9.5/10.

An extremely fast paced fighting game filled with adrenaline pumping do or die moments. Decent story mode that helps as a tutorial for the basics. Arcade is good too, but the real fun starts when fighting against other players. Super fun, whether you're winning or losing. Big learning curve which also means it's very satisfying when the training you've done pays off. Very good online servers with little ping, on average (for me) 2-5 frame delay on inputs so it's nearly unnoticeable. The supers and specials are cool and fun to use.

Try not to spam super dash to close the gap all the time since it's easily beaten by a 2h or dp leaving your opponent a big opportunity to punish you. (You're still safe to block If you hit their block with your dash.)
Reflect comes out frame 1.

I recommend you pirate this game, it's a good fighting game.
However, it doesn't run on a lot of computers - and it needs to be run online at least once to be able to access offline.
As such, you don't really own this game, Denuvo and EasyAntiCheat own it.
I couldn't get it to run on my big rig, only on some old laptop running window 10 (and slowly, at that) - running it on that computer did not allow me to run it offline on my big rig, so essentially you pay for nothing. I say this because paying for the game on steam will not get you any sort of customer support - although pirating it will !

I recommend you do not buy 170$ worth of DLC characters because that is a similarly scummy business practice you shouldn't encourage and rather just pirate this game, so you can play it freely with your buddies. What's more, you'll be reassured in knowing that pirating it means it will never stop working !

Whereas this game's fanbase is a cancer, this is still an excellent ghame. Try not to listen to the people calling it overrated garbage. The small but vocal amount of people calling the the game overrated were told by others that it was the best game ever made, and when it did not meet those expectations, they justifiably thought it was overrated. This may be the best game ever to many, but not all. No matter what however, calling the game simply 'bad' instead of 'not perfect' or 'not my thing' would be an outright lie. Gameplay is tight and very creative, playing into the plot perfectly. I will not reveal any spoilers about this game since it is best to go in completely blind. If you are even somewhat interested in the genre or intrigued by the screenshots, buy this game. You will not regret it.

Otherwise there are a variety of characters that can suit many player's playstyles whether you like fast reaction characters or methodical timing or just throwing people into the air and dunking them into the ground  or just simply want to look badass. There are characters for everyone. Definitely recommend giving it a try

Although this game has some pretty fun gameplay, I like the combat. The menus, lobbys and matchmaking are literal garbage.
I don't understand how they could have made so many mistakes regarding pretty much everything, the DBZ games used to be so good on PS2 back in the day.
To sum up some of the problems I have with this game: 
- it takes minutes to launch
- it takes minutes to connect to online services
- servers are split into regions/countries
- team editing is such a nuisance, why can't we just pick characters/maps like in tekken
- a lot of characters are behind a paywall even when the base game is 60‚Ç¨
- you have to create a ring match to play with friends, you can't just create a lobby, pick a character and play
- online matchmaking takes a long while and when you finally get to play, the connection is usually very bad although you selected the best possible settings
- there are so many characters you can't even play, for example: no ginyu force (except for cpt ginyu), no transformations, no android 17, chaozu, goten, kid trunks, gero, dabura, goku/vegeta fusions, whis, videl,  supreme kai, any universe 6 character, roshi, jaco...
- even exiting the game takes too many steps, when in story mode you have to go trough more than 3 menus to quit
- no character creation
- only xbox controls, no playstation or other devices
- lack of story mode, you can complete it in less than half a day
- no co-op or tenkaichi tournament style PVP/PVE matches with friends

only buy it if it's on sale for less than 15‚Ç¨, it's not worth more than that

One of the best fighting games i've ever played. I've never been into the 3v3/marvel style fighter but for some reason this one just clicks. The graphics are beautiful, and honestly it looks better than the actual anime of Dragon Ball Super. The gameplay is pretty straightforward and the inputs for special moves aren't super complicated like older fighting games. That means you're not doing a bunch of half or full circle directional moves, it's all quarter circle, which is pretty simple. It let's you focus on your tactics rather than mastering frustrating gamepad combinations. The roster is pretty great, sure there are like 5 different Gokus, but it's DRAGON BALL. Each character feels pretty unique and i honestly wouldn't mind if they did a third season of DLC. I'd buy it.

The campaign leaves a little to be desired, mainly because you're fighting a bunch of clone/zombies of the main cast. But aside from that, it's done pretty well. Truly the best Dragon Ball game i've ever played.

This was my first fighting game I ever played, and it has been great fun. For me, it was the perfect fighting game to start with.  Even if you aren't familiar with the controls, you can do cool stuff- the basic combos include neat attacks and special abilities, and you only need to mash one button to continue the combo. As my brother and I played more, we learned more advanced tactics, and found new ways to deal damage to each other, doing special attacks that would surprise our opponent, or just finding an easy way to add moves onto the basic combos. Eventually, we started doing more advanced combos, and now we play at a level of skill that I would have thought impossible when we started.

Easily the best DBZ game ever made, of any genre. It actually takes its source material and improves on its visuals whilst still maintaining the spirit of the show.

Not only does it impress visually but it's also a very deeply competitive game, just check Youtube and watch EVO videos and you'll see how serious this game can get. Fortunately there are still mechanics in the game that make it very satisfying even for the most casual of players.

If you love DBZ, you need this game.

The best fighting game in the past 15 years fpr both skilled veteran fighting game players and casuals alike. The best team fighting game ever made. The best animation in a fighting game ever made. The attention to detail of the individual characters from the show and incorporating that into a fluid game play for each individual fighter while also still having universal standard combos that are unique yet the same inputs for each character. Team setup is highly important and if you're a veteran fighting game fan there are some really insane combos (ToD's) that require high skill and very precise input and mechanical execution so the skill ceiling is high. This does not mean the game isn't also casual friendly with a big story mode that has two difficulties and a very fun arcade mode.

If you like fighting games or DBZ this game is for you. This is the only fighting game i've played outside of smash and I suck honestly compared to anyone I fight online yet I really enjoy the offline experience and keep playing to get better scores on the arcade modes and story. So like I said: it is highly casual friendly yet also has an incredibly high skill ceiling. Absolute perfection. I hope this game gets a sequel It's amazing. 

There's also really cool things in the game like a dramatic opening or finish like if you fight teen gohan vs cell there's a special intro and kill cutscene specifically for that encounter. There are also many more just like that. Like I said the attention to detail and the dedication to replicate the characters moves from the anime is just absolutely 10/10 in every way imaginable.

This version of the game is absolute utter garbage. It crashes constantly, without warning, without messages, and without any sort of fix in sight for me to apply. Not enough? How about when it does run for long enough to get a match it will just disconnect, for no reason, then disconnect from the lobby, so if you wanna try to play again you gotta rejoin the lobby, THEN get another match search going, THEN find a match, THEN M A Y B E you'll be able to finish the match. It doesn't matter if your opponent has a green connection with decent delay and fluidity going, you WILL disconnect and there's absolutely nothing you can do about it. It just baffles me that you HAVE to be inside a lobby just to look for a match. Why don't I get a choice to just do it from a menu? Life would be so much god damn easier then!! But no, aesthetic goes first, so you're gonna spend 95% trying to get into a match, and the rest you'll spend in unfinished online matches. Ten outta fucking ten, thank you so much for ruining the perfect DBZ fighting game.

I'm gonna be honest; I'm not really into most fighting games. Most just plunge you right into it, have complicated combos and complex techs that you HAVE to learn all by yourself if you wanna be considered in any way good. 

In this game, while the combos and techs do exist, there's a pretty smooth learning curve. Each individual attack is pretty unique, and if you don't want to waste hours learning complicated combos, there's a simple but rewarding auto-combo system (which doesn't take away from players who DO the complicated combos). It does it's job well, and actually makes me want to learn more to become better and better.

I haven't even mentioned the fact this is a Dragon Ball game yet. While I haven't watched the series in ages, this game's visuals, which look exactly like they were ripped straight from the anime, awoke the child inside of me. Every character and the way they interact feels spot-on.

However, I do think DLC is kinda overpriced... And I wouldn't say it's worth buying this game at full price. It's best if you can get it at some sale. And personally, I would avoid the Ultimate Edition--FighterZ edition gives you the same DLC Characters, and a Music and Commentator Pack just doesn't sound worth the extra money.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a very solid team combat fighting game. Let's find out why.

Pros:
[b]1. [/b]Easy to learn combo system, with an amazingly freeform combo game, in which any normal move (and most special moves) can be combo'd into pretty much anything, provided you can chain it together. Not to mention, autocombos allow bacically anyone to get at least something done if they don't mash buttons. Even more, Dynamic! autocombos allow for even the worst fighters to obtain Dragon Balls and deal loads of damage, if they can land them.
[b]2:[/b] A rushdown heavy game makes every match feel blazing fast, and with Dragon Ball inspired characters, moves, and movement, every moment feels right at home in the manga.
[b]3:[/b] The variety of characters is phenomenal. Every series has at least some representation (besides the original Dragon Ball, but the majority of prominent DB characters recurred in at least DBZ).
[b]4:[/b] I already touched on this in passing, but the movement is phenomenal, everything from footsies to your air game feels like it has real weight to it, and with instant transmission and chasing available for every character, you can create a lot of confusion with just movement alone; that means that not only are you going to be conscious of and practice your movement, but you'll also gain advantages by conditioning your opponent with your movement options as well as your actual fighting.
[b]5:[/b] The game has a really low entry barrier and a ridiculously high skill ceiling, and a low entry barrier isn't something you get in most Arcsys games.

Cons
[b]1:[/b] DLC is expensive as hell (I mean, it [i]is[/i] an Arcsys game, but that doesn't make it better).
[b]2:[/b] The personalization options can feel a bit lacking at times, which doesn't usually matter in fighting games, but with the amount of unique outfits and accessories the cast of Dragon Ball have worn, it's hard not to feel stiffed with a lot of stuff, I mean, they have colours similar to Vageta's Badman outfit, or Kid Gohan's battle armour, but no actual appearances of the outfits, aside from lobby avatars, if the outfits get any.
[b]3:[/b] The story, while alright, just drags on for way too long, considering that at the end of the day, it's just a grind fest combined with a visual novel.
[b]4:[/b] GT Goku. The fact that I also main him doesn't make it better.

Overall, like I said, it's a great game 9.5-10/10

I dont usualy write reviews, but ive invested a lot of time into this game that isnt actually playing the game. Usually I avoid competetive games because people get real fucking sweaty when it comes to them but I figured people treated this game as more of a casual game instead. So onto my point, the game is not friendly to new comers. Wanna play casual to try and practice and get your bearings? most people playing casual will beat your fucking face in and you actually cant move. now you can argue this happens to all new players in fighting games, well im not neccassarily that new, I've played many fighting games as well as I've watched countless hours of guieds, pro players, tutorials, and gameplay of this game because I love dragon ball and i like fighting games. Ok so you cant play casual cuz people who are just bullies and want an easy match will push your fucking face in, thats fine, well what about ranked? that way you can face people who are evenly matched. NOPE, the word "evenly" is used losely here, and i mean VERY losely. My first game of ranked was vs someone with 50000 bp. how is that even fucking possible? (you get 500 bp for a loss and i think 1000 for a win) he is NO WHERE NEAR my skill level, he has played an outstanding amount more than me. okay maybe that was a bug and it wont happen again sense I lost i can only go against worse right? NOPE, an even HIGHER ranked playter fought me next. Ok Ok fine fine but why dont you just look at the move list and learn combos and etc so you can have at least some chance of not being combo'd into the cieling, NOPE the move list only tells you the most basic of basics, it tells you no special moves it doesnt define its words (like wtf rush means or what it does) OK OK youre just complaining because youre bad get good and go play the campaign and tutorial. my argument to that is, so in order to not be bullied online by sweaty players in casual and to not go against unfairly matched players in ranked i have to play against computers for god knows how long to learn how to play against... YOU GUESSED IT COMPUTERS. the computers dont play ANYTHING like the players. with players you have to predict and outplay and block etc etc. computer? you can just mash the same button and they die they wont ever block. and they just randomly drop combos....OK OK go do all of the training. tried that.... IT BUGGED OUT ON THE FIRST FUCKING TRAINING AND STOPPED WORKING. this is a 60 dollar game,,,,, with an INSANE amount of dlc characters (which everyone uses btw and they are significantly better than the characters that come with the game but i try not to play this side of the coin cuz crying p2w is a trigger mechanism for many of the people on the spectrum for this type of game) so why in the world would it EVER bug, letalone on the VERY FIRST TRAINING MISSION. inexcusable. and look maybe youre really good at fighting games. or maybe you dont care about pvp you only care about story, or maybe you boguht it on sale, well good im glad that the franchise can live on through people like you so they can create, hopefully, a better pvp fighting game (god dont get me started on pvp in xenoverse)

This is a team fighting game, so the battles have a very fast paced, balls to the wall kind of feel to it. In lieu of it being a team fighting game, the characters have more simplified moves-mostly just quarter circles back and forward- compared to to other more mainstream fighters like KOF or Street Fighter.
 It is also a very intuitive fighting game. There are a lot of systems that are very beginner friendly that can help a-lot such as autocombo's. The combo's themselves are also very easy to do with very forgiving timing, none of them require accurate one frame links to execute. There is a natural combo progression, from light to medium to heavy attacks, that most characters have to follow and can make learning cool looking combo's a breeze.
 However, there is also a more complicated side to find if you so wish. Plus the game is great looking. If you like games like Marvel vs Capcom 2 then you'll love this.
Definitely a good recommendation from me.

Super fun once you put the time in to get good enough to actually fight people, prioritizes offense to defense, which I like, and has a super nice art style with good graphics, making it super cool to see stuff from Dragon Ball recreated if you're a fan. It was also extremely easy to get into, I felt like I was able to start improving as soon as I started playing, while with other fighters I've kind of just felt stuck upon trying to get into it. Only downside I see is how annoying it is getting demolished by smurfs who do super long lasting dlc character combos that get super repetitive. Some matches just feel like I'm watching a 3 minute video of me getting my ass beat, but obviously as I get better at the game I'll be able to deal with them better, so I don't see it as a huge problem. Overall super good game, highly recommend, especially if you're a dragon ball fan.

If you're a huge Dragon Ball (OG, Z, GT & Super) fan you'll definitely enjoy this game. I've scrubbed most 2D fighters since 1992 (notable exceptions are Mortal Kombat and Melty Blood) and started going to both domestic and international tournaments, beginning with Guilty Gear XX #R, up until AC+R. And I have to say that this game is brilliant in so many ways.

Obviously, for someone from the past like me, the [b]graphics are a dream come true[/b].
The [b]music is great[/b] for the genre. (Korean GGXX#R OST is still the best, IMHO)

Having small kids, I have really come to appreciate how [b]this game lowered (or even removed) the mechanical threshold[/b] with the auto combos. SF players might think I'm too soft on my kids for not having them grinding combos with tight links, but if I did that, they'd lose interest in a heartbeat. Having instant access to meterless and metered punishes (while looking awesome at the same time) enables jumping straight into the fun part, reading and reacting to your opponent.

Should small kids play Dragon Ball FighterZ? That's a different story, perhaps. I would argue it's too good for them to [i]not[/i] play it.

Pros:
Visuals: Good graphics, it looks pretty close to the anime, they greatly fixed their cell shade technique so it doesnt look awful anymore,
Combat: The fighting is fluid and is more of a regular fighter in controls, though i do miss the budokai combat system.

Cons
Single player: The Story is weeeeeeak, they have made some abominable concoction of a story just to make the player fit into a role in the dbz world (and having characters interact with the player) they could of just retold the same old story and it would of been fine imo. also the main enemies you fight are just clones of the z fighters.
Financial Capital: Good ol Zeni, i find almost no reason to want zeni or capsules for that matter, after buying a thousand of the bastards they dont seem to unlock anything worth a fuck, sure as hell not characters (good ol' american dollars are reservered for that), buying capsules just gives you different colors of the same outfit and sound/songs and i think artwork so nothing important.
CHARACTERS BEHIND PAYWAAAAAAAAAAAALLLLLLLLSSSSSSSSSS! Do you like playing as yamcha? or tien? how about fat ol majin buu, or just generic goku, you'd better like playing them cause are free! if you want the fun character get ready to throw some shekels, thankfully 1 of the 2 vegetas is free otherwise i would write a bad review.

all in all just buy the damn game when its on sale like all steam games.

Fun game.
---Cons---
Would be better if it had less gtgoku and bardock cheese as they severely dumb down the game, turning whiffs into actual convertable combos. While other characters suffer due to having less forgiving combos.

the netcode is pretty horrid at times, Even with a green connection you will get roughly 5 frame delay which can still put people off to dropping some combos.

The blockstrings in this game can be incredibly long and I had a hard time figuring out when It was essentially my turn in this game, as you progress to tougher players it becomes a lot more stressful for defending.

--Pros--
-It's a beautiful looking game.

-The combos are super fun to do and easy to learn until you want to try your hand at tougher characters like Ginyu.

-Being able to build your own team gives you the option to make your own kind of combos for some creative fun and more reasons to try out other characters.

-Its still got a thriving community even after months of the games release.

-a fairly good match making system so even the most novice of players will always find someone of roughly equal skill, with the option to fight tougher players.
-----------

But man I can't stress how terrible the netcode its.

If you're a fan of fighting games or Dragon Ball in any of its forms, then you'll want to check this game out. The devs have been crafting anime fighters sine the first Guilty Gear on the original Playstation in 1998, and FighterZ is the culmination of everything they learned up to the point of this game's release. The fighting is fast (like the anime), and the control scheme is simple, but there's enough meat to the game's mechanics that fighting game vets and newbies alike can play for 10-15 minutes and feel like they've leveled an entire city to ashes. Oh, and the graphics are decent, too, if you're into that sort of thing. 

Buy this game!

The best game for DB Fans. For fighting game fans, its a simplified anime fighter that goes like this;

Low tier play > Auto combos and occasional supers, high spectacle low complexity.
Mid tier play > Everyone can do a combo string and you'll know about it, because it's all they do, easy counterplay minimal spectacle. 
High tier play > Whoops i got hit time to sit back as I get combo'd into oblivion with tag in supers for half an hour for a chance to try and not get hit again.
Very good!

The game itself is really good. This port isn't though. I played a lot on the Nintendo switch and thought that maybe I should upgrade to the PC port, since I can play it at max settings. The difference in the picture quality and refresh rate is day and night. I really loved the port in the first 2 matches so far. After that though, the constant crashing kept occurring. I try to play one match and a few seconds in my game closes completely. There's a fix for it, but I shouldn't have to fix the developers mistakes. And most people i'm matched with don't know it exists so, they end up crashing either way.

Ran this game twice on 2 different computers.

Laptop (Asus EEE Slate ep121, Intel Dual-Core i5 470um): 
Even with the lowest possible settings this game looks and plays horrible. Which is really a shame cause I always like to take my laptop everywhere, especially since I'm a college student. Was looking forward to play with friends but yeah, this is just not going to happen

Desktop, (some Asus PC I built, AMD A4-5300, Radeon HD Graphics):
Like again, Lowest setting just to make sure things would run smoothly... 
Game was amazing, and ran at a good framerate. Honestly was suprised, cause it was a pain to download and install compaired to my laptop. 
The biggest con here though is that I intended to get this game to play with friends, and I don't see myself carrying my desktop tower with me everywhere I go. Or leaving it on at home for streaming...

Controller (Hori Switch B attle Pad:
If you plan on using this controller on PC with this game, I strongly recommend changing the controlls a bit cause it still treats it like an Xbox controller with the lettering being the same.
Pressing B+Y to teleport will not be comfortable so I reccomend mapping that to LS instead. 
I don't know how Switch treats the controls and I'm worried about that...

On a personal note to the game developers
- They should've released an actual demo to allow PC users to test if the game can run on their systems instead of having to buy, play under 2 hrs, then request refund if it doesn't work... Reading spects alone doesn't help cause as a Novice PC user, I cannot tell if my Graphics card is good or not, cause manufactures do not list the cards by any order but weird ass names.
Because of this stupid new trend of Beta testing, I missed the chance to actually try the game on PC!
-There should've been some meathods included to disable/scale back some things so even gamers with low tier PCs wouldn't have to worry about being forced to buy new hardware just to enjoy your game.

A game I was waiting for my entire life after all the Budokai Tenkaichis and similar games... I'm really enjoying this game, however some things must be fixed. Ring matches won't work unless you have the same download settings and that really isn't acceptable for a game of this caliber. Connection issues to lobbies as well are horrendous. Even when playing Ranked matches, you get disconnected even though there's no issue with your internet and it makes you look like a leaver whether you're winning or losing the game. Something also has to be done about the intentional leavers. You get them to do the last bit of health and what do they do? Leave the game. Hooray! Look at us we're so smart at highest ranks having almost no defeats and why? Because of a shit system where they don't get punished for alt+f4ing the game.
Will still give it an upvote just because of my love for Dragon Ball, the love that went into making this game, and for introducing me to fighting games. The best.

Must buy for Dragon Ball fans and fighting game fans, this is the perfect medium. Dragon Ball FighterZ is one of the most solid fighting game titles to date. Visually this game is stunning, using stills from the manga to the movies with tons of amazing nods for any Dragon Ball fan. Fun roster with all the classic specials you can think of. Pretty scrub friendly fighting game with auto combos to a decent training mode that will teach you some bread and butters with every character.  If you're into fighting games you already know how sick this game is, so just do everyone a favor and pick it up.

I'm gonna be honest here I am a huge fan of Dragon Ball and a sucker for anime games, but when I say that FighterZ is good I genuinely mean it. I hesitated to get it at first due to the large amount of $5 DLC but, after a juicy steam sale I got it for like $15 and it has been by far worth that money, it started off as good fun between a friend and I and I now find myself buying all the characters and practicing combos between games.

PROS- 
    - Great attention to detail by the Devs
    - While being easy to pick up and mash square it also has a solid level of depth to allow for growth into competitive play
    - A great diverse cast full of characters that are all decent enough to hold their own
    - Tons of callbacks to Dragonball Z, with lots of easter eggs and attacks based off of moves in the show.
    - Does a great job not looking like Dragonball, but looking like you remember Dragonball
CONS-
    - The net code is kind of lacking, compared to other Anime game net code though (Ninja Storm 4, Sao GGO) it is quite good
    - Expensive to pick up from the get go

I have over 500 hours on the console version of Dragon Ball FighterZ, and let me just say, this is the best Dragon Ball game we've ever had. From a visual standpoint alone this game takes the cake, using moves from the anime or manga right down to the last detail. The gameplay is simple to learn, but difficult to master, and you'll have a ton of fun coming up with combos while you wait for a match.

The story is ok. I like that it has a new character, and as a fan I can appreciate the dialogue. However, it can sometimes feel like fan service. 'What would these two characters say to each other if they were together'. At times it can get cringe worthy too. It wouldn't feel out of place at 9am on Saturday with the early morning cartoons.

I still play this game regularly after almost two years. With any other Dragon Ball game, once I've completed it, it goes on the shelf, never to be played again. Not with this game. I want to hop right back in and watch Goku activate his Kaioken, or Gogeta to do his level 5 super. I want to land the combos that I practice online. I love this game.

9/10.

+Blow your friend's face off as you blast him into the stratosphere while screaming KAMEHAMEHAAA in real life
+Make all your friends hate you because you troll them with Captain Ginyu (just pose repeatedly)
+Add "It keeps happening!" to your vocabulary, because you'll get good use out of it
+Initially try to combo but then just end up button mashing like a dolt, but then you win and feel bad that your terrible techniques somehow won you the match
+Play terrible in the anime characters like Yamcha and cackle like a madman when they underestimate your ability to wolf fang on em' (Yamcha is lit)

Overall I've had a positive experience with Dragon Ball FighterZ and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys kick punchers.

I bought this game in order to play with one of my friends who has been enjoying the game for a while. The graphics are simply amazing, and the fights are so intense with crazy visual effects! Out of anime fighters, this has got to be one of the greats. I basically only have one problem with the game, which is that the CPUs are essentially punching bags. The AI is not very smart, and playing against them is so much of a cakewalk you cannot improve by fighting against them. This might not be an issue to some, but I personally like to improve in a fighting game by trying my hand against the toughest CPUs before I go head to head with a real player, but this game does not offer that option because of how underdeveloped the AI is. Outside of this niche complaint, the game plays wonderfully and I would highly recommend it to any veteran or newcomer to the anime fighting game genre. The formula is easy to learn but hard to master, and you never feel like you are being cheated in a fight with little to no counterplay.

So, nobody else is going to say it? Okay, well, someone has to.

This game is terrible.

I came into high hopes for this. Arc System Works are the masters of the fighting game genre. Where most franchises excel at either technical play (Street Fighter Alpha, the Namco games) and some at spectacle (Netherrealm games), BlazBlue, Guilty Gear, and Persona 4 Arena are games that are the peak of pefection in both aspects of fighting games. While some (BBCP) are better than others (GG Isuka), they consistently produce top-shelf fighters.

Well, except Isuka. And Dragonball FighterZ. In fact, Dragonball FighterZ is not only the worst game ASW have ever made, it's one of the worst fighters in DECADES.

Presentation is what everyone praises about this but... I'm sorry, but no. The presentation here is absolutely nothing special. The menu is BBCP's with a DragonBall coat of paint on it. The roster is utterly anemic, with half the roster locked behind DLC and even with DLC there's some unforgivable gaps. Where's Mr. Satan? Why are the Ginyus just ancillary to the Captain? Why is Gotenks and Worst Goku the only kid characters? DB Xenoverse got it right. DBFZ's presentation just feels lazy. The spectacle feels just very bland and the Dramatic finishes are lacking, the few we do get have arcane requirements to pull off and they could have done so much more than 'this is how the fight ended in the anime'. If you're going to do that, show more! How could Krillin defeat Cell, for example. How would Freeza have beaten Goku? So much potential in that idea... but they went the lazy route.

Story mode is another dissapointment. The VAs do a stellar job, and seem the only people involved with this game that gave half a crap. The story itself however is razor thin compared to ASW fare. What is there is decent... but it could have been better. It's a McDonald's burger. It'll do in a pinch, but not as good as a real burger.

Gameplay is utterly boring. Controls are responsive and nothing is broken, but there's no depth whatsoever. Everyone plays virtually exactly the same. It doesn't even feel like an Arc System Works fighter despite using a dumbed-down version of the engine. Feels more like an alpha for a Capcom crossover fighter than anything.

Overall a shoddy licensed cashgrab. DB Xenoverse felt true to the series and was clearly made with passion. DB FighterZ does not and was not.

Shame on Arc System Works. You guys are so much better than this! BlazBlue but DBZ sounds great on paper but the execution just isn't there.

Avoid at all costs. Even if you're a huge DBZ fan. Just watch an LP of the story instead. It'll be actually more fun than actually playing this abomination of a game. Get DB Xenoverse instead. If you're a fighting game fan, play any other Arc System Works game. If you never played one before, I'd suggest the entire BlazBlue franchise because the story in those games are utterly epic and you kind of need to start from the beginning to make sense of it. 

Scores:

Presentation: 5/10, and that's mostly because of the VA work. Marks taken off for missed potential.

Gameplay: 2/10. It's not broken, and it's responsive. But it's still miserably dull. 

Story: 2/10. Story Mode campaign is grindy and the plot makes less sense the more it's explained. Points deducted for a complete lack of arcade endings, as that basically makes arcade mode a waste of time for people looking for lore or story in them.

Overall: 1/10. Marks taken off again for missed potential and failure to live up to the Arc System Works legacy. I am being harsh here, but ASW let me down.

This game hit my life like an unexpected 6m, it really hooked me into competitive fighting games after years of not touching the genre, the subtle and not so subtle references to one of my childhood favourite shows may have also helped. Every attack feels so heavy and brutal. Even throwing jabs out is just enough to get me giddy! Some of the super animations are so large and so devastating looking they're downright cathartic, to watch Earth, Namek, and the Heavenly Realms buckle under the sheer magnitude of the attacks you commonly throw around in this game is downright satisfying. Even when I'm getting my a** handed to me on a silver platter with a side of Yagyu Steak, I can't help but have a beaming smile on my face playing this game. If you're a lucky enough person to have friends on this easily disposable rock floating in space like me, get them on this game, even if you don't like fighting games or Dragon Ball, you're bound to have a whale of a time.

Good:
The ranking system pits you up against players nearly perfectly. You'll almost always be playing against someone on the same level as you. If you want to play against someone better or worse than you, you can ask the game to pair you up that way. It's fun. You get compared to different dragonball character types and levels based on your skill/rank. The more points the better the comparison. You start off as a saibamen. It feels special when you hit supersaiyan for the first time.
Boss mode is perfect. 3 strangers versus tough bots. Very nice. Krillin needs to be nerfed for Boss mode but buffed for online ranked play.
 The character roster is very balanced aside from Broly, Gogeta, Gt Goku and Ultimate Gohan.
The Z union system lets you know the popularity of dragonball characters but is skewed on in game viability. Android 16 used to be the most popular dragonball character for example.
Training mode is perfect for learning combos.

Bad:
If the opponent rage quits, they're rewarded.
Super armor moves in this game are broken.
Ultimate Gohan has an infinte attacking loop.
The developers noticed the game was losing popularity and threw game balancing out the window. Every new DLC character is the best character in the game. Other than Broly, Gogeta, Gt Goku and Gohan, the game is perfectly balanced.
Story mode is boring.
You'll never have enough strangers playing to be able to hold a tournament in game.

Pros:
[*] Easy to pick up. Great game for people getting into fighting games.

[*] Terrific and loyal homage to the Dragon Ball series. Likely one of the best games to come out.

[*] Wonderful character and stage themes.

[*] Absolutely stunning anime-style graphics you won't find outside of an Arc Sys game.

[*] Very friendly community, one of the more positive FGC communties

[*] Active servers, especially for a PC Fighting Game, expect less matches at the higher ranks/during off-peak hours.

Cons:
[*] Bad delay-based netcode. 

[*] Random lag spikes occur that only seem to disappear when restarting the game, makes it borderline unbearable

[*] Weak tutorial and single player content. I'm sad to see Arc Sys abandon the fantastic tutorial they had in Guilty Gear Xrd. 

[*] Lack of playstyle variety. Concepts such as fuzzies and auto-tracking autocombos can be frustrating to deal with at a higher level making some characters leagues above the rest in the right hands.

This game is easily still the best game on the market, I will give this game 9/10 only because of balance issues with characters such as GT Goku but otherwise a very worthwhile purchase for any fan of the franchise.

TLDR: Community is lovely and game is both challenging and fun
Within my 40 or so matches, i‚Äôve met so many different people of skill levels, i can go from completely getting destroyed to completely destroying someone. However, what all the people had in common was respect and genuine love for this game. Sure i might get upset sometimes but every match i lost makes me feel that it wasn‚Äôt the games fault but rather my fault for not being able to match up with my opponent‚Äòa skill level. The only other game that made me understand this challenging ness was DOTA2, but even in dota 2, dbfz has a community that is super great. Every match has always ended with both of us thanking each other for the match all the while being respectful to each other and in my opinion, this is the most important part. Onto the skill cap, this game continues to prove it immensly high level cap with great adaptability and great characters that synergise well with the game while still being incredibly enjoyable. I love how bandai made this game being both competitive and casual mixed in together. Even though the story mode might be subpar, everything else i absolutely wonderful. Get this game if your looking for a fun but competitive fighting game with a wonderful community.

The main reason that I even play longer than 15 mins is because the load time between fights is so long, seriously the load times are longer than the fights, it reminds me of the old PS1 generation of video games. All that beautiful animation comes at a price.

If you're a hardcore dragon ball fan like I am, then you'll want it, though wait for the price to drop or for a steam sale weekend.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is genuinely a great game. It has it's bad habits that many games do nowadays (micro-transactions and broken patches), but as far as speaking on terms of fighting games and Dragon Ball games, it's pretty solid. 
Dragon Ball games have had a really bad habit over the past couple of decades that cause them to be only mediocre or repetitively bad. They usually all tell the exact same story (ie: the entire DBZ saga) and they usually all have the same hashed out Bandai Namco gameplay. However, FighterZ uniquely breaks that chain, by giving you a traditional fighting style game and keeps the spirit of the anime. It has very tight and comfortable button controls and combos that make for a great experience. I will say, this game is difficult when it comes to fighting games. Like most, you have to master the game in certain ways. Be patient with each session and learn your combos. Once you pick up a character you like and sit down to learn how they play, it becomes massively easier to play with other players. 

I'd like to say that this game deserves a chance by people and should be considered high on your list if you are a fan of fighting games and/or Dragon Ball!

I want to preface this review by saying I was never a fan of dragon ball before playing this so the fanservice means a lot less to me and I only have a small understanding of the characters, but I do enjoy fighting games. With that out of the way here are the pros and cons.

Pros:
-Excellent visuals and animations
-Deep gameplay that is very easy to learn the basics of in spite of the high skill ceiling
-Good net code for the most part, albeit input delay can be frustrating at the worst of times
-Careful attention to detail, with clever references in the dramatic finishes and destructible backgrounds giving battles an action heavy feel to them
-Lots of unique dialogue between characters
-Great voice acting on both the English and Japanese side
-Enjoyable fanservice, at least considering the little I know about the series
-Decent roster of characters
-Mod support for most aesthetic mods

Cons:
-Terrible and confusing lobby system and over complicated method of playing with friends
-Story mode is repetitive and boring. It is a step up from the movie length cutscenes of guilty gear's story but it isn't particularly satisfying either.
-Arcade sticks require tampering with files to work, and playing with friends from another country require you to change steam's download region
-Expensive by fighting game standards
-A few questionable balance decisions, mostly relating to Bardock
-No punishment for rage quitting, if anything it rewards you with a flawless winrate if you rage quit

In spite of all of the negatives I have mentioned here a lot of these are nitpicks and personal gripes. I would still recommend this absolutely fantastic game to fans of both dragon ball and fighting games alike as the positives greatly outweigh the negatives.

I'm an absolute Dragonball series fan. Although I haven't played all DBZ games, I've played a few and even enjoyed shitty DB Final Bout from PS. But I gotta say, I'm massively impressed with the way Arc System created DBZ fighters game. All the cutscenes, voice acting, skills, and dialogues are spot on and stay true to the source, and that must impress all DBZ fans like myself even if some don't like the game system. 
As for the game system, I really haven't played much multiplyer to know the complexity of combat system. However, it seems to me that combat system is very easy to enter, but complicated enough for hardcore fighting game enthusiasts. It's probably not as complex as games like Guilty Gear series or Tekken series, but I'm forever grateful that Arc Systems made a competitive DBZ game. This is too soon to say, but I can't being to imagine how much they could improve upon this game in the future.

It's a dream game for Dragon Ball die-hards, a great new way to test your skills for fighting game nuts and an all-around great experience for everyone else in between. The story and arcade modes present plenty of challenge and things to keep you occupied, and the roster is large enough to make no two battles feel the same. And, refreshingly, the online modes appeal to not just those who have immersed themselves in online battles for years, but newcomers and even just the mildly interested as well. At present time, the PS4 version looks to be the one to get due to a few issues with the Xbox One's online capabilities, but both versions perform even better than you might have hoped. For a game with nearly a full year of hype behind it, Dragon Ball FighterZ delivers in ways that will exceed even the most lofty of expectations. This is a fighting game for the ages.

100% the best Dragon Ball game to date. If you even mildly enjoy fighting games and love the dragon ball universe, this game is amazing. All the references to the anime with dramatic finishes and special moves straight out of the anime and manga make this game a masterpiece to Dragon Ball fans. As a fighting game it is also great. The fast pace is really fun, and the assist system lets you make a team with synergy between certain characters. Complex combos are stylish and fun to pull off, but most characters have a simple combo that even someone new to fighting games can get a grasp on pretty easily. The worst part of the game is the story which is just some silly OC about a forgotten android and should not be considered when buying the game. If you enjoy Dragon Ball, just pick up the game already dude.

Best part of the game is making a team, and making up random combos for said team. Has a lower skill floor than other fg's but lacks a compelling story/arcade mode for beginners that dont want to grind out training mode or get stomped online.

Online mode is alright if you set the connection filter to be aggressive. Custom lobbies are easy to do, training mode has a solid feature list and everything cosmetic can be earned for free even if they are recolours.

This is an absolutely beautiful game that not only connects to those who love Dragon Ball and its series, but also to fighting game fanatics. I would say this game is a great starter for people to branch to other fighting game genres. Lastly, if you love learning flashy, long hitting combos for huge damage with any team you want, BUY THIS GAME.

Review. Dragon Ball FighterZ. I love it. Probably nostalgia is a strong factor. Objectively, I can identify a small list of flaws you may want to consider before opening your wallet (it is a pricey title after all the DLC).

Controls strike me as being designed for console, not PC. Took me a while to re-assign everything to a comfortable layout. If you're tech savvy enough to plug your Playstation/X-box controller into you PC, probably not an issue. 

Story mode. VERY repetitive. Endless clone minions. Saps the fun from a decent saga story.

Online Multiplayer. What, you enjoy getting spanked or something?  Those guys have been perfecting combo chains since release. I'm just a casual gamer and a fighting genre noob. I steer clear of it. Still, online multiplayer looks to be 3/4 of the game. So 3/4 of what you're paying for.

Combat. Even a fighting genre noob can see the real trick is to keep your opponent trapped and stunned in a never-ending combo chain. Figure out how to get out of it when they do the same back to you. Not at all much more depth to the combat. All your favourite special attacks from the series play like cinematics. The team of three, tag team element is nice. Hyper Dimension sure couldn't do that.
A really fun fighting game and a good Dragon Ball fighting game.

So... Dragon Ball FighterZ. This game is regarded as one of the best fighting games of recent years and I do feel that way as well. This game is really good and enjoyable. But there are some things that in my opinion, have decreased the game's value and could have been executed better. I have tried to make my points more brief than other reviews I have written because of time constraints. But if you still need a TL;DR summary, just skip to the end.

Let's get all the positives out of the way first. This game looks and sounds AMAZING. Not only the graphical style is utterly gorgeous, but the English dub (I'm not really a fan of JP dub in this franchise) and the music tracks of the game are seriously good.

Even the gameplay is really fun; despite being simplified in comparison to other ArcSys fighters (excluding BBTAG. I prefer not to talk about that game). Although I have to say that it feels kinda limited and does not have the same amount of freedom that games like Guilty Gear or BlazBlue offer in their gameplay. So, there's a chance that the game might become repetitive.

Now... let's rant about the things I have serious problems with:

[h1] Story Mode [/h1]
This game uses a cinematic story mode which is kinda similar to the same thing in Guilty Gear Xrd. The story revolves around this mysterious character named Android 21 (a new character in the DB universe created by Akira Toriyama himself) and what she does. But overall... it's both a great thing and a great disaster at the same time. Because it has a lot of nice moments and also a lot of issues.

The story is presented in a pretty weird way in my opinion. The story mode features 3 story arcs; each one of them focusing on a different set of characters and how they go through the story events. Now this would have been great if these arcs DIDN'T RETCON EACH OTHER! Contrary to what you might have thought, every story arc has it's own story-line & ending, and aside from some minor points and events, does not show the same story from different perspectives. So in the first two arcs, you're basically going through "What If?" scenarios with little real events and the last arc is where the exact real events take place. I don't know about you, but that seems like a waste of time to me; even if the special events that happen by using certain characters in your team (like using Nappa & Yamcha) are pretty great.

To be honest, the decision to let people play through the story instead of watching it (like Guilty Gear Xrd's story mode) is great and was much needed. But it has not executed well and I would be lying if I say the game doesn't get repetitive & boring after a while. All you do in the story mode is fighting clones over, and over, and over again. And the AI difficulty is pretty inconsistent as well, constantly changing between a scale of "dumb as a rock" and "you're already dead"; meaning sometimes it doesn't do anything noticeable and sometimes it pummels you like you're playing a match against Daigo or SonicFox. Even the light RPG elements (like leveling up and using special skills which make the story mode really similar to M.O.M. mode in Guilty Gear Xrd) can't do anything to fix this repetitiveness and sometimes, make it even worse.

[h1] Arcade Mode [/h1]
To be quite honest, I don't like the new take on arcade mode in this game. In this game's arcade mode, you are presented with a map that has several paths with different opponents, and which path you take is based on how good you play the matches. This means if you play the game really good, then the difficulty gets higher and vice versa, and you can even get different opponents based on your performance. Now this is a nice idea, but what if I just want a normal arcade mode where I can customize my own experience? Maybe I just want to blow off some steam and pummel some easy/normal AI opponents. With this system, you cannot do that.

Other than that, there's almost no reason to replay the arcade mode rather than trying to increase your score. In other fighting games, you can beat an arcade ladder with a character and get an illustration or a video as a reward each time you do so. But here? None of that is present.

[h1] Online Modes [/h1]
I don't play online that much (being a busy guy doing... business) and have no idea about how the netcode is (people say it's average at its best and abysmal at its worst). But if you want my advice about online modes, if you don't want to get absolutely destroyed, don't try ranked matches without proper training. This game has been out for a year and nearly everyone in the online mode is a beast who traps you in seemingly endless combos, which ruins the fun completely. I really advise you to play with a friend or join a community and find people who are willing to play with you for now. After a while and gathering more experience, start taking on the other guys in the ranked mode.

[h1] The Roster [/h1]
I know... this has been said a lot before. But seriously, why there are 3 Gokus, 3 Vegetas and 2 Brolys in the roster? I know each one of them is from a different series or story arc, but that's honestly a lot. They could have added much more requested characters. Like... for example... a guy named Mr. Satan?

[h1] Lack of Modes [/h1]
Let me explain this. The story is repetitive and the arcade mode is seriously a downgrade compared to other fighters, as there's almost no reason to replay it.This game could have had much more modes to offer to the players; modes that already exist in many other fighting games and could have added a lot of value to the game for those who play offline like me or even those who play online. For example, a party mode like KOF XIV where you can play with up to 6 players (some say this exists in the switch version and not PC & console versions for some odd reason), a challenge mode where you have to defeat the enemy under special circumstances (like the tutorial fight in early parts of story mode or the same mode in GGXXAC+R), or even a classic survival mode. Hell, you can even use the same excuse in the story mode and create an online mode like Heroes & Heralds in UMVC3!

-------------------------------------------------------------------

[h1] [b] TL;DR [/b] [/h1]
Dragon Ball FighterZ is not flawless; it has many issues and some tidbits & design choices that could have been executed better. But it is also really fun to play. If you want to play offline, then play it in short bursts to avoid repetitiveness; although I don't recommend the game due to how lackluster it is in this regard. And if you want to play online without fear of losing over and over again, find someone friendly to play against.

You can fix the error, but the only methods are temporary. 
First, you delete a folder in your AppData>Local then relaunch the game. All of your audio/graphical settings reset, so you'd have to re-do them every launch, then after fixing them you have to cross your fingers it won't crash again. If it does, repeat the process until it no longer crashes. Also leads to the game randomly closing, then the crashing starts after relaunching.

Second, verify game files. This generally doesn't work.

This has apparently been an issue since launch, though it just randomly started happening to me a few weeks ago and hasn't stopped since.

It's an incredible game and I've heard there are people who haven't had this error once, your mileage may vary.

Like most fighting games, DBFZ is most fun:
[b](A)[/b] When you have friends who [i][b]want[/b][/i] to play with you, [b]OR[/b]
[b](B)[/b] If you take the game seriously enough to compete online.

If you have [b](A)[/b] or [b](B)[/b], go wild & enjoy!  
You are probably already a fan of fighting games and you will enjoy what the game has to offer. 
There is more than enough depth to keep you and your friends busy. 

BUT, [i]If you [b]don't[/b] have [b](A)[/b] or [b](B)[/b], then I [b]do not[/b] recommend buying this game.[/i]

Although it is easy for beginners to get into this game due to auto-combos (which some people will say is a selling-point for casuals), once you peel back the onion it is very difficult & frustrating to compete against someone who knows what they are doing.  You need to dedicate a lot of time in order to fully appreciate the cast of characters and how they play in battle (outside of tapping Light Attack ad nauseam).

I know this is basically true in virtually any fighting game, but in DBFZ it is especially true.  DBFZ is one of the most unforgiving 2D fighting games I've ever played (for better or for worse, depending on the skill disparity). 

Part of the reason is because the meta-game is very fast and quick-thinking compared to other 2D fighting games.  So, unless you and your friend(s) are relatively matched in skill/knowledge, you probably won't play for very long before someone quits out of frustration, helplessness, or boredom.

Once you give up on trying to convince your friends to play, you are then stuck trying to compete online.  And, well, online is neither for the feint of heart nor for those who don't have the time/patience to learn.

The "campaign" and other PvE elements aren't really worth mentioning, and the DLC structure is not ideal.

[i][b]Dragon Ball FighterZ (DBFZ) is without a doubt the best 3v3 fighter on the market and possibly the best fighting game on the market as well.[/b] However, Scamco's business practices continue to be predatory and exceedingly greedy. There needs to be a "middle" recommendation option because the DLC money-gouging is so bad that it's very hard to actually recommend this game.[/i]

[h1]The Good![/h1]
[list]
[*]Ark System Works (ASW) usually knocks it out of the park when it comes to the visual style, graphical fidelity, and sound design in their games. DBFZ is no exception, as it is one of the best looking fighting games ever. DBFZ also includes a great musical score using old and new compositions.
[*]Stellar fighting mechanics that allow for near-marvel levels of insane setups and combos that not only look great but do tons of damage, but also accommodates for lower skill levels and offers plenty of ways to enter a situation.
[*]Has absolutely fantastic training modes that let you set up just about anything and test for whatever you want to find out.
[*]Offers a handful of online and offline modes and also has a competitive ranked mode.
[*]The game is still in its prime with a lot of hype, being actively supported and holding regular tournaments, and the community for this game isn't going to dwindle for another good few years.
[*]If you're into the current Dragon Ball franchise at all, you will get to enjoy plenty of fanservice with some of the franchise's most popular characters.
[*]Character balancing is slowly improving. However while the top tiers have cycled through this game's lifespan you will still find yourself fighting people online who collectively pick the same 6-7 characters.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad![/h1]
[list]
[*]The roster is incredibly small for a Dragon Ball game, even compared to games like Xenoverse 1, and about half of the DBFZ roster is DLC. That's Scamco for you!
[*]Did I mention the DLC is ludicrously expensive when it's not on sale? Allegedly, even those who purchased the Ultimate Edition (FULL PRICE BEING $109.97, MIND YOU) don't get all of the DLC. Scamco has done this kind of crap for other titles, most relevantly to Dragon Ball being Xenoverse 2. They will release multiple different "sets" of character/DLC packs so that even if you buy a set of packs, you will have to buy the new set! It is no different in DBFZ, currently nearing the end of its second $25 season pass. Expect a third season pass to be announced sooner than you think. But hey, at least DBFZ 2 isn't coming anytime soon!
[*]The lobby system is garbage, and almost unnecessary on top of that. At least it doesn't detract from the game all too much, but you still have to enter it even when you play offline.
[*]You may be wondering if I was ever going to mention a story mode, or you might not even care that it has a story mode. Some fighting game story modes tend to be superfluous after all, and it most certainly is in DBFZ. The fanservice is there at times, but it is mostly in the character interactions that you have between team members. The actual story is forgettable and not worth going into, only a portion of it dedicated as an introduction to Android 21 who is written in a lackluster manner. The gameplay consists of doing fight after fight with clone versions of the main cast, and it gets repetitive very fast. The maps in which these fights are laid out are almost pointless and only serve as a micro-commute between other teams on said maps to challenge. It's only worth to go through so you can create a Zeni farm by the time you're done, as well as to unlock Android 21, Goku Blue and Vegeta Blue.
[/list]

Let me start by saying this game is amazing! When they announced it, I thought it was cool but since I tend to suck at fighting games, I decided it wasn't the game for me. One day, I log in and it's free for a weekend so I thought, "Why not".

Even if you are terrible at fighting games like me, this game is still a blast to play. The game is easy to play but lots to master. The developers were clearly giant fans of Dragon Ball because the game is full of references to the series and the community. The game comes with 24 characters, then with the two FighterZ Pass, the total comes to 38 characters. Each character feels different too, with their different combos and button combinations.

The gameplay is fast pace, the story is alright and there is an arcade mode, a tournament mode and you can fight the computer. You can play online, which opens up a ton of things to do but I don't play online so I can't speak for that.

If you are a Dragon Ball fan or if you love fighting games, you should absolutely give this game a try.

I was hoping that the campaign would be cool, but unfortunately it's reeaaaallly stupid and an embarrassment to DragonBall Z. That being said, the combat is obviously alot of fun, and there are cool upgrades from previous DBZ games. The multiplayer lobby is a decent concept and it's fun to mess around in there. If the price is 60, I do not recommend this game. If you get it lower, I recommend.

My Review of Dragon Ball Fighter Z

Story (took 8 hours to complete);
I can‚Äôt say good things about story mode other than well voice acted. I didn‚Äôt enjoy the story and found it very tedious and a waste of time because of an awkward leveling system (that creates artificial difficulty that just makes enemies deal/receive more/less damage), a slow paced story, and a limited roster of playable characters in this mode. The only value in story mode is unlocking android 21, but to unlock her you need to play story mode 3 times. I would recommend buying the fighter pass (More info in future value and DLC) because the time you spend playing the story mode could be better spent in training mode, learning the characters play-styles and their techniques, playing local/online battles, or even arcade mode for a pretty good challenge (you can get better at the game faster via stronger opponents and challenge versus computers who practically let you win in story mode).

Other Modes:

Local Mode:
The settings are basic but they work. Select your player limit (1-3), select your difficulty and go. The best part of local is the CPU difficulty slider that tailors to your skill level (though there is a point even after max difficulty where I go to online mode to get an extra challenge).

Arcade mode: 
It‚Äôs a simple number of rounds from (3-5-7) on easy or hard. It provides a nice challenge and the way this game does its arcade mode is something I find interesting. It increases in challenge depending on your gameplay performance, S-A, Challenge goes up, B, challenge is constant, and C-D, Challenge is lowered. 

Training Mode:
I find myself coming back to this mode frequent because the combo challenges give a quick tutorial of each character but can be limited in that it shows a limited amount of technique combinations and doesn‚Äôt show many advance techniques. 


Gameplay;
Game play is easy to pick up.

Offense
The basic combo loop is; Weak, Mid, Strong, Projectile, Technique, Super
And you can skip ahead if you need a different type of move.
Techniques are executed by quarter inputs and the technique and speed is based on whether it was a weak, mid, or strong attack. 
This game contains a super meter. Using quarter inputs and the triggers each character has at least 2 supers. A super uses 1 bar and an ultra that uses 3.
The player has access to a vanish (cost 1 meter) that teleports the player behind the opponent and strikes them so they bounce them off the wall.
The player has access to two other playable characters via the left triggers and if you have a meter after a super by pressing the corresponding trigger you can swap into your other character that follows with their special on entering. 

Defense
Blocking is hold back to block overhead and standing attacks, vulnerable to crouching attacks and back and down (diagonally away) to block crouching and standing attacks, vulnerable to overhead and jumping attacks. 
Blocking can be broken by grabs
Grabs in this game can be used on the ground and air and can be used to force swap the opponents team mates or extend combos. (Opponents can‚Äôt be grabbed during an attack).

Movement 
Basic left and right movement with dashing and back stepping.
A homing dash called a dragon dash can be used to fly towards your opponent but can also be used to extend combos such as after a heavy attack. ! Watch out, for dragon dashing can be countered by a crouching heavy attack 


Future Value and DLC; 
Local battle is great for a quick match and unwinding after a stressful day. 
Online provides strong people to improve your gameplay skill. 
The combo challenge in training mode makes it easy to get reacquainted with characters you haven‚Äôt used in some time.
The game is simple enough to teach a friend for a quick match but complex enough to have depth.

DLC;
I find the DLC is overpriced on default and would wait for a sale (This game goes on sale constantly). 
The first DLC is 35$ for 8 characters and unlocking android 21 without playing story mode (defiantly worth it to avoid the story mode). I bought this first DLC at 17.50 and that was worth it for me. 
There is more DLC on the way for the second set but I‚Äôm waiting till all the content is released before purchasing.
I do have a strong feeling that a 3rd DLC will be created but I may be wrong on that. 

Other Nitpicks;
SSGSS Vegeta and Goku are locked until you buy them of unlock them via gaining 300,000 and 500,000 zenny, if you enjoy the game or do story mode (which I advise against) you‚Äôll unlock them without paying, but if you don‚Äôt enjoy the game as much as the game expects you to, then this is going to be a problem for your experience of the game. 


My Recommendation;
I would recommend this game to anyone who likes fighting games, with friends or online people.
I spent the most amount of time in local battle for 20 minutes of unwinding or break time, I‚Äôll often go to training modes combo challenge to have an idea on how the character is ‚Äúsupposed‚Äù to be played, and go online for a nice challenge against a real person.

Dragon Ball FighterZ has a power level that transcends time and space by combining the iconic DBZ franchise with true fighting game mechanics.

This combination has resulted in a catastrophic cluster crunch that any fighting game or DBZ fan should take a long look at.

Here are some features to consider:

- A sizable roster of 30+ with DLC. Noteworthy fighters include Yamcha, Piccolo the Namekian, Super Saiyan God Super Saiyan Vegito, the entire Ginyu Force as one character, and 5 different versions of Goku. All characters possess unique movesets unlike popular DBZ games such as Budokai Tenkaichi 3, where the roster is insanely huge, but the characters have little differences between each other.

- DBFZ uses 3-on-3 tag team style combat similar to Marvel Vs. Capcom, which means you have characters popping in to chuck destructo discs and senzu beans all over the place, swapping characters mid-fight, and you can have all 3 of your characters jump in at once to BLAST your opponent with an array of giant ultimate attacks.

- As a traditional fighting game, there is plenty of depth, strategy, and techniques to learn that will keep the dedicated players busy.

- Because the game is 3v3, and there are 3 different versions of Vegeta in the game, you have the choice to play as only Vegeta. This is a big selling point.

- I believe that the visuals in DBFZ are the most impressive to ever grace a fighting game, and is stunning to look at compared to any video game. Characters' attacks are extremely faithful to the source material, and the hand-drawn/3D model style that allows for dynamic camera angles and perspective is a great accomplishment on its own.

- And of course, there any many iconic, heavy-hitting, bunker-busting, ultra-mega special moves that each character can use that will result in both hype and world destruction. Gohan brings in the whole fam to launch a triple Kamehameha beam, Majin Buu can get angry and blow up the entire screen, Android 16 can try to grab you and self-destruct, INSTANTLY KILLING YOU. The list goes on and on.

The bottom line here, is that it's Dragon Ball Z combined with proper fighting game mechanics. It is a combo so deadly, that many pairs of pants were soiled at the moment of its first debut.

DBFZ is easily one of my favorite fighting games out there. It is an easy recommendation for fighting game fans, and especially for those who enjoy watching Chiaotzu blow himself up to do massive damage to the enemy.

It's a fun fighting game.  I warn you there's a casino in it.  I don't even want the random things in the casino but it's addicting because it's designed to be.  If you have a gambling problem I wouldn't touch this game.  The game play itself is very simple.  It's very flashy but the commands are simple.  It's a fun, laid back fighter.  I watched the Dragon Ball cartoon growing up and remember playing a DBZ fighter when I was younger.  I don't watch cartoons now.  I still find the game pretty fun and a good break from more serious fighters.   The game looks mediocre but good.  The music is incredibly repetitive and annoying.  Every time it cycles it makes me just a little more angry.  In contrast to Tekken that I can leave on in the background constantly.  The menu is stupid.  You have to walk around with a little avatar.  So instead of quickly scrolling to your option you have to walk in this stupid hub world.   I got the game for $15.  It's worth $15 as long as you don't have a gambling problem.  

This game can be picked up and played immediately.  If you're looking for first 2D fighter or something to play on the side this is pretty alright.  I'm saying I'm not upset about paying $15 for the game.  If it was any more than that I would be.  The roaster is small when you consider this is a tag team game and the characters don't have a lot of depth.  It's flashy.  It's a flashy game that you can play for a solid 20 hours before moving on.

Pros:  Great animation, explosive Supers and Meteors, and a large and growing roster of fighters.  Fast-paced gameplay will make sure that you are never bored by slow pacing.

Cons:  Heavily offense-oriented, with little in the way of combo-breakers.  Some characters can take down half your life bar if you don't block the first shot.  Story mode needs a MAJOR overhaul, as it does not include any of the DLC characters, and the storyline itself is only average.  The high-speed nature of the game requires very fast reflexes.  There are only 3 characters that can be unlocked through gameplay - the rest cost money.

Overall:  Recommended for the fans, but be prepared to shell out 2 to 3 times the initial price of the game if you want all the locked characters.

Love the game, couple of caveats,


First, the DLC is pretty steep. It's already a 60$ game, and the roster is already pretty small for them to be charging an additional 35$ for 8 extra characters. Also considering how many clone characters are on the cast, you'd think they would be less greedy. I didn't mind paying 5 bucks for Bardock, but there really should be more free characters.

Second, the three unlockable characters in the game are a real pain in the butt to get. For Android 21, you have to complete the story mode. Which doesn't sound bad, until you play it. It's mind-numbingly boring. It's rediculously easy, and it mainly consists of watching the same rehashed cutscenes over and over and fighting wimpy NPCs to clear maps. I'd pay 5 more dollars to unlock 21 instead of wasting several hours of my time, but weirdly she is the only character you can't pay to unlock. 

Also there are still force-closing errors over a month after release. Hopefully this will get hotfixed soon. (edit 2019, it did)

And hopefully the remaining 6 DLC characters will be something other than more Goku variants. We have 3 generations of Gokus, plus all his kids, plus 2 Vegetas, all of whom play somewhat similarly. Come on Bandai. You have a literal multiverse and hundreds of episodes-worth of fucking amazing characters to choose from. Add someone interesting for the love of Jesus. For such a simple and adrenaline pumped world, THIS GAME is the BEST format for DBZ to me. Thank you BANDAI NAMCO! We all know how cool this game is. What concerns me is the Story Mode. The clone story was a lazy direction. If you want to make a DBZ fighting game story where you are dealing with legions of "no-name" henchmen and baddies, you have Red Ribbon Army members, Siebermen, Freiza's troops, or Cell babies. Instead you fight clones of a portion of an already limited roster of characters for hours. I quickly forgave this laziness, because I saw the potential in the Leveling System. Imagining that eventually I'll take on a Level 80 Majin Buu, being called upon to manage my 8-11 characters regarding remaining HP, Level, Team Moves, and Special Perks strategically. Feeling like a leader of a team of Z Fighters trying to somehow combat a single god-like super-villain. The way this game is built, that would have been easy and just a matter of RPG math. At Level 80, Buu can take alot of damage at 800,000 HP, has his own Special Perks, can take you down in 5 Light Attacks, on top of that has good AI that the game already has at Max Difficulty. Either you have to play perfectly or grind to get to Level 80 too. I think the online "Party Battle" gives you this David vs Goliath experience to an extent, but you have to wait every 70 hours for it because it's considered a "Special Event".  So there is no difficulty setting for Story mode, nor a way to control Enemy Levels, only too accept the game's long, lazy, repetitive, and insultingly easy Story campaign. The boardgame-like mechanic of progression is nonsensical and impossible to run out of moves/time to get to the next chapter. And don't get me started on the focus on Avatars, Banners, and Stamps. Another concern is the vanilla and DLC character roster of various levels of Super Saiyen of the SAME DUDE, with the slightest differences, being treated as a totally separate character. You can simply Super Saiyen his butt with the color options, because that's all it is, colors and skins. So in the end, you are left with fighting people online if you can find them (I'm reading an alarming rate of reviews as old as 2 years that say you cannot!), local match, arcade mode that your Marvel vs Capcom 3, Blaze-Blue, or Guilty Gear is already giving you. 20 years ago this game with it's limited content would have been a trail blazing hit, but we need to progress on. I wish I could rate this as "Yes, but...", but I only have two choices. And I need to give masterpieces with bad corporate decision makers discipline in these dangerous times in the gaming industry.

While Dragon Ball FighterZ is not the most demanding fighting game there is out there, it still manages to hit a very solid middle ground between for fun and for serious play.  Even though there are some streamlined systems like auto combos or flowcharty characters/combos, there is more than enough that teams can offer where creative people can make some really disgusting team combinations that aren't super simple yet immensely rewarding.  There are plenty of nods to the anime present, but even those who just like tag team fighting games and aren't necessarily big Dragon Ball fans may still get a bunch of fun here.
