Amazingly awesome fighting game, and also awesome dragon ball game. 

The only issues I have are on netplay, the arena matches are broken, and at certain hours there aren't many people playing, but the game's far from dead.

The  AI is quite decent on hard dificulty arcade mode, but of course nothing in comparison to what a skilled player can do. Still, it's a joy to fight even against the pc-if only to enjoy looking at superiorly animated characters and attack sequences which frankly speaking surpass the level of animation in dragonball super anime and give me that dragonball Z nostalgia that recent animations failed to deliver.

 The single player story is a masterpiece of writing by dragonball's standarts(read:it's medicore), and just like a dragonball story should, it has tiny bits of plot in between tedious filler of fighting mute clone mobs, which made finishing all three storylines quite a drag tbh. still if you're a little bit of completionist, like myself, it takes about 9 hours to finish all storylines and get the coressponding unlocks and achievements, and about another 9 hours to get the remaining achievements, except for zeni and bp grinding which im yet to obtain(fortunatley the game is really generous on zeni just two days ago i got 300 thousand just for logging in). 

Speaking of bp, it s a rank point system you get for fighting ranked matched. You get a lot of bp for winning, you lose some bp for losing. As long as you don't lose all the time your bp count should be steadly increasing. Players are matched based on same bp rank or higher if the player wishes so, so you don't need to worry about being randomly matched with someone who outclasses you greatly. 

In the beginning it might seem like combat is just button mashing and inputing same combos over and over again, and you might even think that "every character plays the same"(a complaint i saw in several reviews under this game) but this mindest will soon change after you start being paired up with more advanced players.  The combo key inputs might be more or else the same for every character, but what each character does during these inputs is often extremly different, and all that makes game easy to learn but hard to master.

Wow, amazing game. Being a DBZ fan may bring my bias but this 2-D Fighter has so much replay value simply for its balance of fun and skill, its pretty basic for a fighter but still has mechanics to learn and master which reaching is so satisfying and fun to play at high levels. The art style is simply amazingly stylised to fit DB's bright and colourful style in the anime, and a joy to watch the super moves and cinematic finishes every time. The wide array of characters and making lesser characters more unique and cinematic is interesting to see, although I'd like maybe one LESS Goku and Vegeta, and the fact that DLC characters were announced on day one is a *BIG THINK* it doesn't de-value the characters any less.

The main mode people play is online of course but the story mode has really cool interactions and conversations between the classic characters is a delight, however the gameplay of the story is ehhh grindy and kinda redundant. The music is refreshing too hearing that hard rock and intense fighting music really helps with the gameplay.

I love dragonball Z but I was always booty cheeks at Xenoverse. so for the longest time, I had wanted a game that I could excel at that could make me feel like I was actually in control of my favorite characters. When this game, a 2D fighter was announced, I was ecstatic. Because I had been playing fighting games my whole life but the 3D arena fighter I just couldn‚Äôt wrap my head around. When I got my hands on this game, the controls felt crisp and responsive unlike xenoverse. the combos are long, and actually do simultate how the characters themselves fight in the anime and manga and the super moves are spectacular. This game is easy to learn and Hard to master. I appreciate the devs putting in auto combos for the newer player but the mechanics require that for some extremely hard hitting combos, your going to have to utilize some of those auto combo mechanics to send your combos into the higher digit hit counts. However, every game isn‚Äôt without its faults. To make it easy for you I‚Äôll list the pros and cons of the game below.

Pros:
Colorful...Every color on every character is accurate and the artstyle is amazing. Since Dragonball is a 2D anime, it fits much better here then it does on Xenoverse.

Hype...after a great practice session and learning a brand new high damaging combos, it feels so amazing to go into a multiplayer match and show your opponent that new combo you‚Äôve practiced so much. It actually does make you feel like Goku after stepping out of the Hyperbolic Time Chamber with your new found power. It makes you feel so proud of yourself.

Style...The best part of the mechanics system in this game is that there isn‚Äôt a set combo your forced to do or else. Absolutely not...This game allows you to customize your own combos in order to get absurd amounts of damage or just to style on your opponent.

Character Selection...The amount of characters in this game is fair. However the majority of the big names in dragonball are here: Krillin, Goku, Vegeta, Frieza the Androids etc. This allows you to finally create that dream team you‚Äôve always wanted to see in the anime and put them up against other peoples dream teams

Music...all of your favorite tracks from both Dragonball, Z and Super are here and it just adds to the hype being able to fight along to best tracks in the series.

Character Diversity...Every character doesn‚Äôt play the same. Every character has their own unique playstyle and archetype that make him weak and excel in different situations. Taking this into account when creating your squad is definitely important. Even though most characters do have the same BnB combos, their special moves and mobility is really what makes every character. 

Dramatic/Destructive Finishes...If your able to finish off an opponent character with a certain special move, it triggers a cinematic that can show replays of iconic moments from the anime or just all around incredible destructive power. Nothings better than completing a flashy combo on an opponent and then letting Vegeta disintegrate his opponent, and half the planet with his Final Flash..Gets me everytime.

Cons
(Please forgive me on this section but I have much more to say about the cons of this game because both this game and Dragonball in general is very sacred to me so I take these points personally. This doesn‚Äôt mean that these points carry more weight then the Pros)

Multiplayer...now, please understand that when I say ‚ÄúMultiplayer‚Äù I‚Äôm talking about the ‚ÄúOTHER PLAYERS.‚Äù Due to this I‚Äôm going to split this point up into 2 different sections:

Tier Whoring: 

Unfortunatly, this is still a fighting game, and that means that the majority of players you face online aren‚Äôt going to be Dragon Ball fans. Most of the time, you‚Äôll be facing hardcore fighting game fans who see this game as their ticket to EVO. Because of this, you‚Äôll see a lot of ‚ÄúTier whoring‚Äù as we call it in the Fighting game community (FGC). This refers to the act of a player who simply chooses a team full of the best characters in the game. Even professional players are guilty of this. This can lead to a lot of anger for the other player as they are constantly seeing the same 5 or 6 characters in multiplayer when the roster has anywhere from 15-20 playable characters.

This particular point is what bothers me the most about this game mostly because Arc System Works did their absolute best to make this game FROM Dragon Ball Fans FOR Dragon Ball fans, and unfortunately, it‚Äôs been infested with the low lives of the FGC community that couldn‚Äôt give less of a shit about dragon ball. People that probably haven‚Äôt even seen a single episode of Dragonball; all they see is another fighting game to practice on.

Rage Quitting

Although there are some penalties for rage quitting, it hasn‚Äôt been enough to discourage players from doing it; ESPECIALLY in casual matches. If your kicking your opponents ass, or maybe win a scramble you probably weren‚Äôt supposed to, don‚Äôt be surprised if your opponent disconnects. This has become worse in accordance with my last point. People at this point are tired of seeing the same 5 characters in multiplayer. SO...I‚Äôve seen matches where players will disconnect at the LOADING screen because they just don‚Äôt feel like playing an opponent whose going to Tier Whore.

Lack of Respect for Characters
This point may seem a bit odd for some, but for me it's kinda personal. This ALSO reverts back to the Tier whoring point. This game has a variety of different characters in it varying from earlier in the series to characters we were just introduced to. In accordance with that, it is extremely hard to watch characters who are notoriously powerful in the anime and manga get absolutely curb stomped in this game specifically because of the way they were designed in the game. FOR EXAMPLE:

Bardock Vs. God of Destruction Beerus

On paper, this shouldn‚Äôt even be a contest. Lord Beerus is an actual GOD in the dragonball series that was introduced to Goku as his next milestone of power he was supposed to aspire to. Bardock on the other hand was a low class saiyan warrior who at the time of his death couldn‚Äôt overpower 1st Form Frieza. Now before I sound like too much of a weeb here let me make my point. Bardock in the anime and manga, is the weakest of the weak, Lord Beerus on the other hand is supposed to be the Strongest of the strong. Unfortunately, in Fighterz, it's the opposite. 9 times out of 10 a Bardock in game will absolutely destroy a Beerus just due to the matchups, mechanics comparison and overall combo potential.
 
This isn‚Äôt the only example I could give you. There are plenty of notoriously powerful characters in the anime that are on the lower end of the totem pole Tier wise in this game and there are plenty of weaker and obsolete characters that top the charts in this game, Bardock, Yamcha, Android 16 (Pre-Patch) are examples of this. It doesn‚Äôt have to do necessarily with damage output but overall mechanics and what each character brings to the team

Bardock: a combo monster, amazing assist, wake up options, double super options, In the air and on ground lvl 1-3 ultimate moves. Amazing damage output, auto combo that can combo you anywhere at anytime with no risk of dropping.

 Kid Buu: Extreme range on normals, unbelievable mixup potential, almost completely safe on all normals and specials. Assist locks you down for about 3 seconds, instant air dash monster

SS Vegeta: Even after many nerfs his assist is still one of the best in the game regarding lockdowns and ‚Äúget out of jail free‚Äù potential

Cell: Again, even after nerfs, Cell still has some of the best corner potential in the game

Saiyan Saga Vegeta: unbelievable corner pressure and combo potential, Instant air dash monster

Videl: Not played as much anymore due to her demanding inputs and execution but still more mechanically sound then most low tier characters and still an absolute terror in the hands of a skilled player.

I used to play DBZ Mugen 2 a lot with my schoolmates when I was a kid. Dragon Ball Fighterz reminds me of these moments. It's easy to learn but hard to master. You can finish whole singleplayer campaign with autocombos but when you face real enemy in multiplayer be ready for a beating :D Campaign is really fun to play. There's a lot of characters you can try (Z warriors, Androids, "bad guys"), dialogues are hilarious (roasting Yamcha and Krillin is so much fun but Majin Buu and Gotenks chitchat are even better :D) and story has this dragon ball feeling. Battles are great but making long and effective combos require a lot of practice and good reflex. Game looks great, sometimes you can't tell difference between game and anime. When you're done with campaign there's still a lot of singlepleyer content left - courses, tournament, combo challenges - and of course there's multiplayer full of pro who likes crushing beginners :D 
If you want to buy it for singleplayer and occasional play with friends go on and buy it. If you're looking for good multiplayer game then you should buy it all the more :D

PS. DB Fighterz has one major disadvantage - YOU CAN'T play as Muten R≈çshi! :(

This is more of a PSA for people with simulation sickness more so then a Review, although I will say what I did enjoy about the game for the very little amount I played with it.

First the bad, the Varying degrees of different running frame rates even though it is running at 60, the models during cutscenes specifically are running at around 15fps with everything else in the background including aura effects running at 60fps this can induce heavy eyestrain for people that experience major simulation sickness, for those that have never experienced what simulation sickness feels like, for some people it can feel like being car sick, among others though it can induce migraines and eyestrain that feels like someone is taking a needle to your eye and sticking it in. 
This is a bad design decision that can exclude a minority that just wants to enjoy a game. While actually playing the meat of the game being the fighting, I didn't feel as bad so perhaps I just need to avoid playing the story, still this is something that can't be tolerated and developers should take a page from this if they don't want to make people with simulation sickness unwell.

Now the good, The responses are very snappy, and it's very easy to pick up, I assume it's low skill floor while a high skill mastery, for those that don't experience simulation sickness this is definently a easy game to recommend, however for people that do experience simulation sickness you should consider whether or not this is a series you can enjoy, if you don't you may want to avoid it.

I did initially have a rough start and thought about refunding the game but after giving it a bit more time I *really* got into it and here I am now.

Yes, it might feel very frustrating fighting opponents that easily destroy you but you could take them as insipration to get better.

About the DLC characters, they aren't a must - some of them are very powerful and unique but personally I find myself always ending up with a team made out of the original roster.

My only issue with the DLC characters is that you can't test them in training mode before you buy them (you can use Ginyu's body swap in arcade mode to give them a quick test but that's quite a hassle).

Anyway, even after....700 hours? I'm *still* having a lot of fun, it almost never gets boring - I am definitely recommending this.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a fantastic game. As someone who grew up reading the original Dragon Ball manga and watching the original DBZ anime, DBFZ makes for a genuine nostalgia trip. The gameplay is smooth, easy to pick up and play but difficult to master. Moves like "Goodbye Tien" made me especially nostalgic. Hearing Tien yell "CHOWTZUUUU" as Chiaotzu sacrifices himself is too good. 

The story mode is great imo. It's a bit repetitive and easy but it's still more than serviceable. Lots of great character moments, quips and callbacks that will make fans of Dragon Ball Z very happy. All of the characters look super good and the voice acting is phenomenal as well. 

So essentially, I'm happy with the game's single player content. I wish there was a bit more variety and substance but it's definitely passable and worth the $20 I spent. I obviously have to touch on the online. At first I absolutely loved it. My first 10 matches were really fun. I destroyed 4 of my first 5 matches and then got destroyed 4 of the next 5. The guy I was vsing was brand new and so was I. It was an even, fun match. Because I'm in Australia and it's 18 months after launch, the player base I can be matched with is extremely small. Like, I've played on 4 separate days and only been matched with 4 different people small. The 2nd, 3rd and 4th players were all drastically more experienced than me by a magnitude of 100+ hours. Needless to say, I got bodied nearly every match. 

Sooo online is pretty hit or miss. There's also the classic fighting game player who will leave right before you beat them in casual and ranked matches. But I digress. It's not so much a problem with the game but rather the community and lack of player base. If you're looking for online, I suggest you be American or European and preferably be living in Europe or America. Most fighting games have extremely imbalanced matches 18 months after launch and I kinda accepted that when I purchased DBFZ. The single player content and that one perfect day of balanced online matches will have to be enough I suppose. For $20 you could do a lot worse if you love Dragon Ball/Z.
Really fun game. Online can be hard sometimes because of the net code but its still a great fighting game

DRAGON BALL FighterZ is a great fighting game experience. Not only is it easy to pick up and play, but it is also very VERY hard to master. There is a decent roster (not including the DLC) and while the characters do not feel as diverse as they should, the team-building aspect of the game leads to a wide range of options in gameplay. Team synergy is a big focus in this game; assists can extend combos, help with block strings, and help deal more damage. If you are new to fighting games, I heavily recommend you consider picking up this game. The game is fun, the ranked matchmaking is quite good (although you may want to scream when you fight that one Vegito player that spams auto-combos), and it is easy to get into. This game was the first fighting game I really invested time in and I still find it to be a very good fighting game experience.

As someone who has never played a fighting game before, I feel that DBFZ was very welcoming and understanding to newer players, like myself. While there are some aspects that I am still understanding, I am still able to have fun and win matches. To be fair though, in the beginning, I did get stomped like 60% of the time. But over time, I learned the system and what to do and it doesn't happen  as often. 


Give DBFZ a try, and don't get dismayed that you aren't winning immediately.

dragon ball fighterz is an exhausting game. I've reached about the 200 hour mark and can safely say i don't regret those hours, but coming back to the game now the experience gets a little more frustrating every time. The game on a technical level is nearly perfect, eye-catching visuals, tight controls, fun systems, large roster, etc. The online certainly leaves something to be desired, in traditional arc system works fashion, but works well enough that you will be able to find and fight your friends (provided they have decent internet). The assist mechanics combined with no marvel-esque pushblocking leads to very long blockstrings and what really feels like a 1 player game at times. 
If you're a dragon ball fan, you'll love it. 
If you like arc system works titles you'll love it.
Considering the current summer sale price, I really suggest picking this game up.

An excellent fighter and good addition to the various Dragon Ball games. The graphics are excellent, and highly reminiscent of  Dragon Ball Z. The roster is fairly large, with multiple season passes constantly adding new characters. If you're looking for a good fighter with heavy combo focus, a game that brings you back to watching Dragon Ball every Sunday morning, and something to play with friends, this is an excellent choice. However, playing the game solo really isn't worth it (you gotta be into the multiplayer). Another consideration is the Season Passes, while its great they keep adding to the game, you will have to pay for the new content. Overall, a great game and do reccomend for the multiplayer experience!

[u]Pros[/u] 
- Generally balanced characters and gameplay.  While there are characters like Bardock, Cell, Yamcha and Super Saiyan Goku who are quite powerful and do well competitively, casual play allows you to build just about any team of whatever characters you like and still perform decently.  You'll never really feel like you're losing simply because a character is too weak.

- Plenty of gameplay depth while being easy to pick up.  The game is simple on the surface, but you'll eventually have to practice certain combos and techniques in order to play on par with competent players.  Training mode is essential and that's how it should be.

- Amazing visuals using the same game engine as Guilty Gear Xrd.  Every character is perfectly rendered and animated along with plenty of fan service in their moves that directly reference the original manga and anime.

- Good variety of characters.  Just about all of the major fighters from most of the Dragonball Z and Dragonball Super sagas are playable.

- Good player base on PC makes it easy to find matches online.  You'll usually be able to find a casual matches anytime you play.

- Good soundtrack with each character having their own unique theme that can be played in place of the stages original stage music.

[u]Cons[/u] 
- Some game mechanics can bog the game down and make matches drag on a bit too long.  Sparking in particular allows quick health regeneration in addition to being a pretty reliable defensive mechanic (similar to burst is Guilty Gear or Blaze Blue).  While this makes it a useful tool it also slows the pace of the match at times.

- Some characters benefit greatly from the auto combo mechanic, like Bardock who's auto combo is a good anti air.  Auto combos also auto correct, meaning if the opponent goes behind you while performing it, your character will automatically turn around and continue their attack rather than face the same direction.  A mechanic like this rewards players for simply mashing a single button without any consideration for what way their characters face.

- The "Super-dash" mechanic discourages any sort of in depth neutral play or zoning in favor of every character having a rush down move that can lead to a strong combo.  While it's not unbeatable and can be anti-aired and countered, this becomes increasingly difficult the closer you are to the opponent.  A lot of the time neutral comes down to who performed a super-dash first, and discourages players from using other tools like projectiles and special attacks.  Super-dash also negates normal projectiles, so they become a lot less useful as a result.  Zoning in this game is generally not a viable strategy.

-Netplay is a step down from previous Arc Sys fighting games.  You cannot make player lobbies, making playing with friends or a group of players online inconvenient.  If you're not playing ranked or casual matches and being paired up automatically, prepare to be disappointed.

-Lots of Gokus and Vegetas.  While this doesn't bother me specifically, some players may not like that Goku and Vegeta have a lot of representation in the roster representing their various forms from the series.  Goku alone has 4 different character variations not counting Goku Black and Bardock who are almost visually identical.

Overall the game is still worth playing, especially at a casual level.  Despite its flaws it may still be the most competent Dragonball fighting game ever created.  If you're a dragonball fan and a fighting game fan you'll enjoy it.

Good Dragon Ball game, but not a good fighting game.

Its amazing as a Dragon Ball game in its fan service, animations, art everything. This game is gorgeous. This game screams, "Play me, I look fucking amazing." Definitely did something right there.

But as a fighting game, most characters feel the same. Combos look good, but aren't too difficult. But neutral is almost completely missed in many interactions. For those that don't know, neutral is a fighting game concept where both players try to land the first hit (basically). But this game doesn't teach that well. It doesn't introduce you to it well. And if this is your first foray into fighting games, what you learn in this game will not carry over. You will be locked into one playstyle, expect too much leniency on combos, and not have a strong base in fighting game fundamentals. 

The game is a fun game, just not a good fighting game. You can absolutely shit on someone, but if someones better than you, you don't get to play.

Fun, pretty well balanced, and approachable even for complete newcomers to the fighting game genre (like me). The characters in the base game are definitely sufficient to win games against DLC characters. As is typical of ArcSys games, the anime-inspired cel-shaded aesthetic looks great, despite being a game with fully 3d characters and environments. The animations are fluid and flashy, and the combat is fun, even if you have no idea what you're doing.

Ever felt hesitant about buying a fighter game, because you might suck at it, because you do not have a controller, or because the game requires super hard combo's for you to use?

If that's the case, DRAGON BALL FighterZ is the game for you.

DRAGON BALL FighterZ is a game that is essentially easy to learn, but give it some room and it becomes a game that is very hard to master. I myself play with an keyboard, and found it hard at first, give it some time and even with a keyboard, you can do all the combo's you desperately want to.

You do NOT need a controller to play this game, the default keybinds for keyboard are good enough. Obviously, if you want tho change your keybinds, feel free to do so, nobody is stopping you, right?

You can have a windows vista PC and still run this game on the max settings, this game is optimized in.. one of the best ways. No matter if you have a Potato PC, you can still run this beauty with no problem at all.

This game ALSO has a very good OST. Especially one that will give nostalgia if you are a DBZ fan in general.

As mentioned before, this game is a MUST for all the DBZ fans out there. I do have to say that.. putting some of the characters behind paywalls is a shit move, but.. i totally understand that Bandai did this. Gotta make money /shrug

Overall, really nice game, nice story, amazing visuals and OST. And ofcourse the classic DBZ Cast.

Once again, 10/10. (Android 21 still best girl.)

This game is one of the best fighting games I've played. The combos feel rewarding, the game is great for newcomers (the auto combo system tends to ease players in) and has a wide cast of characters from the Dragon Ball universe (aside from 5 Gokus and 3 Vegetas). This game is definitely for those who are looking to get better at fighting games and want take this game seriously online. One gripe I have though, is the story mode. The game has very entertaining cutscenes, however it is FILLED with pointless clone fights that overstay their welcome. I'd rather it be much shorter, but that's my only complaint. Other than that, this game is great and a must have for any fan of Dragon Ball, Fighting games or even UMVC3 (if you suck at that game like I do, then don't worry, this game will definitely feel more natural).

Even though this game has been out for a while, I feel like I should preface this with , it's not a casual-friendly game. This is a deep fighting game developed by ArcSys, so if you're looking for something to mess around with for a few hours and watch some flashy visuals without putting much effort into it, you may want to stick to Xenoverse.

That being said, mechanically, the game is great. Visually wonderful. You can tell a lot of love went into this project. The voice acting is done by the cast of the anime, which is spot on. The story is okay, but it's impressive how long it is. Highly unusual for a fighting game to have a story as long or in depth as this one is, so even if you're not one of those people who is into online play, there is plenty there for you.

 I had a bit of trouble getting my stick to work at first, but steam has upgraded their controller compatibility. No issues anymore.

Netcode is passable for the most part. occasional hiccup playing with someone in the same city as me, but for the most part, I haven't run into many laggy matches. It's nice that there is a large player base, so it's fairly easy to find people at your skill level.

TL:DR
Great game if you're willing to put in the time to learn a fighting game

I'm tired, guys.

I'm tired of getting frame-hacked by Vegito and Gohan.
I'm tired of getting poked by cheeky scrubs who secretly have no clue what they're doing.
I'm tired of the disrespect by aerial launching after death.
I'm tired of lag always favoring the enemy and never me.
I'm tired of being minus on block in every situation no matter what I do.
I'm tired of being yellow and fighting pink players in Casual.
I'm tired of the smartest AI using the medium auto-combo.
I'm tired of Adult Gohan just existing in general.
I'm tired of Videl players thinking her voice actor is any good.

I'm never playing online again. It is the single most biased, unfair online I have ever played in a fighting game, and I fought Bayonetta back when Smash 4 was big. Combat is repetitive and analyzed, and it's only flashy and exciting if you have amazing connection or are playing offline. AI is stupid, especially in Story Mode which is basically a button masher if you can time it right, so offline is no fun. You can't even get Dramatic Finish over and over because the AI is just an impenetrable wall of block half the time unless you cheese them with ki blasts, which might not work if they're at low health, which you'll want them to be.

Story Mode isn't much better. Fighting clone after clone while having characters talking about clone after clone. Sure, there's some funny banter (especially pairing Nappa with Cell), but it's few and far between. And the linking system didn't feel immersive or special, just extremely homosexual. And the villain? Android 21? Boring. Boring and underdeveloped. They hyped her up to be this threatening new foe, but she just amounts to a female Cell. Her personality isn't much better, either. She has two halves, both of which are dumpster fires in execution. Her good half is just Tsubaki Yayoi with a doctorate, and her evil half is just Himiko Toga with a vore fetish. Both bland and tasteless, ironically enough. The only people who are going to like her are the Rule 34 artists and the people who get paid to say they like Dragon Ball. The endings suck, too. The Super Warrior ending feels unsatisfying, and the Enemy Warrior ending is a cliffhanger for some reason, but the Android 21 ending is by far the worst of them all. For those who don't know, Goku chucks a Spirit Bomb at Evil 21, but she's too powerful for some reason. So Good 21 has to sacrifice herself to kill her off. This should have spared Good 21 since Spirit Bombs cannot harm good-natured souls, but for some reason she also dies. Whis goes on about her being a slave to her vore fetish, even though the whole arc is about her overcoming it. And then Goku pulls the Uub card on her by getting King Yemma to reincarnate her, even though that's the worst thing that can happen for everyone. Oh, and if you're wondering what 16 has to say, he doesn't. 21 kills him in all three storylines. He's not even the real 16. He was rebuilt, only to be destroyed later. So he has basically zero purpose in the plot, and his inclusion and relation to 21 is just an excuse to put him in the base game.

I cannot stress this enough. Only, and I mean [b] [i] ONLY [/i] [/b] get this game if you sincerely don't give a single solitary damn about online play. Online play picks favorites. Either you got it, or you don't. It's unforgiving, and it's not fun unless you're the one winning. It's never fair or challenging. Either you win by a landslide, or you get your own butt handed to you on a silver platter. And if you're in the latter category, suck it up. Deal with it. Like I have.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is just like every other fighting game. Play against bots and it seems like the easiest game ever and you wonder to yourself, "Getting rank one shouldn't be that hard?" You get a boost saying, "Holy shit, this is fun I'm destroying these bots." You enter a game and as soon as you click play, you made the worst decision in your life. You have then succumbed to Dragon Ball FighterZ and it is the worst experience in your life. The feeling of not improving and not being able to improve is the absolute worst. The first couple ranks are the easiest things in the universe until you get to Supreme Kai or Demon, you then realize how far behind in skill you are to people. Every once in a while you'll meet another player who is worse than you and resorts to auto-combos. This renders the game unfun because I want to play against someone I can actually improve my skill on and show off my skill I've accumulated throughout the time I've played. I genuinely I'm so sorry for anyone who plays this game religiously. If you're considering buying, picking up, and playing this game. Please second guess to see what other game is on the market because I'm 99% sure there is something else that looks a lot more fun. If you really want this game, by all means go ahead, I wish I could have my money and time back because I really wasted both. I bid you good luck.

DB FighterZ is a 2D fighting gaming. I am a big Dragonball since the original show with Kid Goku. I played most of the DB Games since Budokai 1. This is the second biggest let-down since the ‚ÄòSuper Dragon Ball Z‚Äô game, but it has some good aspects.

Good:
+ excellent graphics and visuals. The best DBZ game so far in this aspect. Most accurate portrayal of the manga stil.
+ excellent fan service ‚Äì character poses, stances, moves and facial expressions are all matching the manga
+ unique character dialogues are funny and consistent with the lore
+ story is not excellent but good for a dragonball game. It's not only the retelling of the saiyan to boo arc. Unique and self-containing story arc.
+ fast paced action brawling ‚Äì you can feel the DBZ speed
+ voice actor's are doing a great job - very authentic

Neutral:
= Roster selection is questionable - Yamcha is in but no Kid Trunks or Goten
= Dialoge options during the story mode fells weird
= Adding of skill/perks ‚Äì like extra damage, health regeneration or exp after the fight

Bad:
- You will begin to use only very few combos and mash them again and again.
- No real individual transformation which stays in that form until Ki runs out - exception is Freeza with his Golden From.
  Transformations are mostly part of a combo and last a few seconds
- 2 season passes for characters (cash-grab) - than you get double characters e.g. 2x Broly‚Äôs (1x DBZ & 1x DBS), even if they have different move- and skill-sets
- All the maps in the story mode always have the same clone fights over and over again
- CPU / AI is very often extermly dull
- Similar ‚Äústory mode‚Äù mechanic than in Budokai 2 where you move your figure across a ‚Äúboard-map‚Äù.  Why did they not fully animate the story, instead we only get the few gorgous animated cutscenes during or after eventful fights.

Conclusion:
I can't recommand this game. Story mode is always same clone fights, AI is stupid, no real transformation mechanic like in older DB games - like the great Budokai 3 or Budokai Tenkaichi 3.

Great fighting game; high skill ceiling and lots of room to get good and improve.

However, I played online match only and it was against a living legend ( basically like a diamond+ level player) and got destroyed by him. It is impossible to find matches on the Canadian west coast online for whatever reason and especially impossible when trying to find someone that's around your skill level if you're just starting out.

Regardless of that it is the best party fighting game of all time and I strongly recommend you buy it and play it with your friends. You can forget about ranked and casual play online because the party mode totally makes up for that.

This is the first Dragon Ball game I played in more than ten years, and it is the very first one I buy myself. Thing is, it wasn't good enough for me, actually the story mode was as boring as hell, I didn't even complete it. It was a mistake buying it. I didn't even enjoy the game mechanics. Four hours of gameplay were more than enough for me to stop playing it. At least I bought it with a discount (70 % if I am not wrong). I stick to Killer Instinct, now that is a good fighting game. 

Maybe I will give this game a second chance some time in the future.

Honestly, the fact that the auto-combos are in the game make it such a great pick up and play with friends. I can practice combos all day and still get stomped by a friend who spams the same moves and for once in a fighting game that's actually acceptable. the reason is just that it's very simple to pick up and so accessible for new players. But then for those who want a bit more from it there are tons of combos to practice and learn after that. It's quite a bit like smash bros in that regard. 

The art style is of course the main attraction in this game, and every animation, fight, scene, and frame looks like a hand painted masterpiece from the anime. Well, maybe that's exaggerating a bit, but the sheer thrill and spectacle of the game makes every hit and move feel over the top and powerful, and oh, so satisfying.  

In the end it's pretty good, would recommend if you like fighting games. Good for playing with friends.

Honestly, i play this game a lot more on ps4. I'm not good at it on there and im not good at it on here either. But let me say this. This game is radical af. The gameplay is smooth and combos are incredibly easy to string together if you know what to do, the characters are balanced for the most part and even character that's bad can still tear a god tier up, and the roster is also incredible. The story leaves a lot to be desired and the match pairing is a bit poor but other than that i have to admit this is one of m favorite games at the moment. Definitely a must have for any fighting game fan or DB fan or literally anyone who enjoy playing games.
Not worth 60$ and I don't like how you have to pay money to get some good characters, but other than that combos are good and playing with friends is fun.

This is an amazing DRAGON BALL game, but i can't recommend it in good conscious when i can't stand playing the fighting game underneath the incredible visuals.

if you want an "accessible" fighting game play SFV or wait for GBV.
What matters isn't the entry barrier, but rather how effectively it teaches fighting game basics, and in my experience DBFZ does not do a particularly good job at that.

I love this game. I'm recommending this game due to it being very approachable to players of all skill levels as well as it being done by Arc System Works. Also for several other reasons but I'm going to list these due to them being my stronger reasons.

1. A TUTORIAL MODE!! This game has a tutorial mode to help grasp the basics of the game and get ya started as well as making the game approachable.

2. The game's structure for combos and gameplay is well balanced and very easy to just pick up and play.

3. Has a very deep structure to the gameplay and combos for your more competitive scene players as well as something for new players to strive for.

4. It has IN-GAME FRAME DATA!! Not many fighting games do this and I'm so glad that FighterZ has done this (although it took a year but, better than never). This allows player to get better at the game without having to hit Google and Youtube real hard.

5. Its fucking Dragonball fellas. If you're a fan of the series you're gonna love this game, even more so if you love fighting games.

6. A FUCKING TUTORIAL MODE!!

Now there are a few niche complaints from me about it, but I'm able to look past them a bit and they shouldn't be takin' too seriously due to them not ruining the entire experience of the game for me. Then again its up to your preference if it deters you from gettin' it.

1. RAGE QUITTERS are not penalized for shit. As well as you won't get the win or Battle Points (BP) to rank up in Ranked if they rage quit before the K.O.

2. A lot of representation of Goku in the game. Goku SS, Goku SSB, Goku Base, Goku GT. There could've been a different way to approach this, but I'm not sure. I just know we didn't need 4 different iterations of Goku taking up character slots. 

3. The game is a bit slow on the uptake when it comes to balance patches and other things. The Game is getting more and more balanced as well as tuned, but its quite slow to do so.

Overall I give the game a 9 out of 10 and highly recommend to players who love Dragonball, fighting games, and new players who want to start their first fighting game.

DRAGON BALL FighterZ is a fantastic fighting game whether you're a beginner or an expert. With automatic combos and flashy cinematics to make newcomers feel like badasses and a deep system for 'true' combos that veteran fighting game players will enjoy, this game seems to have successfully bridged the gap between casual and competitive.

Every special move in the game is a quarter-circle forward or back and then one button press. That may seem like a turn-off to some, but understand that the game's rich combo system more than makes up for it. No amount of dash spamming or auto-comboing will let a newbie cheap out a good player, and that's where I think this game truly succeeds.

The story is pretty decent, too. Don't expect anything great, as it's very derivative, but that's what most should expect when picking up a game with the Dragon Ball name. The first arc is a glorified tutorial and isn't especially good, the second arc is substantially better, and the third arc is the only one with any true character progression behind it. Android 21 starts off feeling like a fanfiction character but definitely comes into her own by the end of the story.

I'm also with the majority of DBZ fans in preferring the English dub to the Japanese due to certain voices just sounding.. off (70 year old woman Goku, generic bad guy Cell, etc), but certain voices in the dub definitely underperform. Vegeta's battle lines sound a little goofy, and Android 21's voice actress sounds like she's never had a villain role before in her life. Either way, both choices are solid and don't matter too much to begin with.

TL;DR, FighterZ is a good fighting game and a good Dragon Ball game. Get it.

DBFZ is an easy-to-learn but hard-to-master fighting game with outstanding art, tight controls, a simple and free-form combo system, and some of the most exciting combat I've ever seen in a videogame. Overall, I don't know what more someone could ask for from a fighting game.

Whether you are a fan of team-based fighters like Marvel, fast-paced aerial combat like BlazBlue, or the intense neutral game of Street Fighter, I think DBFZ has something to offer that you will enjoy. If you like fighters, then you'll like FighterZ.

By far my most favourite game of all time, this is the first "real" fighting game I've played, otherwise I've just been playing smash bros. which doesn't have any real "moves" if you can call it that, and when I first started I fell in love instantly, visually everything is really nice to look at, you've got the smaller details like dramatic finishes which reenacts scenes from the animes (some fan moments people wanted like Yamcha, vs Nappa) and the combat system is really good.

I decided to get at least 100 hours played before I gave this game any sort of review.

The actual fighting game play is both fun to play and watch. But that's where the fun ends. The online options for play are severely limited by an ill-conceived lobby system. The netcode still needs work as well. There's no telling how long it may take to find a match during peak hours (If there's a port that needs to be open - I am still unaware of it), and if your opponent is even fun to play against. They may even choose to drop after the first match as well, plunging you back into the abyss of wait times.

The single player experience, in theory, should make up for this in some regard. It does not. Arcade mode rely's on artificial difficulty ramping (More HP, Damage, Meter Gain for CPU) instead of utilizing a more skilled AI. The single player tournament mode confirms that there's a high difficulty AI - and while it may never compare to a player, it still cheapens the experience of the Arcade which yields rewards to be spent on unlockables.

Finally, there is too much repetitious use of Goku as a character. With such a wide range of characters in the Dragon Ball universe they could have branched out much further. 

I can't recommend this game as it is right now. It's making baby steps but It's a year old now and it needs to learn how to walk. When it's core is fixed (Online Play - You don't get these games to play by yourself.) it'll be much better.

[h1] Short Summary: [/h1]

FighterZ is a gorgeous looking game that has obviously has a lot of love put into it. It's easy to pick up for newcomers to the fighting genre yet still offers a high skill ceiling as a result of the 3v3 fighter mechanic. The story is repetitive yet there are some neat little interactions between characters.

[b] Main Review: [/b]

[u] Core Fighting Mechanics: [/u]

I'm not a seasoned veteran of fighting games. In fact in the community I might just manage to scratch into being called average. So take what I say with a dose of salt if you are deep into the FGC.

The basic fighting mechanics are easy to pick up. You pick three characters for each match. The move pool for each character is a bit smaller than most games but this is made up with the massive options for interactions between the characters as you switch in for assists and super moves. The sparking mechanic that adds a bit of healing to the game allows for some great close matches and comebacks. The game is filled with what are called auto-combos where a repeated button press will launch a flashy combo. As you progress you'll learn to interrupt these basic combos with teleports and ground slams in order to get of super moves. You'll intersperce the combos with some of the basic special moves and for a while as you learn the opponents animations and this will be enough. Then you'll learn about manuals and how to do jump cancels to extend combos and use assists for denials and further extensions. Then you'll spend time learning each of the characters strengths and the roles they play in teams.

There is a very high skill ceiling to this game and it is still  one of the easiest games to get started in.

[u] Visuals [/u]

What can I say. The trailers and footage speaks for itself. Visually speaking this game is a near masterpiece. It captures the exuberance and power from the show and manga so effortlessly. Special beams and moves are animated with such care and attention to detail seeing all the little details while you play is a joy in and of itself. Each character feels utterly different to play just because of how they have managed to capture fighting styles direct from the show.

[u] Story [/u]

The story is the biggest let down in the game. Its fairly generic and the campaign itself is very repetitive having you fight shadow clone after shadow clone. The tutorial also needlessly drags on and repeats itself. The saving grace to the story is that it is full of these little moments of character interaction that is driven byt the characters you choose to have on your team leading to some interesting and unexpected moments.

[u] Misc Features [/u]

The menu is set in a little arena where you run around as miniature versions of the shows characters. You have options for story, and ranked and casual multiplayer as expected. You also have arcade mode which is a challenge of increasingly difficult AI in a row. You also have a local multiplayer area which has most of the customisation options you normally get such as round length and tournament brackets.

For other multiplayer options you can set up little rooms in this hub where people can join and spectate and participate in winner stays on matches. There is also a public fighting ring in each lobby where other members can join and fight but this mostly goes unused.

There are no microtransactions in the game. The game rewards you with a currency which can be used to buy capsules that contain random cosmetics for your lobby character. Any repeats  you get net you with a secondary currency that can be used to buy a capsule that guarantees no duplicates.

[u] DLC/Patches [/u]

So far there there is one completed season of characters and a second ongoing season. These characters have been good additions to the game with them all having unique play styles and feeling different to play. And with these characters have come some necessary balancing to the characters overtime to buff here and nerf there. As someone who isn't skilled enough I can't comment on how balanced the game currently is but there has been a decent amount of updates that have been addressing balance issues.

[u] Conclusion [/u]

As said above I have gotten a lot of enjoyment out of the game and the mechanics and visuals consistently draw me back in for a match or two when I have a few free minutes.

A review from someone that is slowly coming up on 100 hours in this game.
Dragon ball fighterz is a 3vs3 anime style fighter with a heavy emphasis on offence, you will spend most of your time vanishing, super dashing, and getting down heavied. For the first 30 or so hours of the game you will, at least in my experience, be completely shit a wont win a single online match against anyone with a colour higher than blue (this a colour based system showing how well you do against players of the same rank: blue bad light blue mediocre green/light green medium yellow ok orange good pink great). This game is primarily you training to get better at online matches over a long period of time, if this isn't your kind of thing then this game isn't for you, as the story and arcade are lackluster at best. The menu is fairly unintuitive (a lobby rather than regular menu), but this setup works well for online as you can challenge other players to ring matches, and have short conversations via the z-stamps and emotes. The netcode is solid and the online matches, that the game is so geared towards are very good, though don't expect anything less than at least 2 frames worth of delay for most matches, also if your opponent rage quits at the end of a ranked match (if you've already killed them) then you will still be awarded a win, which is nice. It would also be nice if the ps4 controller was fully supported in terms of button prompts etc, and the monetization strategy of multiple season passes is abhorent, and if i wasn't so invested in the game, I wouldn't even participate in it.
Overall apart from a few grevences this game is brilliant, if you like the online aspect of fighting games, and are willing to re-learn you neutral game (if you play other fighters).

TL;DR
Good online, beautiful graphics, ok music, terrible dlc practices(it's a fighting game what do you expect), easy to learn for new comers to fighting games

Most of the typical modes are here, the practice tutorials are as good as is expected in most modern fighters now.  The story mode is kinda bad but the banter between characters makes up for it, a lot of amusing fan service.

Definitely my favourite fighting game of all time. On top of my Steam hours, I have hundreds of hours on Xbox too, cos I've been playing since release.
The factor that separates it from the average fighting game is the speed. Super Dashing makes it fast to close the gap between you and your opponent, not coming without risk of course. Plus, you don't have to spend your time learning all these insane commands to pull off supers. Unlike in other games, the challenge isn't pulling off the super attacks, but using them in the best way possible. Using your assists to set up combos using your supers, or even chaining your supers to theirs is also a major part of the game.
Matchmaking is quick, modes are all a lot of fun (including the ones that have unfortunately been deserted due to the playerbase declining), and each character feels completely different in terms of weight, height, mobility, abilities and how their combos suit you.

Definitely worth a play, it's the simplest, most-accessible fighting game to start playing by far, but it definitely has a lot to master.

Gohan society rise up

Yes he could have. The original Funimation dub stated that Kid Buu was stronger than Super Buu, but that was only a line in the dub. The truth is that while it‚Äôs not outright stated, Kid Buu is the second weakest form of Majin Buu.

Goku stated that even if he tried when he fought Majin Buu, he could not have defeated him. He also stated that even if he and Vegeta freed everyone who was absorbed by Buu, the two of them would not have been able to beat him. On the other hand, he did say that at as Super Saiyan 3 he could possibly have killed Kid Buu.

Also in the manga it was stated that when Fat Buu spawned Evil Buu, contrary to what the original Funimation dub said, his power was actually split between the two of them, with Evil Buu of course getting most of it. And Fat Buu actually managed to do better against Kid Buu than he did against Evil Buu.

So all this points to Kid Buu being weaker than Evil Buu, who was weaker than base Super Buu. Base Super Buu, who when he went up against Mystic Gohan, got utterly floored and would have been killed if he didn‚Äôt cheat, pull out his absorption powers, and then Gotenks stupidly got involved and got absorbed rather than letting Gohan handle things.

Hell Goku openly stated in the manga that once Gotenks split inside Super Buu, that without Gotenks‚Äô power that Buu would not be strong enough to beat Gohan. This was despite Gohan getting weaker from the beating he took from Buu.

So in short, Gohan could have killed Super Buu, or Kid Buu, if he had actually been allowed to do it and not robbed of the chance by Buu‚Äôs plot armor.

Played a very small amount of KOF, BB UNIEL/ST but never really invested in any of them, so this could be considered my first proper FG.

Gameplay 
So as a 3v3 hyper fighter game like Marvel vs Capcom games, it has it's fair share of speed, bizarre and overflowing screen elements in the heat of battle which can be hard to keep track of if you're new; the gameplay speed is relatively fast compared to most other FGs and this can be daunting (it especially was for me) but within time you get used to it. Combo wise it starts off relatively simple with auto combos and the like but there is depth to it (and of course, loops). Some say the defence mechanics went from lackluster to borderline broken at the time of writing this, but at a casual level its impact is limited. Touch of Death (ToD/1 shot) combos are present, but the majority require practice and timing to pull off and use a good amount of resources and can only be realistically performed once per match making them quite risky, and therefore balanced. 1v3 comebacks happen quite frequently, and to some extent even in pro play which means they're even more of a gamble.
Graphics -
For the 1000th time, it really is just like playing/watching the anime at times and the graphics really are just THAT good, ArcSystemWorks know how to make both 2D and 2.5D graphics look stunning and easily make this the most attractive fighting game yet. 
Music - So many good soundtracks, but sadly the anime packs are rather pricey for being looped instrumental versions of many iconic songs
9/10

[h1]Short version:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Gorgeous and smooth at 60fps
[*]Gameplay is balanced and superb
[*]A true competitive fighter, but also casual-friendly
[*]Tons of fan-favorite characters and voices
[*]Tons of nods and easter eggs that true fans will notice
[*]Plenty of both offline and online content
[*]Lots of active players online of all skill types
[*]Developers that listen and patch/fix promptly
[/list]
The best Dragonball Z game ever made, hands down. This is the game I waited 20 years for.  9.9/10

[h1]Long version:[/h1]

From the moment you start playing, it will be immediately obvious that the developers are huge fans of the show. Every voice actor is represented, both Japanese and English, and every character uniquely represents how they fight in the anime. No matter who your favorite character is, you will find yourself admitting how badass every character in DBZ is, even down to the 'weaklings'. Putting this game side-by-side with the anime, the difference is practically indistinguishable. On maximum graphics, the game is absolutely gorgeous, and runs like a dream at 60fps.

The roster is pretty much what you would expect, all of the favorites are here from the original Z-fighter gang, as well as quite a few Dragonball Super and (non-canon) DBZ movie characters. Fan favorites like Jiren and Brolly have been added in DLC, and there are rumours of even more obscure favorites like Master Roshi and Janemba. The attention to detail on the characters is staggering, down to characters trash talking each other by name, and special cinematic endings if lore-specific situations occur. [spoiler] Example: Beat Frieza with SSJ Goku on Planet Namek. [/spoiler]

The core gameplay is a 3v3 tag fighter, reminiscient of games like Marvel VS Capcom 3. Personally I did not know what to think of this going in, as I had never played a tag fighter before (other than a few hours of skullgirls), but it actually works amazing with the DBZ universe. The intensity of the battles gets downright insane at moments, and to the untrained eye, it can sometimes be hard to even tell what is happening (lots of cool explosions, teleports, etc).

The combat is extremely deep, and is a true competitive fighting game. Just look at tournament play and you will see how high the skill ceiling can be. Even after hundreds or thousands of hours you will be finding new combos, new setups, etc. This is one of the only fighting games I have genuinely had fun in training mode with, finding new combo routes and tinkering with my team synergy.

That being said, you don't need to be a pro to enjoy this game. There is a brilliant "auto-combo" system that lets you mash  single buttons and get (non-optimal) full combos, including a knockdown and even automatically triggering a super (if desired). With the auto-combo system you can skip memorizing and practicing combos and get straight into learning team synergy, advanced techniques, etc. Once you're ready, it is pretty easy to transition from auto-combos into real ones. I consider myself an intermediate, and I use both real and auto-combos, depending on the character/combo.

The story is a breath of fresh air compared to most other DBZ games and isn't just playing through the anime sagas in order like most other games in the past have lazily done. The story does get a bit repetitive later in the game, as it sometimes requires upwards of 20-30 fights before getting a cutscene that contains actual story. A minor complaint considering the fights are the main part of the game anyway.

There is plenty of offline and online content, and a lot of creative modes if you have friends to play with. 6-player ring fight mode is particularly crazy, with each person controlling one individual Z-fighter. Every few weeks or so there are temporary challenges, such as 3 players teaming up to beat a (very strong) AI opponent. I mainly stick to the online ranked and matchmaking, but have had fun with every single mode I've tried.

Speaking of online, the netcode is excellent, and even very bad connections are usually at least playable. I have heard others complain about it being delay-based instead of rollback, but personally I prefer delay-based netcode. As far as I know, it's the same netcode as the Guilty Gear games.

Finally, the amount of content being added and tweaked is outstanding. The developers are funding tournament leagues while also adding a new character roughly every month or two. All of the balance patches have generally been received by the community as positive, and there are only a couple characters that aren't considered tournament viable (and they aren't who you probably think they are).

Literally the only reason I cannot give this a 10/10 is the menu system. It seems Dragonball Z games will be forever cursed to have some confusing menus (and hub-based online). Changing your team loadout can be a little bit confusing at times, and customizing things like emotes is downright challenging to figure out. This is such a minor detail that I'm only taking off 0.1.

If you're a Dragon Ball fan you already know the answer. If you're not comfortable with fighting games I would still recommend this game too. But this review is from the perspective of a Tekken (and Street Fighter, I can hear the booing already) player who enjoys the complexity of fighting games.

So as a Fighting game enthusiast I had picked this up because a friend of mine was interested in playing it. He said he wanted to play this because Street Fighter among other games had inputs that didn't make sense to him and were difficult to pull off in a pinch. Plus he was a fan of Dragon Ball.

He told me about this game and how it was easier to play thanks to not needing complex directional inputs and not having to spend (too much) time learning combos. I decided I'd try it and I like it a lot, but can't help but miss those Tekken/Street Fighter style inputs. However, I can still enjoy this game, and I think you might too. I'll be honest I've never had so much fun playing something I DIDN'T know how to play.

Dragon Ball FighterZ seems to be flexible enough accommodate both a competitive scene and a large casual community, so it's a great place to start loving fighting games, especially if you already love the characters themselves. The controls are simple enough, and auto combos put much less stress on needing to pull off combos and more so on opening up your opponent in the first place. Trust me, whiff punishing in this game is super easy on top of that, so this game condenses all the barrier of entry down to smart decision making.

In all honesty, I think competitive dragonball is a joke compared to tekken or even street fighter but I wouldn't blame someone for taking this game seriously and getting into the grind to get better. The community has found a number of...well, exploits that still expand the gameplay of the game into the next level and allow for professional and expressive play. It's now a part of the FGC and a very welcome part of it (after all Melee got there like the exact same way). This probably won't become your "main game" if you already play a more true fighting game, but it's a killer game to have at a party. Especially if lots of your party goers aren't into fighting games.

[h1]Before ignoring my review because it is negative, please take a look at my time spent playing DBFZ. I gave it a fair chance but it wasn't for me.[/h1]

[b]Positives[/b]
[list]
[*] The game is amazing-looking.
[*] Well-optimized, runs pretty well even at 4K.
[/list]
[b]Negatives[/b]
[list]
[*] The online lobbies are a step back from both BBCF [i]and[/i] DBFZ. Can't invite a friend to a room without joining the same online server first, it's dumb as hell.
[*] Combo trials are a joke. Every character gets 10 and 3 are always "mash autocombo" by default. Might as well not have included them.
[*] No equivalent to M.O.M. mode from GG Xrd or Grim of Abyss from BBCF. Only Story Mode, Arcade, and that's it for single player content. Even SFV has Score Attack SMH.
[*] Gameplay-wise the base game had the most bland cast of characters I've ever seen in a fighting game. Since combos were pretty much the same across the board, everything boiled down to tiers.
[*] Season Pass 1 characters were more interesting to play but frankly I still find insulting to charge people for base Goku and Vegeta.
[*] Superdash renders zoning useless in this game, might as well call the game Rushdown Simulator Z. As a result, the neutral game is boring and unengaging.
[/list]
I was hoping for Season Pass 2 to address some of these problems but it actually managed to widen the gap between the top and bottom tiers. The game was fun for the first 30 hours but it grew stale extremely quickly. All style but no substance.

This is my first fighting game produced from a company that is a household name in the FGC Community and I'm glad they branched out into Dragon Ball to pique my interest. The shaders, attention to detail and the way Arc Systems strives to fight for accuracy within the smallest of movements is a masterpiece. 

The game possesses dramatic finishes, a unique cinematic rewarded to the player for completing a K.O on the final member of someones team with a specific character. My only critique is that they decide to change these finshers so that you can't skip them, as I have pulled them off only twice in about 200 hours over console and PC. 

Here is a comprehensive list of Dramatic Finishes and the stage you need to attain them: (Note, you must use a heavy or vanish attack to trigger these!!!)
Teen Gohan Vs Cell in Cell Games Arena,  SSGoku can't be on either team.
Beerus Vs Goku in Space	 .
SSGoku Vs Frieza in Planet Namek (Destroyed)
Trunks Vs Frieza in Rocky Field (Noon)
Yamcha Vs Nappa in Rocky Field (Noon)	 
Nappa Vs Yamcha in Rocky Field (Noon)	 
Goku Vs Kid Buu in Land of the Kai's	 
Beerus Vs Goku Black in Any stage! (Goku Black needs to be below 10% health to initiate a special cinematic that isn't a dramatic finish, and Black doesn't need to be the last character.)
Yamcha Vs Nappa in Rocky Field (Noon)	 
Bardock VS Frieza in Space
Frieza Vs Bardock in Space	 
Goku Vs Broly in Space	 
Adult Gohan Vs Broly in Wasteland	 
Vegito Vs Zamasu in Destroyed West City	 
Trunks Vs Zamasu in Destroyed West City	 
Beerus Vs Zamasu in Any stage! (This is the same as Goku Black, get him to 10% or below health for a small cinematic down.)
Base Goku Vs Base Vegeta in Rocky Field (Noon)	 
Base Goku Vs Frieza in Planet Namek

These finishers are all cinematic beauties, and I strongly recommend watching them as a Dragon Ball fan or FGC member!

First of all, before I review this game, I want to say that if you are a Dragon Ball fan, this game is a [b]MUST HAVE[/b]!

I will make this review as arranged as possible, so I will divide it in different sections and all of them will have their [b]Pros[/b] and their [b]Cons[/b]:

[u]Gameplay[/u]

[b]Pros[/b]: The [u]Gameplay[/u] of this game (3v3 Arcade) is actually really good, including three types of combos (Light, Medium and Heavy) that can be changed with practice and make them deal more damage. Every single character has their own combos, super attacks and ultimates, these two last ones can even have variations. The graphics are good having in mind that this is an arcade game and doesn't need to have the best ones to look beautiful - it already does, and it makes you experience a real Dragon Ball fight, like in the anime!

[b]Cons[/b]: The medium combo is a good combo for starters, but it becomes stressful as it's an autocombo that can be spammed over and over in battles. When you reach become a good player and play against other good players, you can get 70% (or more) of you character's health just with a combo that started by your fault for not countering or blocking the first hit of that combo - which can be painful when you are nervous. Also, keep in mind that you will find a lot of ragequitters, which won't even get punished for it - they will just have their names in purple.

[u]Gamemodes[/u]:

[b]Pros[/b]: This game has a good amount of gamemodes, including: Story; Arcade, in which you defeat several oponents (offline) and try to get the best rank possible; Training, that is the best gamemode to practice and make better your skills; and Informal & Competitive Matches. Then there are other interactions such as the arena matches and the ring matches, that match you with people in your lobby.

[b]Cons[/b]: I can't really tell any Con for this section, you can't add much more to the actual gamemodes (maybe a Raid gamemode, but might not be as good as I think), so that's it for this section.

[u]Story[/u]:

[b]Pros[/b]: The story of this game is something new, talking about the Android 21 who is an Android and can transform into a Majin. Summarizing, the story is divided in three parts, the Good Guys one, the Bad Guys one and the Androids one, all of them with different endings and different playable characters. 

[b]Cons[/b]: It's not very well done and get boring especially in the Bad Guys part because all you do is defeat useless bots that can't even touch you... And the worst thing is that to play with Android 21 you have to complete all the three parts. I feel like this is one of the worst Dragon Ball stories in games... Really Disappointed!

[u]Characters[/u]:

[b]Pros[/b]: This game has a really extense variety of characters and colors of themselves (these last ones can be bought in the store for a good price) and like I said before each one of them has their one moves, supers and ultimate attacks. You won't get bored trying to main all of the characters and trying to make combinations for making the team that suits you well and makes you win a lot of matches! Another good thing is that new characters have been released such as Bardock, which make a even bigger character roster.

[b]Cons[/b]: The only cons that I find in this section is the fact that you have to complete all the story mode to play with Android 21 and that some characters are better than others (talking about skills).

So this was my Dragon Ball FighterZ review! Hope you liked it and that it could help you decide if you should buy this game or not, even though I'm missing some things.

As I said at the start of the review this game is a [b]MUST HAVE[/b] if you love Dragon Ball, hope you like it!

Let me start off with this: I want [i] Dragon Ball FighterZ [/i] to succeed in every way, shape, and form possible; both critically for the foreseeable future and commercially going forward.

So taking this into account, my mixed feelings after 8 hours of play have left me feeling somewhat disillusioned.

Lets start off with the good before getting into some problems with [i] FighterZ [/i] which need to be addressed ASAP, and some on which I think [i] Arc Sys [/i] screwed the pooch:

[h1] The Good [/h1]

[i] Arc [/i] has created a brilliant, fluid, and sonically paced fighter with the Dragon Ball IP which we've been waiting for for a bloody long time. As much as I love games like [i] Budokai 3 [/i] on one end and [i] Xenoverse 2 [/i] (perhaps a little reluctantly) on the other, [i] FighterZ [/i] is a completely different breed of fighter. I see a great deal of reviews bashing [i] FighterZ [/i] for being far too button-mashy, subsequently calling out the [i] Budokai [/i] games as having done it better. With this I can't help but laugh; Budokai's universal combo-set and [A] (or [X] if you're on Playstation) dodge/block function practically tore through three of my controllers. 

Now this is not to say [i] Budokai [/i] wasn't a shitload of fun, but that's because it NAILED the power fanatsy of DBZ and had a relatively low barrier to entry. But we needed something a little more complex; something that could actually be taken online or to couch parties, where practice shone through and those long combos actually took some semblance of skill. A game where each character played quite distinctly and you could work your way to mastering your favourite members of the [i] Dragon Ball [/i] roster (and I'm sure there'll be more to come... hopefully...). As far s comparisons to [i] Xenoverse 2 [/i] go, this is a completey different game, but I'll admit that it doesn't quite carry the same fanfare and customizability.

[i] FighterZ [/i] is an outstandingly gorgeous game when you're in combat, though the cinematics leave a little to be desired at times. Soundtrack wise, the [i] FighterZ [/i] OST is an absolute romp and just adds to the fast-paced combat of FZ. 

However, there are a couple elephants in the room...

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Firstly, with the exception of a few unique interactions between different party combinations, the likes of which can be hilarious at times, something about the cutscene animation in FZ is a little off-putting. But this gripe pales in comparison to the content of these cutscenes. I'll be blunt about this: [b] FZ's story mode is ABSOLUTE GARBAGE. [/b] With cliches galore, it is terribly boring and provides the most lacklustre character introduction (though Android 21 is pretty rad as a character) I've experienced in a [i] Dragon Ball [/i] game. In addition to this, about 50% of the story mode is mind-numbingly boring due to the ease of your opponents, before eventually scaling up a bit, at which point it's too little too late. [b] It is repetitive and wholly uninteresting. [/b]

[b] "BUT THE STORY ISN'T WHAT YOU PLAY FIGHTERZ FOR! ITS THAT SWEET, HIGHLY COMPETITIVE ONLINE COMBAT!" [/b]

Time to start calling out the pachyderms... 

Firstly, [i] Arc Sys [/i] needs to fix its goddamn netcode! Playing FZ out here in South Africa without any local severs, I've been feeling this gripe that some have had pretty hard; it is nigh impossible to maintain anything of a stable connection so multiplayer is a bit of a pipedream... but there's one thing which exacerbates this further:

As I'm sure anyone who has yet to purchase FZ, doing their due dilligence before dropping that hard-earned cash, will have seen it over the last couple of days: [b] Dragon Ball FighterZ has hemorrhaged 80% of its once bragged-about playerbase! [/b]
When it comes to this wee slip-up, I think there's a perfectly reasonable explanation (in addition to the shitty netcode) for this loss in interest: [b] Dragon Ball FighterZ has abosultely nothing resembling a compelling progression system (and no, new character palettes and lobby avatars are not sufficient). [/b] Some might say that you see personal progression, mastering character combos and whatnot. In this sense, FZ is a pretty bog-standard fighting game. However, surely there needs to be something more to entice play, especially when one needs to take things offline. Hell, even new character models or outfits, new skillsets perhaps, might be sufficient. As it stands though, FZ just feels pretty tedious when you're not testing your skills in ranked matches.

Despite the scathing criticism above, I'm still giving [i] FighterZ [/i] a thumbs up. Mechanically (in combat), DBFZ is an outstanding fighter! I wish more than anything that this mass exodus had not taken place, but [b] Dragon Ball FighterZ needs more content in order to keep community interest afloat! [/b] Some might consider a game like [i] Injustice 2 [/i] a relatively bog-standard fighter, but i'm convinced that its gear system made a world of difference to the game's longevity.

Consider this review more of a warning than anything else. If things don't improve netcode and interest-wise, [i] FighterZ [/i] will be dead in the water before we know it. [i] Arc Sys [/i] and [i] Bandai Namco [/i] need to get on it! Maybe consider watching the space before dropping your cashmunies on this one if you've not yet. And though this is terribly futile, [i] Bandai, [/i] maybe consider give us an SA server?

[h1] Update [/h1]

You know what... After playing for a bit longer this afternoon, I came to the pretty obvious realisation that I can't recommend a game that I can hardly play (online).

I've gone from trying to see the virtues of this game, offering praise where it is due, to resenting my decision to pre-order this game and to give online multiplayer (without local servers) a bash again. I suppose I was trying to justify spending an absurd amount of money before doing the due dilligence I recommended above.

I'm gonna stick with [i] Xenoverse 2. [/i] It's certainly got its flaws, but at least offline is an option. It scatches that Dragon Ball itch (heh heh)... At least more than FZ has in my hours of incredibly dodgy connection, server issues, and a dead playerbase.

Poes. (lets see if Steam gets that one)

[h1] Update 2 [/h1]

So it's about a full year later and, in Vietnam of all places, I've finally got the internet connection necessary to play FighterZ properly. Mind you, I'm absolutely shit at it, but I won't let my salt and nerd-rage cloud my judgement. This is a [b] DAMN FINE [/b] fighter!
