before I get down into the details I'm gonna give you a quick disclaimer - I absolutely love this game. after playing it baked a few times with a friend I finally picked it up for myself in may. had never played a single fighting game in my life, much less seen anything of the show. I now do both. I'll list pros and cons at length below, but the short version is this: dbfz is visually gorgeous, easy to learn (for ANYONE, not just people who play fighting games), extremely difficult to master, and endlessly entertaining.

cons first, because while the game isn't perfect it has a lot more going for it than the cons list makes it seem.

cons:
-if you're a cheapass like me, $60 plus all the dlc seems a bit steep, and the game doesn't go on sale often
-casual matchmaking tends to be much harder than competitive because people have ladder anxiety
-you ~can~ play online with a wireless connection, but it's gonna hurt. an extra $5 for an ethernet cable is highly recommended
-netplay, especially at high ranks, tends to have more than a few ragequitters who will auto-disconnect if they think they're about to lose. PROTIP, never do this. your ego may be bruised while you learn the game but if you don't go out and get bodied by better players you'll never improve
-fighting games tend to be most popular on PS4 so depending on where you live, matchmaking may not be as lively as other games depending on time of day
-story mode is pretty dull but you have to finish it to get android 21 (she's not amazing though, so don't go out of your way for it)
-you don't HAVE to buy the dlc, but a lot of dlc chars (namely bardock, vegito, arguably broly) are really good and you'll be annoyed running into them in netplay after a while if you don't know how to play them
THAT BEING SAID,

pros
-visually and stylistically, this is the best looking fighting game on the market (better than MK11 too, fight me)
-if you're a fan of the show there are tons of little nods scattered around for you to enjoy
-if you're not a fan of the show, it won't hurt your ability to enjoy the game in the slightest
-this game is really easy to pick up for a first-time FG player, the tutorials are solid and there's tons of resources (i recommend turtle hermit school) online to help
-unlike most other fighting games (MKX, SFV, etc) DBFZ is much more rewarding of aggression and doesn't force you to sit patiently and play neutral for long periods of time
-super moves look kickass, and combos are pretty easy to start learning and really rewarding to execute
-the professional scene for this game is pretty sizeable right now and IMO it'll only get bigger. for first timers, i highly recommend you watch a few pro matches now and then.
-again if you like dragon ball there's so much in here to enjoy. the attention to detail arcsys put into this game is really incredible, all the moves each character has are pulled from things they actually did on the show/movies, and ngl it's really fun to run your favorite characters
-if you're thinking about it even a little, honestly buy the game. i'll warn you that fighting games require patience and practice and if it's your first one it may take a while to develop those skills, but god damn if it isn't worth it.

I love DBZ. I love fighting games.
I love the old DBZ games.
and-
I love this game.

If you are into Fighting Games, want to take one seriously, and love DBZ, then stop reading this and buy this game immediately. Like right now. Leave. I am done talking to you.

If you're not all of the above then know that the game can turn off certain people. I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.

I recommend this game if you:
- Are a fan of DBZ
AND EITHER
- Are interested in diving into competitive fighting games
OR
- Have one or more friends to play local matches against


==============

[b]Why I wouldn't recommend this to people who are ONLY fans of DBZ[/b]

[h1]What you can enjoy as a fan of DBZ who doesn't like competitive Fighting Games[/h1]

[list]
[*]The game is absolutely stunning. Best looking DBZ game ever made. It's very. very much like watching the anime(with consistently excellent animation).

[*]Dramatic Finishes and Dramatic Entrances reenact iconic moments in DBZ before and after matches.

[*]The story mode includes unlockable special character interactions with eachother as well as the player. Seriously. There is Tiencha-grade fanservice in this game if you can find it. It's awesome.

[*]The combat is very beginner-friendly(as far as fighting games go). You can easily pull off satisfying combos and specials.

[*]If you and a friend are of equal skill level, fights will be super fun. No matter the skill level, fights of two people around the same level can be intense and satisfying. Even for two complete beginners.
[/list]


[h1]What you probably won't enjoy:[/h1]

[list]
[*]Unlocking the fantastic character interactions isn't easy, and is very boring to do. You need to start certain fights with certain characters on your team for some. For others, you need to play enough with a specific character in your team. It will feel like a grind if you're looking to see them all for yourself.

[*]The story mode is irredeemably poorly designed. The story mode will feel like a grind rather quickly if you're in it for the story.

[*]The story is relatively uninteresting. It does not retell or expand upon the story of DBZ like games of old. It tells its own story which, in my opinion, feels like an excuse to get you into fights constantly to pad the story time.
[/list]

==============

[h1]In Summary[/h1]

The single player content is not well designed. It will not be fun for long. 
If you're expecting a fun single player story driven experience like Uncharted, do not buy.
If you have friends to tag along on the ride who are interested, consider picking it up.

But the multiplayer.
The multiplayer has infinite potential just like any fighting game, but you're gonna have to have that competitive drive and willingness to grind as all fighting games require.
This is the first game that got me to actually train at a competitive fighting game.
Love it to bits.

[b]Its mf-in ki-blastin' Dragonball baby. LET'S GO[/b]

I've received the product for free (play for free), played few hours, understood nothing and then I got the idea, got a rush of adrenaline so I bought it. However, I have had a problem, buying the game twice. Since it was a Play For Free installation, then Steam didn't allowed me to buy the game and accidentally, I purchased twice, but Steam refunded me because of that reason. So keep that in mind and don't blow up anything. 

If you get an error code 20006, is because EasyAntiCheat is disabled. To fix that, go to the loupe in your window task and search for Services, inside there look for Easy AntiCheat, double click and set to "manual". It also works with Ghost Recon Wildlands. Also, if you get an Steam API error is probably due Comodo sandboxing it. Go to Comodo icon in the task bar, unfold the menu and set Autosandbox to deactivated.

I really regret having spent money on this game.

There is no place for beginners in this game. The combat system encourages long strings where one player can do nothing other than wait until their opponent is done pounding them. For someone who hasn't played a fighting game since SF2, it is nearly impossible to overcome the learning curve.

The online matach-making system is terrible, especially on PC where the total number of players seems lower. You will find yourself matched with players vastly better than you no matter how much you lose or rank down. The barrier to entry in this game is incredibly steep, so be prepared to either spend all day practicing or just accept you are gonna be a punching bag.

If I could get my money back on this game, I'd do it today.

Long Story Short: Hell of a blast to play through.

-Story mode is hit and miss but still pretty cool and progressively harder AI for training.
-Online multiplayer battles are the majority of the time pretty awesome, only minor connection errors on my side, though when it does lag, inputs are majorly delayed and can lead to a one-sided loss.
-Raids with friends are a cool bonus.
-Recent nerfs and buffs to characters don't ruin the game.
-Already gorgeous visuals and animations to imitate the manga and anime.
-Easy to use combos while also rewarding the more difficult combos to pull off. Somewhat frustating at times, but only due to my button mashing nature.

I'd rate this an easy 85/100

An ode to comeptitive fighters. While certainly not the most complex and satisfying 2D fighter to learn, there is still much to see with FighterZ. Besides the gorgeous visuals, the amazing soundtrack there is still a charm to the gameplay that cannot be denied. While at its core, it is very simple with new players to the genre in mind, there is still a level of complexity within its mechanics that can take some time to truly perfect. Mixing the in-game mechanics with techniques straight from the source material, there is a really flashy time to be had. 

Having played this game extensively in most consoles, I can say I'm very satisfied with the performance on the PC. Although my personal machine isn't exactly top of the line, I still manage to get a very consistent 60 FPS on the highest settings without so much of a stutter. However, there seems to be quite a lot of issues with the online connection and I have tested with multiple options. 

Beginners can use this as their stepping stone to move on to more "household names" in the competitive scene, but I think that anyone willing to learn the game (even if you're a complete beginner or an experienced EVO contender) will have a hard time putting it down once they get into a couple of good fights online.

A decently sized single player, with an original story that is OK at best (Although it is robust enough and has some unique mechanics that make it stand out) As a fan of the show, I cannot say the story really impressed me and left me in awe, but it was good enough to entertain me for a few hours. The arcade mode is quite robust, with different paths and multiple difficulties. Added to this FighterZ offers some more casual approaches online, with Casual battles, Arena battles as well as Party Battles were one can enjoy some interesting matches (Such as 3 players vs 3 player matches, or super boss fights). Ranked battles allow for multiple rematches instead of the normal first to 3. But I prefer it this way to be honest.

The lobby is a cute and efficient way of bypassing the need of a text menu, so its a small plus. All other average functions for Fighting games are there, but it does lack a bigger "Challenges" mode that so many people enjoy. It only has a 10 mission per character system were very basic combo challenges are offered. In terms of cast selection, all the logical choices (and some surprises like Cooler and A.16) are present. Its nice to be able to use a fully fledged Yamcha or Android 16 in the game, instead of just the bigger names. However, the season pass did add some questionable choices, which makes it hard to trust the end result of Season 2.

Overall, the game lacks a few things, and it can be a tad simplistic for groups of players looking for Virtua Fighter or Tekken levels of complexity. However, the frantic action and fast gameplay make the game well worth recommending.

After over 500 hours (including PC + Switch) I think it's time to review this game.

I'll premise by saying, this is the first competitive fighting game that I got serious in, mainly because of the franchise.  I love the Dragon Ball universe from its comedic beginnings, to its action-packed climaxes in Z, to its lows in GT, and even its sort-of cringeworthy parts of Super..  FighterZ offers a little bit for everyone, and there's really so much I can say about it, which is what makes it such a great game.  I found that I liked this game so much that I bought it on another platform just to practice on the go and it rekindled the love I once had for fighting games and have since played SFV, SFIV, MVCI, MKXL, Tekken 7, UNIST, and BB Cross Tag Battle, but I keep coming back to this title (maybe because it's what I'm best at, maybe because it's the franchise, but I honestly feel like it's the gameplay).  It's fast, frenetic, and so damn fun.  It looks better than the actual anime itself most times.  The netplay has drastically improved since launch.  Season 2 should be coming soon.  Hell, even the tournaments are fun to watch online.

If you like DBZ, this is the best gameplay the license has ever seen (don't buy this game for any sort of story mode or to have the ability to play 150 characters, that's where you'd want something like Xenoverse 2).

If you hate DBZ but want something kind of similar to this game, get BlazBlue Cross Tag Battle.

If you wanted MvCI to be good, get this game.

If you want to learn how to play competitive fighting games at a decent level, get this game for the fast-paced anime style.  If you want a slower game with more "footsies" and strategy, get Street Fighter V.

If you want a 3D fighter, Tekken 7 or SoulCalibur 6 are your best bets.

The game is solid, puts on a good show, and if you're a die hard fan, get it.
That said, my honest impression after over an hour of play:

This game is mechanically uninspired and fails to deliver where Budokai 3 did not (personally, the best in the series of DBZ fighters). I play, and sure there are an assortment of combos and the like, but I can't help but feel like the game is extremely piecemealed. 

I bought the "Ultimate" Edition on sale for 58~$, and yet when I go in the game and play, it feels far inferior in quality delivered than a number of other fighting games. I especially hate this since I love my favorites, Bardock & Broly, but the total roster is pathetically small - compared to previous iterations.

Aside from the lack of gripping gameplay, the Game also showed many moments where I thought the FPS was off. Thought it was just me, but it happens on all footage I see. I kind of figure this was a purposeful choice, but it was just a bad decision from a visual direction standpoint. 

TL;DR
This game makes me sigh, and is "Meh" if anything. Too many good options out there as it is, and this one just seems a bit to reminiscent of MvC or Tekken Tag.

This is a good dragonball z game, its a terrible fighting game. 

Ill start positive and then rant about the negatives.

I love dragon ball. I grew up with it, I still watch it, i even go back and rewatch it every year. This game has a veried roster of fighters. Their are a few variations of the same fighter like "echo fighters" from Smash U. The stages can change visualy based on what the players do in the match such as cracking the ground, blowing stuff up in the background, switching to a different stage entirly, and even blasting the whole place into a molten hellscape. The combo system is easy to learn but extreamly hard to master. This opens the game up to a wide playerbase. you can earn titels, character color pallets, lobby skins, and fighter card decals through the ingame store with ingame money wich you earn as you play at a very decent rate. 

This game is very fun, but only in 15-20 minute sperts. The negatives greatly out-number the positives.

next to no definsive options, can't jump and block at the same time so you will be hit if you try. vanishes are supposed to be possitive on block but rarly are. character changes come in super dashing (unless you DHC) this leaves them open 100% of the time to a down heavy wich is air attack immune (super dash is conciderd an air attack) and launches into a guaranteed combo wich leads to a guaranteed snap back. the input time for normal dashes are so tight that you rarly get them with the d-pad. its much easier with the stick but the stick has such a small dead zone that useing it for blocking is nearly impossible. imputs in general are very finicky. in a single match, i don't have enough fingers to count how many inputs are droped out right. The airdashing is so wonky and broken it should just be removed or compleatly overhauled. it can turn 270 degrees to hit you on a dime. half the time when high in the air it misses entirly. they just recently changed how it interacts with vanish so the vanisher gets hit less often but still can be. The auto tracking for turning around is clucky. you dont turn around in the air half the time when you absolutly should be able too. its worse on the ground but in the opposite way. nearly instant turn arounds in combos. some characters even cut a few frames off their animations when this happens (bardock) The game is so jank mechanically that ive had entire inputs miss-read for something to happen that is a different button entirly. 

I want to love this game, I really really do but it infuriates me so much that i can't. It is the most rage enducing game that i have ever played. I rage quit matches. i havent rage quit a game in over 10 years but this game did it. This game producces 3 or 4 emotions from me and they all conflict with eachother that it sucks the fun out of the game. 

2/5 wish it was higher.

It's a buttonmasher. Some people will be whining about how 'That's just the auto-combos', however, that doesn't negate the fact that:
a) autocombos shouldn't even be a thing and
b) the autocombos work better than pressing random button combinations to get a combo.
Another thing, the animations are really weird. I know that the whole ArcSys style is choppy animations, but sometimes I can't tell if the game is low fps or not. If you like ArcSys' style, then, forget that argument. Everyone online is mega-asian and will whoop your ass unless you're a god. The base game is far too expensive. Even so, I'd be fine with the game being $80 CAD, if the DLCs(because yes, there are DLCs) weren't $2-15 for something that should be unlockable. Look at how many DLCs there are! 15 or so! to buy them all, it's roughly 2/3 the price of the game, I bet.
Overall, not a very good game. Personally I prefer Xenoverse to this. I just want another Budokai game.
Yeah.

As a fan of fighting games (despite my ineptitude at them) and die-hard DBZ lover, I can say that this game pleases on both sides of that coin!
The fighting mechanics you need to play the game on a decent level are simplistic enough to allow for newcomers to ease into the more complex parts of gameplay, there's a great amount of depth in it, and it just feels so satisfying and fun to kick the crap out of your opponent with your favorite characters.
As far as a DBZ game goes, while it certainly doesn't boast a roster as definitive and mind-boggling as, say, Xenoverse 2 or Tenkaichi 3, it easily makes up for that in that the characters are all wholly unique, rather than one base character with a few different aspects to them in their 100+ different versions. The game, at base, boasts a solid 24 characters, with plenty more as DLC. There's also plenty of fanservice, with funny conversations going on between certain characters in intros/outros and certain story segments, as well as many callbacks to the series itself, some almost frame-by-frame recreations of moments from the anime.
Overall, definite recommendation from me for fighting game fans, and a must-play for any Dragon Ball gamer

I bought this game as soon as it came out, with all the DLC and i was not let down. While i must admit that now, after many tournaments and EVO, the online community is somewhat repetitive in the teams or strategies you would face, the game is still always fun to play. Whether you are casually playing to have fun (w/ or w/o friends) or you are actively trying to become better, online fights are always fun because you get to learn better moves, combos, strats, and see some pretty awesome, cinematic scenes with supers. As for the story, while it does get repetitive over time, it allowed me to play and learn characters that i would normally never touch, and i would actually like playing with them and learning their combos. All-in-all, if you love fighting games and Dragon ball, then i would highly recommend it. However, if you are one without the other, or just trying to get into it because your friends told you to, i would recommend waiting for it to go on sale. There is a somewhat learning curve with figuring out how certain characters work, as well as finding what works best for you, and if you arent used to that or do not have the patience for that and just want cool DBZ fight scenes, then it may not be in your best interest to pay full price.

I usually give games with Denuvo a bad review automatically, but I'm making an exception just this time. This is the fighting game that Dragon Ball Z deserves. Well over a decade of licensed fighting games have largely ranged between absolutely awful and mediocre, this game is the one that completely smashes that trend.

This game is amazing. It looks exactly like the anime, *plays* like the anime, and manages to still be a technical fighter at the same time. FighterZ puts Marvel Infinite to shame, or more accurately this game feels like a better balanced, better designed continuation of the 90s Marvel formula. The game's roster is already full sized, and features characters from every era of Dragonball Z and forward, and even fan favorites from the movies. 

I'll admit I don't know Dragonball lore that well, but you can quickly and easily get the sense that even the less appreciated characters had time and care put into them to ensure they're faithful to the source. Look up the various comparison videos for different characters on Youtube, most of the character's moves are pulled straight from either the show or the movies and reproduced almost frame by frame with careful attention to detail.

The story is probably the weakest part, and yet it still has more effort put into it than most fighting games put into their arcade mode. Even if it is a bit by-the-numbers fighting game-y, it has excellent voice acting, with some of the best roasting between characters possible.

Dragon Ball FighterZ, the revolutionary anime fighter that finally showed the world what a GOOD fighting game based on a popular show could really achieve. But is it still worth your time and money? Let's delve into it a bit.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
FighterZ, due to its rather large nature, has too many positives to list. Instead I will cover what I believe are the most beneficial positives as reasons to get the game.

[b][u]Fantastic Art Style[/u][/b]
The art style of FighterZ is something to behold. With absolutely beautiful cell shading, gigantic explosions and beams that do the show justice, the entire game almost looks like the manga / anime came alive onto your screen. The art, paired with the near flawlessly smooth animations, do the fights of the source material justice, unlike many previous titles that despite however good they may have been, were just "good for an anime game" at best. The fact they looked like marionettes dancing around didn't help.

[b][u]Picture-Perfect Replication of the Source Material[/u][/b]
This is a more subtle strength of the game, but I think it's worthy of mention. ArcSystem clearly watched the ENTIRE show and all the movies just to make this game. With very few exceptions, almost every single move in the game is a direct copy of a move in the show that character used. (Obviously not including characters that never actually fought seriously in the originals, such as Android 18) This even extends to basic moves, such as Broly's down-heavy and ki blasts, Kid Buu's underground stomp mediums, etc etc. The incredibly and frankly insane level of replication is worthy of immense praise. The fact that nearly none of the normal moves or Supers were made up without using the source material is incredible.

[b][u]Easy to Learn, Hard to Master[/u][/b]
Unlike a lot of fighting games, in which every individual character has their own specific circle turns required, button inputs, yadda yadda, FighterZ uses a very basic system. Every Super and basic premade combos are universal inputs, and many special attacks share inputs as well. This system encourages players to experiment with as many characters as they want, instead of being the one dude who looked at all the full-circle inputs for Hugo on Street Fighter, looked down at his Xbox controller D-Pad, and immediately gave up. However, the mechanics in FighterZ are also much deeper than they appear. The combo potential for every character, including jump canceling, reflecting at the right time, proper reflect baiting, etc, gives so much room for improvement.

[b][u]References Everywhere[/u][/b]
The absolute BEST praiseworthy aspect of FighterZ is the love letter it has written to long time fans of the material. FighterZ is absolutely OVERFLOWING with references, heartwarming interactions between old friends, and if you take the time to really crack open Story Mode, humorous and fascinating opinions the characters have on certain outlooks. Nearly every single time a character opens their mouth, it takes you right back to the show / manga you originally fell in love with.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
While FighterZ may be a fantastic anime game, it has no shortage of glaring problems as well for prospective players. The ones Ive listed below are the most problematic of the bunch and are things I believe prospective buyers should be aware of before purchasing.

[b][u]Story Mode and Arcade are Kinda Sh*t[/u][/b]
The major problem with the game is the lack of any decent content outside of online play. Story Mode alternates between pathetically easy at lower levels, with AI basically never even moving, to absolute omnipotent gods at high levels that can punish a 6 frame jab with a Level 3 80% of the time. Arcade is much of the same, except enemies enjoy a hefty damage increase of around 40% max, meaning that even the most basic of combos will still cripple all your characters. Its the same trashy single-player fighting game design we've all come to know and hate.

[b][u]Skilled Opponents Won't Let You Play[/u][/b]
As I previously mentioned, FighterZ has a wealth of deep mechanics to master for dedicated fighting game players. However, for anyone looking for a casual option, this game is no better than any other fighting games. A skilled opponent will have an answer to EVERY single thing you throw at them, and will usually counter you with ease before performing their maximum damage perfectly optimized corner combo loop to keep you in unbreakable hitstun for over 30 seconds. And you can't even defend against them, because they also have an answer to all your blocking techniques and can perfectly crack you open so fast you don't even properly learn what went wrong. Like all fighting games, this is a huge, glaring problem that is NEVER fixed properly due to generally inaccurate matchmaking skill levels. It will take you hours to ever stand a chance in online play.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
FighterZ is, despite the pretty exterior, a fighting game through and through. Any previous fan of the Dragon Ball franchise will get great satisfaction at all the jokes and references intended for them, but will find their dedication severely tested if you attempt to get deeper into the game mechanics. Be prepared to spend hundreds upon hundreds of hours grinding away to even rival the players you meet online, let alone defeat them. Story Mode and Arcade are functional, but have their own clear flaws after a while of playing. 

I would recommend this only for people who are great fans of the franchise and can tolerate the mediocre story combat for the character interactions, or people looking for a very good fighting game they don't mind sinking months into. If you don't fit either of those descriptions, FighterZ may be a risky purchase for you.

Alot of people say this game isn't worth 60$. If you aren't into fighting games, thats true, maybe. I did enjoy fighting games before getting into this game, but not quite to the same extent as I do now. 301 hours later, I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this game was worth every cent for me. There's also plenty of complaints about the DLC characters being an extra 5$. Personally, each character is unique enough that, I don't particularly mind at all. Most of the enjoyment and longevity of this game comes from the mechanics themselves, and playing online. Currently I've played about 2000 ranked matches, and I'm fairly high ranked, along with an unknown number of casual matches. I have a single DLC character on my team. Meaning to get the enjoyment that I have right now, I'd only need to pay an extra 5$. That being said, I have purchased each character, because I feel like each character is worth the 5$ and adds something unique to the game. I jump around the roster quite a bit in casual, so its fun to mix it up everynow and then and try out new teams, but that in no way means you *have* to buy the DLC characters to get the full enjoyment out of this game. Most of my favorite characters in the game come with the base game. The only character anybody would feel pressured into buying right now, would probably be Bardock, as he's currently considered one of the best in the game. But I can say with first hand experience that you do not need high tier characters to do well in the online mode in this game. That, added with the fact that Bardock is the only DLC character considered high tier, makes me believe that there is no real reason to purchasing the DLC beyond just simply thinking it to be worth it. All in all an absolutely worth it buy if you are both a Dragon Ball and Fighting Game fan. If you're a fan of one or the other, but not really both, try to get it on sale if you can, but its still a really solid purchase.

Finally, a proper fighting game based on a popular IP. Developer Arc System Works took their years of experience with the Guilty Gear franchise, and their newest effort mixes elements of their previous works, tag team mechanics borrowed from other classic tag fighters such as Marvel vs Capcom, along with stuff exclusive to this game and the Dragon Ball series (the summoning of Shenron by collecting all 7 Dragon Balls, for instance).

The game is a true love letter to fans of Dragon Ball, with animations, quotes, voices and super moves straight from the anime. ArcSys obviously knows how hard most fighting games are to learn, and made DBFZ really easy to pick up and play for basically anyone. The hardest motion in the entire game is the quarter-circle-forward (236), AKA the first motion learned for most other FG players. The combo system is very forgiving, and even if you don't want to learn your own combos you can always use the auto-combos that every character has. The roster, while not enormous by any means, is very well balanced, if you want to play your favorite character, go right ahead, it's much more important to build a good team around him.

The game isn't perfect though; the story mode is way too easy and extremely boring, the roster is dominated my male characters (only 2 females at the time this review is posted IIRC), last enemies in the arcade mode straight up cheat by dealing like 5x damage to you, and most importantly there are less than 2k daily active players, so the few online matches you do find might be against much more experienced opponents who will absolutely crush those just trying to learn the game.

Nevertheless, I still really enjoy this game, and the beautiful graphics, the gameplay that manages to be fun and easy while having a high skill ceiling, the great soundtrack, and the sheer fun of combo challenge mode keeps me coming back. I recommend buying on sale/free weekend/big update, as the lack of a large playerbase will hurt your experience otherwise. My GOTY

First, this game isn't as difficult to pick up as some people might think. Traditionally, arcade-fighter style games have had difficult to master, arcane controls that have made it difficult for new, fresh players to enter the genre. This is not the case with FighterZ. Controls are easy to learn, while not being so simple as to make the game boring.

   Next, the content. Almost goes without saying that this game is a must-buy for Dragon Ball fans. The visuals are almost magical; Arcsys somehow managed to make this game look like it popped straight out of the anime. The music is good and makes a nice fusion of Dragon Ball aesthetic and arcade fighter sound.

   Fights are fluid and make sense in context. Each character has lines of dialogue specific to who they are fighting against and who they are fighting with. Story mode is full of short and funny one-off conversations between characters that would make any DB fan laugh. The plot itself doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but eehhh, who cares. 

   Dragon Ball fans, buy this game. Seriously.

Honestly just a fun fighter in all aspects. It's not  too technical that you can only play it by spending days and days perfecting each indivual combo but varied enough that it doesn't devolve into just pressing buttons and waiting to see who wins. On top of that enough care and thought was put into that if you're a DBZ fan you'll gush over all the little things and character interactions but not totally reaching fan service levels that make it unbareable to someone who has never seen DB  before.

Some people may think that the dlc characters are a put off but with 24 character free in the base game I don't see a problem with the dlc standards. You have a strong full roster when you buy the game so it doesn't feel incomplete at all. The dlc characters would never have made it into the game without the games as a service model and it doesn't feel lacking in content without them so it's perfectly fine to have it.

The game looks pretty, it sounds great, and it runs well even on lower tier machines.
 
All in all the game is a solid pickup for anyone who enjoys fighters even if they aren't a DB fan themselves.

I've put a hefty amount of time into this game and I can easily say I've had a good time playing.

HOWEVER

-The story mode is dumb and boring and it just fills the game with extra hours of gameplay, but still forcing us to play it to unlock a new character.  

-The online is actually full of bugs.  Not everyone is experiencing it, but there are definite issues involving the game unable to open, game crashing during gameplay, and SUPER long load times that actually force the player to disconnect from online games because the game believes the player is afk.  

Despite these issues, the game is super fun. Just a blast to play with friends. But an absolute nightmare to play online.  
If you haven't experienced any of the issues I mentioned, be happy. You're one of the lucky ones.

If Arksys solves these issues, I can definitely recommend.

UPDATE: Online has gotten better. Can recommend!

I am rewriting this review that I have much more experience in the game, and have even reached the ranked SSJ3 on the ranked ladder, and played in a tournament since this came out.

To start off, despite having a few fighting games between all my systems, I've never really be that great at them. I just don't have much of a patience for sitting down to learn the combos, and end up being terrible because it. But with this game, it was never a problem for me. I don't know why, maybe it's because it's Dragon Ball, and I grew up with most of the cast, and love Team Four Star. It just clicked with me.

That being said, this game is easily 10/10. It has very solid 3v3 fighting game mechanics similar to, but not as broken as, UMvC3. The game is extremely easy to pick up, and is very newbie friendly. I don't think I'd ever be able to climb as high as I have in any other fighting game. This game is the perfect balance between "I have no idea what I'm doing" and "esports level plays." It's fast paced, Dragon Ball action, with the perfect look for a Dragon Ball game. While it isn't quite a 100% recreation of the Dragon Ball fights in the anime, it is still the most fun I've had in both a fighting game, and in a Dragon Ball game. Nothing has topped this to this date, and I this game is a solid addition to any fighting game collection anyone could have, and probably won't disapear until a sequal comes out.

As a long time Dragon Ball fan, this game is a game for the fans AND for fighting game enuthsiasts. I picked up this game simply because of the DB name, not sure what to expect going into it. I played games like Budokai when I was younger, but the only "competitive" fighting game I played consistently was Melee. I've played bits and pieces of games like MK9 and SFV, but never really been into fighting games. However, DBFZ changed that for me.

The game is fan service to a T. Cinematics before/after fights that reference DB, 99% of the moves having source material from the series, character interactions, this game has it all. Even sound effects and visuals are a fantastic representation of the series, 

As a fighting game itself I cannot give much review, but I can say the game even inspired me to pick up a fight stick and look up combos, unlike any other fighting game has done before.

I personally give the game a 9/10, and the only reason it doesn't have a solid 10 is because the single player mode is repetative and lacking, but as a multiplayer fighter, it is phenomenal.

I've been a major sucker for Arc System fighters for along time, ever since I first played Guilty Gear. I just love not only the fast-paced 2D combat, but, more than that, the concepts behind the fights. Completely insane, off the wall characters with absolutely weird designs, weapons and ludicrous attacks. This is what I love most about Arc System fighters: their uniqueness.

Sadly, though, there's nothing unique about Dragon Ball, not anymore at least. This is not a jab at Dragon Ball, which is a perfectly fine franchise. The thing is, I've seen it all over the span of 20 years and it's become extremely familiar. Even with an Arc System coat of paint. It's still the same old kind of fighting we've been experiencieng for a while now, and it just didn't grab me.

The game felt a little too simple compared to, say, GGXRD, where every character has its own set of moves and they all feel quite distintc. Here, most characters used the same combinations to perform similar moves. Yamcha might throw some punches, Goku might do some kicks and... that's about it. Again: completely competente, but insufficient if you're looking for something more.

Overall, the game looks great, sounds great and plays great. It doesn't, however, surprise, not in the mechanichs nor in the presentation, and that's what in the end killed it for me.  If you're a fan of Arc System Works, this might not be enough for you. If you're a DBZ fan, this most certainly will be your jam.

Attention all gamers,
This game is by far the best dragon ball fighting game.

I'm nominating this as game of the year.  With very stylized animation, graphics and robust mechanics, Dragon Ball Fighterz is a well produced and well designed fighting game.  If you are a fan of Dragon Ball or tag-fighters,  you'll definitely find a lot of fun with this title.

This is one of the best fighting games I have played in a long time. I enjoyed it so much, that I bought it on switch as well to take with me on the go.

A Dragonball game first and a fighting game second.

FighterZ is simultaneously easy to jump into, even if you've never played a fighting game before, and has enough depth to satisfy more dedicated fighting-game fans. Take for example that different characters use the same button inputs to do radically different moves.

Story mode is a filler arc that takes place either before or after the Goku Black arc. While the plot isn't anything special, the real enjoyment comes from the cheeky interactions between the characters. Take for example Cell chatting with Adult Gohan or Gotenks trying to help Nappa go Super Saiyan. You can tell that the developers were big Dragonball fans.

This game may have what you would call ‚Äúloot boxes‚Äù, but they're earned through play and the game is so ridiculously generous with them that you'll probably have all the cosmetics you want after only a day or two.

As a Dragonball fan I did not regret pre-ordering FighterZ.

I'm not a huge fan of fighting games and I'm horrible at them, but with this, I can play it well, it has so much depth still, but it's super easy to jump into, pick it up any chance you get, PLEASE.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is an easy to play, difficult to master, 3 v 3 fighter similar to the Marvel vs Capcom series. As a fan of the Dragon Ball series I committed the worst sin amongst gamers and pre-ordered the game, I had played XV, XV2 and a couple other DB games before and I had never been let down by a DB game, so I took the risk. I‚Äôve been playing for about 13 hours and I have to say that I‚Äôm very impressed.

The netcode is fine, I set up my controller with no issues and the lobby system isn‚Äôt as bad as people are making it out to be so don‚Äôt be put off by what some people are saying. I will say that it takes me quite a while to find an online ranked match, but I‚Äôve already played about 12 so I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs so bad that it‚Äôs a put off. The story mode can get a bit tedious when you get to the 100th clone but again that isn‚Äôt too much of a complaint.

The storyline, artwork and gameplay put this game up at god tier for me and I‚Äôm not even a huge fan of fighting games, it‚Äôs been executed very well. I would say that fans of Dragon Ball will enjoy this one, fans of fighting games will enjoy this one and even people who are neither may enjoy this one. I can honestly see myself playing this for another 100+ hours and I‚Äôve only got two games up to that amount (Didn't quite make it to 100+ hours but I do find myself revisiting the game time and time again).

Arc System Works and Bandai Namco Entertainment have given us something special here. A 2.5D fighter entitled to a lot of praise.

I‚Äôd honestly give the game a 9.5 out of 10.

As an avid fan of Dragon Ball and somewhat of a stranger to fighting games, I fell in love with this game even with my limited skill in the genre. The main reason why I dislike fighting games is the need to pull off super complex combos and arthritus causing joystick super moves, both of which are thankfully remedied by the game. Auto combos already exist by mashing the same attacks and you can even follow up with other moves, while every super move is just a quarter circle forwards or backward. Other than gameplay, this game is still amazing. While the story mode is boring gameplay wise, the amount of dialogue and character interactions make up for it and more. Beautiful graphics and funky music make you FEEL like you're playing an HD version of the anime. Add plenty of memorable DLC movie and Super characters along with the jaw-dropping Dramatic Finishers, any Dragon Ball fan's brain will be overflowing with dopamine. Of course, server issues and the horrendous idea of locking character palettes and lobby avatars through glorified lootboxes do prevent this game from being Super Perfect. However, this game is nonetheless amazing

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a breath of fresh air for tag-team fightings AND for Dragon Ball games. It is fun, it looks great and the interaction between characters is a nice bonus. Arc System Works put a lot of effort into everything in this game (though Story Mode looks a lame tbh). Especially when it comes to the representation of the Dragon Ball universe. ASW really cared about it during the development process and this is great.
The fighting side is also good. Newbies can catch up with autocombos while adepts can start by rolling right into the flashy tag super combos (by the way, in order to do this just press the assist button during your 1 bar super if you want to both switch the character and deal some more damage. If you're going for max damage press back+assist button after the 1 bar super to instantly perform next character's 3 bar super). 
Balance is another thing, so let's discuss some characters right now:
1) Android 16 or Michael Jordan - one of the most powerful characters for now. Watch out for grabs and armor (which doesn't work againist supers and projectiles). Also remember that if he touches you once you might stop moving forever.
2) Cell or Mr. Perfect Cell - pretty terrifying opponent due to his mix up options and speed but can be outpressured. Espesially dangerous with Kid Buu in one team.
3) Kid Buu or JUST STOP EXISTING YOU LITTLE **** - 2nd most dangerous character in the game. He can literally catch you from the other side of the screen and go for the full combo. However he hates being under pressure where he is extremely defenseless.
4) Adult Gohan or HOW IS THIS POSITIVE ON BLOCK?! - 1st most dangerous character for now. I really don't know how to handle him due to his level up system, this requires further investigation.
5) Bardock or The Rushdown King - he might look overpowered but he is completely defenseless under the pressure. In other words, The Rushdown King can't deal with The Rushdown.
6) Captain Ginyu or TOKUSENTAI, TOKUSENTAI TOOOOKUSENTAI! - the strongest AND the hardest character in the whole game. And his theme is cool.

P.S. Still waiting for Ultra Instinct Monaka

Final count
Graphics: 10 destructive/dramatic finishes out of 10
Gameplay: 8 never missing autocombos out of 10
Story: Akira Toriyama out of 10
Online: 9 ragequits out of 10
Fun: 10 Broly the Pain Trains/Yamcha comebacks/Special Beam Cannons/ Vegito the Corner Dunkster parries/ "Frieza brother is Cooler"s/ Walking Cells/ Android 17's Barrier Explosions/ Ginyu's Goons/ Krillin's OP rocks/ Tien's mental breakdowns out of 10
Overall: (What? "Over 9000" joke? Nah) 9,7 stances out of 10

I'll keep things short for my first review. 

When I play FighterZ I feel like I‚Äôm playing a game that was designed with me, as the fan, in mind. Not just money and ‚Äúhow can we cram as much content as possible into this‚Äù. FighterZ is more like ‚Äúwhat is the most unnecessary little detail we can put in that the fans will love because we love dragon ball too.‚Äù It‚Äôs a wholesome experience especially coming out xenoverse.Ôªø It may not be absolutely perfect but its still pretty damn good. and for a dragon ball game this is as good as it gets. On the topic of the prices. I'd rather pay 100 dollars on a game I know is going to be good and Im going to play for hundreds of hours than save a little money on one thats subpar with shitty buissness practices. I want to encourage well developed games rather than shitty ones even if it means paying a lot of money because I feel like im getting my money's worth.

DBFZ is a game that is a wok in progress. When the game first came out it was dominated by 3 characters- Adult Gohan, Cell, and Android 16. Since then the developeres have slowly been listening to the players and created a game that is becoming one of the most entertaining fighting games on the market. I am hoping that the developers continue to balance, strengthen the roster, and add a few more characters. Gameplay = 9/10 - easy to learn , hard to master
Fun = 9/10 - anyone that spends an hour would easily get the hang of it and enjoy this to its fullness
Story = 8/10 - the story its pretty interesting and the amount of dialogue that they manage to record for every character is astonishing.
Story Mode = 6.5/10 - even though the story is interesting and fun, the campaing tends to drag too much (if you wanna level up characters in that mode and get every modifier) and can make it a bit boring (it should be 1/3 shorter in my opinion).
Performance = 8.5/10 - I play it on a notebook (i7 , 8gb of ram, radeon graphics)  and it plays really good, sometimes can get a bit laggy (online matches can get a bit slow) but overall the experience is great.

Final Score: 8.5/10  (and a MUST HAVE for every fan of the series, IT IS the BEST DB Game of all Time ; and if we want a second DLC season and a sequel, please support it, on sale its a bargain)

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a game that can test your patience, especially if you are new to fighting games. At first it can be frustrating as some characters are tougher than others. Don't let this discourage you. In fact let it motivate you. Don't sit there playing a character you hate just because they're top tier. I can promise you if you do that this game will be way less fun. Stick with your team, change it up, practice, learn, adapt, and show out in a match. Because seeing your favorite characters, that you put time and effort into, spit out victory quotes at the end of a match is so satisfying in the end

This game opens the fighting genre up for people who may have previously not enjoyed or felt competent enough to enjoy a fighting game. This, in addition to the fact that this is an obvious love letter to the series by the publishers, makes this game wildly enjoyable and beautifully designed.

- While the story line is a bit confusing, as it is released in chunks that do not contain all of the information, the story becomes worthwhile by the last chapter. 
- Each character offeres a reasonably unique set of moves and a definitie difference in feeling when fighting. There are obviously phsyical fighters (e.g. Nappa), harrassment fighters (e.g. Ginyu), specialist fighters (e.g. Android 21), etc. They all feel smooth and use the same moveset to open the game up to those who have mastered the fighting genre and to those who might be playing for the first time.
- The graphics and animation are a stunning reinvigoration of the tire cell shaded games by utilizing true to series, yet highly stylized animation.
- For the fighting fan, there is an unlimited amount to do after the story has ended: arcade modes, local matches, world matches... You'll find yourself losing yourself to this game eventually.

So i may or may not have the most experience in the game, but through playing most of the other Bandai Namco Dragon Ball games like Xenoverse, Budokai etc i feel like FighterZ is slightly detatched from the other games, it feels more like Tekken with Dragon Ball characters, not like thats a bad thing, infact i think its a cool change. In terms of graphics the game is definately game of the year material, one of the superior fighting games this year graphically. The mechanics in FighterZ are very expansive, with the combos having very interesting chains and air-combos that you can do which were more restricted in the previous games. I think the biggest issue with FighterZ is it's networks and server problems with the infamous 'disconnected from lobby' message every couple minutes when playing, this is a prominent theme in many of Bandai Namco's fighting games, but not at as bad of a scale of FighterZ. Another large issue i'd like to touch upon is the story mode, it feels lack-lustre at best with having almost no relation to Dragon Ball entirely, feeling like a lazy filler for a singleplayer mode instead of actually taking the singleplayer as an important component of the game. In comparison to Xenoverse the story is very lame in fairness, with not toxicity at all, im a huge fan of the anime and manga, watching all of the episodes and reading all of the seasons word for word, i take the story very seriously in Dragon Ball games, it feels like something that is essential in a game based around something as complex as the Dragon Ball universe. The game does feel like it is being updated, but not nearly as frequently as i should be, i think more frequent and larger changes would be very beneficial for the health of the game. 

In conclusion, i think DBFZ is a fantastic fighting game for Dragon Ball anime/manga fans, the experience is very gripping and exciting, the combat is intense, the graphics are stunning and the characters each feel like they have their own personalities, rightfully so. The game has it's problems, with atrocious net code, very unreliable online servers and a lack-lustre story. The game is great, and definately deserves a place for respect.

+Good fighting game fundamentals. It's very rushdown oriented with few characters who are true zoners (that sounds ridiculous when most of the cast has full screen laser blasts, but trust me on this one). My only gripe is that there aren't enough defensive options for my tastes.
+Will scratch DAT MAHVEL itch for team-based combat.
+Easy to pick up and play for even casual players while still having considerable depth.
+Stunning visuals. They really nailed the art style of the series with this one.
+Decent music, complimented by the original voice actors and excellent sounds.
+A varied (playstyle) cast that has a little bit for everyone.

-There are too many Gokus. This isn't really a detractment from the enjoyment of the game, but it's pretty silly.
-Get used to seeing Bardock every game. He's not unbeatable, but he has easy oven bake pressure that you can exert almost full screen while still being super safe.

Overall, fantastic fighting game that you don't have to be a fan of the series to enjoy. If you've been waiting for the definitive Dragon Ball fighting game, this is it. If you don't like 2D fighters however, this will not change your mind and you're better off playing something like Xenoverse.

A labor of love create by ArcSystemWorks and possibly the first truly competitive dragon ball game out there. You can tell based on how every move is recreated from the series and manga itself. From the 5L to the cinematic finishes, the beautiful cel shading, and excellent sound design.

The single player consists of you roaming around fighting as a character that's stuck in random character's bodies which gives them back their powers. That's the excuse they came up with to explain Krillin being able to attack Cell. It feels like a slog with the endless waves of enemies. You do get to see interactions between characters like Gotenks and Ginyu having a contest to see who can make the superior pose. Beyond those interactions, I don't see people enjoying it too much.

The multiplayer is an unwelcome departure from previous ArcSys games with a lack of invites to "lobbies." You're forced to go to a server, pick where you would like to go, create a ring match, enter a passcode, relay this passcode to friends, then have them come to the same server to join. It is one of the most poor decisions I have seen for a fighter regarding private "lobbies." The netcode still uses ArcSys' delay-based netcode which is a severe disappointment because that limits the number of people you can fight under playable conditions.

However, despite me just destroying this game, it is still a very good game. I wanted to get the negatives out of the way immediately. Now I'll try to convince you despite these glaring flaws it's a good game.

The music in this game is superb and your typical ArcSys soundtrack. You're not missing anything without the anime BGM pack. It consists of a lot of rock music, not anime if you're concerned about that. Check out themes like Goku Black, Ginyu, West City, Last Battle (21), and more on youtube.

The attention to detail in this game is something I immediately gushed about, but there are still things like when you reflect a fireball it goes into the background and destroys a piece of the stage. Doing a smash attack can also send your opponent flying and you transition to another stage. The battle damage you take is visible on the victory screen and depending on your team there will be little easter eggs like krillin joining 18 for her level 3 super instead of 17.

Now the most important part of any fighter... the gameplay. When you first pick it up and play, you'll find it to be very simple. You have two standard auto-combos, they auto-correct, and track the enemy. You might find this to be annoying at first, but some serve a genuine purpose. There is an annoying one or two, but you'll learn as you play that these are very useful at times. They can help you track your opponent in the air and keep momentum for certain combos. Don't sleep on them, especially on some reflect happy enemies. Give them a big ole' hug for mashing on that reflect.

Okay, now that I've addressed that concern, let's continue. You have your basic smash attacks that send the opponent flying, you can use super dash once in the air for follow-ups, some characters have command normals to compliment their moveset, you have a vanish you can use to wallbounce for confirms or combo extensions, etc. You have more freedom with assists than you usually would in other tag fighters like calling both at once or during unsafe moves. You have a plethora of tech options including a delayed wake-up. The only time you don't is after you get hit with a level 3 super barring a few exceptions. Reflect acts as the game's push block, so you will get rushed the hell down. You need to find the gaps in their block strings and punish appropriately or reset neutral. Dragon Rush is this game's version of a throw. You can tech it by inputting it, but you can also tech it by pressing an attack button for a shorter tech window at varying times.

Those are just some of the gameplay basics, what's really important is team synergy. Things like "will this character help my neutral? what combo extensions can I get off of this? does his super allow me to double super?" and other various stuff. The balance of the game is good even if there are some characters that are clearly better than others. It's the typical "this character does what this character does, but better." Maybe the other character is better suited for your team? Maybe they fit your play style more?

With all that said, remember the basics. 2H the shit out of every super dash, snap their ass out to take that blue life, and reflecting vanish in the corner is a free punish. I would say more, but Steam has a character limit for reviews. Enjoy FighterZ and what not.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to play Bardock. Mashing light is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of autocombo physics most of the jump heavy attacks will go over a typical Bardock's head. There's also Rebellion Spear, which is deftly woven into his characterisation - his personal philosophy draws heavily from using it at round start, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of his neutral, to realize that they're not just using his level 3 super for oki- Bardock sparking TOD says something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Bardock truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humour in Bardock's existencial catchphrase "Prepare to die," which itself is a cryptic reference to Toriyama's Japanese epic Dragon Ball:Episode of Bardock I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Arc System Works' genius unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools... how I pity them. üòÇ And yes by the way, I DO have a Bardock tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.

There is a lot to be desired on the side of online, menu u.i and pretty much removing Bardock from the game, but past that this game is truely a good next step for 2d fighting games, appealing to more people without sacrificing much of the complexities that hardcore fgc goers look for. Its also the most gorgeous looking anime game I have ever seen, and the amount of painstaking detail that went into (most) of the roster is staggering. Story is not the best but not bad. If you are looking for a good jumping off point for fighting games I would say this is a good choice, take it from a competitive party game player

Favorite 2D fighter EVER. Very fast paced, very deep, low skill floor but incredibly high skill cap. Highly reccommend to anyone wanting to get into fighting games for the first time, as well as any fighting game veteran, or any DBZ fan. 

If you have tried to get into fighters but you give up early because you cant do combos and everyone else beats your ass, start here. You can do lots of damage and do multi-hit combos just by spamming the same button, enough to win plenty of matches in the low ranks. However if you wish to do more, your skill can improve at the game by doing other things but spamming the same button. But my point is it's super easy to get into for new players.

The 2D-3D art direction works perfectly and is incredibly reminiscent to real DBZ, the map destruction and explosion effects from every impact are so satisfying, and the cinematics beautifully illustrate the most iconic and loved moments of DBZ which every fan will appreciate, as well as the many fan-service filled quotes and hidden content deep within the game.

Story mode is fun as well but pretty standard for a fighting game story mode. Just fun and you unlock a sexy bitch so yeah

If you were interested in this game because Arc System Works made it I would not recomend it.
If you were interested in this game because you like DBZ then get it. It can be kind of fun.

This game doesn't feel like any other Arc System Works game. The arcade mode sucks. they tried to make it interesting by making it get harder the better you do against the enemy team. This is intended to scale to the player's skill level but it just ends up finding how hard it has to make the computers so that you don't win.
Arcade mode is usually how I get better at a fighting game (slowly turning up the difficulty)  but this one is unusable as a means of training for me.
Story mode is VERY grindy and the computers don't get progresively harder.

Lastly I really don't like the auto combos in this game. I would like to be able to turn them off.
By far the best Dragon Ball game yet, both visualy and in gameplay. Even if you are not into traditional 2D fighting games, you should al least give it a try

Abyssmal interface outside of combat:
- Clunky lobby.
- Cannot browse through available matches or people easily. I wish I just had a list of matches or a quick matchmaking button without navigating in this lame 3D interface.
- I also wish I could select my 3 characters easily online before every match or chose from a preset rather than manipulate presets in a very inconvenient menu (why would you develop 2 character selection screens !!).
- I wish I just had interactive buttons that I could navigate through on the screen rather than learning again how to do something in every sub menu in which controller buttons always do something different.

Unlockables:
- Stupidly slow to get.
- Based on random.
- Besides colors of the characters in game, most feel completely useless (stickers, titles, lobby avatars & colors... these do not feel like a reward at all).
- Frustrating coin system: spend coins, most of the times you get another kind of coins instead, then eventually get something you don't even want.

Value for money:
- Felt ripped off by the "ultimate edition" which uses "songs" (literally with a singer) as combat soundtrack while totally not appropriate for the fighting ambiance. The genuine soundtrack that was implemented does not fit well as you can have nice fighting music which suddenly changes for something peaceful or very cheerful in the middle or the fight. There was a a free mod at some point that made a far better job. Commenter's voice is also useless.
- DLC character price is very high.

Playing with friends:
- Finding your friends online is insanely complicated, as you have to sync to know in which lobby they are. I could not find any option to simply invite or join them.
- Simplest way to do so is do a quick phone call and sync and let him know on which lobby you are and under which umbrella your character is hiding.
- 64-person-limited-lobby and random connection to any one of them to make sure finding your friends is not too easy.
- Impossibility to play with someone outside of current lobby.

Online issues:
- Frequent lag.
- Now struggling to play online with a friend as we have the "EAC disconnect: peer untrusted" error while we both have the basic version of the game without mods. We can both play online on our own with other players though. Does not make sense.


=> Now some positive stuff: the fighting part is very good but the devs made a mess out of everything around it. Please just make something simple that works and stay focused on the essential.

[h1]Dragon Ball FighterZ is a (beautiful looking) mess of a game[/h1]
I don't even know where to begin with this thing. It basically does 2 things right: graphics and fanservice, while failing at everythig else.
The implementation of the Guilty Gear Xrd engine gives this game a gorgeous faux 2D style that's honestly hard to improve on, to say the least. It's colorful, clean and really gives the illusion of 2D animation thanks to a carefully animated moves following the principles of 2D animation, which most games 3D games don't do anymore.
As for the fanservice, Arc System Works really did their homework for this. The game is filled with canonical moves extracted from the manga down to very basic melee moves. Furthermore, unique intros and dramatic finishes put the cherry on top with really cool moments and recreations of the anime that are rare enough to keep feeling special through time.
However, that's where the good news end. Everything else, from the very first minute of gameplay up to the long term experience offers diverse degrees of awful. 
For starters, the game uses a system of [b]online lobbies[/b] as a substitute for both online rooms and the main menu. This would be perfectly fine if it wasn't for the fact that it replaces both the menu and the player made lobbies, which generates a few issues. For starters, entering the "main menu" in online mode will get you an appalling 11 popups and 4 loading screens between the start screen and the "main menu". Then, you are left in a lobby with up to 63 other people in which you can access the different modes and several online play options. Between these online play options, 3 of them use automated matchmaking, which sometimes can be underwhelming; and Ring Match, a replacement for the "player room" feature. This Ring Match system is the biggest issue of this lobby system. In the first place, it will only be accessible for people within the same lobby; giving it way less exposition than a regular player made room and thus making it harder for random people to join and a nuisance for friends to join. But worse than that, Ring Matches can be joined by up to 7 other players, but only 4 can be playing at a time, which is a huge downgrade from the Xrd rooms and quite nonsensical.
For the [b]single player[/b] enthusiasts that may be looking for a nice Dragon Ball experience here, it's not their lucky day either. The game offers 2 single player modes: an unorthodox arcade mode with poorly implemented incremental difficulty, and story mode. The story is a completely new arc unique to the game starring Android 21, an original character made for this game, and it's told from 3 points of view (the good, the bad and 21). The story is weak even for battle shounen standards, and the fighting is so incredibly easy that the entire thing feels like a chore, specially taking into account that it is mandatory to finish the story in order to be able to play as A21.
And to end with game modes: [b]the tutorial[/b]. It's a decent tutorial, but also tricky. It does explain every mechanic to you, but somehow some mechanics are only explain in the pause menu, such as tagging in with a super without doing your active character's super first. It could be better, but it could also be a lot worse (I'm looking at you, Tekken).
Now, how about the most important piece of the puzzle: [b]gameplay[/b]. Dragon Ball FighterZ is a lot like SFV in that it tries too hard to please casual players that lack experience with the game, ruining the entire thing and also somewhat similar to Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm, hilariously enough.
There are 2 halves I want to comment about here: universal mechanics and character mechanics. The [b]universal mechanics[/b] (or those that are available to every character) are not only bad but also makes the character mechanics situation worse than it could be. For starters, the "super dash" (meant to be a button for casual players to skip the neutral game as, and I quote, "Casual players don't enjoy the neutral game as much as the experienced players do"), a mechanic really similar to Naruto's chakra dash,  is probably the most awful mechanic I have ever seen put into a fighting game. Just like in the Ultimate Ninja Storm series; it gets a combo on hit, relatively safe on block, tracks the opponent extremelly well, goes through some projectiles and will be a key element in why the neutral in this game is so awful.
Alongside that, we have a safe on block teleport with the cost of an EX move which can cancel other moves even on whiff. Not a great mechanic, yet not the worst we have here.
To understand why the neutral game is so awful, I must explain a few things before getting into assists. First, projectiles can be "light" and "heavy", based on whether or not they can stop a super dash or nullify another heavy projectile (again, much like the ones in UNS). The heavy projectiles include the famous "kamehameha", which virtually limitless horizontal range and relatively low startup and similar techniques which will be addressed here as "beams". And second, the crouching heavy attack is completely invulnerable to airbourne attacks.
Now, assists let you call one of your inactive characters to throw a predefined move. Some of which are beams. Being an inactive character performing the move, you character is completely free to move. All of this creates a huge problem when it comes to the neutral game. The combination of the super dash and the beams, both of them able to cross the entire screen, makes careful spacing non-existent; as the beams hit the entire screen at once and will end the neutral as soon as they hit, thanks to the ability of your character to take the leading hand while the assist does its thing. Thus, an optimal play usually consists in almost immediately ending the neutral with an assist. Furthermore, the trinity made by the superdash, the beams and the crouching heavy generates a rock-paper-scissors kind of scenario in which those 3 options define the neutral game in the absence of assists, working from full screen without really taking space into account.  To make it worse, regular (non-assist) beams can also be cancelled into a teleport to get the leading hand.
That sums up how [b]the universal mechanics work together to remove the neutral game, which is the most important part of any fighting game[/b].
Now, Arc System Works' games have always had really odd, interesting and creative [b]character mechanics[/b] that made it feel that each character was its own little game. That is not the case here. Most of the cast has a really redundant set of tools and lack any kind of unique traits. There are some that do have their own unique mechanics, yet here another problem arises, and that's that most of them don't really get a chance to exploit them in a meaningful way, and their mechanics, if anything, are limited to be used in combos, as the neutral is dominated by a handful of universal mechanics.
The greatest example for this is Beerus, the character with the greatest (lost) potential in the game. In short, he can set projectiles with which he can interact, hitting them to move them around somewhat like Guilty Gear's Venom. However, these projectiles are light projectiles with low damage that will go awaywhen you get touched. Both on hit and block (but not reflect). As light projectlies, they get mercilessly destroyed by beams and flought through by the superdash. Furthermore, they only last 5 seconds, regardless of whether or not you set additional projectiles (unlike Venom). This makes it extremelly hard for a Beerus to actually develop a dangerous zoning game as it is really hard to keep a high amount of projectiles in the screen and each projectile does little damage. Just like him, characters like Krillin can't really get the most out of their unique mechanics. Rendering them redundant.
The lack of defensive mechanics is also a problem, but Steam won't let me write more.
TL;DR: Terrible.

I wanted to like this game, I really did. But a subpar opening hour to a story mode that more or less serves as an extended tutorial, and online connectivity issues that plague this game nearly a year after its release, and I can't fathom why this game is getting exceptional reviews.

Some people get kicked from matches or online lobbies, while I can't even connect to a lobby within my selected region. I can't even load the player data I created for online play because of a network error. Even at 60% off, this failure to connect online for about an hour, prompted me to issue a refund request, which was granted to my surprise. 

I was a huge fan of the Budokai games growing up, and I've always wanted to test my skills against other players within a 2-D dragon ball universe, but I can't - and many others can't either. 

The game looks beautiful though and the animations are crisp - they're amazing to watch. But it seems that reviewers around the Internet are letting online play issues slip through their thinly vailed glasses - favoring eye candy over playability and performance. We are talking about a fighting game after all. If players from around the world can't connect to fight one another, then how can this entry in the Dragon Ball series of video games, ever be taken seriously as a fighter?

Dragon Ball FighterZ isn't so much a fighting game as much as it's a game that struggles to deliver on that promise in the first place. 

2/10

The solo content is near non existent. The story mode is a joke, and If you want to learn how to play the game, you'll have to ask a friend or go to youtube. The tutorials are useless. Special awful mention to the "combo" section not containing assist switch or assist combos.... shame really.
1 star, don't buy this game if you are going solo. Go for MK or Injustice for solo content.

For the rest, we could have had a bit more diversity on characters. I'm not talking about cloning half the cast 4 or 5 times like a Budokai or a Xenoverse does. But, I would have liked some better grapplers or zoning alternatives strategies. Right now, beatdown is your (somewhat) only real option even with C16 who's a grappler on paper.

Sure one might complain about the DLC policy. But this is the times.
Or the fact that this game is no Xenoverse or Budokai. But then, may be this isn't the game for you.

11/20 if you are playing alone.

16/20 if you go multiplayer (hotseat or online)

20/20 if you enjoyed Marvel vs Capcom and asked yourself what if would look like if set in the DB 'verse.

I don't like fighting games. They often require rote memorization, hours of practice to be halfway decent, and there's often a meta that locks you into a couple chars if you want to have any fun online. I don't like DBZ, outside of DBZ abridged. 

So when I say that I really love DBZF, you know this is a good game. You can look good being a scrub and learning to be competetive is just as fun. The roster is varied, with lots of viable strats, and I've never seen the 3-man assist strats be so complex. This game is easy to learn, hard to master, and really fun all the way through. If you like DBZ or fighting games, get it. If you're like me, and you like neither, but you have one friend that really wants you to play it with them... get it!

A great example of a good game ruined by terrible netcode.

Ever since the weeklong network issues from late August got ''fixed'' (which you could fix yourself by first launching Fornite during that time... for whatever reason) the netcode has remained incredibly unstable for me. 
This has lead to multiple random lobby disconnects, the infamous ''EAC Peer Untrusted'' errors and various network errors. I think i've seen them all at this point.

Everytime I start this game it's a gamble of how good the game will run because these issues don't always occur. 
Restarting the game, steam or my PC helped for a while I believed, until I figured it is just random.

I enjoyed my time in this game, reaching triple digits in playtime. The netcode at launch was bad but it got better and for a long while it was very stable. I genuinely enjoy the gameplay and in between the network errors im having a very good time with the gameplay. (although the lobby system leaves ALOT to be desired)

But ever since the netcode/servers/whatever broke late August, the netcode just hasn't been the same for me.
As such I can't recommend this game to anyone newly interested unless its on a deep sale.
You may get lucky and get no issues, or the coin flips the wrong way and you're stuck with frustration.

As for me, ill probably try to gamble for a while longer as I think the game is fun enough when it works.
And who knows? Maybe the game will magically get fixed the same way as it magically broke.
