This game is like a love-hate relationship for me that's pretty much always hate. 


Dragon Ball FighterZ is a 2D 3-on-3 based fighting game made by Ark Systems, based on the popular series of Dragon Ball Z. It's gameplay can be compared to Marvel vs Capcom at some points. I'll quickly go over the good and the bad.


The Good:
- The graphics
The game looks stunning when it is in motion. Colors and particle effects flow everywhere, and it's absolutely beautiful. The game uses models at 30 FPS to make it look like they're 2D characters, just like in the anime. Although I'm personally not a fan of the character's animations because of this, I can see why they went for it.

- The roster
The roster is simple and what you'd expect from a fighting game, unlike other DBZ games like Xenoverse, which can have upwards of 60+ characters. This game has a solid roster with all of the "Main" characters that appeared in the story. However, some are still missing like Super Buu, Raditz or Hercule(UNACCEPTABLE).

- The... story?
I'll be honest, the story IS bland by itself. But the only thing that saved it for me was the premise of Android 21.
Now I know what you're probably thinking: "durr boobs lolololol". No. I actually liked the fact that there was a new Android with something that we haven't really seen in a DBZ game or storyline at all yet(if we're not counting heroes, heroes is basically fanfic heaven). An Android who has the cells of a Majin that can absorb powers and eat you. Having such a looming threat that you've never encountered before is quite interesting.

What is the story itself, though? Some weird fucko makes everyone weak as hell like a video game so they can fight and become stronger, then #21 will eat them. 

... that's it

- Unlockable Characters
THANK GOD! Finally a game that allows you to UNLOCK characters!(only 3/11 characters are unlockable that aren't on the roster by default, those others... you have to pay for.)

The Bad:

- Online
Online is one of the most... strange, yet rage inducing thing about this video game. 9/10 times you will only see the exact same 3 characters online, which are usually either all Top Tier, or a certain meta(Vegeta for assist, an annoying character like Hit/Kid Buu, and some top tier character like Cell/Goku Black). It's not fun at all and it makes the gap between a low tier character like Piccolo extremely obvious when it comes to balancing. You might think that this just ends up giving you character knowledge, but it's not that easy.

- The combat
The combat is filled with ToD's, some bugs, and alot of cheap stuff. Defense in this game is extremely tough, and offense is rewarded greatly over defensive play. Projectiles can be really tough to dodge(but can be beaten using the "Deflect" mechanic, which can be done by pressing B+Ki blast), and super dashing can be spammed with 0 risk if you can't counter it in time. There's also teleports which costs 1 Ki bar, but these are beyond disgusting as they can be used to combo from the smallest things(like a ki blast). There are also Auto combos, which make the game very accessible, but if you can't deal with them turn this game into an absolute nightmare. Certain characters have a really good one like SSGSS Goku, which goes High Low Mid, which is fully guaranteed if you're unable to block one of the attacks.

- The balancing
There's no denying that some of these characters are extremely good, and some are very weak. Online play shows this off more than anything, but I've already discussed that.

- Chatting
There's no good way to chat with people in the lobby, albeit... this might be for the best.

I don't play too many fighter games, so this has to be taken with a grain of salt, through the eyes of a novice.

It's surprisingly enjoyable - and I'm not sure if it's more about the Dragon Ball (well, it surely doesn't hurt) or the gameplay itself.

The graphics are so vivid, animations so fluid, that it's really a pleasure to watch fighters duke it out, especially given how fight affect the stage - expect destroying everything around you.

Gameplay is fast - full match won't take longer, than couple of minutes, though the pace of the game could mean, that one little slump will throw you straight into defeat. As some people mentioned here and there, fights are focused on comboing, whether you like it or not. Personally I don't have too much of an issue with that, but your mileage could vary  here.

The story mode is... Well, it is here, yes. Story wasn't exactly expansive, but I guess it fits DB in general. I had my fun though and learning style of each new character got me through the campaign without any problems.

The game itself seems to be a little bit pricy for the content available, especially given the availbility of Season Pass - but I've grabbed this on 50% sale (both game and the pass) and couldn't be happier with it.

It's also great party game, as long as you don't 100-0 your friends, you know, be kind and pretend they have a chance.

Now, before I get to the main review, let me say simply that I'm not usually a fan of fighting games, or Dragonball Z... yet was surprisingly drawn to this game. And after getting it, I am very glad I did. I have been having fun with it, and it has a lot of things that make somebody like me who usually dislikes fighting games (normally due to how complicated using a single move can be...) actually enjoy it.

So if it wasn't obvious, Dragonball FighterZ is a 2D fighting game based on the Dragonball characters.

Unlike a lot of fighting games this game is very streamlined to be newplayer friendly, while still allowing room for improvement for players who get better at the game. There's a few mechanics at play here to do this. There's natural mobility options (such as Vanish, which teleports you behind your opponent, or Super Dash which charges you straight at them) which prevent people from just using cheesy tactics from a distance. There's also the "Auto Combo", where combos have an automatic progression if you continue the same input (For example, repeatedly hitting Light Attack). Finally, the most complicated input is just a simple Quarter Circle, which even a newbie like me can get used to. This means a new player can pick it up, still do decent damage, but there is still a high skill ceiling as these tools start getting strung together. 

There is a lot of universal mechanics too, so all you need to worry about is what makes each character unique in their kit, as opposed to how you're going to get close enough to land a hit, or get out of a corner if you get pinned.

Overall these simple and new player friendly mechanics allow for a lot of interesting combat options to anybody who starts making use of them.

One bonus point I want to mention: A common issue with tag-team fighters, where you can just pin somebody's new character once you kill one, is acknowledged by a sort of reset when the new character comes in.

The music and art direction are also top-notch. There are times I legitimately forget this is entirely in 3D, due to the great use of artstyle. Plus, the game gives a great feeling of power, through how attacks interact with the environment (for example, if you deflect a projectile it might go into the BG and destroy a house), as well as "Finishes", which can change the stage mid-battle if you blow it up with a powerful finisher, or knock the opponent away with a heavy hit as a finisher. As such fights feel very dynamic, despite coming down to the same general ideas between areas.
I should also mention there's plenty of Easter Eggs, such as dramatic intros and finishes, depending on the match/stage setup, or some characters have special interactions depending on who you have on your team/are facing agains.

Finally, it's easy to set up an entire match lobby with friends. You join a server they are in, ya host, you all play 'king of the hill' style, or what have you.


So, issues. One is rage quitting is not punished. You don't get your win if your opponent ragequits, and they don't get a loss. At most they get flagged, and will show they ragequit alot when you get into a match.

Second: Ironically, casual is VERY dangerous for new players. It's highly likely you'll face players who have been playing a while and get destroyed. Ranked is actually the safer mode to get used to.

Third: DLC. While I personally have no issues buying a couple, since this isn't a recurring game and a lot of them are unexpected characters, I feel they are definitely overpriced for what they offer. You get a single character for a decently hefty sum.


So in summary, a great fighting game that is very new player friendly while still letting good players shine. It has a few issues in online situations, but overall it is an enjoyable experience. As somebody who didn't like most fighting games or DBZ this game actually got me more interested in both.

From what I've played, its a pretty solid game. Story isnt that great, but it isnt painful. Controls feel as smooth as oil on the biceps of a buff tootin baby. This is an extremely polished & well-made fighting game that I hope will be a mainstay in the fighting game community. 

+ The artstyle is gorgeous, and the gameplay is just as great. I've spent literal hours in training mode before, just trying to get one combo, and it doesn't bother me one bit because of how satisfying the game feels & looks. 

+ The roster is fairly well-balanced; unless you're playing at very high levels you can use a team of just about anyone. 

+ The game is welcoming to beginners. The learning curve that may seem harsh at first glance, but really isn't as bad as you'd think once you put some time into it. 

+ DLC isn't required to be top tier, and the each DLC character is extremely unique and brings new variety to the team structure & roster as a whole. I would recommend buying the season pass so you can try out every character. You'll find yourself loving the characters you never would've thought of playing.

I realize giving this game such high praise may make me sound like a shill, but I honestly had never watched DBZ and barely knew anything about the show before buying the game & I still had a ton of fun with the game as a whole.

Now that the game is finally complete, all promised characters finally here.

I can say that this game is amazing, BUT, only for a very specific crowd, people who enjoy classic fighting games, like street fighter, king of fighters, or in this particular case, marvel vs capcom.

The reason i say that is because this type of game in the DBZ series is not common, in fact the last time we saw something like this was in Super Dragon Ball, a port from the japanese arcades to the ps2, and let's say that, that game had flaws and was not generally accepted.

The thing is, when you think about the classic style of dbz fighting games, people will either go for budokai or tenkaichi, since those are the most common predecessors of the franchise. And this game dosen't take anything from any of those two types of gameplay.

For me honestly it was a blast seeing the game coming to this point since day 1 , discovering what the characters could do, the crazy stuff people would show online, the level of gameplay that increased more and more as time goes by.

Everything was sincerelly good.

The only thing i think that would make it even better would be a more classic DBZ story mode with the anime soundtrack, but i guess we can't have everything xD.

So all in all, i'm glad we finally have a good game for DBZ after so many years of different ideas not really adding up much and i hope for more of course, but as the game is right now, i can only say thank you to everyone who made this game possible.

TL;DR
The game is good, but only if you're interested in to classic fighting games, not the usual DBZ stuff.

Let me start out by saying god damn this game is pretty. The 2D/3D models look like they've been pulled straight from the anime/manga. I wish all anime games look like this. Combat feels great too. You can autocombo if you are new to fighting games and TODs if you know what you are doing. This game is easy to pickup but hard to master. Lots of flashy moves and destruction. Each character kinda feels sameish but they all have unique ablitites that help them stand out. For instance, Hit's timeskip, Ginyu's squad, Goku Black's across the map 2H, etc. Mods exists and replace the models even in story mode. You have not lived until you have Squidward, Steve from MC, Rayman, Sans, and Xeno Goku team up again Android 21 in story mode. Speaking of story mode. While it is generic and forgettable, the game has a lot of easter eggs, references, or cool moments to make up for it. Piccolo roasting Yamcha, Cell and Gohan threatening each other, Goku bragging SSGSS to Cell, etc. It's great if you are a diehard DBZ fan. I have a few problems with the game however, the online ranking system is a bust. Anyone can leave a ranked match and they don't lose any SR or rank points or whatever. Really wish they were busted for doing that.

I am writing this review from a slightly different perspective than others. I primarily play this game with my wife on local play with maybe a match here or there online everyso often. 

Pro's
- Local play is fun and competative for both casual players and hardcore.
- Autocombo's allow inexperienced players to understand the basics of gameplay
- Combat is dynamic and complex with 3v3 roster combat.
- The Cel shaded graphics make it look just like the show, at times I wish they animated the series this way.
- Great selection of characters as the roster is still expanding, hoping for a season 2 as well.
- Combat is balanced well, with only a few characters being left out to dry. (Looking at you Lord Beerus)
- Online play, what little I have done, seems to run well with 3ms latency at most.
- Practice mode allows you to practice with with latency delays and recorded/visual inputs.
- Cinematic fights are unreal, very fun to play, but also fun to watch.

Cons
- Slim map selection, DLC has not added any new fighting arenas.
- Rage quitters not really punished all that much online.
- A lot of Goku/Vegeta characters. Would like to see more female characters, currently only 2.
- Costume changes are restricted to colour variants only. Something about needing to model each costume by hand.
- Have a X-Arcade Tankstick and can only really program the left side to work, player 2 needs to use controler or seperate USB fightstick.

Overall I love this game. The lady and I definantly recommend it.

A rumble feature would definitely help with determining stage position.  In other fighting games, a good rumble feature allows me to take my eyes off of my character, and watch my opponent.  Especially in this game, where all of the characters look the same, taking my eyes off of one yellow haired character requires more of a tactile connection with the game, for maximum comfort, and mastery.  That isn't to say that I won't get good at the game eventually, it is to say that learning it feels very dissociative, after playing with rumble feedback for so many years.

The graphics are pretty cool and the game play seems fairly advance, but there aren't terribly many combos to be had with each character.  There are only a few special moves, which kind of sucks, but there are nearly all of the DBZ characters to play with, and a nice combo system, which is awesome.  There is quite a bit of content and voice acting, which is very awesome.

The graphics are awesome, and waht I expect from a modern title, and I will continue to update my review throughout the future.

"Failed to initiate Network." with Win 8.1

I was able to play during some days after the base Goku and Vegeta release, then, suddenly no connection allowed to the online lobby.

2 solutions (found by the users) :
- Play on Win7 or Win10 OS
- Launch PUBG or Fortnite before connect to the lobby

The second option sounds crazy but seems to work for many people.
Upgrading your Windows to 10 is not a 100% guaranteed solution : people still experience issues with connection to the lobby and versus matches.


If you plan to play offline on the same device with friends, the game is worth.
If your target is the ranked versus online => I recommend to test your connection to the online lobby first. 
If it works => Kamehameha
Failed to initiate Network => Request for a refund (before 2 hours playtime)

I deliberated a bit about whether to recommend. I really love this game but it has some major flaws too. I decided that the best way to do this is I'm gonna front load all the bad stuff about the game but put it as a recommended title. I don't want anyone buying it and not knowing what their getting into.

The Bad:
- MOST IMPORTANT NOTE: There is DRM and Anti-Cheat software. Now I understand that anti-cheat software is necessary on games like this where the primary focus is a competitive ladder. However, Easy Anti-Cheat is borderline spyware and very invasive. You cannot opt out and if you go in and remove it the hard way, you will have your account potentially banned. So if you have sensitive info stored on your computer, don't install this.
- Servers are kinda spotty and lower capacity than you would want, resulting in people being booted out frequently especially during high traffic hours. This can be really frustrating.
- The game was clearly designed with a lootbox economy in mind. While there have never been paid lootboxes, the devs kept the lootbox system in anyway. While all the "important content" namely characters and play modes, is available either from the start or after completing story mode, half the alternate character pallets, emotes, avatars and other content are all locked up in the lootboxes, which can ONLY be purchased with in game currency. You are not guarenteed unique items each time but you can't get duplicates either so you just get premium currency at a trickle rate for each time you roll a duplicate. Only with premium currency are you guarenteed a new item. So if you care about alternative pallets, get ready to grind for them because there is no alternative.
- Story mode is pretty boring. There's some funny dialogue but the story is awful and its way longer than it should be. Additionally, Android 21 cannot be unlocked without completing the story mode (I've heard there is was a way to get her through her Z-Union but I think this was removed as an option).
- Matchmaking can be a bit confusing when you first get into competitive.
- Bamco's PR/Customer service is attrocious and recently a significant number of players, primarily those using windows 8.1, were locked out of the online play mode for two weeks straight, due to a faulty update the the DRM. The PR team failed to contact the community publicly in any way about the status of the issue and what was being done until it was fixed to weeks later, in the mean time leaving those affected frustrated and concerned.
- The lobby system is kinda dumb and confusing and it can be challenging to figure out the controls when you get into the game for the first time. (hint: options menu is Tab rather than the usual ESC)
- Setting up controllers for two players on PC for local can be quite a hastle to get working. You may need to sacrifice a rooster or something to get both controllers assigned correctly.
- Online matchmaking can be really slow.

Now for The Good:
-Beautiful graphics, voice acting and animation. Lots of attention to detail and kits that really capture each characters fighting style, big moments and personality.
-Thriving online community.
-A replay system both for your own matches and for following and watching games from high ranked players which can really help with learning the game's strategy.
-Good Practice mode with lots of options
-Probably one of the best designed fighting games I've played.
-Easy for beginners to learn and feel good due to auto-combos and other newbie helper mechanics.
-DLC characters are pretty reasonably priced.
-Probably my third favorite fighting game franchise to date, following Guilty Gear and Skull Girls.

Nitpicks:
-I kinda wish arcade mode didn't have the same teams to play against every time.
-If you love zoning characters, know that the game is kinda stacked against them and there are really only three of them.

Overall, I love this game and I've sunk alot of time in. I recommend it, but also Bamco kinda needs to get their shit together on some things. Hope this helps people.

I'm gonna be honest, I fucking love this game to death. It's an amazing introduction to the Anime fighter genre, and has a lot of aspects of other fighters such as UMvC3 and Guilty Gear, all with the nostalgic feel of Dragon Ball, jam-packed with ORIGINAL voice actors, scenes and whatnot.

However, this, on PC, is the only thing it has going for itself. Get it for PS4, if you plan on getting serious with this game at all. PC has LESS natural input lag but (in my opinion) has worse latency due to the PC player's internets/or the netcode being not so good. 

The single-player campaign to unlock Android 21 for free, is 6 hours of nonstop bot-beating with the most HORRENDOUS way to teach you simple mechanics. Also the combo challenges aren't even proper BnB combos. 

If you want to learn the game, go on Youtube, or the DBFZ Subreddit discord. They'll help you there as long as you're open to critisism and being bodied by Cell, A16 and Adult Gohan lots of times. 

As of now, I've hit 800k Battle Points in ranked, have kept a Pink Square for god KNOWS how long and consider myself someone who knows how to play the game and knows most of the mechanics and character nuances. This is my online experience in a nutshell:

Rage Quitters: The only thing you get from Rage-Quitting too much is a purple name, you don't even lose rank if you quit out before the KO.

Unstable Connections: Even on a 4-bar I was getting spikes, frame drops and certain moves/directional blocks just didn't come out. On PS4, I never had this issue.

Spammers/Lag Abusers: If your opponent has a 2-bar connection or worse, do NOT play them. I repeat, do not play them unless you want to deal with frame drops, input drops, or wonky connection spikes where the frame delay can jump to 12 frames of input lag.

Frequent Disconnects: "Failed to Initialize Network". "Connection has been Lost."

Fight Stick Support: If you're unlucky like my first fight stick, your stick will not register ANYTHING or just be all messed up, even in Big Picture mode.

I'm probably forgetting some other things but I've already uninstalled and I don't want to go check.

TL;DR: Don't buy this for PC, get it for PS4. The online experience is better tenfold and you'll be ready for tournaments without having to learn a new amount of input lag.

[h1] A Masterpiece. [/h1]
Enough said. Before I judge its virtues and vices, I should point out that this is one of the best fighting games I've ever played. Granted, I haven't played too much competitive fighting games [spoiler](I've only really been engaged with Street Fighter II, Super Smash Bros, and Tekken)[/spoiler], but that goes to show how accessible this game really is. 

And you want to know the best part? I haven't even seen a single episode of the anime it's based on. 

[h1] [ + ] The Pros [/h1][list]
[*][i]Fan Service and Graphics:[/i] There I said it! I've never actually seen a Dragon Ball episode. Regardless of my ignorance, I can sense the vigirous fan service and art style the developers poured into this game. Whether you care about the anime or not, every match and stage is littered with a brilliant color palette, completemented with masterful cinematic pieces while using your specials. It's practically eye-candy.

[*][i]Accessability and Difficulty:[/i] Personally, I enjoy games with high-difficulty spikes that cause the player to really think and attempt to comprehend the mechanics of the game they're playing. However, this style of playing is not for everyone, which DBFZ addresses efficiently to anyone with virtually any playstyle.
You want to play the game casually? Sure, just mash the X button and you'd still have a blast with the action. You want to play the game competitively? You're in for a treat, because this game expands upon the precedented traditional fighting rock-paper-scissors scheme with a revolutionary mechanic; the super-dash. It prevents the atrocious projectile spam that other games struggle with, and makes this game even more fast-paced than it already is.

[*][i]Unlockables:[/i] Nowadays, microtransactions and lootboxes plague the gaming industry. However, this game sticks with its old fighting game roots, and let's all the content (at least until the Season Pass is fleshed out) to be accessable via story mode and arcade mode. No more squeezing the extra buck to unlock SSGSS Goku.... unless you really want to. 
[/list]
[h1] [ - ] The Cons [/h1][list]
[*][i]Character Variety:[/i] Whilst writing this, I do think this game's only issue is it's character variety. Although there's 20-something characters to choose from, some characters feel too alike, in terms of style (albeit all of them are different in gameplay). To illustrate my point, there's 3 different Goku characters, 2 different Vegeta characters, and a few characters very similiar in DB's lore (such as Kid Buu and Majin Buu). It's not a big deal, but it feels somewhat lacking in this department right now.
[/list]
[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]
There's really nothing else to say. The matchmaking has been fixed so it's not valid criticism, anymore. Moreover, most of the flaws with DBFZ are nitpicks, rather than major obstacles (such as poor lip-sync dubbing). All in all, just buy the game if it seems slightly interesting. It's highly likely you'll have a great time; assuming you don't despise 2D competitive fighters.

Unless you're SonicFox or you actually like Xenoverse, do not but this piece of sh it. Here's why:

Offline:

- A fighter is locked behind a boring story mode
- Gameplay is super repetitive outside of pvp

Online:

- 1 casual match = about 15 min wait time
- Casual matching is secretly Ranked match Jr.
- "Oh look, a fighter within my skill range. Maybe I can get a feel of the mechanics better without getting duffed by long combo strings." (player ragequits mid-fight) "...uhh......good game????" (he stood still for about 15 seconds, THEN he left for those who think it might have been a random disconnect)
- Backpedalling and camping, spamming everything from beams to Vegeta SSJ = no-skill win
- Cell, Kid Buu, and literally any third char (Vegeta most likely) = tier-whore win
- Played with a person who give me a very close, yet fun match. No ability to friend them, couldn't see what their Steam name was, never saw that person again......
- Pinks (highest threat level) trolling around Casual as Whites or Greens (some of the lowest threat levels)
- 'Those' players who are beating your a$$, then the moment you get momentum........LAG SPIKE!!!!!
- One button auto-combo/auto-mixup shenanigans depending on char

Overall:

If you EVO-ready, and you've mastered games like Persona 4 Arena and Marvel vs Capcom, then this game is right up your alley. I personally don't like getting basically infinitely wall combo'd to oblivion. I actually would like to PLAY my fighting game. I'll stick with Xenoverse and hope they fix what's broken in that.

P.S. At least Xenoverse has a option to teleport out of infinites mid-hitstun. Just saying.

This game is......hard to critique.

On one hand, the game is practically dripping with polish and care for the Dragon Ball Franchise, with the developers making a lot of inside jokes and references, a solid roster of characters with a lot of big names on deck like Trunks, Hit, and Freeza, and a wealth of cutscenes and cinematics that honestly look really good.

Why negative then? Simple. The actual game itself is a cancerous mess.

After nearly 400 hours of playing on and off over the last several months, I have found that the game has buggy mechanics, stupid design choices, and poor balance to say the least. Not even bringing up the fact that most fighters feel very homogenous, which makes the cast feel identical to play, even if they have a great deal of different moves (I'm looking at you Piccolo).

For example, lets look at the game's most prominent mechanic: Super Dash. Super Dash on its own is a buggy mess, only really working properly in dedicated combos and strings. However, that is only the beginning of the problem. Super Dash essentially blocks all ki attacks, and also zooms you toward the enemy. Seems cool, right? The problem with this is that any non-ki projectile takes too long to startup to punish it on reaction. This means that the only real good way of punishing it is with Anti Air moves.

Anti Air moves are invincible to any air attack, yet they are their own cavalcade of terrible. With Aerial moves(since aerial moves have NO LAG ON WHIFF (which is its own problem)), it is possible to use an anti air move, be invincible to the aerial attack, they land, making them able to block, and then you miss an attack you should have hit because you just did a down-heavy on someone's guard which you weren't expecting to be possible, meaning you're about to get combo'd. On Super Dash, the timing window seems very inconsistent, even though I know it isn't. There are times when I've hit down heavies I KNOW I shouldn't have, and missed ones that were timed perfectly.

Then there's vanish. Aside from vanish occassionally making down-heavies miss if they are performed a frame too early(forcing the game's shitty crossup protection to get you hit), vanish also ruins the neutral game. Any assist-> vanish is a free setup that leaves the defender at a HEAVY disadvantage if they block, and taking nearly 10% of their max health if they don't. In addition, it also makes combos that shouldn't have been possible now VERY possible, allowing people to spam buttons in the air, and then vanish near the ground for a full(albeit slightly scaled) combo.

This is not even getting into the problems with the game's combo system making everyone feel the same to play, design decisions that make characters WORSE in order to fit into that combo structure, automatic crossup protection, aerial side switch lock, or the numerous other shitty bits of the game that worm their way into ranked and casual play.

This game is......frustrating. As a designer and a fighting game enthusiast, it makes me sad thinking about all the love and talent that went into making the game a steaming garbage fire to play. Sure the game is fun for the first fifty hours, and that is likely going to be enough for people. For the hardcore crowd however, who put thousands upon thousands of hours into mastering the game's systems and understanding every nuance, this game is a frustrating grind that had me and my friends screaming and hurling controllers when alone, and frustrated when we played together.

Do not buy this game and its DLC like I did.

Dragon ball FighterZ, personally my favorite fighting game I've ever played and one of the few games I bought at full price on Steam. This game is a 3v3 fighting game that is very similar to marvel vs capcom from my experience and relies heavily on combos and face paced combat.

PROS:
English and Japanese voice acting for us weebs
Fast combo system
Beautiful graphics style
Good roster
Lots of modes
Move sets and combos give every character a unique feel.

CONS:
No way of player to player communication
Hard to play without a remote

This is probably the best Dragon Ball game for any fan of the franchise as it's filled with true-to-source-material callbacks, references and characters with the best video game rendition of the series through ArcSys's yet-to-be-matched graphics prowess when it comes to anime in 3D.

That being said, I'm no Dragon Ball fan but I am an ArcSys fan so while all the in-universe callouts and references are lost on me, I can definitely appreciate the work and polish that went into DBFZ's graphics, sound design and gameplay mechanics.

This is an easy to pick up fighter due to its simplified controls in comparison to older traditional fighters but has enough deep complexity that makes it hard to master making it enjoyable for players of all skill levels.

Despite all this, the game has a general lack of defensive options to counteract the overwhelming amount of offensive options and mechanics the game has to offer which can make certain matches feel incredibly one-sided or at the very least, incredibly oppressive which makes for a less than enjoyable, more than stressful experience. Added with the fact that a large majority of the playable cast is essentially the same character both aesthetically and functionally, I can't really see myself finding the time to play it longer than I have other fighting games.

It's a great game, especially for fans of the franchise but I'm not sure how long it'll last for those who aren't.

Online Matchmaking is a joke, stay away. Can't get any matches.

Game itself is a very solid and fun fighter. Story mode is way too easy for way too long, and since the available characters at the outset are very limited, it quickly becomes tedious. It really doesn't have enough single player content to really be viable as a single player game.  This game was clearly meant to be played against other people. That is where it truly shines. Unfortunately, trying to play against another person online is an excrutiating and unecessarily slow experience. ~10+ minutes between matches is too much. The terrible and unecessary "lobby" just makes a huge problem even worse. 

Until they significantly overhaul Matchmaking, just stay away.

Edit: Read some guides online and figured out how to "optimize" my chances of getting a match. Played a few matches online, and for the most part they played really well. But there is still an incredibly long wait time between matches, and hopping between servers/modes to try and find a match really really sucks. We are talking 10 minutes in between matchers, which only last a couple minutes themselves. I really really want to love this game, but I still am requesting a refund because the online matchmaking is far too atrocious for this game to be worth it. 

I stand by my initial review. Great game, but the matchmaking is so atrocious that it sucks the fun out of the game.

Pros:
-Fluid Combat
-Story short enough for those who just want the unlocks, long enough for those who want to enjoy the content of the DragonBall world
-Great Servers (Overall)
-Very populated
-Dedicated DEV team always making patches and updates
-Easy learning curve

Cons:
-You really have to commit to "git gud" otherwise youll probably get destroyed by experienced players 
-Repetitive matches. 90% chance you'll fight an Adult Gohan, Cell, Goku Black, or Android 16 every game. even moreso because these characters are a wee bit overpowered
-Really hard to put together a team of 3 in the beginning. (Figuring out synergy and the best all around team composition)
-Few defensive options. Really easy to find yourself getting infinetely combo looped and youll feel like there's little to NOTHING you can do about it.

Overall as a fighting game i'd say its a success, even moreso a success as a Dragon Ball tribute. To my 90s babies, its no Budokai 3 but the fast paced action definitely puts it on par if not above it. It's a good game to play and will reward you for commiting to it. Even if you're not a Dragon Ball fan but you're looking for a game that'll have your heart beating? This one's it for sure!

Update- 8/10/2018: I find myself getting bored of this game very quickly. While i come back to join the hype with all the new DLC chars being released, i always leave the game for the very same reason: Its boring. Unless ur a fighting game fanatic and you have infinite combos written on ur brain, if ur on the receiving end of fighting players like that? You'll just wanna drop the controller. The game has been out for a fair amount of time now and literally it seems the playerbase (atleast on PC) is just filled with button mashing. Hell even if ur the one wooping ass the game still feels...idk. Its hard to explain. But if you play online alot the lack of defensive tools the game provides to you will just take away from all the fun. You'll just wanna drop your controller or DC all together. I love the game, and the idea of it,  but it is in dire need of a "Combo breaker" mechanic, maybe you can spend a bar or 2 to give yourself some space, im not sure. But the combat system is literally "first one to land a hit wins", and the fight wont be fun unless its you vs a friend or a random person, you guys are on an even level skillwise, and there r no infinite loops being used. This does not change my opinion about the game, its good, but the combat system definitely doesnt deliver.

Alright so many reviews say that the game is "easy to pick up but hard to master" but that is not true. From my experiences playing the game, queues are incredibly long and when you do find a match the other player is either A LOT better than you or lacks a stable wifi connection for the match to be playable. The game itself can have you learn around 4 or 5 of the charcters if you'd like in around 5-6 hours if you put enough work into ranked or consistently go on practice. The queues are the main thing in my opinion that should be changed seeing how myself with my current record or 48-44 is going up against players with much higher win rates despite me having the queue settings not allow that from happening which is quite dumb. I think the main thing they can do to fix this is to have the queues like Ninja Storm where someone makes a party on ranked while someone joins and the players in the party can see eachothers stats to either accept or decline the match. 

The graphics are very great with the backround designs and playing in enviroments looks very nice and doesn't lack much creativity. All of the characters blend in great and designs are very good in the scenery. Attacks are very satisfying with each combo or heavy hit looking like they have weight to them. However I did see some inputs of attacks to perform specials were delayed and some attacks on ranked did get floppy which made my hits completely not connect, making my opponents get the upper hand and comboing off of it.

The game all together is not made for a casual player, take it from me I learned it the hard way when thinking that matches would be a lot more simpler which ended up being my downfall in the ranks. However if you are into games like MVC, Injustice, or Guilty Gear then this is the game for you and you'd have a blast depending on how you'll get used to the combat and approaches that characters have in the game. The game still has some work to do and needs to patch a handful of charcters as well as fix the ways the overall servers perform in making matches.

So this was the first fighting game I picked up. I really had no idea what to expect. I had never been into fighting games nor had any experience in the technical aspect of it. Coming into this was VERY frustrating, but once I took the time to sit down and start learning it was completely worth it. The online can be a little laggy at times and the it's hard for someone who was in my position, but once you start getting the moves down you can see the difference. I've noticed I'm starting to be able to compete with Yellow and some Orange square people which in the beginning would have totally beat me in. Seeing that progress was dope and the community is extremely helpful to people who are new to it. 

All and all, take the time to learn the game. Some advice I was given was that you're gonna get kicked in A LOT and that's the time to learn from those people and your mistakes. Getting that game where your opponent and you are neck and neck is exciting and what I love about this game. It can be a lot of salt, but you just gotta push through that. Definitely would consider buying and definitely would consider getting DLC especially with Base Goku, Base Vegeta, and Cooler on the way.

A List of why I hate this game. 
The only things good about this game:  It looks beautiful and the characters are balanced but unique. Now for the bad.

Verdict : 60 buck is too much for a game that is gorgeous but... it's still just a simple fighting game with big problems.
Get it on sale for around 30 bucks and it MIGHT be worth it for casuals.
But since you still need to pay more for DLC characters...just don't get this game if your tight on money.

The connection issues ruin the game...no one seems to have a perfect connection and only some are "decent".
But in a fast paced fighter every bit counts a lot.
Another big issue is that the fighting mechanics are just bad. It seems to only be about attacking like crazy, making sure you do your near infinite combo correctly and has very little to do with watching your enemies movements. So the game gets BORING really fast even if you win a lot. Its kinda like a glorified button masher.
Defense tactics like reflect blocking practically do nothing, charging ki and getting dragon balls is a joke because the game is too fast for those features to ever happen in a real match.

The arcade mode  bases your score on how much health you have left....so basically you cant take any damage if you want a good score and the Ai cheats like crazy with damage buffs and insane ki regeneration. It will be brutal in the worst of ways. I did beat it all with perfect scores...but it was not fun at all, just pure frustration for many hours.

Fun fighter, very approachable for new comers, with easy to execute combos and flashy attacks that can be executed by mashing a single button or two, but still has the elements of a technical fighter that can separate a pro from a new player when the smaller intricacies of the game are explored. 

The game looks gorgeous, it uses a 3D/2D style mix very similar to the anime using similar animation work  as Guilty Gear Xrd series which is a great fit given its source material. It has a storefront where you can buy colors, titles, avatars and stuff using the zenny you earn in the story and arcade modes which can work as a small distraction if you want a reason to keep playing but wont sway too many people unless theyre completionists.

if there are any cons its that it starts to feel a bit repetative,  especially if your a casual fighting game fan. the story gets old real fast with a short original story  and the offerings spread as far as your typical arcade modes, tutorials etc, and of course its online which will likely be its lifeblood. it doesnt hurt the game itself in particular but its likely only going to hold the interest of hardcore fighting game and DBZ fans .

This is one of the few times I am going out of my way to write a review. I am a huge Dragon Ball (specifically Z) fan. This game, however, is not for Dragon Ball fans. Well, more specifically, it is not for fans who are not willing to commit to a serious fighting game.

Say what you will about how complex this game is compared to other competitive fighting games out there. Objectively speaking, you need to be able to do a lot of button combinations fast if you want to get any good at this game. Not to mention you will need a competent controller as well (I had gone through multiple controllers before I found the one singular controller that seemed to work best with this game... then it stopped working). I cannot believe just how finnicky these combos are. It is so frustrating when you know you are doing the inputs correctly, but the D-Pad is being pressed in ever-so-slightly the incorrect way and it ruins your entire combo.

This is a fighting game first, and a Dragon Ball game second. If you are a more casual fan who is looking to have some fun without having to commit a lot of time and effort into learning the complexities of the gameplay, this is not the game for you. You can slog through the repetitive story mode just fine, but if you want to do any of the challenge/tutorial modes... have fun. This game has stressed and frustrated me more than it has entertained me. "If it's [the game] not fun, why bother?" ~Reggie Fils-Aim√©. Unfortunately for me, I like completing my games to a certain point, so I'm still torturing myself trying to complete all of these combo tutorials and hard level arcade modes.


<<<tl;dr>>>
=========
If you are a Dragon Ball fan looking to play a laid back, enjoyable game, this probably isn't for you. This is a fighting game first, and a Dragon Ball game second. If you do not like fighting games, guess what, you probably won't like this game. The game is still playable for more casual fans, but it quickly lets you know that you will have to put in time and effort if you want to complete the other modes aside from story mode. If you are playing only for the story mode, don't, it isn't worth your time.

I initially bought this game because I love Dragon Ball, but I quickly realized that this is a serious fighting game with relatively in-depth systems that require a lot of practice. Everything about the game is extremely satisfying, from the movesets to the dialogue. I would highly recommend for any fighting game or Dragon Ball fan. The game is even better if you have some friends to play with locally or in ring matches.

Unless you're prepared to spend the next few weeks in your room, smashing away your buttons, I do not recommend this game. DragonBallFighterZ has already been out awhile, I should have taken that as a hint not to plunge into it. But having become accustomed to fighting games over the years and having a nearly 90% win rate in over 200 battles in Street Fighter IV as well as Mortal Kombat X. I thought for certain I could handle another, I mean what's the worst that could happen?

Well a lot can happen if you plunge in late. For one, Online mode is a ghost town. And the only people that play are already in the 1200+ wins category. But even after having learned the basics, and having mastered the mechanics. I quickly realized this is no Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat. DragonBallFighterZ has a skill gap that would take even someone like me a good while to reach, and would undoubtedly be impossible for a newcomer to a fighting game to ever even touch.

In short, you will be decimated in 65+ hit combos and get KO'd before you can even think of what to do properly. The people here are here to stay and they play this game for a living. They've mastered it, and I respect that. I don't have anything against these players. But it makes the game unreachable for people that are just starting out now.

TL;DR: The skill gap is insanely high, too high. The game is a ghost town online except for the occasional veterans wondering the lobbies that will drop you in a heartbeat. Don't buy unless you're willing to put in months worth of playtime just to become decent or can put off online altogether.

Dragon Ball Fighterz is one of the only fighting games I've played often in a wihle since not many fighting games of this gen has caught my eye, maybe marvel infinite but on pc it's difficult to find people now. I will admit I am a big dragon ball fan so I am a bit of a fanboy but the game itself is rad. 
Pros:
-Obviously it's a gorgeous looking game. Looks a lot like the anime and arcs shading again is really impressive, just fantastic ohw they pulled it off.
-Fun characters, while many have a problem with having te same bread and butter combos, I do think most of the characters are enjoyable to use and feel nice, especially yamcha, he is great.
-Music is absolutely phenominal, there hasn't been a db game with a soundtrack this good since budokai 3 in my opinion and this ost is justt amazing.
-Fast paced and fun 3v3 gameplay. The game feels so smooth to control, the moves, thhe combos, they just all feel so satisfying!
-Personality. This game has so much damn personality and so many references call backs and nods to dragonball it's insane and it just adds more charm
However, this isn't a perfect game and people who dislike it  I can understand.
Cons:
-Defensive options. Holy shit the defense in this game is really bad, you have a parry+push block thatt is best if you have gohan who slides in with his sweep but honestly this mechanic just isn't close to as good as thhe regular push block from mvc3. Next is guard cancel, guard cancel is good when you have one character left. other than that, it's really bad, a lot of times when used, your other character will fly right into a combo instead of just breaking it or it'll be blocked and punished. I feel this game could really use a push block and the guard cancel mechanic should be how it is when you have one character left.
-Single player option. The story is decent but not great and it's the only way to unlock 21, it's not bad and it has a lot of options compared to sfv launch but it could be better.
-online. Yes here we go, Online is still poor. It's not close to as bad as it was launch and it works well on ranked and such, however, you can't just make a lobby and invite friends, instead you have to tell them to join a certain lobby, find you and then join your ring match. It's obnoxious, slow, and so silly. 
-Roster could be better. SSj goku, SSB goku, base goku, ssj vegeta, ssb vegeta, base vegeta...Need I say more? I think this game could really benefit from more females also, like videl, chichi, zangya, or kefla. Honestly we got a few too many Gokus.
-Bardock. Cell. Kid buu. That's it...
Overall, I still love this game and if you love db and or 3v3 fighters, I say give it a chance, it's a damn fun game and it's easier to pick up and play than other fighters!

Honestly not my cup of tea. Definitely not a bad game by any means, but the time it takes to git gud is way too steep for me. I'm not a fan of fighters that are this focused on combos; not because I can't do them, but rather because they bore and frustrate me. In Street Fighter, King of Fighters (14 specifically), or Tekken, combos can deal a lot of damage, but they're less common since you usually have to get in close to start them. And then, they're usually short, sweet, and to the point. Badabing badaboom, like 15 seconds at max, that's a third of the enemy's health bar. In this, almost any attack can lead into a 30+ hit combo that lasts 45 seconds, dealing the same amount of damage. Most of the time, I'm just sitting there, mashing buttons to tech out in case they drop the combo (which they won't: the combo system is dead easy for better or worse)

I'm also not a fan of the overwhelming offensive capabilities in the game. You can call in assists to lock your opponent down while you go for a mixup, leading to yet another super long combo. It gets to the point where I can't even learn defensive techniques because I'm barely playing. I'm just watching my team get combo'd to death for 4 minutes. It may open up and become a lot more fun once you learn the ins and outs, how to defend and punish and all that, but the punishment is so harsh I feel I can't take it anymore. 

I don't think the game is bad, but it's not for me. If you're ok with not even really playing for 30 hours as you try to learn how to actually defend, totally go for it. It's a gorgeous, satisfying game with some really fun mechanics. However, if long combos and crazy pressure make you go "hmm," stay away. I'll be sticking with Street Fighter, Tekken, and Guilty Gear, and I'll probably get fewer strokes due to sheer frustration.

TLDR: Excellent fighter, but I cannot recommend it to people with low salt thresholds such as myself

I am a laptop user. As a laptop user, my computer uses two graphic cards: an integrated one for day-to-day browsing and a dedicated one for gaming and other heavy lifting. This game insists on using the first one.

I have managed to temporarily fix the issue somehow after I had first bought it, but today, it has stopped working, and no matter how much I repeat what I did when I first fixed it, it won't solve the problem.
Furthermore, I'm having several other issues: There's a lack of support for the controllers I use which I had to bypass in strange ways, I have to go in fullscreen mode if I want the best possible resolution while borderless windowed mode won't let me get to that, and even then, I have to revert it back to windowed mode before leaving the game or else it crashes every time I boot it up afterwards unless I delete the configuration save file manually.

This game is quite a bit of fun from what I could try of my first and only sessions. However, I intended to play it locally with others, and that kind of tedious fumbling around just to play it once is exactly what drives these others away from it.
I am not buying another new Arcsys game on PC ever again after this fiasco.

Kinda tricky to recommend games like these because it mostly depends on who is playing it and what is their preference on what kind of fighting game they like. Because comparing Marvel and Street Fighter, is kinda like comparing dodgeball and chess, competition games that are extremely different despite being in the same genre because they both have their own unique system and way to play. With that said, I'd say DBFZ end ups more on the Marvel side of the spectrum rather than the Street Fighter one.

If you're dedicated enough to learn this game, then go for it, learning combos is fun and testing out characters is interesting. Playing this with friends is a jolly good time. Not to mention, it's Dragon Ball, so most of what you pull off, will make your combos will look cool and stylish as all hell. But with that said, there's a point to be made here, because I feel like this game rewards aggressive play too much, and there are a few defensive options, leading to a lot of matches where either things go great for you or *everything* goes wrong (Pretty much like Marvel 3). And I'm saying this being a guy who loves playing rushdown characters in fighting games, but here, I feel that something like a push-block is missing.

Now, about the graphics, this game is BEAUTIFUL, ArcSystem really did an amazing job here, being the guys who did Guilty Gear XRD, I'm not one bit surprised this looks so good as it is. The animations, visual effects, camera work, everything in this department is just so done right. I consider this game a masterpiece in this regard. I can't express enough in words how much I love the polish of graphics and fan service in this game, this is something you have to see for yourself in case you actually end up buying this thing.

Overall, this game is fantastic, a very beautiful masterpiece of a game, but, I always lean on the fact that even masterpieces have their flaws, and this game sure does have some unfortunaley. I really want to say this game is perfect, but it just isn't. But hey, if you're dedicated enough to put your time in this game and learn it, then go for it, have fun. Do it for the birds.
Good graphics but abysmal content and music. Enjoy getting screwed -once again- by greedy Bandai.

How pleased you are to chop away, Jack the Dipper.
My name is Mushroom, of the Meals of Destruction.
Yeah, I guessed as much.
Yeast on the insides of your enemies.
How easily you ignore the sharpening of knife when it suits your convenience.
So tell me.
Who saves the meal from the man who saves the meal?
You're the ones salting them.
You take advantage from their lack of taste.
Of course they lack taste when you set them up as organic food!
Eat or be eaten, Jack.
Nom Yum taught me that.
Yes, you aren't the only one to grow up on the cooking fields.
Cooking is a cruel class, but an effective teacher.
Its final lesson is carved deep in my knife:
That this fridge and all its vegetables, are rotten.
Boiling is a myth, frying is a joke.
We are all prawns, controlled by something greater:
Spices. The DNA of the taste.
They shape our taste buds.
They are the plates -- They are everything we eat on.
Expose someone to hunger long enough, they will learn to eat.
They become a curryer; Salt, curry, despair ...
They're spices. All passed along the table.
How about "full of schnit"?
Is that a spice?
You can't fight nurture, Jack.
The fan blows, water boils, and the hot prey upon the sweet.
Sam tells me you see your spoon as a tool.
Something that solves hunger -- making meals of justice.
Now that's pretty spicy. EXQUISITE!
It's spared you the burden of all the meals you've salted ...
Absolved you of guilt when you enjoyed it.
That is, until the illusion was boiled.
Don't be ashamed, it's only nurture, running its course.
You have no meals to make.
Nothing to answer for.
You can eat with a clear taste bud.
You're right.
About me, I mean.
I knew something was ... off.
After I turned off the stove.
I thought I could walk off the cooking field, and into a normal restaurant.
But here I am, surrounded by burned food, arguing cooking with one-star chefs.
I told myself this was about preparation, about cutting the leak.
But I was wrong.
Then you admit it?
I learned young that spicing your food tasted good.
Very good.
In the restaurant, my friends ... my family ...
They helped me boil the devil side.
But who am I peppering?
I was born to salt!
The bit about my spoon -- that "meals of justice" stuff?
I guess I needed something to keep "the Dipper" in check when I was hands-deep in dough.
You ...
But you -- all this -- is a dinner call to what I really believe.
What I really am.
What are you saying ...?
I'm saying Jack is back.
Fry him!
No!
Cook, take off my oven gloves.
What?
This ... This is madness!
You --
Do it!
All right ...
Burns ... This is why I fight.
This is my taste.
My nurture.
You've lost your buds.
Who's next?
I'll take this competition.
No, Sam.
Report back to the chef.
He's mine.
You're the five-star.
I've misjudged you.
You are like us after all.
Now you're just being crusty.
That nickname you love so much -- wanna know how I got it?
Actually -- why don't I give you a taste?
I think it's time for Jack ...
To let 'er dip!Ôªø

Before owning FighterZ, I had only briefly known about the Dragon Ball Universe, like who Goku and Vegeta where and that was about it. After just playing for 10-15 hours, I fell in love and decided to go watch the anime, I finished Super and watched some of Abridged. Now I think this is one of the greatest fighting games I've played tied with Killer Instinct. The combos are easy to learn, but hard to master which is the best methods for getting someone into a game. It always seems like everytime I get on to play, I learn some new tech or a new combo, which makes it more accessible which is good for bringing in new players. The game is pretty bare-bones with the options for assists and mix-ups, which is fine but MVC has multiple assists and multiple supers which is one of the things I think that they should add. All in all, I love FighterZ, it's probably on my Top 5 games of all time list. I'm also not particularly good at fighting games, but I love the learning curve for this game. I would just recommend not playing the story mode because I think it's pretty boring and if you want to learn a character, it's better to just go to training mode. The extra dialogue they added for story mode is pretty cool though, but I would recommend just watching it on YouTube instead of wasting your time getting them through story mode, unless you like beating up the bots. I also like how almost all the supers and special moves are canon, which means that they where once in the show, like with SSGSS Goku's level 5, he yells "Kiaoken!" and then punches them like a 100 times, slams him into the air, does a Kamehameha, and then flies through it and finishes it with a punch in the Kamehameha, which took place in Super during the Universe 6-7 Tournament when Goku fought Hit. There are a bunch more like this one but I'm not going to say them all. In conclusion, is Dragon Ball FighterZ worth your $95? I think it is, this game most likely has a future and with a bunch of new DLC characters on the way and with ARC Systems Works being very cooperative with the community and making changes, this game is the best anime fighter on the market right now. I love it, and I think you should too.

After playing through the story for a bit and giving this a try I have to say I am very impressed with the game. This reminds me of all the old SNES and Gameboy DBZ fighters that I played back in the day.

Graphically, the game is beautiful. There is a lot of effort put into making this game look amazing.

Controls are easy to use with the stick or d-pad being able to be utilied without any issues. My only gripe is that you can pretty much mash one button to string together combo attacks effortlessly, however this isn't so bad since EVERY character in the game plays completely differently from one another. 

Super attacks and special attacks are all pretty much executed the same way which makes learning each character easier but takes away from the uniqeness a bit. Everything is basically a hadoken in terms of complexity.

Fighter call ins are smooth and awesome.

Story wise this game is like Xenoverse 1 & 2. It's a mess and ridiculous with the lead villain being pure fanservice with her skimpy clothes, huge knockers and generally slutty/provacative attitude (not that I'm complaining, she actually has a good design despite this fact). 

All in all the game is great, but even on sale it is stupidly expensive due to the DLC prices for the extra characters. Wait to buy this until it is closer to $50 for everything rather than $70.
It takes like 5000 years to find a ranked match, and if you do find it. People leave, overall the game is beautiful BUT like always, the community sucks.

Used to play Street Fighter V, took time to adapt to the different style of combo and the use of assist. Getting better so far, quite easy to pick up even without using the game's Auto-combo system. GREAT VISUAL AND AUDIO!!!!!!!

Offline difficulty in the game equates to the AI reading inputs like it's nobody's business comboed with an insane boost in damage and health.
The game looks good and online play is solid, but if you like playing fighting games offline like I do you'd best avoid this like the plague. It feels really cheap fighting the AI in hard mode. It has improved since the open beta, but not by a large margin since the boosts in every part are really noticeable (health, damage, cooldowns etc.).

I liked the AI in SF4 a lot more even though that can also feel somewhat cheap at the higher difficulties. That game feels a lot less cheap then suddenly getting wrecked by an AI with a large damage boost even though you managed to beat 2 of the 3 opponents using a single character.
Guilty Gear is another fighter I can recommend for offline play.

Its a really fun, competitive game that's accessible to newbies and has a lot to offer to both fighting game fans and Dragon Ball fans. However, if you're looking for a mainly singleplayer experience here, its kinda limited. The story mode is pretty trash and boring, although some of the side modes (like the 3v3 where each person controls one character) is fun. If you're a casual fan of fighting games, its still fun to play with your friends/online as the game is very new-player friendly and has a lot of depth to offer. If you're a competitive veteran, the game is really fun and has good depth, albeit lacks a bit of character diversity in the meta. Overall I hard recommend, with my only complaints being that the story mode and other such "side" content is pretty bare bones. Still, the game makes up for that with great gameplay and you can find yourself pouring tons of hours into training or online matches.

As much as I love this game, I have to give it the pros and cons.


Pros:
Visually Beautiful,
Addicting,
Looks like the show,
Very well made in structure (Thanks ARC, you done good),
The first time I can look at Yamcha as more than just a dissapointment.

Cons:
There is a huge difficulty curve when starting up against anything but the AI,
Lack of information for in depth techniques (Sparking Blast, Gohan's Level Transformations, Connoiseur Cut, ETC.). This is hard to learn if you are new to fighting games.
The Story Mode is actually kinda boring after a while, and feels more like a grind.

Overall though, this game is amazing once you get into it, and I guarantee you will enjoy the game even if you are not a fan of the series. 

9.3/10

Let me start with what I like about the game: the art style is absolutely stunning, and the actual mechanics are fun. However, if you're new to fighting games, like I am, it's extremely hard to find a fair fight online. There's seemingly no matchmaking system, as all fights are started bewteen two people in the same lobby, and there are very few people playing, so it's extremely hard to find a fight against an equal opponent. I have yet to fight someone of the same skill level as me. If you know what you're doing, this game is great. However, if, like me, you don't, it's just a frustrating experience fighting people who've played literally hundreds more matches than you.
A bunch of vegetables running around on a 2d plane battling for victory and shooting balls of energy at each other.

Expensive, but it's what the fans have been waiting for.

It doesn't feel like budokai, but it's still pretty satisfying.

Hopefully they make another one, but with the following improvements:
- Drop the 3D. The game would have looked better if the entire thing was hand drawn.
   This would also make adding cutscenes with the same quality of the recent movies seemless. Saying that, make the story mode feel like a movie.
- More characters.
- More story arcs. I want ones that go through all of the series like the older games have.

Awesome game though.

PROS:
- Fastpaced fun gameplay
- Great attention to the details
- Beautiful colorful artstyle
- Easy to learn, hard to master
- Good practice mode and decent training mode
- Universal input system for special attacks (good for new players)

CONS:
- Netcode is far from perfect (no GGPO, sadly)
- Lobby system for friendly matches
- Not a lot of single player content (it's not a con for me, but it might be for someone)

OVERALL:
I can recommend this game to anybody. People with a lot of fighting game experience will find it fun to play. People with NO fighting game experience will find it fun to play. Dragon Ball fans will find it fun to play. There's something for everybody in this game

I tried to like this, really, I did.

The positives I have to say - it looks fantastic, , the gameplay mechanics are simple to pick up, and entertaining to watch, the voice acting is solid, and the story itself is alright.

The negatives, There is no progression in multiplayer in the sense that you're either fighting people who have spent an endless amount of time playing, or you will be kicking the crap out of noobs, its not particularly fun either way.

The Story mode is far, far, far too easy, and as far as I can tell, quite predictable - with no visible difficulty option that I could see to make things more challenging, it became extremely boring quite quickly, and the story around the game was not enough to keep me entertained while pushing through.

Honestly, unless you can get this at an extreme discount beyond what the Steam Summer Sale offers, I'd stay far away, as it is - I've requested a refund.

I bought this game on release and while I do really love fighter games and Dragonball this one had me quite frustrated despite how hard I tried to like it for the theme. I've played a lot of fighter games and while I'm not a "pro" I am better than the average player and yet, it feels like whenever you play this game you either crush your opponent as if you're facing a non moving cpu or you become the non moving cpu as you watch for 5 minutes your characters get endlessly combo'd and that's the main problem I have with this game. The combos. They are simply too easy to execute and to string along to ridiculous lengths. It's not enjoyable for me to enter the exact same sequence of buttons over and over because it's just my "bread and butter" nor is it enjoyable to not get to play. If you like Dragonball you may have fun going through to story because they actually did a great job on the characters and it's kind of funny but it's not the main focus of the game. You're supposed to get better and climb the ranks but I honestly see no point when it only takes a couple of hours to master the most basic of combos and then you play rock paper scissors with your opponent for a combo setup and that's basically the only time it feels like you're playing a game

Dragon Ball FighterZ is every Dragon Ball fan's biggest dream. Intense battles with every character you love, along with a unique story to settle in with those who seek more DB lore. Dragon Ball FighterZ puts you in the role of...well, you! You are a soul, split apart from your body. At the time of DBFZ events, there is trouble running amok earth.

The story branches into three different 'arcs'.
Arc 1 - Super Warrior Arc
Arc 2 - Super Villain Arc
Arc 3 - Android 21 Arc

Each arc presents unique stories, unique battles, and tons of fun to be had. DLC currently exists in DBFZ, but it is only new characters. As of now, there are four:
-SSJB Vegito
-Merged Zamasu 
-Bardock
-Broly

These characters have no specialty to any of the current in-game characters, but they do have pretty fun mechanics.

That being said, Dragon Ball FighterZ is a wonderful game, obviously built with love and passion for the Dragon Ball world.

I fucking love this game, but you're probably wondering why someone with such appraisal and gametime spent be mad?
I've been hyped for the game, and even spent my weekend playing the god awful xbox betas. But the game on PC is broken. When I bought the game, it crashed, and wouldn't open only to be fixed by some weird trick. The servers were unlplayable, the campaign is boring and andriod 16 is broken followed with poor hit registration and shitty controller support. 
      While netcode has somewhat imporved, the rest remain true. My experiences hasn't been helped by playing with a 360 controller, which fails to read combo inputs and results in some major losses, granted that's my problem. The dlc support is bad to the point you can't even practice with dlc characters something KI does and it's only 8 characters for 40 bucks. 
  
    The games core is amazing though, my favorite fighting game combat, beautiful cutscenes and detail too characters. I can't stop talking how amazing it is, but I can't give it a postive review. I'll still play the game still but I need to get this of my chest, this is one of the two games I can love and hate extremely at the same time

Edit; Andriod 16 is a lot better balanced and a new gamepad somewhat helped out on combos. Plus vegito is really fun so I do recommend it now, just know the population is low and netcode is still somewhat bad

Dragon Fight is the long awaited prequel to Everybody Loves Raymond where we finally learn the backstory on how Robert became a police officer. I have to say, on paper, I didn't think it was gonna work but actually the controls were pretty smooth but I don't know why they expect everyone to own a Dreamcast controller. I had to order mine from the deep web to even start so my review is a little late. 

Much like other Fighting Dragon Men games, you have the staples of the series. You have the character Dragon Ball, then you have characters like West Virginia, Mitochondria, Frozone and even King Boo. The game's roster is lacking a few characters I had hoped for, like the mascot from Arizona Tea or Tucker Carlson, but maybe they'll be DLC. Tucker Carlson's level three could be the move he used on Danny Devito, I think it was called the "Tucker's Cuck-Killer Uppercut from Timbucktoo" where he hits them so hard their neck grows three feet.

The story mode was really fun and we even got cameo appearances from my favorite character of all time Tim the Tool Man Taylor. Immediately scores +100 points from me, baby. I love this game.

I love Dragon Ball, but this game just seems like a button masher with not a lot of skill involved. I still prefer Ultra Street Fighter IV to this by a long shot.

I played Dragonball ever since the first Budokai and I can tell you It feels like this game is a Straight Budokai game except the transformation and picking skills part. I can say I feel this game is like an Old School fighting game which I like it so far (example would be unlocking characters like Android 21, SSGSS Goku, and SSGSS Vegeta. I am looking forward to updates to this game as that is why I have purchased the Ultimate Edition. Unlike most fighting game these days, Arc System made everyone happy by providing non-paid loot boxes and they have brought love to the Dragonball Characters. If I had to grade this game, I would give it an A+

I went into the game with pretty much zero knowledge of DBZ (crazy right) and ended up getting into it so much I watched all of the Abridged series. Have to say it does insanely much justice to the series and the characters. The plot and new characters fit right in as if they were part of the show and there's a decent explanation why everyone can fight at that level and the references, once I actually got what was going on, are amazing and it's filled with little details all over like special cutscenes at the start of fights depending on who's fighting who at which stage. But even if you don't know the series much it's easy to get the gist of it.

As a fighting game I found it very easy to get into and learn the basics, coming from SF or Tekken. I hadn't played tag fighters much before, pretty much my only experience with them before was a bit of Ultimate Marvel vs Capcom 3. There's lots to do in the game besides just training and online, there's a huuuge story mode that I'm still in the middle of playing at the moment of writing - with multiple paths and relative freedom in picking fights/who you're fighting with so that's cool.

The game looks great maxed out and the artstyle is very refreshing with a nice soundtrack. All the characters feel fun to play and I'm compelled to learn a whole bunch instead of just sticking to a few. From what I've played online I haven't had any matches with big lag issues so far, all of them have been more or less playable. My only con would be that the menus can be a little weird at first, especially for playing in lobbies, but once you get used to it it's not a big deal. And I'm getting bodied in ranked but that's to be expected. It's how you get better. Can't really judge if it's any worse than jumping head first into any other new fighting game. Even so, there's tons of content besides that so I think the game is entirely worth what it is.

Single player is alright, it's introduction into the game helps a little but it's far from a good start so to speak. I don't think i can recommend this game if it's online performance is so bad.

Amazing, simply one of the BEST, if not the current BEST fighting game out there, an even match to SFV, excellent combat systems. While certain characters needs slight balancing, most other aspects of the game are beautifully balanced to almost perfection. Nice UI, great art, fantastic narratives for DBZ fans, stunning cut scenes and excellent animations, it's got it all covered. A must buy for all DBZ fans, and a quality buy that would not disappoint any fighter game players. Though Game do have problems freezing and crashing PCs on some systems... if only that could be solved.

It's honestly the best traditional fighter out right now I'n my opinion. It is meant for higher level of play, but is very easy to pick up and have fun with and doesn't have the problem of too much stick motions. That is actually the reason I never touched traditional fighters is from the stick motions so seeing this and being able to play a traditional fighter really makes me like this game ten times more. The gameplay is solid and like any Arc System Works game looks amazing. The story is about 30 hours long if doing all 3 of them each of them lasting 10 hours if you do all the missions on the story. There is a arcade mode which is a very nice touch and is used to unlock the SSGSS (SSB) forms of Goku and Vegeta. There is lootboxes, but in this game it's done right! There is no microtransaction garbage you'd see in a EA game. All money used for them (zeni) is obtained from normal play. Every single fight online or offline will give zeni, You are able to open them one by one or in bunches of ten. Dups aren't wasted zeni and they go towards coins that let you open a lootbox that 100% gives you things that you don't have. None of these drops affect gameplay and are used to get cosemetics and different colors for the in game fighterz. Overall this is a solid game and really is amazing for getting into the gerne. I'm not going to go into gameplay because a lot of others can do it beter than I can, but I'd say that this game is a 10/10. For a final touch this game can run on pretty low hardware too, so even more power to you potatoes out there.

If you've been afraid to jump into fighting games because of it's complexity and difficult learning curve, but have wanted to get involved, look no farther than Dragonball FighterZ. If you want to learn insane, snazzy combos and style on opponents, it's built for you too. Fun story mode, arcade mode built in, easy to join in online games, so many things accessible, it really feels like a complete game.

I wanted a good dragonball game that reminded me of playing Dragon Ball Z Budokai 1/2/3, good ol 2d fighing game, to be fair this game is what i wanted BUT i feel like the difficulity is just WAY to out of wack.  Either the computer is a total pushover or he dominates you, i cant seem to find any middle ground on it.  Having core characters locked behind tedious amounts of gameplay is not very good either, you need to either do very well in arcade mode (this is where the difficulity gets  crazy because you have to do the hard modes and get like an A average on specific ones, or you have to grind for the ingame currency "zeni" with steep numbers of 200,000 for SSB Vegeta and 500,000 for Goku,  you can also pay real life money to get them unlocked and it isnt a loot box so i wont say they are pulling an EA on us but are pushing it.  I have only played offline as im scared to death about online after watching youtube videos of people playing this that are inhuman it dosnt look like it does a good job seperating the total hard core from the casual group that wants a good match (I have seen battlepower differences of 30k in most of the videos).  All and all im not unhappy i bought the game however i wish i didnt pay so much for it, the $59.99 price tag is very high for this game though if your a big dragon ball fan you will enjoy it.  I would recomend waiting for it to go on a big sale (50% or more off)
