I DO NOT PLAY FIGHTING GAMES but dear God this is by far the most entertaining dragonball game I have ever played. The base character roster is good. All heroes are viable, but youll probably stick to about 5 or 6 that you really enjoy. 

The visuals and sound effects are so well crafted that you feel like an episode of the tournament of power is happening as you play. The attention to detail is superb and and the dramatc finishes as well as the special introductions really make me feel happy that they chose these developers. 

The port is really good, I have had no issues. However player count can be low despite this being the most played fighting game on steam currently.

When playing against experienced players the combos can be unforgiving but, the game itself is not hard. Put 50 hours into the game online and youll get good enough to have alot of fun, even against "great" players. Coming from Dota 2, 50 hours is practically nothing to put into a game for practice, so im grateful for the game design that allows dragonball fans to really enjoy the game even if they dont play many fighting games.

You don't need this extra review. This is just my two cents.

I love everything about this game other than the way the difficulty works. The AI in the game becomes more and more capable against the player (as it should), but the true difficulty is in how the game will ignore your control inputs while also giving the AI unreasonable advantages. You pressed the arrow to block? Hit anyway. Dragon Rush? Nah, stand completely still. Super attack button combination? Dragon Rush. Opponent's in the middle of hitstun as your ultimate attack sequence is triggered and they have no means of blocking or escaping? Blocked.

If the players can't block at unreasonable times, neither should the AI. If I press a valid button combination before anything comes my way, it should not register as something completely unrelated to my combination. If more than one ki blast (such as what comes from Vegeta's [down] [toward] [A] combination) have gone through and past the victim AI, they should not be able to trigger a super attack because hit stun is supposed to exist.

Honestly, I WANT to love this game. Its concepts are so cool, but they're wasted on how unreasonably broken it is. It's not worth $60 to have an unplayable game.

Pro:
-Beautiful looking game.
-Good pvp.
-Interesting controls for attacks.

Con:
-Built exclusively for pvp.
-the story is an afterthought.
-each arc is built like a rehash of the last, like the first two are beta versions.
-no autosave.
-the only option is save and quit.
-if you want to leave story mode during a fight, then tough luck, your only option is to delete all your progress since the last save, theres no save and quit from mid-fight.
-every story fight is exactly the same.
-arc 3 locks you into two of the worst characters for 2/3 of the time.
-the answer to the big story 'mystery' is that you were yourself the whole time.

As a viewer of most of the anime I was I was intrigued by the videos I had seen of this game since I can usually tell with about 80% accuracy whether a game or movie is crap just based off the trailer.

Fighting games usually have a steep learning curve with many special moves requiring complex timed input, which is difficult to do in actual combat. This is why I dont play fighting games often, lacking fantastic finger dexterity, the only series I played at length was Soul Calibur.

What Fighter Z does really well is standardize alot of the moves to either a quarter joystick roll in the left or right direction with a button press. This makes the game easy to pick up and easy to gain proficiency in new characters. Simple combos can be performed by hitting the same button repeatedly while more complex combos are available to be mastered in the combo challenge mode.

[b]This is the most intuitive fighting game I have ever played[/b]

There are many classic moves from the anime and each character is really unique with a fighting style that really represents them. Overall the game is just really intense, addictive, and fun to play. 

However, the story mode was kind of boring and could have used some more work.

Dragon ball fighterz is probably the closest you'll get to making a fighting game just like the show.
In both look and feel. Technically speaking it's nothing new for fighting mechanics, which in it self is nothing bad for Arc Systems as they've had experiance before. The "menu" overworld layout is a little off-putting to me personally, i'd rather just select my options normally and maybe interact with online in an overworld setting but i've heard others praise it so take what you will from that.They've added nice touches as well, like dramatic finishes and a choice between languages.
A fair chunk the music (to the best of my knowledge) is from the show and it's sounds great.

Network play is mostly solid though Delay can really become an issue. Thankfully Training Mode lets you adjust that if you really want to get a feel for it. Match making is hit and miss for me, rarely are they even skilled matches, more ones where i'm matched with a much lower ranked opponent, or ones where i am said opponent. This could just be my skill rank lacking other people right now.

As good as this game really is there are still a few complaints; The roster feels a bit small. A lot of the fighters feel the same (Though recent dlc's have helped this). Only 3 fighters to actually unlock, and unlocking them felt like a chore more than anything. The Lobby (as I said above). Personally still not a fan of Delay-input though it has worked better than i thought it would. Story Mode drags on a bit, even for me as a long time fan of the show. Arcade mode is interesting to say the least, AI difficulty seems to vary (sometimes the 4th set of fights will spike in difficulty, sometimes later). The AI gets increases to Damage (to almost double) and how much energy it gets as Arcade goes which can become frustrating.

All and all this game has been a lot of fun to play. Visually it looks very nice and very close to matching the shows look.
And while arcade can be a bummer, online can be a lot of fun with or without friends. It's mechanics are the right kind; simple to learn but with lots to master. Full price is a bit much but still worth it for this game. 

I recommend it to anyone who is a fan of fighting games, looking to get into them, or someone who just enjoys the show!

I bought this game when it wasnt on sale for the pirce of $60 and the dlc for $20 so $80 altogether
Now theres alot ot like about this game as well as there is a alot ot dislike about it as well. Some of the pros are its art style its very nice and clean almost makes it look like the anime. Its also very good at being a fightning game. There are lots of chracters and alot of combos with each one so there is a very high skill curve in this game. If you like dragonball and figthning games then this game is probally for you but there are some things that are bad about this game aswell. One of them is the 60$ price tag and that is alot for a fightning game, even when this game is on sale the best sale we have been able to get is 30% off and the dlc has never been on sale. This leads alot of people to not buy the game. There is also a big probally with its player base. The game has been out for awhile now so its playerbace used to be over 50,000 people but it has droped to around 12,000 or less. This is because some people can get extremly good at this game leaveing the ones who dont do that good to get to get crushed by them. But along with that if you want to get better and you try to then you will in this game it just takes time. Another big problem is that this game can make you rage. If someone is a very good player that can beat you in one single combo. That dosent happen to often but this game is full of combos left and right so you need to make sure you can be prepared to get into a big combo that might take away half of your health or more and not get mad. There is also 4 chracters right now that are DLC for $5 each so if you want to get more chacters you can but there not free. So in conclusion this game is really fun and worth the money but if your not a big fan of fighting games then this game might not be for you. Easy to get into, hard to master. 

Coming from someone who's never played a fighting game before, I can tell you this game is very friendly to beginners. There is an auto combo system so you can mash a single button to get very pretty combos. That will most likely get you through most, if not all, of the story mode and the easier arcade runs.

Once you get used to certain moves and get better with dodging, blocking, or reflecting attacks, you can move away from the auto combos and create your own that are bigger and better. 

I'm still pretty bad at fighting games, compared to people that have been playing for years, but I'm certainly way better at this than any other fighter I've tried out. 

Even if you know nothing about the Dragon Ball series, I still recommend this as a great fighting game in general.

I really love this game but I wish it had more game modes. It would be cool if the game had a endless survival mode, challenge mode or something more for peaple who dont play online often. Dont get me wrong, the modes thats are in the game currently are fine but if more modes are added it would be even better.

Pros
- Amazingly in depth combo system.
- Easy to pick up but incredibly difficult to master.
- Jaw dropping special moves.
- All characters are relatively balanced, with some being obviously stronger but none are unplayable necessarily.
- Destructive/Dramatic finishes still make me giddy 200+ hours later.
- My computer is essentially run by a hamster on a wheel and I can run it on the highest graphics.
- You can see how good or bad the connection is before you play someone online.
- The tag team system is incredible and extends combos far beyond their natural limitations.

Cons
- The story mode, except for my waifu Android 21, is subpar at best
- Steep learning curve (Not necessarily a con but you will get your shit pushed in for a while online and especially in competitive).
- No punishment for leavers in online matches, and you won't get the win if they do leave. (However when people leave too many times their name shows up as purple in lobbies and you can choose to decline them).
- As someone relatively high up on the competitive ladder (500,000+ BP) I can state without a doubt that this is the most corner oriented fighting game I've ever seen, some characters like Cell and Hit can pull off otherwordly combos when they have their opponent pinned to the side of the screen.
- The game with the season pass is honestly pretty pricey, but I love this game to death so I personally didn't mind.

Meh
- Arcade mode is rather reptitive, just like the story mode, but you can unlock Goku Blue and Vegeta Blue instead of buying them as DLC if you do well enough, plus the mode earns you a ton of in game currency you can use to get alternate costumes and such.
- A lot of the time your performance in game is dependent on how patient you are, if you try to mash buttons while you're being combo'd you're going to immediatlely be swept up in another combo that takes half, if not more of your health. But when you land those ridiculous combos one after another and make an amazing 1 v 3 comeback you won't be complaining.

Overall
I'd give this game a 9/10, because I can't stress enough how unique and addicting this game is. It has a few flaws both in the gameplay and in its matchmaking/lobby system, but in my opinion the mechanics, graphics, and artstyle more than make up for it. Honestly a near perfect rendition of a 2D fighting Dragon Ball game.

29/05/18 UPDATE
Can't stop playing. It's still good! Balance changes and new characters have kept things fresh and the game has proven to be as deep as it appeared, there's so many avenues to improve on. The game is not without issue, though, as netcode can be janky, and leavers get to save their rank - but it's still a great fighter with a healthy PC community.

ORIGINAL

This game does 3v3 better than Marvel vs Capcom ever did. I didn't enjoy 3v3 fighters before, and I was hesitant when I saw that this game would be in that format, but I needn't have worried:

 DBFZ is fantastic. A few days in, its becoming clear the game will have an extremely high skill cap, but it also has one of the lowest skill floors of any fighting game I've played. 

Anyone can pick this up and play it, making it a good entry point for noobs to fighting games. While this game won't totally melt your brain to start learning it, it has more depth than the average player will get close to mastering. 

The graphics are incredible, when I first saw how things were rendered I thought I was looking at clips from the show. Best looking 2D game I've ever laid eyes on. This is also the best DBZ game PERIOD. Of all the DBZ fighters I've played from ps1 onwards, this one is the closest to actually giving you the feel of a DBZ battle. All the characteristics of them are there, and in the right proportions. Instant transmission, lvl 1 and lvl 3 supers all have appropriate power and frequency of use, for example. The characters get their personalities across very well and there are lots of matchup specific moments and voice lines. Much love and care went into making this, by a team who are clearly fans of the series. 

If you're willing to put a day or two into learning some fundamentals, I'm sure you won't regret your purchase.

Absolutely fantastic Dragon Ball/Fighting game.
From the looks it is the best incarnation of Dragon Ball in any medium and the references are on point.
The combat is easy to learn but very hard to master. IF you are a pink colored player you can be really proud of yurself (I am orange).
The problems with this game are unfortunately many, that could be improved. There isn't a lot engaging singleplayer content and IMO, always playing online can get somewhat exhausting since you always feel some pressure, even in non-ranked games, since they also determine your threat color.
There is no penalty for leavers and the matchmaking can be frustrating, especially for newcomers.

But the positive aspects of this gem really surpass the negative points I just counted cause they nail every aspect of gameplay, style and most importantly it captures the very essence of the later Dragon Ball.

And this game has also unexpectedly cool sounding quotes, which I should quote more often in real life
It's the second best modern fighting game after Killer Instinct.

Fantastic team-based three on three fighter similar to other 'vs' style games, Dragonball Fighterz is a breath of fresh air in the DBZ franchise that offers something for everyone, no matter if you're an ardent follower of the pro scene or a casual who may have played a Budokai game in the past.

The only negatives would be the lack of playerbase in the oceanic region - although there are definitely people playing this game, once you hit a certain rank you're going to see the same players every night and it usually takes 5-10 minutes to find a match. This of course can't be attributed to the game but the lobby disconnect errors certainly can, and if you're in a populated lobby the chance you'll be getting bounced out of a game (except for ring matches) will increase the more people there are. Since the playerbase has dropped off significantly this is rarely an issue.

Frame delay is minimum of 2 which is super playable and is hardly noticable if your opponent has a strong connection. More often than not it'll be 2-4 frames delay with a touch of lag here and there.

Pros and Cons at bottom.

It's pretty good. Looks wise it's beautiful, can't fault that at all. Gameplay wise it's easy to pick up, but ultimately if you're up against someone who knows the game and they get their combo's rolling your goose will be cooked. Not a huge fan of the fact you can be trained 100-0 sometimes purely by someone getting you in a combo loop and dropping everything on your head. ('Git Gud' as my pals tend to say.)
Combat is very tight. As I said, easy to pick up with plenty to get to master. Story mode is utter trash with having to do several levels repeating the same fights against 'clones' (aka recolours of character.) Would of been nice to see a little more effort put into that. Ultimately you're paying for the online experience which I can't comment on. A lot of very skillful people play the game online, however, and it would be wise of you to invest in getting to know three characters fairly well via practice mode before going online. Even then you'll get an utter beating until you build up experience of the game. (I came across a player who had 3000+ matches. Like, holy hell.)
Personally I think the music is garbage, too. I've played since Budokai on PS and the music there was always pretty good. The lack of arena selection and character selection also disappoints but we'll see what happens going forward.

Not nearly enough arenas

Music is garbage compared to past DBZ games. (Seriously, look up Budokai 2+3's music.)
Challenging against better skilled players who can train you into a corner and destroy you.

This is a prett good game to get started in fighting game, also, for those of you who play Xenoverse or some form of 3D "fighting game", you have to be prepared to learn, this game might be the few slightly easier fighting game, it is still hard, you have to be willing to learn, but once you learn the game, it is very fun

If you've never experienced the true joys of fighting games, of training up a bit and learning to play them well, improving constantly and carrying in your chest a competitive spirit, a desire to test your mettle against all others who would dare to face you.

These themes might sound familiar to you if you are a fan of the Dragon Ball, Z, Super, etc, as that is the nature of Son Goku.  Over the course of his life, Son Goku has faced ever increasing peril, each situation more dangerous than the last.  Despite this, he shows no fear.  He faces a series of foes that are powerful beyond reason and malevolent beyond despair with a big dumb smile on his face, because even though everything he cares about is on the line, he like all of the saiyan race, simply relishes the challenge above all else.

Playing this game with seriousness is like walking the path of Goku.  You'll get your ass kicked a lot, but like a saiyan, you won't grow unless you're battered in the fray.  You'll get frustrated, go online and learn new stuff, do a little better next time, your power level always rising as you fight your way through.  (Incidentally, I wouldn't bother much with the offline content, it's good to play when you're just starting out but it'll cause you to develop bad habits because computers play very differently and generally poorly compared to humans.)

This is the absolute perfect "my first fighting game" game.  It has tons of tutorials, and has a unique mechanic called "auto-combo".  Each character has a light auto-combo and a medium auto-combo that can be executed by mashing the light or medium buttons respectively.  They generally don't do very much damage and are very far from optimal, but they will teach you how combos work, feel, and flow.  The game has several mechanics like this, which are not only practical but also help to teach.  Learning to play this game will make you better at nearly any fighting game, and I would also go as far to say that Dragon Ball Fighter Z is an E-sports quality game in its own right.

I suppose I'd be remiss if I didn't talk about graphics and other features.  The look and feel of this game is 3 rungs up from any other dragon ball game as far as evoking the look and feel of the show.  The action is fast and sharp, the character models are beautifully done, the stages while few are functional and nostalgic, without being too distracting - we're here to fight not stargaze.  I will say that I was not and am not fond of the story mode, and also find the whole lobby and menu system to be odd, irrelevant, annoying, and think it's pointless, but it's out of sight out of mind once you get your queue going and get into the practice mode.  I also find it frustrating that you can't send or receive messages from the people you face online.  Fortunately neither of these small annoyances affects the actual gameplay, which is spectacular.

Anyway, I've gotten a ton of hours out of this game most of which was very fun, very satisfying, for the record I haven't played 500+ hours  like my profile suggests, I just keep the game open all the time.  

I honestly think this is the best fighting game on the market, although I understand if you prefer Smash, Street Fighter or Tekken.  I also think this game is simultaneously more accessible than any of those other games, and also as deep or deeper in terms of technique.

After finally getting back into the game I decided to rewrite my review for this game. 

For a fighting game, the playerbase is still going strong and it's pretty quick to find opponents (here in the US anyway).

Each character is unique in their own way, and can play much different from each other. Gives much more diversity in using different characters to choose from.

This is the true Marvel VS Capcom killer, it beats MVC Infinite by leagues with graphics, gameplay, and actual working online play.

You may even find an interest for this game if you liked the old-school MVC games and not even be a fan of DBZ, but is a major plus if you do love the anime series.

Story mode:

Online:

Characters:

Everyone else is pretty bad, or just has a good z assist so the good characters can keep you in corners and make you their bitch. 

fighting system:
This game has the most bullshit, most uncreative fighting system ive ever played. There are no combo breaks, and so everytime you get into a combo you are stuck in it, until: 1. they kill you. 2. they mess up (but in the higher places its rare that they mess up). Characters have easy combos that can be chained into a 3 bar super. Ex; broly, he can start a combo and grab you by your foot, and get a free super attack, and there is nothing you can do about it. Every character has 1 combo, you are going to see the same cell combo everytime, the same android 16 combo everytime. This is so unoriginal and bullshit. It goes off "first hit you win" bs. Ive seen gameplay of low level and high level. Its the same shit, of getting you into a corner, and just punishing you until you mess up on guarding. 

Graphics:
The only good thing about this game is that its flashy, but thats it.


Overrall: 
2/10

Please note that I played the game using the following:
[quote]
PC:
[list]
[*]GTX 960 2 GB
[*]i3-6300 @ 3.8 GHz
[*]8 GB RAM
[*]Windows 10
[/list]

Peripherals:
[list]
[*]Xbox One controller
[*]Dualshock 3 (with a third party driver)
[*]Razer Panthera Arcade Stick (for PS3 and PS4) (with a first party XInput driver)
[/list]
[/quote]

Now, let's begin the review.


[h1]Dragon Ball FighterZ is...[/h1]


[h1]+ very Dragon Ball.[/h1]

A fighting game's got to have sick characters, and a Dragon Ball game's got to have sick Dragon Ball characters.

Thankfully, this game's got a bunch of sick Dragon Ball characters. DBFZ features series staples like Goku, Vegeta, and Freiza, and even features some unexpected, but welcome, characters like Nappa, Captain Ginyu, and Tien. Dragon Ball fans should have no problem finding at least a few characters they like in this game.

What's really great about this game's cast is how well its characters have been faithfully adapted to the game from the source material. From signature moves to basic punches and kicks to character mannerisms, nearly everything in this game is a reference to the Dragon Ball source material.

When you couple faithful character adaptations with Arc System Work's anime graphics magic, you get this game, the most Dragon Ball game in existence so far.


[h1]+ a satisfying gameplay experience.[/h1]

Expect speed, movement, oppressive offense, and long combos. This is a fighting game in the same vein as the Marvel vs. Capcom series, so DBFZ is definitely one of the faster-paced fighting games around. A lot of what I say in this section applies to a lot of fighting games, but my words apply to DBFZ especially.

There's a lot of fun to be had with DBFZ if you're interested in high-speed action.

Connecting with an attack in the open, mounting pressure, breaking defense, and doing big combos are all immensely satisfying. The game's much more stressful when you're on the defensive, but punishing an opponent for being risky or predictable during his/her offense can be just as satisfying and any offensive moment you make.

Basically, the game's a blast as long as you play well (by your own standards). When you make even just a few great gameplay moments happen, the game's fun regardless of whether you win or lose.

Furthermore, like any competitive game, this game only gets better as you get better. I mean, of course you would have more fun the more often you do sick stuff in the game.

Also note that, in this section, I've praised the game without ever mentioning the Dragon Ball franchise. I would play DBFZ even if it weren't a Dragon Ball game. DBFZ's just a blast. This game has the deep and satisfying gameplay I crave as a fighting game fan.


[h1]+ accessible and uncompromised.[/h1]

DBFZ is probably one of the easiest fighting games to learn and play around. In DBFZ, characters have few moves, combos have a straight-forward structure, and move execution doesn't get more complex than a half-circular motion on the stick/dpad/whatever.

You do have to learn how to play three characters, though.

If you've never played fighting games competitively, DBFZ is a great game to start with.

If you've played fighting games before, particularly 2D airdash-y fighting games like BlazBlue, Guilty Gear, Melty Blood, or Marvel vs. Capcom, you're going to take to this game very, very quickly.

Now, after I've just told you how easy this game is, let me tell you how hard this game is. This game's easy to play, but not easy to play well. It's a classic case of easy to learn, hard to master.

I remember reading an excellent quote on the internet somewhere. Please forgive me for forgetting your name, random internet user. The quote goes something like this: "DBFZ is easy to play, but when you play someone better than you, you don't get to play."

Truer words have never been written.


[h1]+ very playable online.[/h1]

DBFZ uses a delay-based netcode, meaning online matches have slightly more input lag than offline matches. It's a bit of a shame that delay is always going to be a factor, but the truth of the matter is that DBFZ feels fine online.

Most of the matches I've played have felt very good. Rarely have I played any matches I'd classify as laggy.

The following is kind of a side note, but I suppose it's relevant to the topic of lag:

I'd say that most of my online matches on PC feel less laggy than offline matches I've played on PS4. The PS4 version unfortunately features a noticable amount of input lag, while the PC version doesn't.

I haven't played any online matches on the PS4 version. Maybe if I had, I would have a completely different opinion about how DBFZ plays online. My guess is that I probably wouldn't like the experience.


[h1]- somewhat unreliable online.[/h1]

DBFZ's lobbies have connection issues, and the game's "ring match" sub lobbies are buggy. Expect to be randomly booted from lobbies and to be unable to rejoin a ring match that you were previously able to join.

DBFZ's lobbies are surprisingly flawed given how Arc System Works has made better functioning lobby systems before for their more recent Guilty Gear and BlazBlue games. I've never had problems with lobbies in those games before.

I wouldn't call DBFZ's unreliable lobby systems deal breakers, but I would call them painful to deal with.


[h1]- somewhat imbalanced.[/h1]

Character balance is a bit of an issue in DBFZ. The balance isn't so bad that some characters are broken and some characters are too weak to be playable, but there's definitely a sizeable power difference between the best characters and the rest of the characters.

Right now, Adult Gohan, Android 16, and Cell are the kings of the game. All three of these characters are the best at something and are good at about everything.

I've gotta stop myself here though. You're here for a review, not my "expert"-level [strike]complaints[/strike] character analyses.

I suppose it's cool that these characters are sick, but it's not really cool that everyone else is notably less sick.


[h1]? a repetitive but amusing story.[/h1]

DBFZ includes a story mode campaign. The story's predictable, and the fights against CPUs can get repetitive, but the character interactions are highly amusing.

The story mode is only barely worth playing for unlocking Android 21 and seeing Dragon Ball characters interact with one another.


[h1]? a bit of a chore depending on who you are.[/h1]

I don't like unlocking characters for fighting games. In fact, I'm not interested in unlocking things in general. I'm more interested in the grind of getting better at a game than I am in the grind of unlocking game content.

I know there are people out there that find satisfaction in unlocking things in games, so I don't want to mark DBFZ down for having three characters be unlockables.

Whether you like unlocking content or not, I think it's best that you are aware that Android 21, SSGSS Goku, and SSGSS Vegeta are locked from the start of the game.


[h1]... an excellent Dragon Ball game and an excellent fighting game.[/h1]

If you're interested in fighting games, this is the game for you to try. DBFZ's a nice and easy introduction to fighting games, and is a quality fighting game itself. You might want to wait for a sale, but personally, I would have bought this game even at full price, even if it weren't a Dragon Ball game. I just really like how DBFZ plays.

If you like Dragon Ball and aren't really interested in fighting games, I still think this game is worth a try. Depending on how big a fan you are of Dragon Ball, you might want to wait for this game to go on sale. There's a lot of Dragon Ball goodness here to admire.

If you like Dragon Ball and you like fighting games, then DBFZ is an easy recommendation, even at full price. You probably already have the game. I have no idea why you're reading this review. Thanks for reading, though!

Is good game

+ Looks fantastic overall; it cannot be understated how well DBZ‚Äôs art style fits into Guilty Gear Xrd‚Äôs special kind of 3d models, environments, and special effects  

- Minor visual nitpick: Most beam/explosion Destructive Finishers are yellow or blue, with some exceptions. 
Frieza‚Äôs death ball super, which is purple, has a yellow Destructive Finish, for example. This is a personal gripe if anything   

- Character color palette choices are played safe, almost to the point of being bland; 
you won‚Äôt find a saiyan who doesn‚Äôt have yellow hair, and you probably never will

- My machine experiences small frame stutters every now and then; your mileage may vary

- - -
+ Music is good, but there are no standout tracks, at least for me (Hit‚Äôs theme notwithstanding)

+ Both the English and Japanese voices are excellent; 
it‚Äôs the voice actors you know and love, and you can‚Äôt go wrong with either
	
- Unfortunately, you are unable to mix and match who voices what; it's either all English, or all Japanese

- For my machine at least, there was a headphone hot swapping issue:
plugging in headphones while the game is running will result in the audio being lost; you‚Äôll have to restart

- - -
+ MVC3-styled gameplay

+ Beginner friendly; but the depth for more advanced players is there

- The game favors aggressive/rushdown/pressuring playstyles, with not enough defensive options to combat this; 
there is no true pushblock, for example

- Personally, I feel like the Super Dash (character missile-homing ala Arcana Heart) 
and Dragon Rush (grabs) mechanics are too strong, and need to be toned down
 
- In line with that, quite a few moves are safe on block; you can get away with a lot

- - -
+ The title screen menu options are perfectly fine, I have no complaints;
configuring your buttons, for example, isn‚Äôt much of a hassle this time around

- The general idea of a lobby/hub that you access all the gamemodes from is cute, but in practice, it gets tired quickly; 
I would prefer standard menus to access the game‚Äôs content

- Back during the launch of DBFZ, because of hideous online infrastructure issues, you would be booted from the lobby to the title screen constantly. This isn‚Äôt as much of a problem now, but this didn‚Äôt change the negative experiences I had, due to my weekend being wasted

+ The lobby is not completely dry; you can customize your lobby avatar, stamps (emotes), player card and title, etc.

- Customization options are locked behind a gacha (lootboxes) shop. Thankfully, the gacha can only be bought with currency earned in-game, but that doesn‚Äôt change the fact that you might never get what you want.  
I would much prefer the plain old, ‚Äúthat customization item costs this much‚Äù system  

- - -
- Barebones tutorials and combo trials

- I am not a fan of DBFZ‚Äôs style of arcade mode for the following reasons:
  - There is no quick restart; this gets annoying quickly at higher difficulties/longer ladders
  - If you end a match with a B rank or lower, and are ‚Äúpunished‚Äù to taking a route that isn‚Äôt the top one, you‚Äôre better off 
  restarting the whole thing; this makes the entire idea behind DBFZ‚Äôs arcade pyramid ladder moot
  - Harder AI simply means that they will read your inputs, block everything, react inhumanely, do more damage then you, 
  build more meter than you, will kill your entire team in a few hits, and be generally cheap and cheesy
  - In the end, the rewards are not even worth it. Whether or not you got Blue Goku/Vegeta through arcade mode, once 
  you have them, you have no reason to touch it ever again

- The story mode is average at best; my thoughts:
  - You will be fighting the same kind of enemies for hours; there is little to no variety; 
  playing the story will get tedious fast
  - A large chunk of your playtime will be spent going through the same repeated tutorial prompts, which override the 
  enemy encounters, and are stuffed down your throat
  - Said enemy encounters are easy to the point of mind-numbing; the occasional boss fight is just as easy; 
  at the very least it is not on the extremely difficult side of the spectrum (which you can experience in the arcade mode)
  - The plot of the story mode is filled with a lot of nothing; any hints of potential to keep you invested are few and far 
  between
  + The character interactions, separate from the story‚Äôs plot beats, are quite good, highlights of the mode even; 
  in fact, they‚Äôre frankly the only hook to keep people playing
  + ...Other than to unlock Android 21, who looks interesting, and keeps the story‚Äôs heartbeat from flatlining. Pity she 
  ended up being very one dimensional

- I have nothing good to say about the online infrastructure for this game; long story short:
  - Constant boots out of the online lobby
  - Lengthy wait times for matchmaking
  - Matchmaking for the arena specifically is even worse
  - Netcode during online matches is spotty at the best of times
  - Getting boot from the lobby would kill your online match; this happened frequently
  - The ring match function did not work at all not too long ago
Though these issues are less prevalent now, they still exist; and my experience with DBFZ‚Äôs launch has colored my opinion towards the negative for the time being 

- Just one last personal gripe towards some specific achievements for DBFZ:
  - I feel that the 530k BP achievement is too high (at least for the PC player base),
  and singlehandedly resulted in the rage-quitting scourge we now suffer through
  - The 20 million zeni achievement is garbage, for obvious reasons. 
  1 million was fine enough; why they went even further beyond, I will never know

- - -
As a fighting game, DBFZ is great
As a video game, that‚Äôs an argument up for debate

As a licensed-anime title, it‚Äôs the best I played so far
But with all these trip ups, it doesn‚Äôt seem to hold up to par

Enough bars‚Äî
When its all said in done, there‚Äôs still plenty of potential here
I hope ArcSys learns from the master assassin Hit
and

to

This game has many aspects made to appeal to the casual Dragon Ball fans and hardcore gamers. It's biggest flaw isn't in the game itself but rather the community. 

If you're a casual gamer who's a fan of Dragon Ball, you're likely going to have complaints about the game. Sometimes you'll blame things like mechanics and combos on the game when it's of no fault to the game itself but rather due to your own lack of skill.

The most common complaints are usually:
The other person keeps comboing me for days.
My opponent keeps bipassing my blocks.
This character is broken.

These problems are all fixable with practice and communication. Fans of Dragon Ball should keep in mind, this game also attracts many fighting game enthusiasts. This means a large majority of people who play this game will likely have thousands of hours worth of practice not only in this game but in many other fighting games as well.

If you lose, it's not the game's fault, it's because you haven't gotten to that level of play and experience yet.

This is a very fun game.  Plyaing very similarly to the MvC series, just with Dragon Ball Z characters, this is the DBZ fighting game that fans have wanted for ages! 

That said, this game has many problems.  Some of which break the game.
1. Albeit a minor issue, $5 per DLC character is bullshit.  The characters also do not play very differently from one another, making the DLC not worth getting.
2. Repeated updates, patches, and fix attempts have all failed to actually fix any server issues.  This game's servers are TRASH and disconnect you every 30 seconds.  As a result, this game is ONLY fit to be played via LAN.  Online play does not work.
3. Story mode is stupid easy, with absolutly no challenge value whatsoever. 

As much as I love this game, any fighting game that forces only LAN play via broken servers cannot recieve my seal of approval.  I may come back at a later time and change this review to a positive one, but only when the devs finally fix the issues they have.  You know, instead of trying to cash grab with more DLC characters.

I am torn on this game. I have FighterZ on console as well and sadly the console version is better. The servers every now and then seem to kick you out after finishing a match with someone which leads to constant login back in and out. The other big problem is the matchmaking. I am around 490k Battle Points which test your skill. I have reached a point where the game thinks it is fair to almost exclusively give me higher level players. I have just played 3 700k BP players and up today. I wait and wait but still it is mostly higher level players.

Some 20 hours into this game, with very little prior FG experience.

The game is very much fun and beginner friendly, but it still has an incredibly steep learning curve. You gotta man up and practice, get wrecked 600 times and some more to be better. There is no other way. 

The game has beautiful graphics, the anime feel is amazing, and a huge bonus that it runs on potato PCs as well via resolution scaling. The fan service for DB fans is there (but I'm still waiting for a Roshi/Kid Goku DLC!). The fight is fluid, fun and spectecular, it's truly an instant classic. Microtransatcions are very limited, you can open every skin and cosmetic via (and only) in-game currency. The game gives you Zeni very generously too.

One major problem: the controller support for local games is abysmal. I play this game with an official X1 controller, my pal came over with his official PS4 controller. And we can't play, because the game recognises the PS4 controller as an input for both P1 and P2. This shouldn't happen in a game like this.

Overall I recommend this game and I give it a 8/10. I'd give a 9/10 or even a 10/10 if I could play locals properly.

In my opinion, Dragon Ball FighterZ is a great game. The game contains:


References and more story from the anime, but you don't need to watch the anime to play this game;

You would get some references if your a dragon ball boy, but even if you don't understand dragon ball, you can still play this game and a get a whole lot of fun out of it. They also have some special scenes which you can trigger by choosing specific characters or just killing the right enemy at the end with a heavy.

Its gameplay:

This game is out of the ordinary of most fighting games. You have 3v3's which are in some games (im assuming) and uses assists. The gameplay is easy to get into, but hard to master, but most combos are literally easy to master, and there are auto combos for you peeps out there who aren't experienced in fighting games.

Its graphics:

Don't even get me started on these dam graphics. I tried this on a gaming PC and a Intel graphics laptop, and the game is still playable on low settings on a standard PC. The graphics on this game at high settings are just beautiful, crisp 2.5D action, The super attack animations and the dramatic finishs are just amazing.

Its story:

The story takes place on a world where clones are made and a android, named 21, specifcally made by Akira Toriyama, takes control of the red ribbon army, and clones are being made everywhere. You play as a little spirit or something taking control of the Heroes or the Villians, depending on which story mode you tackle, Hero Arc, Villian Arc, or Android Arc. Clones are made everywhere by I believe 21? And you have to stop her.

Characters:

The characters you get to play as each have their own playstyle, techniques, assists, and combos. The characters in the game so far (5/4/18) Are SSJ Goku. SSJ Vegeta, SSJ2 Teen Gohan, SSJ Trunks, Piccolo, Krillin ( oh god ), Yamcha, Tien, SSJ3 Gotenks, Adult Gohan (Ultimate), Android 18, Android 16, Beerus, Frieza, Cell, Majin Buu, Nappa, Captain Ginyu, Kid Buu, Goku Black, Hit, SSGSS Goku ( unlockable ), SSGSS Vegeta ( unlockable ), Android 21 ( unlockable ), Bardock ( DLC ) and Broly ( DLC ). They all have different special attacks that represent their power and their abilites, and all are fun to play as.

Online:

Now, online is fun, but as here it can be fun depending on wifi, or you or the opponents sanity. I've tried playing online, but it gets laggy a lot because either wifi, or something else. Half the time though, you'll experience rage quitters ( which believe me, is not fun ) and it just ruins online. But most of the time its pretty fun, and you can do ring matches with your friends and just have a good time.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I guess thats all I gotta say as of now, I would give this game a 9.5/10. I would say buy it, this game will last a hell load of fun for ya, and you can have some fun with your friends.
Its guuuud

If the fact that I have played this game for 20+ hours is anything to go by, I think this game is great - I haven't touched the story mode yet despite that, as my 20+ hours were spent in online matches and training mode.

With that said, I would like to get my biggest complaint about the game out of the way first- I personally think the matchmaking algorithm is bad, for example, when I set the search parameters to look for players that are the 'Same as me', I would either get players whose BP are much higher or lower than mine - I don't think there was one game where the opponent had the same, or was close to my BP level. In short, if I wanted to fight better players, I would pick to search for players 'Stronger than me' - not have some thrown at me when I'm looking for an even game.

I should stress that the rest of the game - at least from what I've seen, does more than make up for the matchmaking, with it's impressive visuals and animations, respect for the source material (there are an abundance of references to both the manga and anime series, from scenarios, dialogue between characters, even movesets are based on what each Fighter can do canonically) and responsive and easy to learn controls. The cast of characters is great, although with the upcoming Vegito Blue DLC, there are a little too many Gokus for my liking. The music is great too, with the exception of a couple of character specific themes, namely Android 21 and Broly's themes (For 21, it sounds like a generic final boss theme that lacks any thrill whatsoever, and for Broly, it's way too loud and distracting). Vegeta, Android 18, and Goku Black have the best themes in the game - give them a listen, either while you're fighting or when training!

This game isn't just a fighting game to me, this game is something else, something special if you will. I was a Dragon Ball fan for as long as i can remember, watching the original series up until the end of Super. Throughout the years i have been waiting for THAT Dragon Ball game, the one that would transcend fans of the series and can just enjoy alone and with a buddy or two. Dragon Ball FighterZ scratched that itch. From the first trailer i could see that this game was gonna be a HUGE thing. I pre-ordered it for $80 and i can tell you now, as college student who's daily meal consists of noodle packs that cost less than a dollar, that this game is worth every single penny i threw at it. 

Story:
This is probably the weakest aspect of the game because it is so inconsistent. The writing is awesome with a lot of cool character interactions and nailing their mannerisms and ideals. the addition of Android 21 as a antagonist is also fresh in the sense that there we get to see a new Dragon Ball baddy as supposed to recycling villains already established in the lore. For a new charcater she fits in well with the rest of the cast and is a good standalone character. However the main weakness of the story is how the story is structured. You have to fight through wave after wave of weak ass clones to get to the "boss" of the stage and move on, all while saving other familiar Dragon Ball characters. The problem with this is that it makes battles extremely boring since there is no proper build up to those fights. Something like a netherrealm style big story mode would have been a lot better. 

Visuals and Sound:
This. Game. Looks. AWESOME. The game's presentation is excellent. Characters look detailed and move fluidly across the screen. Particle effects are large and in your face but not distracting enough to take you out of the action. The dynamic camera everytime you use a super is excellent, it brings you closer to the action and gives a awesome visual flare that makes the game that much more fun to play. The close up of Piccolo's face and seeing his veins when he uses Light Grenade, seeing the Cell's smug smile when using Solar Kamehameha, the spinning camera when Gohan uses the Father-Son Kamehameha stopping behind him to reveil Goku standing behind him, its all done beautifully. The game's dramatic starts and finishes provide fanservice and visual flare that makes the game all the better. I only wished there were more "what if" dramatic finishes but with the amount there are already i can't complain. The soundtrack and voices in this game are also stellar. With both the option of Japanese and English voices and each character having their own theme. Although some voice actors are underplayed or overplayed depending the overall performances of the cast are really good. Especially the Japanese voice actor for Broly and the english voice actor for Vegeta.

Gameplay:
This game made me love fighting games. This game is the pinacle of easy to play but hard to master. It uses a system inspired by Marvel vs Capcom 3 and added to it. This game does have two autocombo buttons but to do optimal damage you need to know a lot of tricks of the trade and explore the mechanics within the game or if you want to play with auto combos you can as well.It feels really god to learn something in this game as you see it pull off on screen you feel a sense of pride and joy. While i will say i'm not the best at this game (i'm average at best) it is still a blast to play. Never before has losing looked and felt so good. 

In summary:
Graphics, visuals and Presentation: 10/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Story: 7.3/10
Sound: 9.8/10
Fun factor: 10/10
Overall: 9.8/10

I love fighters and this one is a great one. I for one love the fast paced, team-based type of fighters such as MvC and what have you; for me this game is perfect. It combines my childhood memories with my favorite game genre. For people out there that are struggling let me say this. I do love fighters, but i was never really great at them. i would play causually for the most part. But for this game, i really fell in love and wanted to get good. All it takes is patience and determination above all else. if u give up because u are to frustrated with your own gameplay or blame some game mechanic and not yourself, that is where u fail. you should always try to get better and improve if u truly do want to get good. Watch good players online, look into your specific characters and watch whoever is good at playing them, watch your own replays, learn, learn, and LEARN. there is always something you can do better. And another thing, combos arent everything. What new people tend to do is just practice combos which isnt particularly bad, but there is no point in practicing combos if you cant even land the hit. You should first try to understand neutral, blocking, and turns. I cant write everything here that you need to do (would be waaaaaaay to long), but my point is if u truly want to get good at this game, you need to put in work. I myself never thought i would be getting to where i am in the game now. Trust me, if u work hard, it will truly pay off and you will have fun. I HIGHLY recommend this game. Absolutely incredible.

I will start off with saying that this game is awesome.  If you are a fighting game fan or a Dragon Ball fan you will like this game.  The system is easy to pick up and there is a lot of depth and things to master.  The animation is top notch and it honestly seems like you are watching an episode of the manga.  Not eveyrthing is sunshine and rainbows though.  The lobby while a good idea in theory can be cumbersome and down right annoying.  I wish there was an optional version where you didn't have to deal with it.  Especially if you know what you want to do already.  Online is hit or miss.  The net code is delay based and not rollback which is discouraging.  Online can also not match you to the right skill level or takes forever to get a match.  There should also be more information about your upcoming opponent.  Overall this is a reallyg ood game which I hopes keeps improving.

This game is fantastic to say the least. Visually it is the best looking Dragonball game to date with the fighters moving at what looks like 24fps to reference back to the animes, while the special FX run at 60fps for smooth and good looking special attacks. Fighting locations are 2-d side scrolling, like BlazBlue or Mortal Kombat, with parellaxed backgrougnd to give an effect of depth. Overall combat is very fluid with good hitboxes and fun mechanics involving super and ultimate attacks. $60 game $35 season pass, so much fun i bought it for myself and 3 friends (and once on ps4 for work).. Best Dragonball game to date IMO.
Now that thay fixed their terrible server issues (have been fixed for a while) game is worth buying.

Ever since this game was released, I had plans to buy it as soon as it went on sale.
...Of course, I got tired of waiting and just paid the $60.
36 hours in, I think I am ready to write a review.

Pros:
-Very Dragon Ball (Most characters feel like they play just about exactly how they should)
-Unique Characters
-(Sort of) easy to jump into
-Great on Local Multiplayer (Unless you use the Keyboard for some reason, and you will still need 2 controllers).
-Easy to enter multiplayer
-Multiplayer is available right from the start
-Tutorial is to the point
-Story mode does a great job of starting you off

Cons:
-Online Play can (sometimes) be pretty laggy
-Casual players are usually BETTER than the lower tier ranked players
-Ranked players are usually extremely good
-It's incredibly hard to get into a match with someone on your (starting) level
-Player challenge rating is unreliable until you are ranked.
-Ring matches are almost impossible to join (usually)
-The entire existance of Android 16 and Kid Buu


Looking at current and future DLC:

Pros:
-Bardock plays quite well
-Broly plays about how you'd expect
- [spoiler] Fused Zamasu's flight ability will make him very unique [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Vegito. Do I actually have to clarify? (seriously though, he seems like a more balanced grab character than Android 16) [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Potentially interesting gameplay with the base form Saiyans [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] A possibly very defensive character with Android 17 [/spoiler]

Cons:
-Each character is a whopping $5
-Episode of Bardock is acknowledged
-Broly is acknowledged
- [spoiler] Zamasu's flight is potentially overpowered, and his immortality will likely be underrepresented [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Everything about Vegito is perfect [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Existence of Base form Saiyans is unneccesary, and assures that we will get 2 less characters that were majorly wanted [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Android 17 could make Android 18 make less sense [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] I cant invision Cooler being much different from Freeza, since his moveset is pretty similar [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Cooler is acknowledged [/spoiler]


Overall, I would say this game is worth it. I plan on playing more in the future, and with the huge balancing fix coming soon, many gripes I have will likely be resolved.

After the disappointment of several entries into the Dragon Ball video game series and Marvel VS. Capcom: Infinite, I was hopeful that Dragon Ball FighterZ was going to be the fighting game I long hoped for. I'm delighted to say that it's even better than that!

Aside from the stunning visuals, ARC System Works have done an incredible job of making a 2D fighting game so accessible, yet so deep. The character selection is fantastic and there are so many moments which live long in the memory when taking on players from around the world.

If there's one down side to the game, it's definitely the Story Mode. Even though the dialogue in between fights is good, the fights themselves are too easy and very repetitive. 

As someone who put a LOT of hours into SFV, I feel very happy with DBFZ and I'll no doubt be disappointing Vegeta until I'm in Oblivion.

I'm trash at Dragon Ball Fighterz and that's okay.

I think it's important to go into this noting that I'm not great at traditional fighting games - MvC, BlazBlue, Street Fighter, etc. I'm awful at learning combos, a bit of a button masher and, as this game is constantly teaching me, I can't block.

However, those are problems on my end. It's not a flaw on the game's part if I have trouble with certain things, both small and large (I seriously need to figure out how to improve my blocking online, I held the back direction for an entire match and they got a perfect on me) but at the same time, you need to keep in mind this game will have a learning curve and be an uphill battle if you're like me and not normally great at these games.

That being said, I absolutely love Fighterz. As a huge fan of Dragon Ball for as long as I can remember, this game is a perfect example of the high energy, character and action that is Toriyama's manga. The game is a passion project that has reminded me of how much I enjoy this franchise and the value I hold for each of its characters.

Despite the difficulties I've mentioned as a player, Fighterz offers a great deal in the way of training its players. From its fantastic tutorial and combo challenges to introduce us to each of the 24 characters (the former teaching basic mechanics in an easy to define way, the latter requiring us to perform 10 combos with a character for each of our roster) and learning the basics of the game. I was familiar with L,M,H and their crouching variants but before these tutorials I never experimented with combos, assists and the like and as a result of these, alongside the community's own guides I've been able to at least make a dent in the mountain I've got to climb if I want to be good.

Each of the 24 has an enjoyable playstyle that does well in exemplifying who they were in the series and what they contribute to the franchise. I can say after playing them all that I've liked almost everyone of them and think they all can act as a valuable member of whatever team you decide to build.

The only issue I would say this game suffers from is an awful story mode, full of repeated fights, terrible AI that will just stand still the whole match and a dragged out story. These parts of the game really weaken the overall product by acting as hours of boredom that are only saved by the Fighterz-exclusive character Android 21, a fun and likeable addition to the cast and the DB fandom, and the individual character interactions the game presents based on whatever team you assemble. Gohan asking Vegeta to train after being scolded, Ginyu being too afraid to steal Cell's body because his skin pattern reminds him of a frog, Android 18 making fun of Yamcha's uselessness and more are all some of the great conversations you can unlock that will give the wide cast of characters chances to have conversations about topics the series generally does not let them do.

Overall, Fighterz is a fantastic game full of great characters to learn and combinations to master as you get better with it, offering a great new fighter in the form of Android 21 but unfortunately offers players a storymode that is basically practice mode without auto-recovery health.

For those reasons, I give Fighterz an 8/10

I've been a pretty big dragonball for most of my 30 something years and this is quite easily the best Dragonball game ever made. Simple really, if you like fighting games and DBZ, then here, have this as a gift from the gods.

the gameplay in DBFZ is a blast with its wacky DBZ mechanics and team versus gameflow. the game is pretty unique, but it still works very well and very much feels like a good ass anime fighter, rather than weird fan service or a party game. if you like dragonball and you like anime fighters, chances are youll like DBFZ

it is a pretty easy game to pick up and learn, and definitely isnt on the level of fundamental depth you find in games like guilty gear or tekken, but that doesnt mean the game is weak. its fun and challenging in its own right, as well as being very open to casuals and newcomers, and theres still a lot to learn and get good at in regards to managing your team, team synergy, movement and spacing, proper use of the games mechanics, all that shit

admittedly, this game has a few quirks that have definitely tired me out:

>[i]ridiculously[/i] long combos. the damage is more or less fair, but between all the assist extensions, vanishes, super animations and whatever, youre going to be watching for 10-15+ seconds on a regular basis. im use to combos, ive been playing FGs casually for half of my life, but DBFZs combos overstay their welcome imo and make it difficult to shrug off getting hit. theyre fun to do and all, but in DBFZ moreso than many other fighters, it sucks to be subjected to them

>character imbalance. its nothing too crazy that you cant beat these characters as long as youre decent at the game and know the matchups, but there is a painfully obvious meta. adult gohan and cell are amazing characters that are just generally more capable than any other char in the roster with great pressure and shit, android 16 gets hard knockdowns whenever he wants and is a grappler with every tool he needs as well as amazing movement thanks to DBFZs gameplay, goku black to a lesser extent is an almost perfect character with tools for everything you could want and no real weaknesses, and vegetas assist outshines all other assists by a extravagantly clear margine. its annoying to have a team put together that you really like when you know so many people default to a combination of the above few characters

>lack of developer support beyond quality-of-life changes and season pass content. there have been a variety of welcome tweaks to the menu system and junk since release, and the DLC characters are being churned out slowly but surely. however, there are still glaring issues with the games lobby system and netcode, nothing has been done to attempt to balance the roster, and theres no way to interact with other players ingame on PC, just off the top of my head. since release, while i maintained hope that some things were getting ironed out, nothing has changed with the games obvious problems/shortcomings

thats all i personally have to complain about, though, and it wont really disrupt your enjoyment of the game if you can look past this stuff. ive stopped playing more or less at around 200 hours in favor of tighter and more involved games like tekken and guilty gear, but i can recommend DBFZ

if you involve yourself in a community like the r/dragonballfighterz discord, youre bound to learn and have a good time playing with peeps. the game plays great, and the awesome visuals, sounds (bar a glitchy crackle here and there), and recognizeable characters are really sweet icing on the cake. just remember that fighting games arent for the faint of heart; be okay with getting your shit pushed and be prepared to learn and apply yourself

As a fighting game: This game stands king. This is the game SO many people have been looking forward to. A pure fighting game, with proper mechanics and Dragon Ball characters to boot. However, personally, I didn't care for it and here's why:

#001: 3 vs 3. This creates FAST gameplay, devastating combos and flashy attacks. You see characters switching in and out of the screen, practically flawless and fluid. However, I am one of the minority who just can't get into this. It's in my opinion, messy and supports button mashing all too well. If you aren't good at the game, don't even step into mutiplayer. You'll be dead in seconds. Literally. If you're looking for some classic 1v1 fighting, you're better off playing one of the old budokai games on PS2.

#002: Auto combos. This is probably the worst thing about the game. There seems to be no actual timing required to use combos, with some combos even letting you hold your button down. While this is beginner friendly, it's near impossible not to be touched in game by a masher, no matter how well you play.

#003: Transformations: One of the biggest letdowns, for me personally, was the inability to transform at will with a separate energy source. Even the old budokai games had this. The ability to push the battle one step further and transform into a super saiyan at will would have been a great feature. Instead, you have to use ultimates and combos to "transform" then "transform back". Just like Xenoverse, they'd rather create a separate character for this, instead of implementing a method of transformation.

What I liked:

#001: Graphics: Supporting rather low end processors and graphics cards, this game is absolutely stunning in visuals. Cranking them up to max feels satisfying as you pound your opponent into the dirt using flashy combos and powerful ki blasts with a fluid 60 frames.

#002: Soundtrack: From the moment you turn the game on, you are seduced by an awesome soundtrack that really helps you feel the heat from the battles. 

#003: Roster: With a growing roster and fan favorite characters, you almost forget that you're usually fighting the same person you're using. However, compared to games such as those in the Naruto franchise, and Budokai Tenkaichi 3, the roster is lacking.

Overall: The game delivered what it promised. It's a bit too fast paced for my liking, but it stands as the best fighting game in years.  Personally, I've been missing the "old" style of Dragon Ball games, which seems to have died off after Raging Blast 2.  A cool 3D world where your attacks create craters, you're able to freely transform and overpower your opponents, with a roster of 50+ characters. Those are the games I miss. FighterZ is a great game, but Budokai Tenkaichi 3 stands as the king of Dragon ball Z games.

By far my favorite fighting game since Marvel vs Capcom 2.  This is the first time in over a decade I have wanted to really commit to a game, get good, and compete.  This game oozes with quality and love.  It's an absolute masterpiece.

Very few cons, mainly a heavy story. If you aren't the kind of person who wants a lot of plot, you may have trouble getting through it. However,  the extremely simple teaching of basic fighting game controls are a godsend; it also leads players into more advanced combinations as they learn each individual essential ability. Additionally, almost nothing from the game seems impossible to understand. The information onscreen is clear cut, and chances are if you encounter the rare lack of understanding what you saw, it's simply a character specific combo someone has practiced.

Would highly recommend for players both new to and experienced in the fighting genre.

Dragoball Fighterz is an exciting and thrilling fighting game that appeals to both hardcore fighting fans and also towards the casual crowd.  I'm not an experianced fighting vet, hell I rarely play any type of fighting game and I can tell you that this game is not too hard to get into. New comers can fight using the games auto combo system which can be done by mashing light or medium buttons respectivly.  This allows new players to land 6-8 hit combos without having to learn to fight manually, but learning to fight manually rewards the player with extra damage and allows to extend combos further and being able to reach up 100 hits. If your a Dragonball fan and want to play this game try playing online using the auto combo system and when learning the basic use the games practice mode to learn how to extend combos and maybe learn to combos manually. This game is perfect for Dragonball fans and fighting game veterans.

I'm pretty new to traditional fighting games, and my friends told me that if I wanted to get into 2D fighters, this game would be a good start.  So I decided to pick up the game and here is what I think of it.
          
           Overall, the game is pretty good but highly overpriced for what it is.  The graphics are nice and the gameplay is pretty solid, but it's nothing to get excited about.  The story mode is to simply put it,  terrible, and unlocking the three secret characters is a long and painful process.  One of them you can only unlock by completing the previously mentioned horrible story mode, and for the other two you're probably better off just buying them as DLC.  On the topic of DLC, the devs announced that there will be not one, or two, but eight total DLC characters that were going to be released in the future.  Now I would be okay with this but they made this announcement BEFORE THE GAME'S INITIAL RELEASE!  This makes me feel that the game is being treated more like some sort of cash cow rather than a proper flagship title.  Summing it up, only buy this game if it's on sale. I cannot reccomend buying it for full price as I can't think of a reason to validate the sixty dollar price tag.

UPDATE:  So the first DLC characters came out fairly recently and for what they are, they are extremely overpriced just like the rest of this game.  The hefty price tag on the DLC Characters pretty much confirms my thoughts on this game being nothing more than a money pit  of sorts for the devs, which makes me sad because the game itself isn't bad and has potential to be really good.  Needless to say, I will not buy the DLC.

To put it simply, this is the best fighting game of all time. Marvel Infinite dropped the ball, and ArcSys decided to pick it up, give it a few looks over, and said "Yeah we can make this look like a Dragon Ball."

Make no mistake, this is a proper fighting game first. A team fighter at that. Assists are incredibly important, it is a high speed game, and to the random onlooker it can be hard to figure out what in the world is going on. Dragon Ball fighting games have been around for a VERY long time.  Going back to the super famicom days.  I have played many, and never got past putting a few hours into each.  This is the Dragonball Fighting game all fans have been waiting for.  If you like the Dragon Ball series and/or comics, you have to get this game.  You have been dissapointed before, but this is what you have dreamed of.  As a long time fighting game fan (street fighter series being my favorite), you have to get this game also.  Although anybody can pick it up and kick butt, there is alot of skill to be attained here.  If you hate Dragon Ball and are a fighting game fan, then this might not be for you.  If you dont care one way or another and are a fighting game fan, then I would definintly give this a try.  If you love Dragon Ball and love fighting games, then you will probably want to use your child's back to school money for this.  They don't need pencils.

This game is the first fighting game that manages to allow casual players to have a good time without compromising depth. The mechanical depth of the game is about as much as you might find in any other competitive fighting game. The roster might be a bit on the smaller side, but each character has enough unique aspects to how they play that the game's roster feels nicely filled out. The gameplay is sharp, responsive, complex, and most of all fun. Each hit lands with the same kind of power you'd expect from characters hailing from the king of over the top action, Dragon Ball Z, the attacks are fast, flashy, satisfying and gorgeous.
The game's visuals and sound design are killer, especially the former. The deceptively simple looking character models manage to come alive, ending up far more animated and expressive than any other Dragon Ball game to date. The bright colors and simple but dynamic cell shading do a good job not only making the game look gorgeous, but providing visual clarity, as it's always obvious what attack each character is throwing out through easily readable silhouettes and models that never feel to visually busy.
To top it off, there's plenty of fanservice for people picking up the game based on a love of the show rather than the competitive gaming scene. Characters have special voice lines, animations, match finishers, and more that manage to provide fun entertainment for longtime fans (like myself) without affecting gameplay at all. Seeing Krillin replace Android 17 to team up with 18 to deliver a powerful combo or reliving the heart pounding moment when Gohan overpowered Cell has never been more satisfying, as the player is given the power to do it themselves.
The game isn't perfect, however. The online and offline lobby system is clunky and unneccessary, the season pass DLC model adds an extra $35 expense to a game that's already full price, and while the balance is quite impressive, there are a few characters that as of now feel just a bit better than all the others. However, these aren't enough to dissuade me from reccommending this game to fans of the show and FGC lab monsters alike, as it's an absolute blast with a currently thriving community.

TL;DR, good for FGC pros and casual players alike, good fanservice that doesn't affect the game, holy shit the visuals, DLC model sucks but still highly reccommend

I have very mixed feelings about DBFZ. I've been a Dragon Ball fan for as long as I can remember, way back to watching the original series on a crappy color TV back in the 90's. The last game in the series I played was Budokai 3. The 3d games just didn't look good to me and after seeing the gameplay for them I just couldn't get hyped about the idea. Then the first footage for this game dropped. I thought to myself, 'Finally! It's like Budokai 4! I've been waiting so long for this!' Quite honestly, it's a fan's wet dream. The characters are gorgeous, the music gets you pumped up, and a lot of the awesome moves you've seen in the anime show up here recreated very faithfully. My problem is that I get fairly competitive when playing games against other players. In most games, that serves me just fine. In this game though, getting my ass kicked causes next level rage. Make no mistake, you will get your ass kicked. A lot. The better players can actually keep you air juggled for most of the match while you watch helplessly waiting for their combos to end. And that's my biggest problem playing online. There is NO WAY to get out of a combo until it's finished. If your opponent is skilled enough to pull aerial cancels they can keep that combo going for what feels like an age. This has led me to more than one smashed controller and I even had to stop playing for a while because all that anger built up to the point that it was toxic. My advice? If you're planning on getting the game but you're not great at fighting games, wait for a sale. It's only worth the full price tag if you're a fighting game veteran and can handle getting your ass kicked repeatedly on a regular basis.

Dragonball Fighter Z as a game is really something. It is probably the best looking fighting game I've ever seen. I love the fast-paced Marvel-style gameplay. The roster is pretty solid too, with a number of favourites that I really enjoy playing. This was only improved with the addition of Broly who has quickly become my favourite character. However, this is a local multiplayer experience. I say this because the online is straight up non-functional. After days of trying to play online just to get kicked repeatedly with a "connection has been lost" message, I can say that at least for the PC version, this game is broken. So broken that the devs should have put all their effort into fixing these online issues far before any dlc was released. Given that they have failed and are continuing to fail to do this, I cannot reccomend this game. Unless you have a lot of friends around. Which is sad because honestly as a game, this is probably my favorite fighter since Capcom vs Snk 2.

This review was edited, I gave this review a negative score a week after launch because the servers were complete garbage, there's no hiding that people who lived in certain regions just could not connect as well to the servers than other people. And the fact that the game was always online was utter bullshit.

However, as of recent, they added offline lobbies, and thank god for that because now I can finally play local battles without the need for internet connection (thanks ArcSys!). Also they've been patching the servers frequently and although they still aren't top notch, they are tolerable now.

So, if you haven't picked this game up yet, please do because it's a modern fighting game masterpiece. Every match to this day still pumps your adrenaline. And the game has such a rich scene and the game is fairly easy to get into.

Pros:
-Practice Mode comes with several challenges and tutorials to help you ascend from a button masher to a combo master to even further beyond!
-Local play with a second controller (something CoD and other shooters need to pick up on)
-A lot of depth to what you can do in the arena with the endless combos you can come up with, something that I'm currently trying to work on

Cons:
-Story Mode feels like something you have to do just to say you completed it rather than something you can really enjoy.  The enemies are extremely easy to defeat, and the story doesn't tie you in like the animes do.
-It's pretty rare, but every blue moon, there's a UE4-RED Fatal Error that crashes the whole game.
-Disconnecting during matches

This game is the first fighting game I've played. "But you've played xenoverse one-" The FIRST FIGHTING game I have played. And I have to say I'm impressed.

I've gone though the normal noob route. Dashing towards enemies every single time, not using assists, basic combos. Over time I learned some new things, first was the jump cancel, which I just added to the end of combos for extra damage. Now I'm learning more advanced combos, when to use assists, but I'm still strugging with escaping the corners! >:c

While there are some things I'd like to see improved, such as arcade mode rewards, end of match chat, being able to do stuff while waiting for a match, and finally some skins that aren't just colour changes.

I like the dlc so far, the characters are fun and polished like the other characters, the graphics are nice although they are a bit lacking in some places...Such as the planet when there's a destructive view from space, or when the characters fly into a rock and they turn into that bad little black cut-out.

Maybe the game would benefit from a history mode? Such as with the before mentioned Xenoverse, but this should be rather optional, and full of fun cutscenes with their new amazing graphics, such as with the special finishers!

Anyway, great game, getting used to the controls, having lots of fun!
