Dragon Ball FighterZ is the best Dragon Ball game ever, one of the best 2D fighters in this generation and, above all of that, a love letter to the series who inspired a whole generation.

The graphics, character models and animations, stages, special effects...all of them look absolutely gorgeous and go along perfectly well with the tone of the game.

The music is absolutely gorgeous (trademark and courtesy of Arc System Works), the sound effects are top tier and the voices are great too (I don't know about the english dub, but the original voices in japanese infuse the game with life).

As for the gameplay, DBFZ is an easy to pick-up-and-play, but hard to master game. It's a 3v3 tag team fighter where teammates can be used as assists to escape troublesome situations or apply pressure, but you can also switch between members during the fight looking for more favourable matchups or to recover some life. It has an autocombo feature, overheads, mixups, ki blasts, rushes, double jumps, and of course supers and ultimates. In concluion a good plethora or options when fighting that makes it similar to MvC3.

But above all, it's the different playstyle in each characters that enrichens the game. Each and every character feels and plays different. Compared to the Budokai series, where almost a hundred characters (compared to the tewnty-some in DBFZ) existed, but each of them with the same attack patterns and execution, this is a huge level-up. DBFZ feels and plays like a god-tier fighting game, stepping up to the heights of SFV, KOFXIV, Tekken7 or MvC3.

As for replay value, we may find the biggest flaw of DBFZ in the story mode. While the approach is good (a brand new storyline that lets you acquire and develop characters, going from stage to stage) the execution is poor: I don't think I lost one single character, let alone a match, in this mode, as it is insultingly easy. More challenge can be found in the arcade mode and, obviously, going online, but the story mode that could have been brilliant is just a waste due to the (non-existing) difficulty spike. That doesn't make the game less desirable, it just lets a good opportunity slide.

The other negative aspect of DBFZ is the DLC policy: the game came out with twenty-some characters at full rpice, but you can pay 35 extra bucks for 8 extra characters and 15 more for extra tracks. While this has become a trend in fighting games, I can only feel sorry for such a money-hungry approach.

All in all, DBFZ is an amazing fighting game, a must-purchase for Dragon Ball Fans and a fighter that can be picked up for new gamers wanting to give this genre a try and consumed fighting game players looking up for a challenge. I give it a 9/10 and with a couple of stitches here and there, it coul have raised even higher. I for one feel happy with the purchase. and think the game met up the expectations (and that's saying something for a game with such a ridiculous hype)

This is the best fighting game I've played in a while. It's absolutely capable of entertaining casual audiences, thanks to it's simple controls, almost as good as Smash Bros. and can be taken to a very hardcore level, just like Marvel vs Capcom 3. The game doesn't have easy touches of death like Marvel 3 had, but it is very snowbally, expect to block for a while if your opponent knows what he's doing and don't be surprised if you get opened up 3 times in a row in the corner.

Every character is suitable for competitive play, even though some are better than others (you WILL see Goku Black, Cell, Hit, Android 16, Adult Gohan and SS Vegeta A LOT), there's nothing stopping you from playing lower tier characters such as Captain Ginyu, Krillin, Yamcha and Beerus with great success! I'm playing Trunks, Yamcha and Beerus and I'm quite high ranked (560k BP, around the top 2000 players on PC).

The netcode is pretty good, can't complain. The servers were buggy on launch but I haven't had a connection problem in a while.

The soundtrack is VERY nice, but the devs are unfortunately trying to sell an anime music pack for quite a high price, eh, don't buy that.

The single player is better than most fighting games around, actually. The story is nice if you're a fan of Dragon Ball I guess, but the gameplay itself is too easy, most bots don't even react until near the end of the first arc (which is actually a good thing if you just want to unlock Android 21, but I guess more casual players won't enjoy that too much). The arcade mode is pretty challenging, even if you're a good player, but it feels unfair at times.
Trash game. I loved it.

If you are a fan of fighting games, chances are you have played or bought this title already and have formed your own opinions on it. Instead, I'll cater this review to those who may not be the kind to play in competition or those who are new to the genre entirely.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is extremely accessible. Special move motions are no more complex than quarter-circles (and half-circles if you wish to activate the super combo of a teammate mid-combo), the utility of normal attacks is somewhat universal: every forward + medium is an overhead, every down + heavy is invincible to airborne attacks, every down + medium is a low. Auto combos are very well designed. They are by no means optimal, but once starting an autocombo, you are not comitted to only completing that specific sequences of attacks, allowing new players to start using the standard auto combos, and eventually expanding on their use by cancelling the auto combos into other normals, specials, or supers.

Despite being accessible, I have to admit the tutorials are absolute trash, especially when compared to other titles by Arc System Works. The tutorials explain most mechanics on the most basic level and require very little actual understanding on the part of the player to complete the challenges (if they require completion at all), and the combo trials are largely wasted on auto-combos that are identical in execution between characters, and those which aren't auto combos are useless, unoptimal, and do a terrible job of demonstrating the characters unusual combo routes. If you want to learn this game, you are on your own. Fortunately, there is a wealth of information for both new and experienced players to hit the ground running with the game, but this absolutely has to be mentioned.

If you have dabbled in a fighting game or two and wish to "git gud," the skill ceiling of this game is enormously high. Anyone who had worries the game would be too simplistic is simply wrong. Applying pressure requires careful consideration of your opponent's tendencies [insert Adult Gohan joke here], defense requires a strong knowledge of the offender's capabilities, and you will get destroyed in neutral if you committ too hard to one thing.

Speaking of committing, this is where assists come in. Assists are more essential to this game than probably any Marvel vs. Capcom-style game in recent memory. In most "versus" titles, characters are a complete toolset, able to apply pressure, mixup, and complete devastating combos by themselves. By default, DBFZ characters aren't able to sustain pressure for very long, and it it can be extremely difficult to impossible to combo out of overhead attacks without leaving yourself open. Pressing buttons in neutral can be highly committal, and once a combo goes on for a long time, combo options become limited. Assists nullify all of these problem, making managing them absolutely paramount to success. You could argue assists feel more "important" in DBFZ than in other tag-team games, but that's my opinion.

As far as single player content goes? Honestly, I'm the wrong person to ask. I personally believe that playing fighting games against AI is to completely defeat the purpose of playing fighting games in the first place. After all, you're playing in a way which the mechanics were not designed around, the interaction between two players who do not know the other's next move with certainty. Story mode is pretty entertaining for the first third, but then gets extremely tedious.

I'm going to be completely honest with you. I used to love this game. I thought it was absolutely great and the best fighting game to come out in a very long time.

That being said, after playing this game along side Guilty Gear, UNIST and Blazblue, I just don't think it's for me. 

I won't talk about the terrible online and lobby system because many reviews have spoken about this already. 

But i've been in denial about it's gameplay for a while. The more I kept playing and kept playing, the more samey things started to become. All the combos I would do would all be the same. All the combos my opponent would do would be the same no matter what character they'd use. (granted some are a bit different, over all it all still plays the same) Apart from your netural, it just doesn't feel very rewarding. 

Some of the balance on characters are just jacked up. It's become a meme that Vegeta is in damn near everyone's team as support. Some characters are ridiclous like SSGSS' auto combo being a low which goes into a mid. This wouldn't be too much of a problem if the online wasn't behaving poorly and causing lag. So I would end up getting hit by it nearly every single time. 

Another issue is the auto combos. Not that I have a problen with autocombos in general, but the autocombo getting completed before connecting I still don't understand. Nearly every anime fighter i've played have the combo start only when the first one hit, And that's fine. But in this game, you can literally just mash it and it will complete.

Overall, it was a game I had fun with...But only with friends and offline. It became a very sour and bitter experience once I played online. Not much of any enjoyment. Not much of any reward. Just battling with the terrible netcode, struggling to find a match for literally 3-5 minutes and all the other reasons listed above. It's sad because I was really looking forward to it but the more I played it, the worse my opinion got with this game. It could be that it's just the online that soured me overall or maybe it helped me realised my other issues with the game.

UPDATE:

Since the update to the game, some of the previously stated problems with the network have been addressed and fixed. So far, these are what i've noticed:

- Netcode doesn't lag as nearly as bad as it did before
- Giving me the option to pick offline and online from the start
- Best 5 out of 3 instead of best 2 out of 3
- Reduced wait time for the opponent to accept the match
- Able to find matches MUCH quicker than before.


Final Update:

So I've given the gameplay a chance again and while it succeeded in every other area, the linear, boring gameplay let it down once again.

The balance problems still remain. Nearly team consists of Vegeta (for assists), SSGSS Goku, Goku Black and Gohan. If you're lucky you'll get all of them in the same team quite often. 

I still feel the general chaotic neutral and the combos still barely feel very different at all minus the inclusion of assists to continue the combos. 

Sadly it's still simply just not for me and I still have very little enjoyment even after the patch. I'm aware that the rather toxic majority of the community doesn't like that and that's fine but i'm just being honest.

Ah yes, another Dragonball game. 

Limited roster? Check.
Filler arc story? Check.
A new exciting way to make me loathe Goku at the end of said story? Check.
Price Gouging DLC? Check.
Style of gameplay that isn't complimented by said limited roster? Check.

There are better 2D fighters out there, but I know, I know, you want a Dragonball Fighting game. It's funny how it delivers on that front and still fails in every way to promote shelf longevity out the gate. The story is trash and filled with clone fights, a glorified survival mode. The roster is the same cats we've been seeing for years with the promise of additional characters (because we've fallen so far in standards that games merits are solely about what they promise us after we waste sixty bucks) and the netplay is ass.

The mechanics and presentation are great. I can enjoy the gameplay greatly but the surrounding failures drag it down into the mud. If this is what Ak-Sys has in mind now, I dread the next wallet-stillbirth I have when I buy into BlazBlue Cross Tag. Dragonball FighterZ is just another high-priced low-return anime video game that fans will praise and love dearly and other gamers will nod their heads once before attending to other, better, sharper products.

For many years, Dragon Ball Fans have consistently requested for a true actual Dragon Ball fighting game. Finally after the struggle we have one. Is it worth your time and money? We'll see.

[b] Story [/b]
With the new addition of Andriod 21 designed by Akira Toriyama, of course we are also introduced to a new story to accompany her. The story is divided up into 3 parts. Super Warrior Arc, Enemy Warrior Arc, and finally the Andriod 21 arc.
Each of the arcs sort of has it's own "perspective" What I mean by that is, in the Super Warrior Arc we can see Frieza and Cell get eaten and absorbed by Andriod 21 for her to grow stronger to fight her off in the final battle. However, in the Enemy Warrior Arc, Frieza and Cell are actually not eaten but rather help Goku in the final battle against Andriod 21. The actual "canon" story relating to Andriod 21, would have to be her own arc. If I'm to be completely honest with you. I didn't give two shits about the story. While I find it great with the cutscenes and voice acting which is absolutely amazing. The actual story... is actually pretty forgettable. 

[b] Gameplay [/b]
I will say this now. I believe Dragon Ball FighterZ to be THE BEST fighting game on the market currently. Dragon Ball FighterZ isn't a 1 on 1 fighting game. Rather, it's a 3 on 3 fighting game. The mechanics in Dragon Ball FighterZ are just amazing. This game just screams creativity. You can create some awesome, over the top creative flashy stuff, or some evil cheap crap to throw your opponents off. I love that! It allows the player to further dive into practice mode alot more often. Whenever I hop into practice mode, I always find out something new. I know of those who don't like the 3 on 3 combat style. However, believe me that it is absolutely amazing in this game. Now will all that's good comes with bad. The thing that sets the fire on the community and game are "auto combos" and it's understandable too. Essentially, auto combos are literally... AUTO COMBOS. You sit there, hit a button mutliple times until the combo ends. This promotes SPAMMING, this is in no way a good thing for players. Especially ones that are new and learning to play. Since the most common thing with newcomers to fighting games is spamming, here spamming actually looks like they are doing something. The auto combos have tracking, no matter how fluid your movement and cross up game is you will eventually get hit. This is absolutely disgusting. The thing with auto combos, they give you sort of "unique" types of strings or animations. For example, Trunks. Trunks has an auto combo string that leads into a crossup followup. It's really good but it's locked behind an auto combo. Therefore even influencing button mashing and spamming in the game. I believe this to be the absolute worse thing in this game.

[b] Graphics [/b]
The graphics in this game are absolutely amazing. After hearing that Arc Systems were making this I expected amazing visuals, and that is exactly what we got. You can increase resolution scaling to make the game look absolutely cripsy clear and clean. Arc Systems has probably the best looking anime games out there.

[b] Soundtrack [/b]
The soundtrack is this game is absolutely amazing. It captures that fighting spirit and motivation to improve your game. Every single track in this game is easy to remember and sounds great.

[b] Difficulty [/b]
Dragon Ball FighterZ isn't a hard game to pick up. It's really beginner friendly and encourages those who aren't exactly interested in fighting games to get into them. The tutorial is simple and clean, showing off tips and tricks you can do in this game. Arc Systems usually have great tutorials in their fighting games. My problem with this however, there are MULTIPLE things the game doesn't teach you, nor let you know of these. For example, did you know you can tag into another partner in your team without using your special and then switching to them? Did you know that if you dragon rush and hold a button down instead of 21 hits you get 31 for more damage? Did you know that if you press up, hold foward and press the right trigger you can do an easy Instant Air Dash compared to the manual way with the dpad or stick? The game doesn't tell you any of this. Now, this could be to encourage players to discover more in practice mode, but I personally believe that these are core mechanics of the game that should be shown to the player to make them aware.

[b] DLC Handling [/b]
I can't go exactly too much into detail since we don't the full roster of DLC characters, but I will try my best. I'm not going to refer to datamines or leaks, because I don't want to give false information. So far we know that there will be 8 new characters. So far we know 2 out of the 8. Bardock and Broly. the actual pricing of them is not confirmed yet however. I'll update this section of my review upon new information.

[b] Pricing [/b]
To be completely honest, I don't think Dragon Ball FighterZ is asking for TOO much... but the price could be reduced. 
The game's roster looks acceptable in my standards. But somtimes it just looks really damn small due to the 3 on 3 gameplay style. The roster includes fan favorite characters, I'm pretty sure everyone is completly fine with this base roster. 

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Dragon Ball FighterZ is an excellent game for newcomers and pros. As I said before, I believe this to be the best fighting game on the market currently. If you are looking for a fighting game, or you just like Dragon Ball, or you want to get into a fighting game that is easy on controls and mechanics then this is the game for you.

[h1] Overall Score: 9/10 [/h1]

After having played this game foe 98 hours, I can safely say that this is a great game with few flaws (still has some flaws though)
Lets talk pros:
- Gameplay: It's easy to learn, and a bit hard to master. Giving characters auto-combos and simplified inputs allow for anyone (with a small amount of knowledge on fighting games) to pick up and play, while leaving enough room to find hidden mechanics and optimal combos.
-Graphics: It looks great......That is all.
-Music: The themes sound amazing and they represent their according character and place perfectly.
-Ranked: This is my first time playing a ranked mode in a fighting game, and I gotta say, it's great. Even with only to bars the matches flow smoothly, and every fight has pushed me to become better at the game, even a loss feels alright as long as I can stop and rethink what I did wrong and learn form my mistakes.
Now, for the few cons:
-Story: The first arc was alright, the second arc was great, the third arc......eeeeeehhhhh...... It padded a lot in the begining, and by the time I could start having pre-battle interactions (the best part of the story mode) it arrived too late and I just wanted to get to the ending. I'm glad I played the story mode, but I wont ever touch it again, not even to farm zenis in hard mode.
-Uuuuhhhh: .....I think that's the only complain I have....... The rest is just nitpicks..... So, uh, yeah.
TL;DR: Game is great, story fizzles out by the end.

I'll write an official-ish review when anti-cheat allows me to play this game. Evidently the Xenoverse 2 problem of anti-cheat hopped over to FighterZ. IF you get it to do the random acceptance, and the one time I got to play it, seems fairly fun though.

UPDATE:
After some help in getting assistance of getting things to work, I started playing and there are some good and some bad. BUT for those who get it... there is a maximum screen it can do, so do not do full screen. You'll be thankful later.

The Good: 
The general flow of combat seems simple but some characters have small differences that would usually require a modification to your usual battle style. (i.e. Vegeta can ki blast damn near rapid fire and the like while Gohan's ki blasts are not so. One shot typically.) These minor tweeks between characters give a variety and those who dig deeper can find combinations that just mop the floor with folks.

The Bad:
If you are not looking to dig deeper, it'll just seem to be 'spam light attack, big move just as they hit the ground or whatever... 
It'll seem repetitive in that light and the slight differences won't be capitalized on.

The Other:
The story is a bit unique and is amusing to go through as well as some scenes where, if you have certain characters, they'll banter before the fight. (Still amused about Gotenks trying to figure out what to call Goku and Vegeta because 'dad' didn't seem right.)

It's mechanics are simple enough (Evil Zone is exceedingly simple but the same general mentality works here) and the more time you put into learning combinations and team super linking, the more fun you'll have with it.

The short review:

This game is only as popular as it is, because it's attached to the Dragon Ball franchise. If any other game released had as many problems as this one does, it would be raked over the coals for it.

The long review:

First off this game is gorgeous, and an excellent attempt at bringing the Dragon Ball universe into a 2D fighter in terms of style and visual fidelity. That's clearly where most of the effort and money was spent however, because the rest of the game flops pretty hard. 

Story mode is sort of what you'd expect for a fighter. It's dumb, and the plot is shoehorned into to what is essentially a long practice mode. That's what it does well however. It offers you a variety of players to choose from, and does an ok job of slowly introducing you to the game mechanics. But lets be honest here. You didn't think about buying this game for a story mode. 

The online multiplayer is without question, the worst experience I've had in any major release, for any genre of game. As other reviews have stated, the lobby system is a joke and full of problems. It takes a long time to even navigate to the lobby (load game, choose online or offline mode, choose region, skip opening cinematic, choose lobby number, load lobby, warp to world match, wait), and even longer to get into a match. You'll be siitting for at least a couple of minutes before you find a match. Once you find the match however, there's no guarantee it's going to keep you connected, as dropped matches are very common. WHEN that happens, until recently, the game booted you back to region select instead of the main lobby and you have to repeat this process over again. It's a complete joke. 

It wouldn't be so bad if matchmaking wasn't paused for every other actioin you take, while waiting for a match. Want to look through your lobby characters? Matchmaking pauses. Change your emblem or logo, or buy capsules, edit team, or BG music etc.? Matchmaking pauses.

Which also brings me to the next point of premade teams. You CANNOT change your team once a match has been found. You MUST select your team before matchmaking. Whoever thought this was a good idea, needs to be fired.

Onto balance. There is none. There's only been a few tournaments thus far, but the amount of tier whoring in this game is insane. You are going to run into a Goku Black every game. Followed by either Cell, Adult Gohan, Android 16, and Vegeta. There is no semblence of balance right now, which is a shame because your nostalgia buttons are definitely going to be pushed.

So overall I can't recommend this game. If it didn't have dragon ball on it, I wouldn't have bought it. It's still a good year away from actually being a polished game, so save your money, and your time.

Now that I got that out of the way, I will make this review short and sweet.

Dragon Ball FighterZ has an easy to learn combat system, but deep enough for enthusiasts to spend hours mastering. (Pro Gaming potential for sure) Anyone familiar with Capcom fighters will feel right at home with this game. 

Despite its derivative nature, Dragon Ball FighterZ excels in the style department capturing the feel of the anime. I grew up watching Dragonball Z. It was sort of an entry point into anime, along with Macross and Gundam. It was a delight to play as Teen Gohan, taking on Cell. Kudos to the game designers!

Problems existed primarily in the UI. The main game HUB features chibi characters and a convuluted menu. Call me old-fashioned, but I prefer my straight forward design. 

Overall, good time to be had in Dragon Ball FighterZ. I recommend playing online with friends. The singleplayer Story Mode will only get you so far.

The combat flows well, the speed of the game is dependant on the player's skill level, and the game has incredible depth and room for you to grow once the basics are understood.

Easily accessible to fighting-game newcomers, due to auto-combos, but still, both the game mechanics and the combos you can actually pull off go a lot deeper and are a lot more complicated than first meets the eye, enough so to keep even professional fighting-game veterans occupied and practicing in training mode for months!

The visuals are absolutely perfect, the characters really look and feel like the original characters with their original designs from the anime, and there are so many little references and call-backs to things in the anime that it's just a treat to play. Even the way each character fights makes you feel like it makes sense, and a big part of that being that almost every move a character will use in their fighting style has been taken from the anime or manga itself, and really makes that character (any character) feel like a unique fighter!

The audio, until very recently, was a little buggy (some characters would call out the wrong names when calling assisst characters), but that was adressed and fixed, otherwise everything else is great. You have a wide-range of classic and new and original songs to listen to while playing, so whether you're looking for the good old songs from the anime or just want some heavy metal/electronic music to listen to, you can do both, and both sound great!

The only problem with this game is some lag while playing online, but to me it's not really a problem with the game itself, seeing as how I can still find many people with good/decent connections to play with, so it's really just a bad internet issue and about finding the right people to play with.

This is probably the best team fighter that's come out in years. I actually adore this game. It fills with me pure enjoyment that I haven't felt in a fighter since Marvel VS Capcom 3's original launch. 3v3 is such a perfect format for an anime fighter like this and after having experienced it I definitely think it was the only way for it to be as good as it is. Matches are fast and flashy, and even if you're getting fucking destroyed all the animations are clear enough to understand HOW you're getting destroyed. Despite this game being a Dragon Ball fighter, it has enough depth in the gameplay to really hook anyone who's been a fan of 3v3 fighters of recent years.

There's a good selection of characters, if you're a Dragon Ball fan you'll find a pretty balanced selection of fighters both from the original arcs all the way up to Super. One of your favorite characters is bound to be in this lineup. Things can sometimes feel too universal between all of them but overall there's enough distinction between the way most characters control that it doesn't bother me. If you aren't a Dragon Ball fan or have never gotten into the series things will be pretty alright too, every character has enough of their personality to make them interesting even without the context behind them.

Though, if I had to change one thing, I'd make defensive play more of a viable option. Matches in FighterZ can oftentimes feel like blockstring after blockstring and there's not really any good way to get out of pressure once you're in it. If you're an aggressive player who's used to rushdowns and mixups this is your game, but you'll have a much harder time taking it slow and forcing patterns into your opponents.

Balance is really good in my opinion. Every character as of 3/19/18 feels really viable and you can really pull some cool stuff off if your team has good synergy. Some are clearly better than others (Sometimes I feel like a good 16 genuinely has no weakness when paired with certain assists) but in general every character can work and work WELL. I can only hope the DLC releases will be as balanced as this main cast.

Then there's the STYLE. This game bleeds Dragon Ball. Is IS Dragon Ball. ArcSys really should be applauded at just how well the environments, characters, and attacks look. They've used their signature style of making 3D models that look like 2D animation the Guilty Gear series usually uses to its fullest here, as every single screenshot of the game genuinely looks like a frame from the show. I really cannot describe how god damn good this game looks in motion through text, my best advice here would be to look up some footage of matches in action, since they're a real marvel to behold.

Finally, the online. The online is fine. It's frame delay based and not fucking rollback based so it already gets a point from me (What the FUCK Street Fighter V) and most of the time matches don't dip beyond 3 - 4 frames of delay even with a pretty run of the mill connection. You also get matches pretty consistently now, as even during hours that aren't peak hours you'll get 2 - 3 bar connection matches at least every 1 - 3 minutes. The matchmaking used to be really fucked but they've fixed it in a recent patch, and in my experience it's pretty consistent now.

Overall, this game is an amazing fighter. I'm a bit biased due to preferring games like Marvel and Skullgirls over Tekken and Street Fighter but I genuinely believe this is the best fighter that's come out in recent years. At the very least, it's the game that's had the most love poured into it, and I hope I'll be playing this one as long as I did Marvel 3.

its good

STORY:
in terms of the story alone, it tells the story it needs to tell. whether or not the story is good is up to you. i personally found the story itself lacking, and having some holes and unexplained scenarios here and there. for the gameplay, it's nice, especially for a newer player of fighting games such as myself. it brings you into the basics and allows you to grasp a natural reaction to playing. this helped out since i knew the 3d aspect of dragonball games far better than i do traditional fighters. the tutorials in the first arc start getting annoying, when you're being told to complete tasks you've already completed before, but it leaves by the 2nd arc and the hard mode doesn't have them either. however, especially coming into the 3rd arc, the gameplay becomes awfully samey. the difficulty doesn't necessarily change, which is fine for the first arc where you're getting into the swing of things, but once you have a grasp on it, you're very rearely losing more than a character, if at all. it's worse since the 3rd arc is a lot of fighting the same bots, having 21 scream a little, and then doing it again. 

ARCADE MODE: 
it's okay. it has the aspect that it's still part of the gameplay, which is great regardless of where it's put, but Arcade actually adds difficulty to the matter. especially in the later "hard mode" stages, where you can be absolutely smashed for minor mistakes that the AI has already read and assessed. the problem arises that it doesn't have replay value. at most you're doing it by the end for the achievment, and nothing more. because there's no way you're going back into arcade mode over and over just to get destroyed by AI that read your movements, have higher health, damage, and Ki recovery than you. 

ONLINE:
online is, whithout a shadow of a doubt, the best aspect of this game, the combination of new players to the fighting scene, already comfortable players to the fighting scene, the heat of playing against similar skilled players, the thrill of the upperhand against more skilled opponents. it the sole reason why most fighting games get the players they get is because of this. and FighterZ does not disappoint. the graphics, the super attacks, the dramatic finishers, the disrespect of some of the level 3's (looking at you Beerus). the ONLY problems are that A. there is no punishment at the moment for people who cant muster the decency to take a loss, and rage quit, and B. lobby and room connections are (or after this patch were) complete trash. it was a struggle to stay within lobbies while waiting for a match. however, after a couple of patches, they were drastically fixed, and as of making this review, i haven't discoennected since the update. this doesn't stop me from running into people who do, and are the same people giving me 8 - 15 frame delays, but thats not the game's fault, that's the player's with bad internet. 

OVERALL:
absolute treat of a game. glad this was the next installment instead of another xenoverse game, which there will inevitably be, but i'm glad this came first. absolutely fantastic game, despite it's faults, and i'm excited for my friends to get it and any of it's new content in the future.

Considering I've put over 80 hours into this game and have yet to complete it's story mode (more on that in my final review), I can't give much of a solid opinion on the quality of the story the game provides. Just know the story mode is a very slow, arduous and painful slog to go through, and might make you sick of the game depending on how long it takes you to beat it. Everything else on the other hand? It's almost as perfect as Cell. Besides a few design choices (which are slowly being fixed with each patch) and slight balancing issues, this game is an absolute blast. If you're a Dragon Ball fan, this is a must buy. It's chock full of chocolatey Dragon Ball goodness that will make any fan smile, grin, and laugh. If you're a fighting game fan, this game is a blast and very varied in terms of it's roster of characters and how you can play it. If you're both, this game is perfect for you. Not a fan of Dragon Ball or fighting games? No problem! This game has a simple yet helpful guide on every character for their basic combos, and shows the capabilities of each character. Hell, if you can't wrap your head around the fighting game lingo and the quick combos just yet, there are auto combos to bide you over until you start getting better. This game is a must own. I'll have a better formulated review later, but, just know now:
YOU. MUST. BUY. THIS. GAME.
Amazing art style, amazing graphics, and it's just plain fun

This game is just amazing in both its animation and gameplay, it is the kind of game that is easy to pick up, with simple QCB (Quarter-circle back) or QCF (Quarter-Circle Forward) motions, yet hard to master huge hitting combos. If you love the Dragon Ball series, this is a must have in your collection because it simply isn't jsut a cash-in of a well known series, but arguably one of the top 2D Dragon Ball  fighter game.

Pros:
-easy controls (and auto combos for beginners)
- amazing animation heavily influenced by the latest Guilty Gear Xrd
- Fast paced over-the-top action
-Flashy moves and combos that would actually fill you with a "sense of pride and accomplishment" *stares at a certain space shooter game*
- No microtransactions other than DLC pass and characters (you use in-game currency to buy colors, lobby characters, titles etc.)
-A fun Ring Party Mode (tag team battle) that has to be tried at least once with a group of 6.
Cons:
-Story Mode seems to be underwhelming, and the only reason to actually do it is to see the characters interact with one another and to unlock a certain Android
- Lag, get ready to experience high FPS delays and connection errors no matter the distance.

Closing remarks: Dragon Ball Fighterz is a great 2d fighting game that does the franchise justice, both casuals and veterans will find joy in playing this game.

Okay, so this is an excellent fighting game. The fighting is pretty intense and it's very fun. Graphics bring back the old anime feel. However, there are a couple of reasons why this game deserves a bad review. First the lobby system is one of the worst designs I have ever seen. You cannot invite friends to a current game. 

Instead they are forced to manually find the same lobby as you. Not to mention there is no voice chat. This limits the knowledge of even knowing where someone is when you start the game up. There is a follow list. But its pointless because all it does is let you see the players stats. It doesn't tell you if they are even online.

Unless you plan to play this game by yourself then this game falls very short of game with friends. I played against some amazing people in this game and wanted to get some tips from them. But of course you CAN NOT message them in any way. You also cant add them on steam as there is no option for it. 

So this makes training someone or trying to rematch them later nearly impossible. Only preset messages are in the game. This game might as well not even have a lobby feature because its very annoying. Hopefully all this is fixed in the future.

If you want to enjoy this game. Don't play online. That simple, online is a complete waste of time. Also this game is WAY over priced for what it has. For sure not a $60 game. But it's lots of fun if you play offline.

Definetily the best Dragon Ball game I've ever played, by far, even if you're not into fighting games but are a fan of Dragon Ball, I highly recommend this game, the Graphics are amazing, it really takes you back to the anime and brings back childhood memories. 
Gameplay is really good, even if you're a beginner, I believe this is one the most accessible fighting games, but like any other, it requires practice in order to get good (you won't be good by just mashing X and do auto-combos all the time), the special moves motions are simple (qcf and qcf), there are some motions that the game doesn't teach you but you can look for them outside the game and what to apply them on (e.g: hcf or hcb to end a combo with an assist dhc without the current character having to super and tk to jump cancel some moves). The 2nd motions mentioned might seem hard but you can play with only a gamepad for sure and the tk (tiger knee) isn't that useful. 
Online so far it was a good, I know they are still working on improving the multiplayer, I had some disconnects bu I believe they will improve it further and the  online experience it will be even better.

Dragon Ball Fighter Z is a bag of mixed emotions for me tbh. There's a lot that I love about the game, but it has its problems. To begin with, the game has beautiful visuals and holds extremely true to the Dragonball series. the game is loaded with tons of references and a surprisingly interesting and engaging storyline. The game also features a lot of mechanics that add a new level of depth to the anime fighter/ team fighter genre. With moves like dragon rush, banish, and z deflect, they create new methods to approach and turn the tide of battle. 

Unfortunately, the game isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs 1 major flaw‚Ä¶ The auto combos. The auto combos in this game are extremely annoying and I feel that they take away from combo freedom. I wish they just made the auto combos something you could toggle on/ off or make it a mode you can switch between like stylish mode for GG / BB. In all honestly, it wouldn't be that big of a complaint if they didn‚Äôt put an auto combo for damn near every button! (I blame you Bandai). 

The final thing I have to say and yes, you've probably already heard about it, is the servers during the first few months of release were god awful. The lobby system completely ruined the online experience. Only now is this any better. My guess is the only reason the online play is doing better is probably because they lost 80% of their player base. Currently online play feels amazing as I'm getting much lower and more consistent frames when playing against opponents. Just like mama Arc used to make. Other than that, its basically UMVC3 mixed with GG but watered down a bit for newer players to get into. In the end the auto combos are easy to overlook and at the end of the day it‚Äôs a really fun and casual team fighter. If you‚Äôre a Dragonball fan or someone who just wants to enjoy a good new team fighter then this is the game for you.

FighterZ is one of the best Dragon Ball fighting games you'll find. Arc system works have really proven themselves to be a league above the rest when it comes to the genre. If you love the series or want a new competitive game then this is something for you. 
 
It goes without saying that the animation in this game is stunning. Much like Bandai Namco's Ninja storm series, FighterZ looks just as good as its TV counterpart. There are numerous nods to the series and Easter eggs to find within that will leave any fan very pleased. 
 
But the largest plus are the mechanics: DBFZ has many hidden techniques and ways of chaining combos together that are still being found today. Unlike many other fighters that involve several directional inputs and combo sequences; Anyone can pull off the special moves in this game. The biggest skill difference comes from how well players understand the system, each characters limits, how far a character will bounce, and if you can rush them to keep a combo going. These are a few examples of the depth to combat.

 
So, why have so many players quit this game? Gameplay is fun, Animations are incredible, and an easy entry competitive fighter for new players.  
 
But this can't excuse a blatant lack of content. 
 
Besides a barebones, tedious story mode, and an arcade mode with less depth than the oldest Mortal Kombat games in the 90s. There's not much to do in the game besides Casual and Ranked matches. For the hardcore audience it means little, but casual players have incentive to return. 
 
Including the very slow and restrictive lobby system; FighterZ becomes restrained. While practice is something that all fighting games rely on, without any fun modes to return to can be a drag. This is what created a large drop in the active player base. 
 
Disappointingly, Dragon Ball FighterZ is magnificent; As well as held back by how shallow this excellent gameplay has been implemented. I can only hope the DLC will help bring it back to life and add more content for us to enjoy.

I haven't enjoyed a game like this in a long time. It's one of my favourites and I'd recommend it for any player level. The visually stunning graphics and art style combined with the fast paced combat go great together to really highlight their idea of a game that's both welcoming to new players and also rewarding to expert players. I've spent most of my time playing this game on my own as my close friends do not own the game. However, I can only imagine how great it would be for any friends buying this game to play together and I have no doubt about the hours of fun you could have just going all out in constant battles.

The game isn't completely rich in single player content, but the story and arcade modes are certainly enjoyable and can offer a challenge. There are three story arcs with character levelling that make sure you can get a lot out of the story. There aren't individual story lines for each character in the game, but it really goes into detail by offering a variety of dialogues/cut scenes when matching up certain characters for a fight. That little extra touch of content makes it really enjoyable to fans of the series and also helps to offer some light humour throughout the game. Both the story and the arcade mode feature hard mode versions to make sure you get that extra challenge. This will often up the difficulty through giving the CPU unfair gameplay mechanics and making them more aggressive - as you would expect from most fighting games. To add to this, there are plenty of combo challenges to complete with each character to learn how different mechanics work.

The main focus, as with any modern fighting game, is playing online. The online community can be difficult to go up against, but playing ranked offers the higher level of gameplay where timing, combos, health management and fast thinking come together to highlight the depth of the game. Depending on your familiarity with the fighting genre, you might need to spend a lot of time in training where you can practise mechanics that the game doesn't explain to you in the basic tutorials. Personally, I'm not a fan of training, learning combos or researching gameplay online. It comes at a disadvantage, but for me it was the direct action of playing ranked games that helped me to learn more about the game. I've really enjoyed playing online as someone who, I would say, is an intermediate level player. At the time of this review I've reached 530,000 BP, which gives you a Steam achievement. You are rewarded monthly for participating in ranked games and considering the current player base, I expect the game will be surviving for a while now, particularly when the DLC characters are released (which I'm looking forward to already).

There are some updates that the game really needs, but the future does look promising with a recent update from the developers. Currently, there isn't any reliable punishment for rage quitting in ranked mode and there are some lobby-based and match finding issues that exist. However, I can't say these are overwhelming problems and they can be overlooked. There is some content you'd find in other fighting games outside of the actual gameplay that doesn't exist here, such as character skins (there are only colour schemes), a progressive unlock system (all cosmetics are purchased through zeni and randomly given) and lobby activities (even the communication is limited). Fortunately, these aren't relevant to the actual fighting and are more like a bit of candy on the side, rather than the main course.

If you're wondering about this game in comparison to other fighters, I can't give you a great deal of insight as I haven't played enough. This is my first time really enjoying a 3v3 based fighting game and I personally feel this is my favourite. For a PC game, Dragon Ball FighterZ does appear to be holding a large player base with around 2,300 players over a month after release. It really makes me want to start playing other titles from Arc System Works. I've previously played BlazBlue, but I've not really explored the game fully and my hours were fairly minimal.

To conclude, I really do love this game and I've enjoyed it so much. At the time of this review, I have 134.1 hours on record. If the price is a bit of a pain, understandably, wait for a sale. For me, I haven't paid full price for a game in a couple of years as I rarely take an interest in new releases. So, the price of the game wasn't really important. I hope that anyone reading this finds the same level of enjoyment and I look forward to seeing you in battle!

The story this game has is pretty interesting and Android 21 is a nicely developed character, however the way single player is executed is just a massive bore. You have three arcs and when you beat the first one you'll unlock the second one and so forth, however it's incredibly linear. You'll be fighting the same enemies (clones) over and over doing the same thing over and over with next to no variation. Then when you unlock the next arc you get to do the exact same thing over and over again, it'll get to the point where you skip nearly all the clones just so you can fight the stage's boss to progress.
A level system with traits that grant effects like increased exp gained or health regen is pretty nice, but the problem is you'll find a particular combination which just invalidates all the others. E.g I had health regen coupled with health being gained from every hit, all you need is those two (unless you want to trigger the character's phase event which is just a grind).
The gameplay itself is visually appealing, and landing your supers/ultimates is very satisfying but that's as far as it goes. The auto-combo system just ruins the gameplay and it's not because it's "cheap" or anything like that, it just limits you to what you can actually do. I find that I can't mix and match the way I want because the input are too close to the auto-combo inputs so a level 1 super just gets triggered randomly, in the end I managed to come up with my own combos by avoiding certain inputs which in a fighting game shouldn't even be a thing.
Then there's arcade mode which is just a missed opportunity, I would've loved to have seen character specific endings or post completion scenes, pretty much like how Ultimate Marvel v Capcom did it. Except you'll find yourself just grinding to unlock Super Saiyan Blue Goku and Vegeta, if you pre-ordered the game and got the two from the get go then there really isn't much point in playing it. Hardmode in arcade is just incredibly unbalanced, as you progress through the mode the AI will have increased damage, ki gain and reacts to pretty much anything and everything you do, if there's a single frame for them they'll do it. I did a basic 25 hit combo to the AI and it did just under 40% damage, then the AI hit me twice which dealt 30% damage. 6 hits and I was left with half my health left, so if you can't unlock them via the score you're just going to be grinding for the zene.
Online is just broken either that or Hit just keeps freezing time, if you're not getting disconnected then you're pretty much finding laggy games. And when you do find a game it's just some prick jumping up and down spamming the same move (but then that's not Arc's fault).

Wait until it comes down in price or until the issues get patched/fixed.

So in usual fashion, as I did with Xenoverse 2, I purchased the game, played it briefly and wrote a scathing review. In Xenoverse 2's case, I was mostly miffed about the reused assets, and how the game didn't feel much different at all apart from 60fps. In FighterZ's case (or "FZ"), my gripes were heavy but came with the caveat that it isn't necessarily a bad game. The price tag is painful and the server limit is, well, utterly silly. None of that has changed. The nail in the coffin for me was what I considered to be very watered-down gameplay, an opinion cemented by the automated combos.

Yet, due to my Youtube history containing lots of video game and Dragon Ball related material, inevitably a lot of the FZ videos cropped up. Still intrigued, I started watching some of the tournament videos. "Cool," I thought, but didn't reignite my desire to play. Then I watched some of the more instructional videos--beginner tips, frequently made mistakes--and my eyes opened. Suddenly the auto-combos are not only surprisingly easy to counter and scale less in damage than a fully input combo, but catching a player off-guard with a full auto rewards a Dragon Ball. After watching several videos and reading more into the depth of the game's combat, my eyes were opened and I sprung for the game once more.

While I haven't had much opportunity to invest more time in it lately due to my crippling Final Fantasy addiction (and have likely spent more time watching videos than actually playing), I don't regret sticking this in my library, even if it is on the backburner. It most certainly is difficult to master. One day I'll master it.

PROS:
* Deceptively intricate combat. Despite auto combos and strictly quarter-circle inputs, I'm reminded that Smash Bros. is just as simple and had its hooks deep in me. Truly easy to pick up but difficult to master.
* Unique and pinpoint-accurate art style in relation to the anime, right along with stylistic animations and camera movement to go with it.
* Fully voice acted with the original actors and dialogue unique to the game, and unique between characters, both in introductions and in combat.

NEUTRAL:
* Ho-hum story that betrays its own pitch line: "you, the player, control all the Dragon Ball fighters, and fight other Dragon Ball fighters." The story takes this *very* literally.

CONS:
* As if the full price tag weren't enough, the DLC character pass costs over half that price. This alone is a huge turn-off for me because I don't like being sucked in to such an obvious cash-grab, especially with the next con in the list, but I am a fighter fan first and a Dragon Ball fan second, so thank you, tax return, for easing the pain.
* The servers. As most other Steam reviews will attest, the servers are extremely limiting and, apparently, unstable for some.

Still, to end on a high note, there's a lot to like if you're the kind of fighting game player that is always thinking ahead. This will provide that tournament-level mastering challenge you crave.

To quit the game from story mode, you first have to save and exit to the story title, then you exit from there back to the lobby. The next step requires you to enter a convoluted menu to quit the lobby back to the main title screen. It is only there that it is possible to exit the game.

Luckily the game is so awesome, that I rarely want to quit playing!
Out of the Budokai, Budokai Tenkaichi, Raging Blast, Xenoverse, and any other DBZ game out there, this is the best Dragon Ball game I've ever played. Definitely worth buying.

This game is awesome. I recommend it to anyone, new or old to fighting games.

I enjoy this game. It has very beautiful visuals. The animations are very crisp and clean. The flow of battle often feels very satisfying. The voice acting is great despite the english dub not matching the animations very well at all. The japanese track is spot on however.

The current roster leaves a bit to be desired in my opinion. There are character choices i question, which seems to be a common occurance in fighting game rosters these days. I mean Nappa? Why? But with Bardock and Broly coming up, I am hopeful that the roster gets a lot more exciting.

I will say that the combo system rubs me in ways both good and bad. Personally I enjoy the harder comboing mechanics of older fighters, but I can see the appeal of this system. I do hope it does not become the norm however. I haven't played around long enough to see just how advanced combos can become without stringing auto combos, but I am sure you can pull off some pretty epic stuff.

I do enjoy the assist system very much. I find the computer and online players have found amazing ways to extend combos and punish me with them, something I am not very good at, but that adds a ton of excitment and dread into my battles. I look forward to playing with them more.

I enjoy the music fully. I do wish there were more stages to fight in though. I don't have too many hours in game, but already I find the stages to feel a bit old and tired. I can't help but feel a little annoyed when I am on the stages select and have to see West City, or West City Destroyed, Planet Namek, or Planet Namek Destroyed, This stage Noon, or This Stage Evening. Pshhh. Boring. I would love for there to be a stage DLC in the future. 

I watched DBZ as a kid, and I forgot, if I ever even really noticed, just how few female fighters there were throughout the show. If I am remembering right, you really only have Android 18, and the new Android 21. Damn, you don't even have a normal female fighter, they got to be androids, that too I just noticed. Not a big deal, but compared to some other anime style fighters, this one is pretty male gender dominate.

Move sets are small, but given the 3 party teams, I don't find this to be a bad thing. It would be nice to have more moves for characters, but I don't think it is really needed, save for maybe Teen Gohan. He seems to be pretty lacking in my eyes. 

Overall though, I would have to recommend this game. It is smooth and enjoyable, and if you are a fan of Dragonball, you can't help but to love it deeply in some way. With DLC and many mechanics that made other fighters before it great, I think the game has a bright future, and hope to see a second installment.

FighterZ is a new experience in terms of Dragon Ball games. Never before has there been a game that's focused more on being a fighting game than being a Dragon Ball game. Not to mention it's made by Arc System Works, who have definitely made it apparent that they know how to make these types of games. The mechanics are simple enough to learn, even for beginners, and a basic combo ending with a super attack is available to every character just from hitting one button over and over, though this doesn't mean longer strings are impossible, or that no skill is required. It just means even new players can pull off a basic string of attacks no problem. The game also looks phenomenal, and every attack and effect looks beautiful. The 3v3 system of battling allows for a wide variety of choice in teams and assists, and the ability to combo into a switch, as well as launch multiple level 3 attacks at once, means players are able to really mix their strategy up. The story is also really well done, and finally gives DB fans something more than just playing through Raditz to Kid Buu again, and Android 21 is a very interesting character with a variety of... Interesting features. All in all, this is both an amazing Dragon Ball game AND an amazing fighting game, and I recommend it to anyone interested in either of those things.

Probably the best new fighter you can buy at the moment but honestly, I would wait to buy this until the online gets fixed up, because let's be honest Arcsys messed up BADLY with the netcoding in this game.
If you're a die hard dragon ball fan then don't let me stop you, but I personally would wait to purchase this until online is fixed. Story mode isn't really that interesting and there's no reason to do arcade mode besides unlocking SSGSS Goku and Vegeta.

Yes, the online can be fine sometimes but randomly getting kicked out of matches and having to reconnect to lobbies gets annoying. Also party arena matches are nearly unplayable because if even one person has a bad connection then the whole game will drop frames.

With that being said, the game is very fun and getting different combinations of teams to work together is nice as well. Art is great, gameplay is fulfilling, music is okay at best but nothing too memorable. 
If you're absolutely dying for a new fighter I suppose this will do the job nicely. Just beware of the admittedly pretty bad netcode and I think you'll have a good time.

-You will spend dozens of hours in training mode trying to perfect a combo, then you will go online and get rekt.
-You will continue to get rekt untill you learn some neutral and then you wont get rekt as hard
-Then you might win a game against a scrub who mashes auto combo and it will feel good. So good in fact that you might start enjoying this game (50 hours in).
-Then you will continue to train for hours on end and might become an average fighting game player.
-Then you will hit a wall: where you dont know anymore what to improve in your game but there are still plenty of people online consistently reking you
-Then you start drinking and contemplating suicide
-Your wife leaves you and your kids want nothing to do with you
-You'll start coming to local fgc meetups in hopes of getting better and to get that rush from winning
-You'll get perfected by an 18 your old furry who plays this game maybe 1/10th of the time you do

10/10

[h1]Dragon Ball FighterZ Review [/h1]

Quite honestly I knew I was going to like this game before it even came out. When I was younger I played Mortal Kombat, and Street Fighters a lot. I also grew up watching Dragon Ball, so the combination of the two made this one of my favorite games. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
1. The Graphics
I cannot stress enough how beautiful this game really is. From the intros of your favorite Dragon Ball characters, to the super attacks, the dramatic finishes, and even how the stage itself can change from its destruction, to a complete change of scene. At points of the game I forget that I'm actually playing and it feels like I'm watching the anime all over again, and it provides a sense of nostalgia.

2. The satisfaction
Nothing is more satisfying in this game to me than winning a very close battle with a destructive finish, it makes all of the hard work and concentration you have seem so worth it. The dramatic finishes also so satisfying to see your enemy get completely obliterated and vaporized out of existence. 

3. The lore and interactions
As I have mentioned before I have watched Dragon Ball all through my life and I have loved every second of it (Yes even with GT even though it was awful) and being able to relive those moments after you do certain tasks to beat your opponent. My favorite character of all time is Dragon Ball Z Trunks, and being able to relive the moment where he kills frieza feels so nice and reminds me why I love this game so much. The unique interactions between the character shows the strong riveralys, to the brothership of characters, and even has a bit of humor like when Trunks asks Krillin if he really married Android 18.

4. Playing with and against Friends
Sadly there is no Co-Op Story mode (and yes I understand that would be hard and tedious) this game is still a SHIT ton of fun to play with friends. My personal favorite is the 3v3 mode where six of your friends can get together and control one person each. It brings a more competitive scene between friends, and I wish you could do this in matchmaking. 

5. The Story
Although, some people didn't enjoy the story as much as they thought they would I still found it so interesting and had a lot of fun. I loved how unique it was to make you not only collect your characters, but do the story not only as the Heroes, but the Villains too. The introduction of Android 21 was also a good idea in my opinion, but not just making her a villain but sorta like Majin Buu where he is evil at first, but a part of them becomes good.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
1. Controles 
Although, I find this game amazing and well developed, not having a controller in this game sucks completely. In my first few hours of playing this game I used the keyboard functions because I couldn't find my old XBox controller and the Micro-USB to plug it in to my computer. The game was still playable with keyboard, but it felt as if all I did was spam buttons and that I didn't understand the game fully making it to where I didn't get the best experience until, I got a controller to work. 


2. The finishers 
Wait, didn't you just say that you enjoyed the finishers? I did and I still love them, but I feel like there should be more finishers for more characters. An example of this would be with the Androids and Trunks. Personally I was looking forward to seeing both the fight with Frieza, and the Androids as a ultimate finisher, or even the fight with Cell after Trunks went back to the future. I know they may be added in the future, or that it takes time to do that, but I would still like to see these added sometime in the future. 

3. The Skins
The main reason I put this as a con was because of two reasons. One I kinda wanted to see multiple forms of Frieza (with them all doing the same damage and having the same stats of course) and the option to switch between Android 17 and 18. Personally I love all the forms of Frieza and the Androids, but just the option to change would make the game even better.

[h1]The Final Review[/h1]
Even with the few cons that I mentioned, I love this game so much. I honestly think that if I wasn't in college and had to do school work every day, I would have over a 1,000 hours on this game already. I can't wait until the new characters and stages (if they are added) come. If you have been thinking about this game, or seen others playing it and wondered if it was good I STRONGLY suggest buying it. Even if you don't like anime the gameplay in itself is fun, exciting, and overall well developed and a great game. I was so hyped to play this game with friends, I even bought a SECOND copy of the game for one of my close friends.
It gets a 11/10 for me, no doubt in my mind.

I don't know what it is about fighting games as of late, but just because the Hard courses are supposed to be hard, doesn't mean that the AI should cheat.

I'm not talking about how they get smarter as you go higher up in the tree, that's fine, it should get harder in the later battles than the early ones, otherwise there's no point in having a tree in the first place.

I'm talking about that in addition to getting smarter, they also just get arbitrarily stronger to the point where getting hit by a normal attack combo(no switching, supers, anything extra) can take up to half your life. And that's not even getting into the ultimates which I've seen take characters from full to about 10-15% which wouldn't be as bad if your ultimates didn't do basically nothing to them.

AI should be harder when you're on hard courses, and going up higher in the trees, but just giving them more strength and less taken damage is not making them hard, it's just annoying.

I still have not won a match online.

10/10

I have been waiting for this game ever since Super Dragon Ball Z on the PS2 made the Budokai series look totally redundant. 

With the splendour of a 2D fighter and the world of Dragon Ball all rolled into one, this game plays very much like Marvel vs. Capcom which along with the source material should be enough to sell this to anyone. Bandai Namco have given us a 2D anime fighter that will keep both the battle-hardened, fightstick flaunting veteran and greenorn button masher entertained for hours. This game offers enough depth for the serious competitor, but also provides an environment where the uninitiated can spend hours and not be tempted to quit through struggling to chain the simplest of combos. 

Fans of the anime will no doubt salivate over 2.5D visuals that, through cel-shade trickery and applied use of low frame rates, throw scenes at the player which look as if they've come straight from the original series and look absolutely stunning on maximum settings. The cast isn't overloaded (there aren't 16 different versions of Goku for you to unlock) but manages to represent series standouts from the early days of DBZ all the way into the current DB Super series. Each character is (fairly) well balanced, with no worries of Yamcha losing outright to Goku Black due to their time of debut on the show. Actually, Yamcha is pretty f**king good here, despite the games included Story Mode taking the same easy swipes at the character that the show's fan community will be used to.

Story Mode itself is a largely fun experience, providing the player with an original story centered around a brand new character designed by the manga's original creator, Akira Toriyama. The battles can become repetitive, but a modest levelling system, plus the incentive of an unlockable character as reward, will make sure this doesn't present much of a grind. 

Sadly, at the time of writing, online is touch and go on the PC version. Having spent 30 hours in game so far, I have managed to connect successfully to 7 matches out of countless attempts to go head to head with other players around the world. The first of at least two patches aiming to remedy this have landed, and hopefully we won't wait long for the situation to change. In the meantime, Local Match mode includes an Arcade Ladder, single player matches and a tournament mode to keep us occupied and exercised. 

Anyone who is a fan of Dragon Ball will have a blast with this game, while anyone with even a passing interest in fighting games would be doing themselves a disservice in not taking this one for a spin. Highly recommend.

Pros: - Very Stylish
- It's DRAGON BALL! Fans of most any itteration have content to enjoy.
- Some variety in play modes
- Good music, entirely devoid of dubstep 
- Good effort with the story mode voice overs and dialog
- Easy to pick up and play at any level
- Every fighter has attacks you would want to see them use. Remember when Gotenks delivered a massive headbutt to Majin Buu?
- XBOX controller support!
- Disconnecting against online opponents too often does come with a penalty

Cons: - SFX (fighter hit noises, dialog and other SFX) are sometimes more annoying than enjoyable. This is true with both JP and ENG voices
- always online DRM
- Easy Anti-Cheat
- Story is far too easy and doesn't make much sense in the dragon ball universe. No difficulty settings.
- Arcade is far too hard
- Netcode isn't great but isn't horrible either. Don't expect to play with accuracy against players outside of your region.
- Timing for some attacks are far too strict while others are far too lenient. Example: after Nappa's 236M you can't even mash his sabiaman. You need to be frame-perfect to continue pressure without an assist. Meanwhile Goku Black and others can score a knockdown, float lazily to the ground, wait for 2-3 seconds and then activate any super and it'll still hit.
- Lack of defenisve options.
- Match timer is also too lenient. Damage output seems a bit too high for some characters and too low for others.
- Some characters are way too easy to play.
- Anti-airs and throws (dragon rushes) seem random too. Sometimes they'll hit no problem, other times they will go into your opponent and not hit (not that you'll notice most of the time with all the chaos going on during a match)
- Consumer censorship (you cannot type to other players, only respond with a pre-set list of replies)
- Premium store is a bit misleading
- no cross-platform

All-in-all it's fun but can be rather frustrating. The casual buyer can't go wrong with this game.

-Lobby system is currently broken. Sometimes getting into a match is instant and other times you get disconnected from lobby 8 times in 20 minutes but they're already talking about fixes for that.
-There aren't any in-fight transformations other than golden frieza and gohan unlocked potential. This is like the cornerstone of dragonball z.... screaming until your hair and muscles get bigger. Same goes for fusions. you can play as gotenks but he's a selectable character.
- Unlockables are kind of meh, it never really feels exciting to spend your zeni because you never get character unlocks or new moves or anything other than avatars and commentators and z-stamps (sticker system)

Overall, this is just a few major thoughts on the game but I would recommend this game to any one that loves fighting games that make your heart race. This is definitely a new breed of fighting game worth trying out.

It simply makes people who don't know what they are doing have more fun looking like a bad-ass, which is an achievement.

At the moment of this review there are some lobby issues and netcode issues, but the game runs flawlessly on local. One of my favorite fighting games.

Update at the bottom. Original review:

At the time of writing this review; I've put in about 5-6 hours into the game. Large amounts of reveiws are complaining about the server issues and low lobby capacity and since I don't have friends, I'm going to tackle this on a primarily solo experince.

Lets say outright that if you are not a fan of the Dragon Ball franchise; I do not reccomend this game. The game is built for the fans of the series; it looks phenomenal outside the different framerates with the character animation. They look almost frame by frame and it completely breaks immersion for the first two seconds of the match. But if you're a fan of cell shaded art styles; every frame is background quality gorgeous.

The fighting; it's okay. It's not Tekken or Streetfighter. It's not extremely deep and brain breaking. It's casual friendly and looks amazing, while simultaneously being fun and engaging. The name of the game is timing, timing your pre-determinded combos with assists and super attcks is the entire game. I'd reccomend going through the practice mode at the beginning so you can blast through story fights and arcade. The game also has a manual combo system where you can string your own combos together if they have a certain order (this may be wrong, but I don't understand it very much) I'd reccomend playing the combo challenges for your favorite characters for practice on timing.

Before I touch on the story; the hub world. It sucks. The warp mechanic (L2) is the only reason I can forgive it. I'm currently about a third through it. (SPOILERS: The game is set up in three arcs, all of which revolves around a singular story from different perspectives and slight different changes.) It's not well written but fan-service makes its debut again and makes the iffy dialogue suprisingly nostalgic. The villian is my favorite part of the story; Android 21 is extremely interesting and stupidly over the top. She's worth the price alone if on sale.

8/10 for Dragon Ball fans
7/10 for a fighting game

Update: I've played more FighterZ quite a bit more than when I wrote this. I said that I didn't understand the manual combo system. I understand it nearly completely and it makes this game so much better. If you're not a dragon ball fan; I said I'd rate this at a 7/10. It's easily an 8/10 fighting game once you've stuck through it and learned it.

What happens when you get crazy, 3v3 MVC style gameplay and put in Dragon Ball Z characters? You got yourself Dragon Ball FighterZ! This game is beautiful and you will be in awe of how accurate this game is to the manga/anime. Its great for anyone that loves fighting games or just Dragon Ball Z, and I mean EVERYONE. This game sets it up perfectly for anyone that isnt good in fighting games with an easy tutorial, and auto combos to assist you in battle. The game offers a Story, Arcade, Local Tournament, Practice/Tutorial and Online mode. Everything you need for a fighting game.

The gameplay which is key for a fighting game is good. It isnt the best thing but it entertains and has skill gaps in it. You'll tell if someone is using auto combos or acutal combos in this game. With Air combos, Assists, DHC, and OTGs it will be familiar if you have ever played a Marvel vs Capcom game. 

The Sound and Graphics are great. It feels your are actually invovled with the anime/manga with the same sound effects, the same animations and such. ArcSys really got their research on this game. Matter of fact, in certain situations you can trigger actual moments in the show/manga. From Goku turning Super Sayain, to the defeat of Kid Buu with the spirit Ball.

The story mode is cool but this mode also is...tedious to say. It has a cool idea on how to progress but I didnt like the story that much and its REALLY long. You will put in 15-20 hours in the story alone, especially if you try to get evey cutscene done. Still, you'll get some laughs as they talk about a lot of "what ifs" and such. 

In conclusion, this game is VERY good, and should be given a try RIGHT NOW! I give it a 9/10

If you're looking for a 2d fighting Dragonball Z game, this is a pretty fun game to play. I used a controller and tried keyboard only once but I prefer using a controller. Anyone of any age, well probably not an elderly person cause of elipesy reasons, can play this game. FighterZ is packed with beautiful artwork and graphics from the iconic anime. However I don't think it's worth the price of $60, so thats why I refunded it and I'm gonna wait till the price is lower. That and the fact that there is no demo version/beta during the time on PC so, I would give this game a 8/10

I have never written a review for a game before, but damn it this game is so much fun I just has to talk about it. As a Dragonball fan and a fighting game player this is a dream come true, a game that does both incredible justice. This is the best Dragonball game ever made hands down. It captures what the series is about insane fighterz doing insane shit. The game is easily accessible to non-fighting game players, but at the same time is complex for the hardcore fighting game enthusiast. The game animates extremely well and each reference and easter egg shows a level of dedication to doing the anime and manga justice. The story is mostly throw away, but to me in a fighting game story is not that crucial. The story does offer amazing interactions between characters and the voice acting is well done compared to other dubs of anime games. I honestly have to give Arc Systems and Bandai Namco props for making a game that gets it right and seems like it was made with so much love where so many other developers and studios, like Capcom, have gotten games wrong in the past few years. This game is so good and has so much support it was able to Galick Gun Marvel vs Capcom off of EVO 2018, and Fighterz was barely out for a month. Trust me when I say this, this games is worth every zeni.

I'm going to be one of the few naysayers here also.  The game is good on some levels and REALLY annoying on others,  The positive reviews do a fair job of hitting on what works.  Here's what doesn't:

The lobby system is REALLY lame.  The only way to communicate is with emotes and an existing set of canned phrases like "good fight".  

Unless you have 100mbps fiber optic internet like me, the online mode can be slow and occasionally disconnect.

The music is extremely tedious and repetative, barely soundling like anything from any of the dragonball shows, or at least maybe a bad knock off put together by a middle school music student on a synthesizer.

My BIG gripe with the game is it's claim of being newbie friendly.  What most of the hurried early reviews missed is that the game quickly become very newbie hostile about 1/2 to 2/3 way thru the story or arcade modes.  Opponents will start stringing extremely difficult to block or counter chains of super combos and assists.  The final fight with the evil version of Andriod 21 (story mode) is so cheap as to defy description.  It makes anything King of Fighters (or any other fighting game) look like a gimme by comparison.  Not just sour grapes here either.  I'm a VERY casual fighting game player.  Better than a newbie but FAR FAR from being an esports competitor.  I had 174 fights total in story mode,  151 I won.  Only TWO of those losses were on the way to the final fight.   The other 21 were the final fight.

Needless to say 152 fights over 3 arcs makes for a gawdawful LONG story mode too.

I also don't like only having the option of 3 on 3 team fights.  1 on 1 and 2 on 2 should have been included as options.

Controls tend to be randomly wonky too.

Oh and let's not forget $36 for a season pass that has absolutely NO content yet.  Somebody's been taking lessons from Capcom and EA
