Just a small background about my exposure to fighting genre throughout my life. As a child, I used to love games such as Marvel vs Capcom 2 and Tekken 5 (Dark Resurrection on PSP to be exact) but I never was efficient at any fighting game I have ever played during that time, just merely button mashing and all for fun. I pretty much gave up on the genre soon after because I saw myself never improving after couple of online matches, although I don't remember which game was the last one for me. Years have passed until I pretty much touched a fighting game one more time and it was just Tekken 7 as a start. The game that actually got me to understand FGC terminology and etc well enough, along with making me develop my competence within the genre was Guilty Gear Xrd Revelator (Rev 2 to be exact). It was a very complex game but thanks to its tutorial along with an experienced friend's match-ups, I have been slowly getting used to it while preparing myself for the hype of DBFZ.

After more than 50 hours and having Super Saiyan rank at the time of this review was written, I am absolutely glad that I have returned to this genre, as I found a game that might someday surpass my play-time for Tekken DR. However, the game has its problems like all others (few are quite serious but ArcSys/Bandai established that they are aiming to fix them).

DBFZ is one of the easier fighting games in the market, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have a good amount of depth into it. "Easy to learn but hard to master" saying can work with it but it still ain't as hard as games like Guilty Gear for example, but its mechanics work wonders in its favor. I initially thought auto-combos would be a major inconvenience while trying to learn manual/BnB combos but actually after playing for a good amount, there are times that auto-combos actually help, especially on air as it has its own properties while it helps to track the distance between you and your opponent, and stuff like that. It is discouraged to just rely on only auto-combos though as people could tell where to block each time and would easily find an opening to punish you for relying on that tactic, along with always superdashing. There is no such thing as "uncounterable attack". Some might be harder than others to deal with but they have their own weaknesses/openings that you can exploit against them and when you find them out, it will feel good. It is also important to note that the inputs in DBFZ are extremely easy, as most of them are quarter-circle turns with nothing complex to worry about. ArcSys did a splendid job in balancing both simplicity and depth within this game.

The story mode, while being genuinely fun as you watch characters interacting each other and watching the cutscenes as their own, is a huge grind borefest unfortunately. You keep fighting brain-dead clones which offer no challenge (however I have not tried hard mode of the story) and the boss characters are meh as well when it comes to difficulty (again though, never tried hard mode yet). Arcade offers a degree of enjoyment as the difficulty slowly ramps up but it has its own severe difficulty spike as opponents gain more buffs and could easily kill you if it ever detects you having an opening, which can be unfair especially to people who want to unlock SSB forms of Goku and Vegeta in hard mode versions of the arcade runs. It is a bit disappointing but it can help waste some time while trying to find matches or you just want to do something quickly.

Now to an important part, which is the online infrastructure of DBFZ as this is where my main complaints will be in. I keep getting disconnected from lobby in an inconsistent manner and it could even disconnect me from couple of matches (one or two of them would make it seem like I rage-quit while I haven't. I actually enjoy getting bodied by better players and try to learn from that) and I find myself getting properly connected to less matches than the ones I managed to find and accept. I had much more favorable experience in Guilty Gear but to be fair, DBFZ is a much more popular game which has a lot more people playing it, so the servers could be strained... but it has been like a month and nothing has changed so far. Disconnections still occur numerous times, ring/party matches are still broken as I rely on Steam download region method, and inconsistent match connections as there are times I could play with the same person and other times it suddenly brings an odd error like "EAC Disconnected: Peer Untrusted". I assume it is the anti-cheat but it is highly unreliable when it comes to potentially detecting an actual cheater. I seriously hope ArcSys/Bandai will fix them soon as they promised in their latest road-map video (Highly appreciate the open communication for that by the way).

The game is a huge blast and makes me happy that I gave this genre one more chance while trying to be a more competent player in it, especially that I have been getting back to Dragon Ball hype (DBS will be over soon unfortunately) while remembering the times playing prominent DB games like Budokai 3 and Budokai Tenkaichi 3 on PS2. It is also important to note that my last purchased and played DB game was Burst Limit. I have never been interested in any DB game after that besides probably Xenoverse series but I never got interested enough to actually try it out. DBFZ was the first one to get me extremely excited and I am very glad it hasn't disappointed gameplay-wise. It only needs to get its online servers/infrastructure to be fixed and it will be an even better game that I could highly recommend (however I still do heavily recommend this game thanks to the love, care, and attention the developers have put into it).

Now I am just waiting for the DLC characters to arrive as I have purchased the FighterZ pass to support the developers even more and judging from Broly and Bardock only, I can tell that my purchase has been already worth it.

I've played alot of Dragon Ball Fighting games. This one offers some nice stuff in comparison to the others but also falls short in certain areas.

Let's start with the pro's:

- Great graphics and art style. Really makes you feel like you're playing the anime.
- Every attack you do feels like it hurts your opponent, which is a lot of fun.
- Story is a good as you can expect from a dragonball game. There's some funny stuff in the cutscenes.
- The Arcade mode on Hard is really difficult, which is awesome. I hate easy to beat CPU opponents.
- Switching between characters and using combo's during combat adds a nice layer of gameplay.

con's:

- The Character Roster. Without any DLC the game contains 24 playable characters. This is a very sad number. Even with upcoming DLC (8 extra c's) it's still only 32. Compare that too Xenoverse (46) or Xenoverse 2 (78) without DLC and I get the feeling I bought half a game for full price.

- The Controls. I'm almost never able to perform an 'ultimate' attack when I want. The combination you need to pull of for such an attack is weird and more often then not I fail at it. (could also be that I'm a noob)

- Lack of transformations. The game lacks the feature to transform characters in combat. Transformations are temporary during an attack (like Goku going SSJ 3 during an ultimate attack). I don't like this.

- Lack of attacks. No Galick Gun for Vegeta. No Spirit Bomb for Goku

Conclusion:
It's a great game and a lot of fun but it's not worth 60 euros. Wait for a complete edition with the extra DLC characters included and buy it during a sale and you'll be much happier with the pruchase.

Quick Review:

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a refreshing take on the 3v3 fighting game style that we've fallen in love in from previous games like Marvel VS Capcom. The game succeeds both in casual and competitive modes. There are many offline modes to play like Story, Arcade, Practice, Locals, and Tournament mode. Visually the game is stunning, and the music and voice work complements the game very well. Combat is both enjoyable and rewarding, feeling natural and beginner friendly. The starting cast is a good size filled with classic and newer characters from the animated series.

I wanted a new, decent fighter with a heavy focus on combos and multiple characters per fight √† la Skullgirls/mvc/kof starring draginbollz characters and guess what, my wish got granted. Thanks Shenron!

[b]But is it good? You bet it is![/b]

+ Gorgeous visuals with the state-of-the-art team red rendering pipeline for characters (look at their GDC guilty gear conference for more detail, crazy use of UV mapping!) which looks INSANELY GOOD on dragon ball characters!
Crazy simple technically yet crazy beautiful effects with generous feedback for every attack and supers all over the place! (7 meter levels and you can DHC (cancel supers into other character supers) allowing for super flashy displays and finishers!

+ Decent content with a cool story mode and a good amount of base playable characters.

+ Super fast-paced gameplay with easy to perform combos (in general, not just autocombos which are pretty bad given they pop out a dragon ball, have meh/ok-ish damage and end up in a soft knockdown).

+ Some characters have really great gameplay. Nappa is a juggernaut/hulk that uses saibaimen with their own AI (cf: Jack-O from GG) for pressure, Beerus can ricochet his projectiles with every attack, Tien/c16 have crazy one-time lv3's, and ginyu can use his signature move! Yes He can swap with the opposing character (and also heavily gimp him because he can't use his squad moves!), making him viable despite his weakness! Also Yamcha is super, SUPER strong!


[b]It does have its downsides, though[/b]:

- Expensive ! Base pricing at launch is 60 bucks + 35 for the season pass making it reach almost 100‚Ç¨$ if you want to have all characters! Arcsys as a whole seems to become greedy lately, with blazblue crosstag battle having half of it's cast being DLC and 4 season passes, this is bad!

- The game "menu" is basically guilty gear xrd rev2's online lobby mode: You move around as a chibi in an ONLINE hub world. Although this one is well made, quirky and ergonomic enough, serverside lags could ruin your experience. I might not have encountered annoying latency yet but I have heard people complain about it a lot so be careful about this.


[b]So should you buy it? If you love dragon ball, are into fighting games (especially combo-heavy ones) or just love games that are the embodiment of Michael Bay, yes by all means get it[/b] (and if you are cautious about the aforementioned downsides, play the waiting game or get it during a sale! But beware because launch window is the absolute best period to start a new fighting game as people are just learning and the average skill level is pretty low, especially in this one where people autocombo and superdash all day without guarding so you might be missing out on some good pubstomping ;) )

I still believe Guilty Gear Xrd Rev 2 to be the superior and more deep game, with an amazing visual and music style (probably the best fighting game cureently on steam and consoles) but it is only natural that ASW hits another homerun, adding one more stylized anime fighter to their impressive resume. 

Amazing visuals, high speed intense battles featuring your favorite childhood characters screaming their lungs out and the revival of the 3vs3 mechanics make this the perfect chaotic competitive.. party game! This polished fighter is definitely worth your attention, with a presentation that aims to satisfy everyone, from the most casual player to the most hardcore and for most of the time it succeeds.

Of course not everything is roses, as i feel that the single player modes are a bit lacking when you compare ASW previous efforts, with a serviceable arcade mode that unfortunately just offers an array of battles withour specific bosses or endings and a story mode that while is fun (with some customization and plenty of interactions)feels a bit repetitive and uninspired at certain points. But still, the content is surely going to keep you occupied for some time especially if you wnat to unlock the higher difficulties. 

The onine system is also a bit marred by some qustionable choices such as the confusing lobby/friend invitation system but I guess that's the price when you try to be a bit more creative! The online experience is most of the time fine, netcode works quite well although persoally i sometimes have difficulty to locate matches and not sure why. But when i do, it's certainly a blast. 

Minor complaint is that the roster starts to feel a bit small after a while but that will improve with the implementation of addtional DLC characters, for better or worse. But bonus points for featurng some "old school" unlocks for not one but three additional characters already on the base game without the need to spend a single dime, along with a ton of cosmetics for lobby avatars, character colors and other small goodies, all completely free.

One of the most enjoyable experiences that allows you to do some pretty impressive comebacks with crazy cinematic supers, Dragonball FighterZ is one of the best games to add to your library if you are a fighting game fan and of course if you love DBZ.

As someone who doesn't buy a lot of games especially with a lot of them I usually get on sale, this is very rare for me to say this.  At the full price of $60, Dragon Ball FighterZ is totally worth it as you will be getting your money's worth.  The fighting mechanics are very fluid and solidly smooth.  The graphics are the perfect mixture of the old-school arcade style and contemporary cel-shading to be as faithful as possible to the anime.  I loved Dragon Ball FighterZ and this excellent title has very simple, but very stunning gameplay that will hook you for many hours to come.  One of my favorite aspects of the game is the roster.  Dragon Ball FighterZ truly delivered the passion of the Dragon Ball franchise by offering 24 distinctively iconic characters that feel truly their own.  The roster may be less than Xenoverse 2, but the quality over quantity is a step in the right direction for Bandai by its turn of more intricately distinct moves from each character.  The storymode of Android 21 is an interesting look at an original story that takes an even bigger risk than the past two Xenoverse games, but nails it as a new DBZ game exactly should.  Instead of being responsible to not alter the timeline, we are introduced into an entirely new one.  This is a great change of pace because we don't have to see the same exact story retold from the anime countless of times to death like we did since the first Budokai game.  Another change that is finally perfected is the RPG element.  Although I appreciate Xenoverse's attempt at making the DBZ experience your own by giving you the option to customize your own character, I feel as though the game distanced itself too much as it didn't feel like a DBZ game.  Instead, it felt like a generically bland RPG with being surrounded by DBZ characters and not feeling like an authentic Dragon Ball Z game.  In Dragon Ball FighterZ, you get to utilize your favorite DBZ heroes of leveling them up and using experience boosters which makes the RPG experience feels a lot more solid and compact as well as having your own avatar to navigate the lobbies with.  The online servers feel much more tighter and organized if you want to play with others.  As a very versatile game for all ranges of DBZ fans, you will definitely have a blast with this fantastic game.
All I have to say is that the random disconnects from online matches make this otherwise near-perfect game unplayable

Shit ass Servers

PROS

1. The models and animations are crazy good.

Nuff' said.

2. Respect for Dragonball fandom.

The character's movesets are 1:1 with their manga counterparts. You can tell parts of this game were made by people who are DBZ fans. My favorite character is Trunks and you guys nailed him.

3. Each match feel like an episode of DBZ

Other features of the game are lacking, but the gameplay feels like an episode of DBZ. It feels rewarding to mix and match teams, learn combos, and execute them. Everything flows so well.

CONS

1. Lobby system is a cesspool of poor UX decisions.

I have to start the game, login, wait for a million loading screens and then walk my avatar all the way over to the 'Online Arena' NPC and then walk all the way over to the 'Training NPC'. The only reason the lobby system exists to further gamify features outside of game play e.g. avatars, emotes, etc... It's just poorly executed and feels worthless. 

2. You can't stay in an online match long enough to enioy it. 

I wish I could count the number of times I've gotten disconnected during a good match. The net code seems to be pretty stable, but you get random disconnects once every other match. Nothing makes me want to throw my controller at the screen more than when I disconnect from a match.

If you want to play this game to play against other people online, don't. 

3. The story mode is stale.

I wish I could unlock Android 21 some other way, but instead I have to grind through a really boring story mode. 


CONCLUSION:

In its current state, I cannot recommend this game. Because I am mostly competitive, the cons far outweigh the pros. Once I complete the story and arcade modes, I want to test my mettle online. I want to combo people's faces off. I can't do that right now because I can't stay in a match. Please fix the disconnecting issues and that will be a great first step in allowing people to enjoy online competitive play.

P.S. Keep your lame DLC strategy until you can fix this game, too. I will personally have none of it and encourage anyone I know to do the same.

This game is great. Seriously top notch. Except...

The netcode isn't great. I mean, it's not bad. I've lived through worse. And I'm sure that this netcode is great for places like Japan, with it's high population density. The only problem is that I live in America, where we pay our ISPs almost twice as much for a fraction of the speed. It's also much, MUCH less reliable. Why does this matter? Well, it matters because this game marks ArcSys's first real push into the modern north american marketplace. They're big boys now. And in big boy world, a fighting game IS the netcode. People get disconnected a lot and some people are playing at 10+ frame delay (basically underwater.) Sometimes you can't find a match even when you can see a bunch of idle people sitting in the same arena waiting for a fight. Ranked takes a while to matchmake as well.

The game is too good for me to not recommend it even with the netcode problems. The presentation is great, the game feels fluid, it's fun and the roster is solid, although I'm sorry to see multiple versions of the same character, even if they play differenty. Buy it. Play it. Try not to get too frustrated by the netplay hiccups. That's really all I can say.

Dragon Ball Fighter Z is arcade style fighting game that showcases the very popular characters from the  Dragon Ball Z and Dragon Ball Super anime and Manga. 

First, if you are not a Dragon Ball Z fan, you will enjoy this game far less than someone who is. A lot of the reward of playing this game comes from its fan service. You will find many character interactions, cut scenes, and dialog that is based entirely on past events that took place in the TV shows, or Manga. If you are someone who has not seen them, Its going to be off beat and confusing.

This game does stand on its own as fighting game. What truly sets it apart is its accommodation to all skill levels. This game finds the perfect balance for all skill levels. Weather you are brand new to fighting games, or are a  fighting game expert, you can enjoy this game. It has simplistic single button combos that are both visually satisfying, and easy to execute, but also embraces a multi layered combo system similar to Marvel Vs Capcom 2. Its also filled with techs like air dashes, parries, teleport  and counters. This makes the game playable for people on every level of skill. 

a word of caution... If you are looking to play online with other players. You will NEED to get some experience before you start winning, as people online are way better than any computer you can face. 

Visually this game is amazing. All moves are visually astounding, and feel tailored to the characters.   Destructive finisher, and dramatic Finishes are over the top endings where a character will be  kicked through a mountain or building, or it will reenact a scene from the anime if a certain criteria is meet during the match. They all are very satisfying to watch, and visually feel very powerful. The combos and moves fit perfectly . All the punches and kicks seemed to be pulled right from the anime. In some ways it's like your in the Anime.

If you are a diehard Dragon Ball fan you will definitely want to get this game. It‚Äôs the best Dragon Ball game that has ever been produced.

First of all, the presentation in this game is top notch, this is the best Dragon Ball has ever looked, period. The gameplay in this game is excellent too, incredibly welcome to newcomers yet with a lot of depth to fighting game enthutiasts which shows really good design.

Aside from that, the netcode is really good even if it is delayed based, although there should be a better punishing system for ragequitters and the server infrastructure and online system in general could use some upgrades, the lobby system is cute and all but it is 2018 c'mon, let me invite my friends directly to matches instead of having to go to a exact lobby and setting up a ring match for example.

Finally one must really commend the hard work and love that has been put in this game, Arcsystems works really outdone themselves showing a lot of respect to the legacy of the franchise, almost every single frame of animation is a reference to the show/manga, and the way it is presented is absolute nuts, so all in all bravo to the developers as it shows an outstanding level of polish and care for the product.

To close things up I would say this is one of the best (if not the best?) dragon ball games there is, and it is a great game if you are looking either for a fun and solid fighting game or you just like the franchise.

Well. I have mixed feelings for the price I paid for ( Fighter Z Edition, 130 CAN $ )
----
The game itself is very fun. The speed, animations and effects makes the game very enjoyable. 
All I can say about it is once you touch it, You wont be able to go back to the other DBZ Games easyly. It's great.
Character wise: Everyone feels rather "Unique". I mean, The game has Auto combos (Press Light attack multiple time to chain Light-Medium-Heavy. If you keep pressing, you'll do a chase and do Airbone Light-Medium-Heavy again.) Wich does make me feel like the characters sorta plays the same, but with different gimicks and special abilities.
In a way, it's both a good and a bad thing. Good as, You can easyly switch characters in your team and do your normal stuff on them, but you wont have the full knowledge and extend of their specials if you didnt trained with them a little bit.  You realy have to be open to little details while trying out characters and see wich you prefer based on your game style.

Single player content? You have Story mode, Arcade mode, Local fights ...  Yeah that's about it.
There's also a TONS of unlockables that you can earn by doing fights, wich earns you Zenis that you can spend on capsules to get Lobby avatars, Things to customise your Fighter card and some alternative colors (6 for each character to unlock, doh they are the same color palette for everyone.) And Z-Stamps. Sorta like Stickers you can show off in the lobby along with some lines to make custom messages. (For exemple: Putting a Z-stamp of a very Pissed off Nappa with the caption "No way!" under it.)

SO YEAH.

NOW FOR THE POINTS I DONT LIKE.

The online matchmaking. "Set me up with someone of my level." Yet I keep getting set up with peoples that are way more wins and matches under their belt that I do. Heck, Even 2-3 ranks over me at some points. This happens Mostely in ranked.
Defensive options Feels limited. If you get in a corner, You'll get spammed by light attacks and mixups with high and low attacks and the few ways to get out of it, is to punish a blocked heavy move, Teleport in your opponent's back, Randomly throw out a level 1 Super that has hit invincibility at the start... you can also try reflecting, but good luck landing a move that takes 30 frames to come out when most of the cast light/mediums comes out un less than 7-10 frames. :^)

Oh. and switching characters. When you swich characters, they are forced into the super dash animation toward the enemy. If they block it or see it comming, it's a free punish. It's also VERY easy to intercept, specialy since you come from across the screen, leaving them plenty of time to do a special or a heavy attack.

...Speaking of switching characters, I also hate a few things about it:
1: Quick switching is bound to Foward + Assist. When you want to use an assist while dashing, You cant. You'll just switch by accident and get your ass kicked. :V
2: While blocking, Switching characters is impossible. You need a certain window  of time to even be able to switch characters, Wich makes your defense options even more limited when you want to pull out a dying character but cant afford to let your guard down.
3: If you dont hold your Assist button long enough during blocking to try to switch character, the Assist will pop up instead and leave you in a 10 second wait before being able to switch characters.
This happens to me so many times. It's upsetting :V


So yeah.

Game is fun, Frustrating as fuck doh.
:V

This has been my first fighting game that I took seriously past playing casually with friends and I must say it's impressive how much it's changed my opinion of fighting games. Before I was not much of a fan because I felt that they were too hard to get into. But this game is sort of an "entry level" fighting game, it will allow you to focus more on your movement and positioning in the beginning with auto combos where you just have to press the same button a few times and it performs a short combo while you focus more on finding the opening on the enemy instead of performing some complicated combo that you can't be expected to implement very early on if you're new to fighting games. 

Because of this the game is very easy to pick up and atleast give a shot if you don't like fighting games. While still being very easy to get into it can become very complex as you improve but the game will let you do that at your own pace giving you breathing room as you don't have to spend your early hours of the game trying to learn a combo before you even know how to find an opening and hit the combo on an enemy. The online community has made it even easier to learn as they will post tech and combo tutorials online (I specifically look on the subreddit which has hundreds of helpful players willing to answer the most basic of questions.) The community has been great on introducing newcomers such as myself to the game as it has one of the (if not the) largest pc release of a fighting game. 

Though the game is not without it's flaws just yet. The servers may disconnect you sometimes but with a solid wired connection I've only been dropped from games 2 times in my play time. The single player is also very very weak currently. I believe it is rumored that more modes will be added later but currently for single player modes you have the practice, the story, and arcade. Practice is just as any other fighting game, nothing to complain about here, it's actually quite nice and gives you lots of options based on what you want to practice. The story however is not good to put it bluntly. If you're a Dragon Ball fan the story is mainly there to teach you the controls and give you nice character interactions in the cutscenes. Other than that don't expect too much. Arcade is also very weird, in most fighting games higher difficulty would mean that the ai reacts better and punishes harder but in the harder arcade modes (which are not available right off the bat and will require you to beat the normal version of that arcade map) are downright BS. Making the Ai do more damage and take less while pumping out supers that do ridiculous amounts of damage. Thankfully that is not the main focus of the game. As it is like other fighting games where the main focus is on online ranked play. Which while others have had many problems I haven't encountered many at all. Maybe a laggy match or two but it was because of an opponents wireless connection.

The games graphics are also top notch and fit the style of Dragon Ball incredibly well. Animations are easy to read and tell what attack is being thrown at you for the most part and allows an easier time at learning how to block attack strings. If you have below the recommended specs for the game it's still worth trying and turning all of the settings down because the lowest settings look nearly like a PSP or DS game which should allow most of anything to run it. It is also moddable which allows for custom skins and music while still being allowed to play online!

TL;DR
This game is a satisfying and accessible game to someone that's never even touched a fighting game. It will take commitment and time to learn and to get good at but it's well worth it as finally being able to pull off your combo you worked on for a while in a ranked match. The graphics and details are wonderful and really fill out the fact that this is a Dragon Ball game. While it has it's flaws the main problems lie in the modes that aren't really much of a focus and you really won't worry about after the beginning of playing. It is well worth the money and probably one of my favorite games right now. I'm truely amazed that this game was able to live up to expectations and give a fun and easy to learn time.

Gameplay is insanely addictive and is finally a Dragonball game I can get into. However, do not be fooled. This is not an easy game lol Button mashers will get annihilated. 

See you on the battlefield!

P.S. Broly needs to be added! NOW!!!!
Greatest Dragon Ball game, 100% recomended. Lots of fun and also nice little details for the fans.

If you're a fan of DBZ then I guess writing this review is pointless but for the rest of you that are looking to buy the game, here you go: 
+ It has an, easy to pick up-hard to master, fighting system. 
+ Good soundtrack variety.
+ Decent amount of characters (DLC excluded). 
+ Amazing graphics, it's pretty much eye candy. 
+ Fun story line, really you just play it for the interactions between the characters you have in your group. 
+ No microtransactions (can't believe that we're at a point where we have to actually address this). 
+ Arcade, local, ranked, casual and a practice mode with many tools for the more competitive players. 
+ Lots of fan service and call back to the show for the fans. 

- Although not often, I do sometimes get disconnected from the lobby. 
- There is currently no punishment for rage quitters apart from making their name purple, as if that's going to change anything. 
- The coloured square infront of your name indicating your ranking is affected by casual matches, making the term "casual" lose its meaning.  

Overall, this is one of, if not the best dragonball game ever made, doing justice to series while also serving as a superb 2D fighting game for any fan of the genre.

After having this game for a while, I personally can't recommend, at least not at full price.  Thankfully I got this game as a gift.

The long story short of this game is that the foundation for the combat is good and overall solid.  There isn't much variety to combos/approaches, nor is there much reason to when the most simple of combos can do 40 - 50 percent health.  It is also a very pretty game, but the content is poor quality, and the online setup is so shitty you can't easily play with a friend without a lot of effort.  


- Online is shit and not worth the hassle.  It doesn't allow for private matchmaking which is lame as hell if you want to setup things with your friends.  You can create ring matches with passwords which are within lobbies, but you can't invite people to them...Also, your buddies have to physically locate you in the game.  This is probably my biggest issue with the game.
- In addition to the above, the game's popularity took Arc Systems off guard so the amount of lobbies are hurting people's ability to play online in a lot of countries/regions, further hitting on the issues above.
- No transformation system/installs (like Budokai games, or characters in MvC games like how Dante and Vergil had Devil Trigger, Ryu, Awakening, etc.,) for the Saiyans outside of Adult Gohan's potential unleashed super, and Frieza's Golden Frieza).  You can only watch them transform in the intro, or as part of a super animation.  It hurts me on the fan-service side of things
- No flight mechanics.  I understand this is a 2D traditional fighter (which I love), but at least they could've given flight to the characters like they do for characters in the Marvel vs Capcom games.
- Story mode may drag out for some folks and get tedious fighting the same few mook clones over and over with braindead AI regardless of the difficulty setting until like the very end of the game where they move.
- Arcade mode AI gets stat buffs on the difficult routes.  I don't mind it too much, but most would consider it a lame way of making it difficult vs just making the AI smarter/using more difficult to handle setups.
- No Arcade endings.  Doesn't bother me with this game honestly since arcade endings only really mattered to me if there wasn't a story like most fighting games in the past, but for traditional fighting game fans it may.    
- While gameplay has a lot of depth and is fun, the movelists having a lack of  command normals, specials, varying combo routes, and things you can do in general in comparison to MvC, Skullgirls, and many other fighters similar to this type, especially without assists is a little on the low side.There are videos out there with people doing awesome things like Clayton's stuff from SRK, but damn is it a bit dull at times in comparison.
- Challenges consist mainly of auto combos up until the last 2 or 3 generally (8-10) and even the final challenges don't do much in providing you something useful to make a gameplan out of like other fighters.  You'll want to do some experimenting in training mode on your own or finding videos online to set yourself up to get better if you don't have much experience with 2D fighters.  
- There is a decent amount of content. Story mode that has RPG style stats mixed with a board game thing with various routes for fights and such and a shit ton of grinding that can quickly become a drag.  The AI that's braindead until like the final arc of the story is lame  There are also challenges, the tutorial, and goodies like colors to unlock for the cast, but colors are locked under a loot box type of thing that you buy from the game shop, challenges are mainly doing auto combos up into the last 2-3 challenges, and don't really have anything useful..  Overall, the content is poor quality personally speaking.

That's pretty much where the bulk of my thoughts are with the game.  

I couldn't recommend this game at full price at all.  Solid combat, pretty game, poor everything else.

I can't recommend a game meant for online play, yet endlessly disconnects. That is a fatal flaw none of us should have to deal with. Until then I cannot recomend this. Graphics are incredible, however. I'll stick to Xenoverse2.

As a dragon ball fan, this game is a wet dream. It looks, feels, and sounds absolutely amazing. The effort that went into this aspect of the game is incredible, as well as the story mode having around 3 hours of cutscenes, many of them fun interactions between your favorite dragon ball characters. The characters feel amazing and their movesets are perfect, bringing out the best of every saga of dragon ball z.
Where this game starts to fall short for me is the actual fighting game behind it. Its designed as a hyper fighting game where you play with 3 characters, very similar to MvC3. However this game, unlike MvC, is made to be very friendly to new players. This was necessary, as the audience for this game is massive, and many of them don't know the first thing about fighting games. The game is programmed so that if you just mash any of the attack buttons, you will do a guaranteed target combo, many of them ending in supers. Although the game gives you many options to do manual combos, unless you are extending them to great lengths, they do just about as much if not less than the target combos. The game also gives you a large amount of movement options, specifically the chase mechanic, in which you fly forward surrounded by energy, classic dragon ball style. The implementation of this mechanic, as well as the one bar instant transmission counter, will make this game absolute hell for any new player not familiar with fighting games. The chase also tracks opponents, and in the air can sometime result in free cross ups. This, plus the large array of beam attacks and assists really water down the actual fighting in this game. Also unlike MvC, this game is lacking an advancing guard, making enemies much more likely to zone you out. Although they do try to make up for this with a reflect mechanic, its lackluster at best and has almost no practical capabilities, minus negating beam attack damage. In my mind, this game does not give you the motivation to want to improve.

Although i said i do not recommend this game, its split 50/50 for me.
If you like Dragon Ball Z, you'll like this game. Just don't try to hop online, it will most likely just enrage you, as the community for this game right now is absolutely apalling.
If you're trying to get into fighting games by learning this one, its a bad place to start. There's no other fighting game like this one, and although learning manual combos will definitely give you a boost, overall you'll likely feel no sense of improvement for a very long time.
And if you're a fan of fighting games looking for a new online scene to smash to bits, stay far, far, far away from this game.

-2 DRMs

-8 hours of story to unlock 21, unless you preordered

-season pass
-rage quitting is abundant and goes unpunished
-lack of friends list system
-lack of lobby communication, with only preset messages and stamps
+Online community has improved significantly after losing 80% of daily players

I got this game with birthday money and man im glad my birthday is the time great games are released. This is a fun fighting game that is some what simple but very streamlined. Being a Dragonball z fan growing up i enjoy the story line and the banter between characters adds another level of enjoyabilty. You can unlock characters and and alternate color character palets which is awesome. Some dlc stuff and what not i dont like and the story is pretty simple but dragonball was best when it wasn't over complicated. (20 hours later) I love this game, The story is a true dragon ball story written by Akira Toriyama and you can unlock SSGSS Goku and Vegeta through playing the Arcade mode fully and also unlock color palet swaps for all of the fighters as well. Still not syched about the DLC characters but if you can unlock them somehow in game that will be awesome and i will update my review then. I recommend this game fully for DBZ fans and if you love fighting games as well.

Wait for patches, right now the netcode is ABYSSMAL. I tried to just power through the laggy matches but its just not worth it. Especially when 3 out of 5 matches are 7 and above frame delay. Otherwise the arcade is alright, but the story is just such a boring grind in between fun cutscenes that I don't think it's worth $60 for the offline modes.

FIrst off,

Would i reccomend this game as a whole...Heck Yeah!! Are there things in the game that seem unpolished....absolutely. What it really comes down to is the replay value for me.

Im no professional at fighting games, absolutely not my strong suit but being a fan of fighting games has always made me want to pick up a stick or pad and try my best at it. This game is one of the best fighting games for beginner players. If you think your interested in fighting games and want to give them a try start with this first. Mechanics are easy to learn in the tutorials that new players can pick it up really quickly. But just because you finish tutorial doesnt mean yull be an expert. As with all fighting games it takes a tad bit pf practice to master your craft.

Thats one of the flaws with this game. To go more indepth with the mechanics you have to search online forums or videos to learn the diffent tech for characters or actual mechanics.( For example the sparking blast mechanics) Theres not an advanced tutorial that some other Arc Sys games have. Also the combo challenges are 90% the same for all the character.

Another flaw in the game is story mode. Im not going to sugar coat it at all. ITS BORING!!! In the beginning Arc you actually play training dummys. It would be a bit more bearable if they had auto feature for the cutscenes instead of me clicking the A button to continuiously advance in the story.

Lets get to the good stuff!!

While the online servers have their issues on occasion. Multiplayer is where this game shines, besides a few instances where i get completely blown out. ive never had a game where i didnt want to rematch someone to see if i could beat them more. Let me explain....There are times where i lose such close matches i instanly hit that rematch button without a second thought. The mechanics along with the character knowledge i learn in this game makes me actually want to learn from my mistake and play better. I can still lose but i dont lose as bad as i did the first game of the set.... like Hit "im constantly improving"

DRAGON BALL FighterZ is an excellent introduction to fighting games. It's simple mechanics make it accessable by almost anyone. If you were ever tired of learning the overly complex combos that come with games like Mortal Kombat or Injustice, then this is the fighter for you. If you're a Dragon Ball fan, the game offers up a story mode, which is somewhat generic, but still worth the play to see your favourite DB characters. Lastly, the art style makes DBfZ one of the prettiest games I have ever played. A bit expensive at 59.99USD, but if it's on sale, 100% grab it.

This game is amazing. Brought back childhood memories. The only thing that i dont think is right with this game is that its way to expensive for what it is. In my opinion it should be around ¬£20 or less. But other than that i have no quarry's.

This game is just awesome. One of the best fighting games I've played. 
It is a lot of fun and all the hype about this game is more than justified.
I Strongly recommend it.

Pros:
- Visually stunning. The characters look exactly(or even better) like they look in the anime. The animations are fluid and gorgeous. The scenarios are simple but they fit the game as it focus on the characters. 
- The Dragon Ball universe is weel represented here. Not only do the characters look exactly like they should but every single movement, pose, animation and attack comes straight from the manga or anime. The voice actors(English or Japanese) are the same as the anime. The respect that the team showed for the source material is unparalled. This isn't just a Dragon Ball adaptation. This is as Dragon Ball as it gets.
- The game mechanics are easy to learn but complex and difficult to master. It can be enjoyed by newcomers as well as fighting game experts. It is very rewarding see yourself grow as a player and become better at the game.
- The characters are well balanced and very unique. The main characters in Dragon Ball are playable and there are more on the way. 
- The game has many game options including arcade, story, practice, combo practice, local play and of course online multiplayer.
- The netcode is good. Playing online is fluid. The game allows you to choose the connection level, which lets you avoid bad connections.
- The story itself is good and it feels like you're watching the anime. The main villain is interesting and the character interactions are funny and natural.

Cons
- The main menu being a lobby is cute but it doesn't really work for me. To play the game you need to move your avatar in a map and I would've preferred a tradicional main menu.
- The Story mode gameplay is repetitive. In between cutscenes you fight with a never ending stream of CPU clones and it gets a little boring. It is worth it to get 21.
It it the best "Classic" fighter I have ever played but do not buy it until they fix ragequit penalties in ranked!

Been a huge DBZ fan since I was a kid. I played all the games on the gameboy advance and ps2. especially Budokai 3. 

Ive been waiting for a 2D DBZ fighting game since then and I was not disapointed. I highly recommend this game.

Easy to learn, real hard to try to get in the competitive scene.

The game is developed by Arc System Works, which I'm a fan of. I'm happy they ditched the 3D arena type fighting style and went with a classic 2D fighting style. It handles pretty well, welcoming to people interested in fighting games, and offers a lot for fighting game enthusiasts and Dragon Ball fans. I wish they online services were patched a bit better, but other than that my experience with the game has been pretty awesome. 10/10 would super dash into a dragon rush again.

Nothing beats finishing a match with a dramatic finish rather it be yamtcha being roasted by saibaman from nappa or frieza getting ki blasted to death by Trunks. 

This gives you five iconic dramatic finishes as well as dramatic openings with certain characters.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is a fantastic game and I would say the definitive Dragon Ball Z game. There has never been a DBZ game with this much polish or flare. The visuals are amazing, the sound is on point and the game does a wonderful job of making you feel like a super saiyan yourself. If you want something that is both easy to pick up and deep enough for fighting game vets then this is a good choice for you. Voice work is steller and there is nothing quite like pulling off a last minute Final Flash or a desperate attempt to turn you opponent into candy with Majin Buu.

Story mode is long and has three major arcs. This is a fighting game that you can really spend some time with. I have no doubt I will be playing this game a year from now and that speaks to it's quality.

Arc System Works and BANDAI NAMCO have a winner here and you can tell they put everything they had into this game. 10/10 for DBZ fans, 9/10 for everyone else.

Some of the most fun I've had in a long time playing a fighter. 

-----
Positives
-----
+ Crazy good anime graphics
+ Fighting mechanics are surprisingly deep, lots of loooong combos
+ Active community
+ Decent roster, has a season pass with 8 more characters coming
+ No loot boxes

-----
Negatives
-----
- Story mode is super boring, and you need to do all of it to unlock a certain character.
- Matchmaking is kind of inaccurate, even in casual mode. A lot of the time you'll just get wrecked by someone the same threat level as you and it gets demoralizing.

-----
Overall
-----
If you like Dragon Ball and/or fighting games, do yourself a favor and try this out. I definitely got my money's worth.

I usually buy games once they're sale, but this is one of the few that were worth buying at release. I was a huge fan of Budokai 3 and Infinite, but this one takes the cake. They did not hold anything back creating this game, and it's fantastic. Money well spent!

[b]In Short:[/b] A 3v3 Tag-Team Fighter akin to the Capcom VS Series or Skullgirls, complete with story mode, (partly unfair) arcade mode and a decent rooster of well-known Dragonball characters. Basic combos are easy, motions rarely more complex than Down Forward Punch and it is very unlikely you will find a Dragonball game more Dragonball than this.

[b]Good Time[/b] for amateurs and experts of fighting games alike. 

[b]Bad Time,[/b] if you hate managing multiple fighters and getting lost in huge explosions.

Dragon ball fighterz is one hell of a fighting game/Dragon ball game. 

+Super good visuals and very impressive to look at.

+Compared to other fighting games this game is more so about playing neutral and opening up your oppenent than knowing your combos. Even just doing your auto combos is fine if you figure out how to open up your opponent first which makes the game super noob friend to people like myself and all combos are generally just quarter foward or back and then learning to jump cancel until you get into the really advanced stuff (Game actually has a very intensive combo system for how simple it looks)

+Game just feels nice to play and the characters are fun and hold true to how the generally fight in the anime/manga.

-As of right now the matchmaking system is pretty bad but with how much hype and how well it is still doing that should be fixed soon hopefully.

-34 dollar season pass....

-3 base characters locked behind mildly annoying content 21 behind story mode and ssgss vegeta and goku behind the hard versions of the arcade mode which unlocking goku and vegeta can be a problem for really new players as you need an s ranking on two different maps to unlock them both

-story mode just feels like a grind.

All in all fighterz is ready to take the fighting game scene by storm and with how bad MVCI is this is pretty much the best 3v3 fighter you can get next to maybe UMVC3.

2) If you are playing on Wi-Fi you should NOT be allowed to play Ranked. Please, do us all a favour.

Virtually everything about this game except for the fact that it's DBZ is absolute trash.

The balance is dumb, you have heavy slow characters that have the same health but deal less damage than the fast characters.

You have auto combos that deal 50% health so people have to put virtually no effort or thought into what they're doing.

Assists recall if your character is hit making them 100% worthless outside of combo extensions.

There is no combo variety that doesn't involve assists. If you don't have an assist available be ready to literally do the same exact combo off of the same exact hit confirm every single time.

The lobby system is absolutely retarded. You can't queue for an online match from the main menu, every time you enter a menu your match search is paused.

Super Dash is a busted mechanic that tracks, is safe on block and leads to a full combo on hit.

It's not hard to beat but makes the game incredibly unfun to play against virtually everyone that does super dash all the time. The risk/reward for super dash is non existent.

The gameplay is bad, the lobby is bad.

Soundtrack is good though.

It's terrible for any real DB or DBZ fan.

Quick sidenote to avoid intellectual misunderstandings, it's a joke, I love the game.

A lot of single player content for non competitive players, the depth of the game slowly uncovered, great graphics, online matches not a ghost town, amazing training mode options for labbing, replays having buttons inputs and so on and so forth. If there's a checklist for how fighting games are done right, this will tick a majority, if not all of it. 

Great for casuals just wanting to enjoy single player content, casuals who want to get into competitive fighting games and veterans who enjoy competitive. 

If there's one thing I'd say that's not to my taste is the game not having a "real main menu" and just put you into a lobby, What makes things worse is that the lobby is quite unstable and can kick you out any time, which can be quite annoying but otherwise just a great package overall. 

If you don't want to deal with the lobby kicking BS, maybe hold off your purchase until they patch it.

As a relatively new fighting game player, this feels like a good balance between accessibility and depth to me. Button inputs are much easier than other fighting games I've played but high-level combos are still difficult to execute consistently. 

The online connection is shaky but acceptable, matches go smoothly 80% of the time, sometimes there's lag but it's hard to tell what's causing it. There are occasional random lobby disconnects which are annoying but no big deal.
Es a great game, you just have to take the time to learn combos

9/10, be wary of matchmaking

Fantastic controls, very low barrier of entry with good skill curve for those who take the time to learn more in depth.
Visuals are spot on to the show, with great sound design as well.
A wide variety of modes and characters, with more DLC on the way being promising.

CONS: Matchmaking is a joke/broken. You have a prompt of being asked who to fight, with "Match my skill" and "Stronger than me" as your choices, yet out of 20 ranked matches thus far and 30 casual, ive had 2-3 that felt like I was on par with my opponent. Best example: My ratio: 2 wins out of 13. My opponent was 8 wins out of 8. I chose to match my skill, and that shows up.
It is my responsibility as a player to get better at the game, but being put in the same bracket as people who are significantly better leaves little room to improve or learn.

I really like this game but damn it's a chore to get around and the online is really unreliable. I'm having a tonne of fun playing the game. I'm enjoying learning a fighting game again (first since Street Fighter 4) and the gameplay and graphics are wonderful. I have two complaints. One is that I keep getting kicked out of the online, sometimes in the middle of a match with another person which is really frustrating. I have an otherwise reliable internet connection. Haven't experienced thsi with any other game. The second complaint is how the UI of the game is structured. Layer upon layer of menus to get into the lobby in the first place and then the same to get back out again. I can't remember a game where it took so long to navigate in and out of. These are fairly minor complaints, but they are having an impact on how much I'm enjoying the game. A robust online experience and a UI designed with some intelligence doesn't feel like too much to ask to me.

Even after thirty minutes of gameplay it is clear that this game sets the bar in terms of menus, UI, graphics, and all around design. Nothing has ever proven to be so aestethically pleasing right off the bat for me, and the animations and art are intense and beautiful. The lobby system is such a unique idea for fighting games, I have never seen anything like it. The lobbies make you feel so much more connected and in the game. Other fighting games barely even have working multiplayer support, so this is so refreshing. Finally, I can already tell that this game has a much better menu and user interface system than other fighting games. Right off the bat, there are fully designed, animated, and complete menus with plenty of helpful options, that are easy to navigate. Ultra Street Fighter IV looks and feels like a rickety old shack compared to FighterZ.

So this is not only everything Dragonball Z smashed into a game, but it is an amazing fighting game in it's own right.
[list]
[*] All the kickassery and badassness of DBZ/Super smashed into one game? You bet!
[*] Deep, easy to learn yet difficult to master fighting system? Damn straight!
[*] Snazzy, fun campaign mode that also serves as a tutorial to get you used to the game system? Of course!
[*] Thematic yet functionally useless lobby system? Indeed, but we can live with that.
[*] Gorgeous visuals that perfectly bring Toriyama-sama's art style into 3d? Yup!
[*] True-to-form characters that act like their TV and Manga counterparts? All there from Piccolo's snark to Gotenk's hyperactivity to Frieza's imperious snobbery.
[*] Cool original villian character that everyone online seems to salivate over even though we all know 18 is the best  dragonball waifu? Yeah, she's in there.
[*] Japanese and English voices? Hai! (with terrible innacurate subtitles included, free of charge)

[/list]

In essence, if you like fighting games or DBZ/Super Get this, if you like both, get it now, it's the game MvCi wishies it could be, the only thing missing is Broly, and 99:1 says he's coming later as DLC.

I gave the thumb up for this game and I will explain it later,but first, let me explain why this game is actually bad:
1) This game is NOT competitive(blasphemy mode activated). I've seen guys who say that chars are balanced... they are not; most of them have a peculiar way to fight that differs from char to char, someone has got the Z assist such as N¬∞18, others have got the guardbreak, such as Goku Black. Still believe the contrary? Please go online and check how many Nappa,Ginew and Krillin you see. 

2)According to the first point, this game isn't fair.  To have a real fair play, 2 players should match with the the same characters and the same non-autofired joypad... that would be a competition, otherwise it is just "fun" (yea, games used to be fun once). You can't even stop the combo by using ki.

3) Original Story mode? Pfff... 
Okay, Android 21 is interesting, but that soul connection is totally lame.

4) Small roster... it feels like to play a Nintendo DS game.

5) 2.5D is so limitating for this brand. I mean, I can even fly in Ultimate Battle 22, and that was a PS1 game!

6)It's an online based game, because Arcade has got just 3 sub-arcades and their hard mode respectively, and story mode isn't that much. Should online games cost less than games who have got single and multiplayer?

7) Hard to socialize: unlike XV2, FZ hasn't got the co-op mode, no one is using the social tab even.

---

So you might think that this isn't the right game for you... still it is DBZ.
This game can be a pain in the ass for casual gamers, but it's Dragon Ball. That anime you used to watch on TV when you were a kid, now it returns on your monitor. I must admit that firing a Kamehameha on DBFZ is so damn satisfying; the cool thing is that it's not only about fighting over and over, you can see even how Z warriors and villains act to each other. And especially after all that story mode's mess, Goku will break the fourth wall and he will say "You're the best!", that's the true Dragon Ball's spirit. There's even a fourth wall breaking in game you can achieve by not breaking it, and an easter egg which is not a easter egg, but I will leave the rest for you ;) 
If I should give it a vote, it would be 7/10 lol
Enjoy this game.

Ok so here's the thing. I'm a both fan. As in I love DBZ as well as fighting games in general (my library). This game, is sooo hype. My favorite fighter besides maybe Smash, is Blazblue, a highly technical anime fighter. The disadvantage of BB is that it's tough to git gud. And can be really unforgiving against anyone who remotely knows what they're doing. DBFZ is NOT that game. If you have ANY experience with anime fighters at all messing around in the training room will mostly prepare you. Tutorial is good just incase you missed something. Combos are easy to execute. Frame windows are very forgiving with loose timing. Auto combos, while present, are not everything and far from optimal. The offensive and defensive options are very cut and dry almost to the point of rock paper scissors. But here's what's the most important. While it is certainly easy to get a handle on, it is still fun for people who appreciate other harder fighters. It's vibrant, it's cinematic, it's colorful, it's everything a Dragonball game should be. If you've never played a hardcore fighter before, start here. Especially if you're a fan of DBZ. This game is the perfect opportunity to get your feet wet. Yeah, the online is still being worked on. It's not a perfect lobby system. There are cons. It's not a 10/10. But it is the most fun I've had with a fighting game since I first got into Blazblue a few years ago.

Coming from the usual dragon ball based games that we have had in the past couple of years were basically blown out of the water! I've always wanted a new 2d fighter that had my favorite anime in consideration, and Bandi with Arc Systems really out did themselves with Dragon Ball FighterZ. With optimized graphics to easy to use controls to the competitve play style sold me from the moment I heard of this game. The animated cutscenes and gameplay make you feel like you are right in the anime.

With every positive there are a couple concerns that I'd like to address. The new storyline has an interesting feel and take on the dragon ball universe, however the story is basically repetitive on fighting the same group of enemies. There are the usual rage quitters that found there way from the xenoverse series so expect the loss of connection during or after a match. Servers are a bit crowded but just wait a few minutes to snag a spot.

If you love competitve 2d/3d fighter games, dragon ball, or a typical weekend showdown with your friends, Dragon Ball FighterZ is for you!

I actually like this game a lot. But have just 2 complains.

1- The Story is great, but the filler part were you have to fight hordes of "random generic characters" (Dont want to spoil) is just too long if you want to 100% complete every map.

2- There are not that many characters, they feel good but I think more (free ones) would be a welcome addition. The FighterZ pass including 8 more I think will be worth it (if the leaks are true)

Now some of the good things are: (There are more, but I dont have the time to think about all of them right now)

1- Android 21 is a really cool character. Once you play through all 3 Arcs you really get to like her. It is well though, has a good design and story.

2-Interactions in this game are awesome. You get some major ones in the story (I feel sorry for yamcha most the time) and then you get some when you mix and match characters during normal battles on the winning screen. As an example, if you play as Vegeta and Kakarot in the same team and win as Vegeta, he will proceed to say that he didnt need his help to win wich is right on Vegeta¬¥s character and much more.

3-You get a lot of gamemodes and "splitscreen" versus. I played a lot of Story and local versus, as well as the arcade mode.
Then you get Casual, Ranked and Arena matches wich I didnt play a lot but bring some refreshing variety to the game.

4- The graphics and animations are really well made, even the parallax effect on each map feels spot on.

5- No character (At the moment of writing) feels OP to me. You have 1 ultimate you can do with Android 16 that includes blowing up as he did in the cell saga that just kills the oponent if he gets to grab him and leaves him with 1 hp. This is a cool and dificult to do move, but I think 16 being able to regain health after this (if not killed in 1 hit before changing him) is not ok, he should stay at 1 hp. (He cant use this ability again)

Overall I would give this game a solid 8/10 that could climb to a 9/10 if they gave at least 2 more free characters.
Every character is well made and has some uniqueness, but I still feel they felt just a little bit short.

Disclaimer (moved here the interesting part):
For those who have never played a 2D fighting game it'll be hard to go online and enjoy the game without understanding all the mechanics and spending time practicing combos, movement and general basic strategies ( blocking, how to counter spamming, SD, etc.etc.). 
It's not rocket science, and in the end, there's enough information out there to understand how to deal with pretty much any scrub and mindless tactics that there is. 
Once players are able to recognize and punish those weak strategies the real game begins. 

The visuals are gorgeous, and many animations and poses are the exact recreation of the original anime/manga.

The gameplay is smooth, polished and fun. It can be a mash-fest with friends and newcomers to fighting game or a highly technical and deep battle of reads, skill and knowledge between experts. 

Sound and BGM work well, Voiceovers are good however there are no OST or classic DB soundtracks. 

The roster is small compared to most DB games ( average if compared to 2D fighters) but every character plays with a unique style and more will be available as DLC

Story mode and Arcade won't last longer than 10-15 hrs, so you'd better play it for the multiplayer content.

As a person that usually avoids fighting games like the plaque (unless it's something like Smash Brothers), the fact that this game not only grabbed my attention (if only because I'm a Dragon Ball fan), but kept me coming back to it and getting slowly better, just shows how accessible this is to even fighting game newbies.

That said, it's most likely the fact that I am a Dragon Ball fan that keeps me coming back. If you're not that big on Dragon Ball in any way (particularly Z and Super, which this game draws a lot of its material from), you're likely not going to be able to stay invested and appreciate how well this game represents the series and its characters. 

If you are a fan, however, then I can say with confidence that this game will satisfy on visual appeal alone. The fact that Arc System was able to almost perfectly translate the 2D style of the show into 3D is a sight to behold, and I hope that future DBZ games, Arc System or otherwise, keeps up this art style, because it would be a waste of potential for this engine to be unused after 1 game.

I can't really give the fighting system a true, in-depth look, as I haven't even come close to understanding it. However, as I said before, I've never played an arcade fighter of this style until now, and the fact that a total newbie like myself can jump in, and enjoy the game as much as I do, shows how accessible it is, so if you are at all wanting to jump into the fighting genre, I think this is a good starting point.

If I could name two negatives about the game, it's the lack of replay saving and the current methods of playing online with friends. DBFZ allows you to save your matches as "replays" and watch them back in the hub area. I say "replays" when they are really just saves of the inputs from both players that gets looped back. The problem I have is that there's no option to save it as a video file. I can understand this for the console versions of the game, but it feels like a missed oppurtunity to not have it on PC. Yes, you can just record them using any screen-recording software you have, but that's a tedious process if you have multiple replays you want to save. I'm not asking for anything complex; a simple, one-button method of saving replays as video files would be greatly appreciated.

As for my second problem, playing with friends online is quite a crab-shoot. With local play, all you need is two control methods and two players, and its as easy as going to the "local play" hub and adjusting some things. With online, you have to be in the same lobby as each other and hope that the lobby doesn't boot you out after a match. Granted, the latter part didn't happen often when me and a friend of mine played, but it was still annoying to finish a match only to get booted back to the home screen because we disconnected from the lobby for a split second.

These are minor complaints compared to the rest of the game, but it would be nice to see these fixed in some way. If that's not too much of a bother to you, however, this game is definitely worth every penny.
It's like all the cool bits from the anime and without all the pausing and episodes of little importance.

**I returned the game** Now before anything else, it was returned because my controller died on me and I decided to get the game on my PS4 instead of buying a new controller. I did not like using the keyboard.

THAT being said, this game (played just under an hour) is flipping fantastic. Now I am not a fighting game fan (this style at least), and Injustice 1 and 2 I got because DCU, and this one is DBZ!!!!!! My first Anime show and favorite. That's not why it's good though.

*PRO'S*
EAsy to learn
Good tutorial for beginners
Amazing animations (I believe they went through the show frame by frame to get the moves and fighting styles as perfect as possible).
Smooth and well optimized in every way.
Near seamless keyboard defaults
CAN MAP YOUR KEYBOARD BUTTONS WITH THEIR RESPECTIVE XBOX CONTROLLER BUTTONS DISPLAYED NEXT TO THEM!!
Has the competitive side with advanced moves and tactics for weathered players.
Every character is unique, from visuals to move sets, to the animations of each fighter as they fight. Krillin's Kamehameha (The quick version) is small, lower damage and quicker than Goku's same Kamehameha version. Yamcha for the first time ever is VALID, and honestly is the best character. His Wolf Fang style is beautiful. 

*Cons*
Using the keyboard is annoying
Some sound issues with the speakers crackling and "shooting" crackling sounds as you run through cut scenes. (This may not happen to everyone, but it is there.)
Character roster, while amazing to it's own extent, lacks characters, but 8 more are coming soon!!!! (By lacks I mean that even though there are a lot of different characters, I'm excited for apparently Broly, Bardock, Janemba, Kefla, Jiren, Toppo, and two others.) 

ALL in ALL, 9.7/10 overall!!!!! Whether you get it on Steam, XBox, or PS... it is 100% worth the price tag. I'd hold off of getting the FighterZ PASS (unless you plan on getting the FighterZ Edition version of the game) seeing as we haven't gotten the 8 additional characters yet.

Are you a fan of Dragonball? Buy this game.
Are you a fan of Arc System? Buy this game.
Are you a fan of fighting games? Buy this game.
Are you flatout broke and can't afford to buy another game? Make an exception.

This is one of the best fighting games to come out in a long time. If you have played other fighting games, especially other 2D ones like Street Fighter V or Marvel vs. Capcom Infinite, and were turned off by it, then you should give this one a try. Its basic systems mean that beginners and veterans alike can play the game through the easier automatic combos or the more difficult combos that require jump canceling and other similar mechanics. The story mode is also good for a fighting game, offering many hours of content to those wanting it. If you have any interest in fighting games you will want to play this one. If you are a fan of Dragon Ball you will want to play this one.
Mannn...all I gotta say is...Marvel Infinite who?

TL;DR at the end

Ok, let's tackle this game shall we? This game, is freaking good, and I mean it when I say it's good. You can see there is a lot of passion put into this game, and true knowledge of the Dragon Ball universe, full voice acting of various languages, a story mode, arcade mode, overworld that you can do alot of stuff, online gameplay, combo challenges, great gameplay with outstanding graphics and so it goes, BUT it has it's weaknesses. 

First things first story mode, I'm glad it's here, and it took me around 15 hours to beat, BUT, you'll be fighting a bunch of potatoes, there is not a single challenging fight in the whole story mode, and it gets repetitive really fast, so those 15 hours might hurt. The amazing thing about the story are the character interactions, setting up different parties to see how they talk to each other in some very funny to watch cutscenes  with full voice acting to each character. The story itself is just an excuse to gather the cast and make they punch things, it's meh, but it works. You'll unlock Android 21 after you finish all the segments in the story mode.

Arcade mode, present in 3 different "courses" that have a normal and hard mode, you can unlock Goku and Vegeta SSGSS in the arcade, if you beat two courses being able to score at least an A rank at the end, it's fun single player memes to enjoy, and i'm glad there is a way to unlock the characters without the purchase.

The overworld, this is a pretty cute feature, you'll walk around and talk to NPCs that can take you to each activity in the game, there are also other players that you can interact with and create rooms to fight with a bunch of people, and that removes the wait of the matchmaker. You earn Zeni in the game, and gaining 300k and 500k zeni will also unlock you vegeta SSGSS and Goku SSGSS respectively, again, very nice. Zeni can be used to purchase capsules that contain avatar skins, colour for characters, announcers for the fights, a bunch of cool stuff to unlock. 

To the online now, it's important to note that I'm playing in the South America server, so I'm not the best example of game population, but the matchmaker can take some time to find matches. It's nice that you can select the desired connection you want to play with and skill level so the match will be smooth and balanced. Now how does ranked work? You'll fight other players in a best of 3 match, and after the match ends you'll get points,  as you gain more points, you'll rise in rank, if you lose points, you lose rank.

And last but not least, the combat, the gameplay, so how is it? It's nice, yet chaotic, and very unforgiving, if you are a fighting game fan you'll most likely enjoy the game, and it's Marvel vs Capcom esque style, with teams of 3 that can tag in and out and call for support attacks. The auto combo system allows for a new player to get into the game faster, but a good player will stray from this and learn a bunch of combos and synergy between characters, and here might be the pickle of the situation. Like I said, chaotic, and unforgiving, it feels great to deliver a massive combo and chain supers from all your team, the problem in my eyes is that you can sometimes delete an enemy character with a good combo, or nearly kill it, if your enemy mess up, you'll juggle him like a sack of potatoes left to right for several seconds without much the enemy can do to escape this punishment, and the same works for you, i've seen combos that simply delete one of my team members before I can even say shit. So if this hypes you to get online and destroy people getting the cinematic endings, those are really cool btw, this game is for you. But if you just want to play this because you're a dragon ball fan and you don't really have interest in going online, I would probably wait for a price drop, when the full deluxe xxx edition comes out with all characters from DLC and stuff, because this game doesn't have enough single player content to sustain it's full price, xenoverse 2 has the better single player dragon ball fun, but not the more serious combat system that FighterZ has, if you're paying the whole thing for this game, you should play the online.

So for the TL;DR
If you're a fan of fighting games, go right for it, it's a great and fun game.
If you're just a dragon ball fan wanting to play around for a bit, I would wait for a price drop. But if you're too hungry for the action, this a great game.

To be simple and blunt. This is an excellent fighter game, A true credit to the DragonBall universe, and easily worth the purchase. I am old school and I bought the season pass just to get my hands on the DLC when it drops.

The fighting system is easy to learn, if you have played any Marvel VS Capcom games, then your likely good to go as far as Dragon Ball fighterZ is concerned. It's simple enough a new player can get involved and really enjoy the combat, but complex enough the advanced players will be analizing frame by frame for months to come.

The graphics even though 2.5D are perfect. It's right in line with the anime and I have not seen anything come this close before now, with the exception of Dragon Ball Z Tudokai Tienkaichi 3.

Okay- This game is super fun as long as you have the internet or literally anyone to play with. The characters are unique and represent the span of the series really well, the general playstyle is easy to pick up but each character has a unique twist that makes them different to play, and it's generally really satisfying.

I see literally two problems with the game.

1. The AI is a bit bad. They don't fall for things like humans do, and fall for weird stuff like raw level 3 supers... constantly. That's not to say people won't fall for that, but you kind of have to bait them into it. Buy them dinner first.

2. Like the show, it's not entirely balanced. I can do much more with Kid Buu or Goku Black than I could if I spend as long with say... Vegeta or Kid Gohan. It's not the end of the world, but you can expect a lot of Hit, Goku Black, and Kid Buu online.

Aside from that, it's seriously not just a solid Dragon Ball game, but a legitimately solid fighting game, with it's own systems to keep it unique and different. You won't get a fighting game that feels like FighterZ anywhere else, not even in other Arc System Works games, and that's dang impressive.

If your game constantly crashes with a fatal error, it's likely your CPU causing the issue if clearing the data doesn't fix it. For some reason this game doesn't like less than 4 cores; at least in my experience.

Finally, a legit 2d DBZ fighter on PC. Sorry Xenoverse, but you play like Dragon Ball Z: Budokai Tenkaichi: a dumded down fighting game with repetitive moves used by all the same characters just slightly different so each fight plays out the same.

I still think the old Budokai games released back in 2003-2004 got DBZ fighting right, but DB FigtherZ comes close with an awesome roster, beautiful graphics, a good selection of maps (hoping for more down the road) and characters (with more coming in a few months), and good old arcade style fighting that's pleasantly and surprisingly easy for newcomers to learn and enjoy. 

Yes, the game has a few hiccups, like needing to get into a lobby to do anything and some bugs, but these are things that the devs can fix/change. Hope this is the begining of a long series of DB FighterZ games!

This is the most accessible fighting game I've played in recent years.  Everything in the game builds off of something basic and modifies or combines it in some amazing way. The game has a big emphasis on the neutral game, where players get that first hit in. Then, once that first hit connects, new players can auto-combo it into reasonable damage, good players can combo it into good damage, and great players can do even more. The biggest praise I can put on it is that it's still a fun game to lose. Even when I was most outclassed, I thought to myself "Argh! If I'd only done X" or "If I had done Y instead of mashing out X".

My only complaint is the translation. They've taken some liberties with the dialogue, espeically in story mode. Any time that the characters say something particularly snarky to eachother, it's probably been altered from the original line.

For example, in story mode, Yamcha might pray to god in hopes that their enemies will be weak.
Japanese Piccolo: "You know Kami is Dende now..."
English Piccolo: "This is why Bulma chose Vegeta."
