Perfect DBZ fighting game, easy enough to get into even for a fighting game noob like myself but much to learn and many combos which open up depending on team composition and skill. Very impressed with the game and graphics, only shortcoming is the story which is pretty tedious.

Good: Pretty good gameplay and it's easy to settle into, even if traditional fighting games aren't your thing. Pretty lovingly crafted with animations and references any fan would appreciate on some level.

Good: Online matchmaking is crap and it's rare to get matched with anyone. There's no way to fight your friends or anyone specifically unless you're in the same lobby (which is often over saturated). The music is a pretty generic light-rock. Story mode is arse, pretty shallow and grindy.

I want to love it but I can't.

To be honest, I don't know if I really recommend this game, I have a neutral feeling about it.

The Story : You don't buy this game for the story. It's not even worth 10$, and we play the story 3 times through different "factions", The good people, the bad people and the androids. I won't spoil it but it took like 12 hours to do the 3 factions and I honestly think this faction thing is because the original story was 4 hours and they wanted it to be longer artificially, which is really sad. They also tried to do a scientific explanation about why is Cell as strong as Goku SSB, etc. which I found weird but I think is to avoid fans to cry over Bandai Namco. 5/10

Gameplay : This is the interesting part. I love the gameplay and I think is the main reason why you should get that game, it's so satisfying to do a kamehameha with Goku. The only thing is the "easy combos" when you spam x or y to do a combo, but these are not the most powerful combos in the game. To get better you need to actually practice, and that is nice. I also think that the DBS Character are stronger than the rest of the cast, but that's just my opinion.

Roster : The roster is correct, but there are a lot of character missing. Where's Muten-Roshi? Goku as a kid? Broly? Chichi? Oolong? Mr. Popo? Lunch? Jackie Chun?

DLC : I bought the FighterZ Pass, but I don't recommend it until you see the DLC Characters, Namco is greedy and until we see what we pay for, just keep your money.

Overall, buy this game only if you're a fan of Dragon Ball. The story is bad but the gameplay is good and the fights really look like in the anime.



TL;DR : Don't buy the game until we get Mr. Popo

When you put together the fun of Marvel Vs Capcom 2 with the easy controls of the Budokais series and the gameplay of Guilty Gear you have Dragon Ball FighterZ.

Certainly does not have a lot of characters and the easy input may you thought is not a deep and challenging game compare to others but is not like that. This game reminds me all those fighting games of the 90's, where they were simply fun and makes you feel happy while playing!

The first fighting game I ever really wanted to spend a significant amount of time just learning. It has the overwhelming depth the genre is known for, but it has beginner-friendly mechanics that make this the gateway drug of fighting games.

ArcSys did what Capcom couldn't.

DBFZ is one hell of a 3v3 fighter that's been designed from the ground up to be extremely accessible yet retains a lot of depth from both Capcom's VS series and ArcSys' traditional anime airdashers (Guilty Gear and BlazBlue). Graphics are brilliant as expected from this studio and the attention to detail in this game will surely satisfy even the most casual DB fans. It's a damn good final product and the DLC will only make it better from here on out.

Also worth nothing, this is by far the highest selling fighting game of all time on PC, beating out Tekken 7 by almost 3:1.

(Disclaimer: I've never watched DB or DBZ in my life nor will I ever care to)

+Optimization is stellar (this game will run on anything, I promise).
+Uses a slightly modified control scheme from UMVC3.
+Most traditional fighting game character archetypes are all represented in the base roster.
+Soundtrack is godlike.
+Android 21 is a high tier waifu.
+Seems to use Guilty Gear Rev2's netcode which is without a doubt the best delay-based netcode on the market currently.

+-Lobby system was absolutely busted for a few days after release but seems to have cleared up recently. Still, the lobby system is a mess and it's way too hard to simply play a set with a friend, especially considering Guilty Gear Rev2's lobbies fully support Steamworks invites. Bamco, plz.
+-Android 21, SSGSS Goku and SSGSS Vegeta are locked behind story mode completion and S ranks on arcade mode, respectively. Could be difficult for super casuals to unlock.
+-Voice acting is very hit or miss.

-The neutral in this game is more fucked up than Marvel 3, although I'm not sure this is something that can be easily fixed.
-Some assists are laughably terrible, and considering each character only has 1 assist this could be problematic down the line.
-Uses EasyAntiCheat for literally no reason at all whatsoever. Cheating in fighting games on PC has never been an issue.
-Expensive season pass/DLC.

TL;DR it's pretty much what we all wanted MvC4 to be. Thank you, based ArcSys.

Yet to find any flaws. This game is 100% worth what I paid. Better than Xenoverse 2 or any other Dragon Ball game since Budokai 3. The graphics are amazing and catch the anime and game surprisingly close. The story is interesting with tons of different interactions between villains and heroes alike. Although I pre-ordered, I have to say one of my favorite things about this game is the fact that you don't have to pay to get SSGSS Goku and Vegeta. In fact, there are a couple ways to get them without having to pre-order. The game has auto-combos that allow new people to have some help if they are new to fighter games while still providing several different combos and moves that people with knowledge of this type of play style can use in devastating and deadly ways. The online is filled with good players who are learning and skilled players that will leave you sweating after each battle. The battles are extremely intense at some points with mechanics that leave no room for cheap or scummy play. Truly a great experience.

Gonna keep this short, gotta get back to playing the game.

- THIS is the go-to game for fighter game beginners. It's fairly easy to get into, even for scrublords like me.

- Story mode is a hit or miss for people, personally IMO this story mode is on par if not better than Xenoverse's. It does get repetitive, even for me. There are 3 acts, First one is a pushover, second one is fairly challenging and the third one can whoop your ass if you handicap yourself by not using passives like me (I started using health regen passives after one GAME OVER). You can make storymode faster by just heading straight for the boss of the area but you'll miss out on finding new passives and potentially being underleveled and etc.

Update 1 - The arcade mode is rough, the enemies are made artificially tougher if you do very well (attack, defense, Ki bar regens faster). I'll just assume that this is made to compensate for the lack of brain from the AI, although a single combo can end you on higher difficulties regardless.

So far the game is a solid 9/10 for me right now. If you want to get into fighting games and you're a true Dragon Ball fan then this game is PERFECT for you. (Get it?).

Where should i start? First off this game is a dragon ball fighting game, and in my opinion, far surpasses all that came before it. I would go out and state that this game is the game that REVOLUTIONIZES the fighting game genre of video gaming. The mechanics of the game are easy to grasp by beginners of the genre; the high-level of play has, in my opinion, a steep learning curve which makes the game fun and fresh to play.

I did state that this game revolutionized the fighting game genre, why? Well first, since the game first shipped it sold 2 million copies+ and counting. Lastly, the game is well received by the crowd and a lot of beginners in the fighting game genre are enjoying the experience DBFz has to offer. 

The visuals in the game, despite its anime feel, are absolutely majestic. The game plays exceptionally smooth and everything flows very well. The game also has a feel of "Power" to it since you pretty much have all your abilities in disposal almost all the time making the game more fun to play. And please, you can play three of your favorite characters at a time! Talk about absolute chaos in the field of battle!

Overall the game is, at the moment, my favorite game right now in the fighting game genre. I have yet to see flaws in the game and despite playing many matches i have yet to grasp the learning curve on playing at a high level. If you, as a consumer, are thinking to get this game; I suggest you just go get it. The investment will be worth it! I assure you!

[b][u]Positive[/u][/b]

- The fighting speed is much faster than any of the previous Dragonball titles, making it much more exciting to play.

- The graphics reconcile the animated nature of the universe and new generation quality of detail.

- The UI and the general feel of the universe remained very DBZ-esque. The story mode is reminiscent of DBZ Budokai 2's system, albeit not operating in the same fashion. It was much richer and more developed in Budokai 2.


[b][u]Negative[/u][/b]

- The character number is extremely limited compared to previous titles. It feels empty. Where are the Cell forms, Frieza forms, Android 17, Android 20, kid Gohan, Dabura, base Goku/Vegeta/Trunks/Gotenks, Super Buu, Hercule, Raditz, Recoome, Supreme Kai, Whis, Cooler, Bardock, Broly, Uub, Gogeta, etc.?

- Apparently the upcoming characters will be locked behind a DLC(s). For a game that already costs $60 USD, that would be pathetic.

- You can't transform during the game (ex: taking base Goku and ending up as SS3 at the end of the fight).

- Online play needs to be refined with the whole server limitations, connection issues, searching time and so forth.

- The game's content doesn't justify a $60 USD price tag, especially when important paid DLCs will probably come.


[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]

Great and fast-paced fighting. Feels nostalgic. Harmonizes animated theme with modern generation visuals. However, lacks a lot of content, the online is messy and the content doesn't justify the price tag. I'll still recommend it because it's a good game, its issue are moreso related to how it's managed.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is made by the guys who made the recent Guilty Gear. This isn't the first time they've made games based on this series either. Prior to this they made Supersonic Warriors and Extreme Butoden, both great games in their own right.

This game gives you an interesting roster and tries to make them all feel and play completely different from each other. As with other fighting games you have light, medium and heavy attacks. The use of ki abilities makes combat feel different from other games in this genre.

Story mode gives you a way to ease yourself into the game and explore the backstory and familiarise yourself with the characters. While the clone battles can be repetitive, it doesn't drag on too long and pairing up the different heroes and villains leads to some interesting conversations. Standard modes such as Arcade Mode and Versus play work well here, giving the players a lot of options in terms of battling with others. The fighting system allows for 3v3 battles, with the player able to tag between them to allow the injured fighters to recover health.

Whether you pick English or Japanese voices, the voice acting is great and the music is top-notch too. It's got some orchestral tracks along with rock music that matches the action on-screen. With the promise of extra characters and all the unlockables there is plenty here to get your teeth into.

This is the perfect Dragon Ball game.  I've been waiting for a game like this since 1997 when my friends and imported the PS1 DBZ games Ultimate Battle 22 and Final Bout while watching the edited Ocean dub of the show on Toonami.  

Not to say other Dragon Ball games are bad, but the amount of detail and passion that ASW has put into this game is just astounding.  Look up IKevinX's manga reference series and you'll see what I'm talking about.  

As for the gameplay:  If you've ever wanted to get into fighting games, this is the perfect entry point.  As much as I couldn't stand the auto-combo system at first, it's taught me to be a better player.  Now that anyone can do a basic combo into specials and super moves, I have train myself not to be put into situations where someone can just mash buttons and beat me.  While the auto-combos are present, there's still rewards for doing your traditional manual combos (damage, meter, positioning, hard knockdowns, etc.).   I know something that probably bugged people about assists in the Marvel vs. Capcom series was how frequently you could call them.  Assists like Dr. Doom's Hidden Missiles, you'd just call because it covered you dashing in.  What ASW did for this game was made assist cooldowns longer, and in addition, that cooldown doesn't start until your combo has ended.  There are just as many fine tuned details in the game mechanics as there are with the games aesthetics.  

Oh yeah, there's a story mode too.  And it's awesome.  One reason I quit playing Dragon Ball games was because how often they just had you playthrough the same scenarios we've seen since 1997 (also, there was no online multiplayer back in the day).  So this game's story is a total what-if scenario and Toriyama created a new character (Android 21) just for it.  

I only have two real complaints for the game's online service (which will get sorted out in time):

1.) Because there are so many people playing and it's on ASW/Bamco's servers, I tend to get kicked off randomly during peak hours.  

2.) You create your own tag for this game (like SFV), so if you fight someone that's really good, I don't know of a way of getting in contact with them and sending them a message (I'm guessing this system is in place to avoid hate mail).

I previously wrote a review for this game, but my views on it have changed slightly and I have a better grasp on everything this game has to offer. For this review, I'll be breaking down my likes and dislikes for both the single player modes and the multiplayer. I'll also have a section on graphics, sounds, voices, animation, etc.

First: The multiplayer.

I'm gonna start with the multiplayer, for the simple reason that it's the main selling point of fighting games. A majority of people will buy it in order to test their mettle in the ruthless online. So, first off, the netcode in this game is pretty great. When finding casual matches, you can set the level of ping you wish to find, so if you only want at least decent connections and no bad ones, that option is available to you. The delay is constantly displayed next to the timer, so it's easy to know when things are getting a little shotty. And that's nice, since you can try to lay off being aggressive until it calms back down when someone gets whacked with a lag spike (it happens no matter how good your netcode is).

The things I don't like are the lobby system, and the weird ways that finding matches works in this game. You have options, you can find a casual match, an arena match, or a ring match. I've sat in casual match ques for up to 10 minutes (Longer than that is really not worth it in my honest opinion.) and found no one. So, I generally cross that off. Arena matches are where you randomly get paired up to fight other random people who enter this arena. One match, then it's back to waiting. This system seems to be broken, in the fact that I'll see 4-5 other people waiting to find a match (it shows them on the outside of the arena) but still wait 2+ minutes. Sometimes, I'll deny the person with a bad connection, just to wait 2 mins, and get him again without getting the option to fight the other 4 people waiting. It doesn't seem to make much sense. In the arena, there's also no option for a rematch, so you just have to hope you get lucky if you wanted to play that person again. Lastly with the arena, it seems to not pair 2 people with each other unless there is 3 or more waiting. If two people are waiting for a match, you have to wait for a third person to enter the arena in order to fight each other, which doesn't make much sense. I tend to use it anyways, but these things do annoy me. The last one is Ring matches, where you essentially make a room that sits in the middle of the lobby and people can join. There, you can rotate people in and out. Now, in this mode there's essentially two fights that can go on, and people basically line up to try to take on the winner. For some reason, this mode has the option for a rematch. So, you don't HAVE to give the person in line a turn. You can just rematch and keep them waiting (this has happened to me, and I end up just leaving due to impatience). It doesn't make sense to me that the version where people line up to fight has rematches, but the one where people are randomly paired together (No one is really waiting for a turn, they could fight one of the other people in the arena at the same time) has no rematch. If two people in the arena play a set together, no one is forced to wait longer. It doesn't make much sense to me personally.

Next: The singleplayer.
Again, I'll start with the positives. The story is interesting. Without spoiling much, you are essentially the main character in this anime. And it's fun, creative, and original. There's lots of in-jokes, and it's enjoyable when you get to cutscenes. The arcade mode is interesting. If you pre-ordered there isn't much reason to play it, but it has branching difficulties and if you wanna get some practice in before jumping into online this could be a good place to go against some hardcore computers to try to ready yourself. The combo challenges are very simple, and even a garbage player like myself can manage to complete most of them, but they do teach you the basics of comboing with different characters and how to begin incorporating their gimmicks into your combos.

Onto the negatives of the single player, the number one part is being forced to jump into an online lobby. Me personally, I find it annoying that everything is a weird lobby with the chibi characters. I feel like this should have been solely for the multiplayer, and not the entire menu for the game. Sometimes, I just want to jump in, click story on the menu, and go back to where I left off. Going through a lobby, teleporting to the story man, and talking to him to pick my arc is all steps I shouldn't have to take. Let's not mention the ever annoying fact that New Game is always the first selection, and you have to press down to get to Continue on the story. So many times have I hit A too many times just to wind up in a cutscene for a new story. Why did it have to be like that? Putting continue on top after you save in the story is very basic, and I feel it was overlooked. With the story mode GAMEPLAY itself, I hate it. I find it tedious, annoying, grindy, and basically what I call "Artificial time wasting". Instead of jumping scene to scene and fight to fight, between every cutscene you have a new board and have to play a board game. You encounter different fights to level up your characters JRPG style. It's very annoying, since most of the time you can't avoid fighting 2-3 fights before the boss fight to get to the next part of the story. On top of that, your characters only heal a set amount after every fight. So sometimes you can wind up going into a boss fight with all of your characters at half health. I haven't lost yet, but the game is starting to pick up difficulty (I'm near the end of the second arc) and getting very punishing (compared to the first arc, which was basically pound the punching bags over and over). At first it seemed like an interesting idea, but it's really just a way to make the story mode much much longer without actually putting more content into the game. I don't like it, maybe someone else does, but I don't. I find it tedious and annoying, but I have to play it to unlock Android 21. 

Last things:

Sound - No real complaints. The music doesn't stand out, but it isn't annoying either. The hits and effects in the fights are amazing, and the punches and explosions sound just like the TV show.

Graphics: Beautiful graphics, no complains. Cell shading is very nice, and all of the moves and characters are bright and colorful and filled with explosive particles.

Voices: I use just the japanese voices, since I don't really like the dubbed voices. But the japanese ones sound great, and you can tell the voice actors put a decent amount of effort into it.

Animation: The animations in the fights are amazing, and each character has a ton of personality. The story mode cutscene animations seem to jump back and forth. One scene will look incredible, while another one will look clunky and awkward. The cutscenes overall are hit or miss for me.

Summary: The game has it's issues. Most of these are easy to overlook, since they're more nitpicky and the gameplay itself is pretty great. The fighting, the mechanics, and the combos are all fun and accessible. The story is hit or miss, for me it's a miss but I'll begrudgingly get through it eventually. I still recommend this game, but hope that these criticisms get some notice and maybe one day will be fixed.

I can safely say that this is the best fighting game the Dragonball Franchise has produced to date. I haven't had any online issues either, the only negative I can think of is the story mode, which is divided into three arcs. The first one being a tutorial, the second one being relatively short but with lots of the same fights over and over again. And the third being the "climax". I'll probably never play that mode again, but anything else is just brilliant.

It's literally everything I expect from an Arcsys game and everything they promised for those who are new to the fighting game genre. I honestly don't know what more I can say aside from; if you've ever wanted to approach fighting games and actually understand how one is supposed to "git gud" at them, now would be a better time than ever since the whole point of this game is to bring people in with flashy and beautiful visuals along with a well-thought-out [i]and[/i] well executed fighting game system that has successfully captivated the attention of many newcomers with its straightforward button layout and its easy-to-play-hard-to-master feeling you experience once you hop into training mode and start figuring things out on your own. Not to mention the roster is huge and there's a lot you can do in offline modes as far as "offline content" in fighting games go.

[h1]For those of you who aren't very interested in the competitive aspect of a fighting game :[/h1]

If you're just the type of person who loves playing fighting games for the arcade mode, unlocking colors, characters or for simply booting it up when a couple friends are over and never touching it again until the next event of the sort, then this game has you covered too. I totally understand that point of view since I share a similar one towards CoD type games.

[b]This game's a 10/10 for me. Just my opinion though.[/b]

Fantastic game for both fighting game fans and DB fans alike. Very well optimized and a whole lot of fun. Haven't had a game (let alone a fighting game) that has been able to hold my attention for so long.

-The story mode is pretty meh. There are some cool ideas with the style, and the cutscenes are well done. Overall, though, it just felt lacking. Android 21 is a neat addition, though. That's really my only gripe. 

+Fantastic optimization, runs well even on my laptop (I5, 940mx video card) and even better on my desktop (I7, 1080ti).
+Online play has been generally smooth, though I have only spent a few hours on it. I play on a wired connection.
+Characters are a blast. I have never had so much trouble sticking with a team, and it's because all of the cast is fun to play.
+No (cash) loot boxes.
+Fun little customization options, the lobby is a nice touch.
+Great for fighting game newcomers. Always loved fighting games but ended up dropping most due to the high barrier to entry. Fighterz is a good middle ground of "easy to pick up, hard to master".
+Cast seems generally well balanced, though time will tell a better story. 
+One of the few games I can play for HOURS and still have the "just one more game" feeling. 

Highly recommended!

If I had to rate this game on a scale of 1-10 I would give it OVER 9,000!!!. That said it‚Äôs not perfect. While at its core the game delivers an easy to get in to yet deep fighting game the roster is underwhelming. Sure it has most of the key players that make up the DBZ universe but all the nice side characters seen in other recent games like Xenoverse are absent from this title. The game runs great with my only issue being the resolution wouldn‚Äôt change for me till I did a system restart. 

The story is typical for DBZ game and not a particularly rememberable one at that. The cut scenes are well done with a true to the anime look that‚Äôs better than any game up to this point. As for the social space it‚Äôs a bit dumbed down for its spiritual predecessors with a smaller social space and pint size charter avatars that are separate from the playable character roster. Yet it also has some nice added features like a warp to the current objective option that make navigation the social space simple for players that just want to push through to the action.

Overall it‚Äôs a great addition to the franchise and by far the best looking and playing DBZ game ever, even if the playable charters are lacking.

There are two paths for you to take in this game.

Path 1 = The Button Masher
Fear not, all you need to do is mash light, medium, or heavy attacks. You end up looking cool by doing flashy moves at the end. It'll make you feel like a god with that combo... until you look at your opponent's health bar. It nudged a little. Now I pray that you find your way to path 2.

Path 2 = The Comboer
This is where you actually learn how to play the game. You learn how to counter, punish, and rush. You learn neat combos that can extend for a lot of inputs and deal more than 50% of your opponent's health if executed perfectly. This is where you want to be.

Dragonball FighterZ is a brilliant way into the fighter game genre. With gorgeous visuals, iconic characters, and clean game-play; this game is worth all the praise it's loving community is pouring over it.

The story mode has the characters in a new scenario, introducing a new 'baddie' named "Android 21". While her personality is a little cliche ticking all the boxes of the evil anime girl trope, she oddly fits nicely into the Dragonball universe. It takes completing the story mode however to fully appreciate the effort put into her character, and the story they've given her. The rest of the cast is full of familiar faces from the show, and they deliver lines that are incredibly faithful to the show. Watching cutscenes, I laughed at how well the lines fit the character who spoke them. The story mode contains a few 'plastered-on' gameplay mechanics that seem out of place, like a turn-based story-pathing system. I never even got near to reaching the turn limit, which made me wonder what it's purpose was. Overall the story mode was a great experience; great practice for people new to the fighting game genre, and a story akin to watching a new Dragonball movie.

The game also contains a lobby mode to play with friends locally. An arcade mode to challenge and reward players outside multiplayer and the story. A practice mode, complete with a combo trainer. The ability to challenge people within your lobby (or hub zone) to a duel, or engage with multiple people within an arena. A shop to use hard-earned in-game currency to aquire a long list of collectables. Finally a way to challenge people region-wide to a duel for either a casual match or a ranked match. With the ranked matches is included a ranked ladder to view the best of the best, and watch replays of their fights.

Arc System Works are no strangers to the fighting game genre, and as such have done an amazing job at bringing Dragonball to the fighting scene. The combat is fluid, the hit-boxes are clean, and the camera angles paired with the vibrant colours make this a game that is hard to grow tired of. While easy for people to pick up, there is no loss to how strategically complex the game can be. A Youtube search for "Dragonball Fighterz Combos" will show you that the mastery curve can get incredibly steep.

With all reviews however, you must spend time to look into the negatives. The lobby system currently in use has recieved some backlash, as people can be kicked out randomly, and some struggle to find space or join a lobby in the first place. Since day 1 however, the amount of lobbies has tripled, and problems experienced have dropped significantly. The only concern this leaves me with now, is whether my opponents have a decent connection. With options to avoid poor connection opponents however, I'm not very concerned.


Final thoughts: It's clear to me that this game was never an after-thought. An incredible amount of love and labour has gone into this game, and the result is astounding. The game is far from over however with the promise of DLC to come. The in-game cutscenes can be compared directly with the anime and manga, shot for shot. A wide variety of game modes that can keep you entertained for hours at a time. Dragonball Fighterz will be a game I remember.

Ladies and Gentlemen, this is the Dragon Ball fighting game we have been waiting for since forever!
Brought to us by the fine folks at Arc System Works with the blessings of Bandai Namco the game features a decent cast of fan favorite characters with a few more newer additions from Super and even a brand new character! 

First off, the game takes cues from the Guilty Gear Xrd series, using Unreal Engine 3 to make 3D models into beautiful renditions of their anime counterparts. The gameplay is smooth and accessible, drawing comparisons to Ultimate Marvel Vs Capcom 3 with their own interpretations of such gameplay systems as 3v3 tag based gameplay, Snapbacks and X-Factor.
Yes, there are auto-combos, but these do very low damage usually and players who use them will be outlasted by players who have a better grasp of how to optimize their options. That being said, the game was made with an emphasis on accessiblity and a lot of things you may find out can be applied to many different characters across the roster.
I have yet to play the Story Mode in the game but I have heard it is an extensive exclusive story and judging by how long it has taken others I know to beat it, it seems pretty involved. It surely is a positive to see a company not neglect the singleplayer experience in a fighting game, especially one with such a deep and beloved lore.

The one thing that leaves a lot to be desired is the route they chose to go with the user interface with an ill advised lobby system that seems obtrusive and unnecessary. It seems that ArcSys seriously underestimated the response to this game on PC as on launch ( 44k+ concurrent users on Steam for a fighting game?! ) a lot of lobbies were full, preventing a lot of people from enjoying the game as soon as they possibly could. Simple menus and options leading into the lobbies would have been a better look but even the best things have their flaws but hopefully some things get done to improve the experience ( simple invitation system, menu based selections anyone?).

Back to the visuals though! They really did a great job optimizing the the whole game to run on many levels of PC hardware with resolutions ranging from 320x200 to the beautiful beast that is 4k! All in all, the porting was well done and should definitely be appreciated,

Pros

+ Great Port with many options for many differing levels of hardware.
++ Hits you right in the nostalgia with many recognizable characters and settings in full anime glory!
+++ Fast paced but accessible gameplay with enough options for more adept fighting gamers.
++++ Adequate singleplayer content on launch day in a genre not known for its singleplayer experiences
Cons

- Cumbersome online system that makes it very unintuitive to invite friends to a match among other things.
-- Slightly anemic roster with more characters to come later ( Not soon enoughhhhh!)
--- Expensive DLC!


Overall Score-

THIS REVIEW IS EDITED. SEE THE ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW.
---
While I wasn't a fan of the servers and UI at launch, things have settled down a bit now that the day one rush is over. 

DBFZ keeps things simple by making each memeber of a three man squad have about 3 to 4 moves with simple inputs. Team building, skill with each character, knowing more tech, and most importantly, NOT AUTO DASHING IN NEUTRAL 24/7 TO GET FACE FUCKED BY 2H ON REACTION, are all important skills in DBFZ. It's not too different from MvC3 with a bit of ArcSys flare thrown in. All in all, it's a damn good mix on top of looking great.

The literal sorcery done with the Unreal 3 engine (later ported to Unreal 4 which is what DBFZ runs on) has shown improvement over the last two entries of the Guilty Gear series and continues to have more of it's potential discovered on each project. 
As a result, DBFZ is a fantastic looking game with a borderline insane level of detail put in to make it faithful to the source material. Even to the point of recreating some of the more akward frames from the anime and manga for the sake of detail.

Story mode feels like a fun DBZ OVA that time forgot, although I might be biased in that statement as it is similar to the Android Arc of the anime. Which was my favorite arc in the series. What wasn't fun about story mode was having to fight through hours of "Clone fighters" of the cast on easy AI difficulty for the majority of the fights in DBFZ. 

I realize what this sounds like, but I honestly would have prefered DBFZ's story mode to be a big, in-game OVA like Guilty Gear. Alternatively they could have made a handfull of set "boss" versions of characters and put it on top of something akin to Guilty Gear's Medal of Millionare mode (commonly refered to as M.O.M. Mode). The story is fun, grinding through AI clones with auto combos to see the next part is not.

While I would still like ArcSys to make the lobbies more convienent and stick support to anything that isn't a Microsoft controller, pad, or stick is not complete. It would be foolish to pass up on this game for those reasons alone. Just be ready to deal with some questionable menu choices and have fun raising that power level.

First thing's first. The game itself is fine and the second the issues I have with it are fixed I will change this review.

As the game is right now, the online is borderline unplayable. To access any online mode, you MUST be in an online lobby and your friends MUST be in the SAME online lobby as you. I am on the US East Coast and there are nowhere near as much lobby space as needed to support the game. 
There are only official lobbies and for the US East Coast only about 400 or so players can be on at once. My guess is that the average volume of people is probably closer to 40,000 at the absolute least.

Unlike Guilty Gear Xrd, all menus are through the lobby system. Both in online lobbies and offline. It makes things unclear even with the menu surfing option under "Teleport". 

You also cannot host private lobbies without being on one of the 64 man servers and anyone you invite MUST be on the same server. 

This NEEDS to be reworked entirely. My guess is Bamco was handling the servers this time around because I have no idea why they wouldn't just copy paste the convienent menus and lobbies from GGXrd. 

While I have not had this problem personally, as I use a fightpad. Apparently some arcade sticks do not register and keyboard support is not what one would consider full. I cannot comment anymore than that as I do not use a stick or a keyboard myself to play.

The game itself is fine, but a rework patch out of the gate is absolutely, 100% needed. Until then, I'd recomend waiting to buy this if you were planning to do so.

This is an arcade style fighting game, where two players with three fighters each battle it until they've killed all of their opponent's fighters. If you've played Marvel vs Capcom, you'll know the kind of game I'm talking about.

Combos are key in a game like this, thankfully FighterZ goes easier on new players. Simply mashing face buttons grant auto combos, and while they aren't as optimal as specific varied inputs, they'll still let you hold your own.

Blocking is done just like MvC, holding away from your opponent, and down to block low sweeps. Guards can be broken with heavier attacks, character specific moves, or using Dragon Rush. This will send the opponent flying and lead you into an aerial combo chain.

Super Dashing will let you charge directly at your opponent and lead into a combo if they don't intercept, block, or reflect it. New players tend to spam this move, and the easiest defense is simply blocking and following it up.

Certain moves require Ki to use. You can your Ki at the bottom of the screen. This is built up by dealing or taking damage, blocking, or charging by holding your Ranged and Light attack buttons simeltaniously. Of course, this leaves you wide open. Pressing the medium and heavy attack buttons simeltaniously will teleport you into a heavy attack behind your enemy, although this costs one bar of Ki can be blocked by avid foes.

Super Moves can be autocomboed into by mashing medium attack on most characters, or dealt on a whim with a quarter circle forward and button input, depending on the character and move. At the cost of three Ki bars, quarter circle back and Dragon Rush will use a X3 super, dealing massive damage generally speaking. Although there are some exceptions, such as Ginyu's body swap.

Characters can be called in to initiate or compliment combos, or swapped to by holding the button. Upon dying, you'll automatically switch to the next character. Standard MvC mechanics.

Less standard are health mechanics. When you take damage, you'll have a blue bar left where some of your health used to be. Sending characters with recoverable HP to reserve will start them healing, certain specials can also heal off that damage, however most interesting is Sparking Mode. Useable once per match by pressing Dragon Rush and Super Dash simeltaniously, this move will make you quickly regenerate HP even whilst being combo'd.

And a mechanic that will likely never come into play in a real match, the Dragon Balls. Either player getting a 10 hit combo will summon the 1 star ball, 20 hit for 2 star, so on and so fourth up to a 70 hit combo for the 7 star ball. Or just, light hit auto combo your way to random dragon balls. Once all the dragon balls are summoned, a player with a maxed out Ki bar has to perform a basic light hit combo, at the end Shenron will be summoned to grant a wish. This lets you bring one of your teammates back to life, heal yourself, and other mechanics. Nothing utterly game breaking, but nothing to sneeze at either. Of course, considering the requirements, I doubt this mechanic will ever turn the tide of a match. It'd be awesome though.

If you're a fan of Dragon Ball Z like myself, you'll love this game's cutscenes. FighterZ is oozing with charm. Characters will talk and interact with one another as the characters would.

This is driven home even further in the game's story mode, featuring an original plotline. As you go through and find more fighters to add to your roster, they'll have banter and cutscenes with one another that'll make any fan of Dragon Ball Z smile.

Every single move, every single animation, even, is animated exactly like the show or manga. Not a single detail is misplaced. Reflecting away energy blasts will damage the enviroments, characters become visibly damaged over time, and finishing off fighters with heavy hits or powerful blasts will send them flying or destroy the terrain!

Even if you have never seen the show before, this is simply a good fighting game, with simple to pick up mechanics, a diverse roster, and a high skill ceiling. Ranked Mode will let you play against people competitively, to increase your rank. And as you play any of the gamemodes, you'll earn currency used to buy capsules. Don't worry, while they are basically loot boxes this game does not have ANY microtransactions, yet (fingers crossed), and nothing in the capsules effect gameplay. They contain colour sets for fighters, custom flair for your player's info card, and namely avatars, emotes and stamps for the game's lobby menu, where all of the gamemode selection takes place.

This leads me to one of my problems with this game, though. The lobby system is far and away, the worst one I have ever seen for a fighting game. You select your region, then a server set from your region. From there, you choose from one of several lobbies, each of which let you play different gamemodes against real people. However, these lobbies have player limits of 64 people, and the server regions are very vague. I mean, US EAST and US WEST, and, that's it. Same for Canada, and Mexico.

Back to the point, these lobbies are not a well thought out system. While there is an offline lobby option, you obviously can't play against anyone online from it, and you can't launch the game straight into an offline lobby. And if you want to play with your friends, you have to both manually find and join the same lobby, create a private match within it, navigate the clunky menus, and then start. You can't simply click "join game."

Aside from the inane server system, the gameplay itself is absolutely solid. I'm no fighting game expert, but every pro player I've seen try this game has liked it.

So, if you're looking for a fantastic 3v3 fighting game that is friendly to those new to the genre, with an active community, large roster and promise of at least 8 more characters in the future, via DLC mind you, FighterZ is a great choice. If you haven't watched the show before, well you should, but the game will likely be of interest regardless! I will admit though, if you hate Dragon Ball Z, you'll likely not be able to stand this game. It's filled with refrences, style, dialogue, and... japan-ness from the show, and it's a bit hard to ignore.

For someone like me, though, who likes fighting games but isn't very good at them, and LOVES Dragon Ball Z, this game is absolutely worth the price.

Love it. It's beautiful and fun. I'm sure any DBZ fan will enjoy playing this. It's managed to create a fighting game easy enough to get into while maintaining the depth of the genre. Solid game, 10/10.

[b] [u] [h1] Summary [/h1] [/u] [/b]
Dragon Ball FighterZ... An amazing fighting style game based on the original series's plot with some extras [spoiler](like the new character Android 21) [/spoiler] , a game which I would recommend to people who have watched the series it self or to old school players who have played 2D fighting games like Street Fighter or Tekken.

[b] [u] [h1] Plot [/h1] [/u] [/b]
The arcs in the game occurs sometime after the Universe 6 Saga story-line before the "Future" Trunks Saga in Dragon Ball Super.
The game has three arcs:
[b] The Super Warrior Arc where goku is the main character,
 The Enemy Warrior Arc  where Frieza is the main character
and the Android 21 Arc where Android 18 and 21 are the main characters, Each arc are similar when it comes to features but somewhat different when it comes to the story.
The main plot of the game is revealed in the Android 21 Arc. [/b]

[b] [u] [h1] Gameplay [/h1] [/u] [/b]
The gameplay borrows concepts from other fighting games, primarily the Marvel vs. Capcom series control scheme and team mechanics, with three primary attack buttons and one unique action buttons blus a few others. Unlike the Arc System Works-developed Extreme Butouden, FighterZ plays out in a scheme much closer to many other of the traditional Arc System Works.
Players each select three characters to form a team. One character is controlled, and can be switched with one of the other characters at any time. Players can also call one of their other characters to perform an "Assist" move, allowing simultaneous attacks and combos with the entire team. All three of a team's characters must be defeated for a match to end.
Other mechanics involve the usage of the auto-combo system utilized by fighting games as of Persona 4: Arena (tap one button for an automatic preset combo), which now also applies to the medium attack button as well (giving all characters two auto-combos). Forward + medium attack is also a universal overhead attack for all characters, which cannot be chained out of.
Nearly all characters are also planned to have differing playstyles/archetypes apart from each other akin to more contemporary fighting games as opposed to using recycled base movesets such as in the Budoukai games.
An Instant Kill-like cutscene known as ‚ÄúDramatic Finish‚Äù is only on two certain characters, if one of them won the match.

[spoiler] LootBoxes [/spoiler]
In the game you have the ability to buy loot boxes i.e. "Z Capsules", these loot boxes are unlockable with the in-game currency named zeni, earned through winning matches, completing challanges and chapters and more. When a player receives  a duplicate item, it is transformed into another type of currency - the Premium Z Coin. As with zeni, these coins are not purchasable with real-life money. Ten Premium Z Coins can be exchanged for a single, non-duplicate item of the player's choice.

This game is an absolutely excellent, fun, streamlined, well-polished triple A fighter.  It is a complete joy for fans of Dragonball Z.  The story mode, while I found it a bit slow at first, has truly grown on me.  The premise is a bit silly, but the voice-acting, animation, and the dialogue itself is amazing!   The online lobby is cute, functional, and probably works for someone:

Therein lies my only problem with Dragonball FighterZ so far: the online connection.   I get booted from lobbies almost as soon as I join them; it was fine yesterday, and terrible today.  I get booted from matches for no apparent reason.  My internet is broadband and can manage seven megabytes down and at least one up.   I've heard rumor that it might be because I'm operating on wifi.  Setting the game up to require a hardline ethernet connection is kind of crap in the modern age (I do not encounter this problem on other fighters online).  I hope the devs fix this soon.  

More impressions: story mode is too easy, but fun.  Arcade mode is properly challenging.  The few PvP fights I've managed to get all the way through were very fun, even if I felt like I was getting juggled a lot.  That's my fault for not learning the very accessible assist/combo system.   There is no chat in-game, so there are no trolls or flamers to encounter.  Instead all you have is the option to customize various preset messages and stamps to create cute little emotes.  I think it's rather genius.   

People are complaining that there is no way to directly invite a friend to a match, that's true.  If you want to play with your friend online you'll need to both join the same lobby, and create a ring match to play each other.   This probably isn't nearly as difficult as people are making it out to be, except for the infuriating connection issues.   

If they fix their wonky servers, this game will be the best Dragonball game to ever have been made, not to mention a superb fighter that is very addictive and fun.   I look forward to seeing this game blossom into an esport.  Now get to work on making the connection smoother than butter, devs.  I have faith in you!

This game is a blast. You don't have to be hardcore into DBZ, you don't have to be hardcore into fighting games. 

The game is fast, colorful, the animations are fluid and beautiful. It's  easy to pick up, you can pull of some badass and useful moves right away, but learning to string them together in the most effective and brutal ways will take you time. And learning to juggle in the assists from the other members of your team can make you extra deadly. There's a lot to master in this game.

You sign in to a lobby, a little dbz village where you can walk around with 64~ other people, challenge each other, put on ring matches (multiple people can join up, watch ongoing fights, queue to fight winner etc) spend zeni coins (the in game currency you earn as you fight and complete content or do daily tasks), watch replays, or access any of the games many modes and features.

The story is actually fun! You progress through maps with multiple paths, you can fight every fight or choose a more direct path to the boss battle that progresses the story and moves you to the next map. Fighting more fights means you level fighters, earn more rewards (coins, powerups that increase damage/exp etc during storymode), and have potential to see some dialog you might not otherwise. The story mode fights take time to become challenging. Eventually you will lose one and start learning how to counter/guard effectively and not charge in. I felt like the curve was enough that it didn't frustate me but I didn't get bored before I started having to think a bit more.

Training modes are both fun and useful. Combo challenges are a blast and will help make you a better and more competetive player. Grab your favorite chracter and go through a 10 point progression from easy single button combos up to challenging strings of moves that really fuck shit up. You'll be rewarded for your time and effort. There's also a general battle training to take you through the game basics,  and the sort of freeplay training you'd expect with CPU settings, damage/hit data that's useful to serious players.

Is like a dream come true! I remember how much I wanted a game like this. When I was a child and saw at the arcades all the fighting games, including MVC and imaginating if some how it will be a game like that but with DBZ characters!

One of the craziest games I've ever played. As a diehard dbz fan, this is probably the best game you'll ever get your hands on, from the presentation, to the gameplay (which has a bunch of hidden depth), and the fanservice, the game just gives you the most awesome feeling. 10/10.

The game is flashy, looks great, and is fun...if you play against the bots.  But if you're new to fighting games, or even if you're well versed in fighting games but aren't well versed in 2D anime fighting games, you are not going to have a good time with online matches.  The lobbies are already full of people that know how to juggle you start to finish, to the point where if you don't get the first hit, you literally cannot move until you die.  

If you're wanting this for the story, or to play against bots, go for it.  If you're wanting this to play with other people online, skip, unless you're well well well versed in 2D anime fighters.

If you're looking for a really good, fast-paced action fighting game, Dragon Ball FighterZ is the game for you, trust me. I would definitely recommend a controller or arcade stick because playing this with a keyboard is not that great.

Dragon Ball Fighterz is out and now I'm reminded of how mediocre I am at fighting games! 

The world is in danger! Clones of the greatest warriors run wild across the planet and even a few of the universe's most dangerous threats have been resurrected. But even though Goku and friends are weakened by strange ‚ÄúWaves‚Äù they suddenly have a trick up their sleeve. You!
You are a spirit that can inhabit one of their bodies and bring them back to fighting strength. So now I can finally live out my dream of being inside Goku. 

Dragon Ball Fighterz is a 2.5D fighting game developed by Arc System Works, known mostly for Guilty Gear and BlazBlue. Unlike a majority of modern Dragon Ball games which were more like fun brawlers and Dragon Ball fanfic machines, DBF is a very competent fighting game with a weighty roster and a few neat modes to keep you busy.

Play as your favorite characters such as Fightman, Manlet, Big Green, Kid Fightman, Triclops, Real Estate Agent, Chromosome Snatcher, Forehead #18, and who could forget: Fightman but shorter.

Once you start the game you are introduced to a lobby where you choose your avatar before you head out. From here you can pick modes ranging from story to arcade to ranked and casual matches to arena mode, which is basically the ultimate turf fight. Its nice to have a fighting game with all of its options actually fleshed out and ready to play from launch, unlike a few certain other games that came out with missing features.
Its like ordering a pizza and only getting the coke.
The story mode is surprisingly weighty, being a mix of fighting game and visual novel. Though that's par for the course with Arc Systems, they even went out of their way to make a brand new story instead of just treading old ground. Even going as far as to add a new character who I may or may not have a little boy crush on. 
Its refreshing to see your favorite characters on a new adventure instead of just treading old ground over and over again.
Xenoverse could learn a lot from this. 

Something that Arc Systems really did well on is the sense of scale. These are some powerful dudes and ladies, even the weakest one is probably strong enough to blow up a planet at this point. So you get special animations for beating an opponent with certain moves, like giant beam attacks treat you to a zoom out to show just how big these attacks are, some of them even leave the planet. There are also finishers that launch your opponent through a mountain. Or into space.
He's not coming back.

Most of the characters share the same button commands, which makes it easier to memorize specials and combo enders. But at the same time its kind of lame that there isn't a character for certain play styles, so charge character players are basically a left out. 

The game also has an auto-combo feature for easing new players into the genre. Don't rely too much on it though or you're going to get bodied.
I mean, you're going to get bodied anyway, so you know what I mean. I get bodied.
I also cry often. 

It all melds together and helps the player adjust to playing a team of three characters. Since there isn't much difference in commands, you end up learning your characters quickly, a hopefully improving as you climb the ranks. Or just stop playing after getting beaten up by a man with the Steam name of Pedro Mustachio, I don't care.
There are a few problems, at least on launch. Finding a game, ranked or otherwise takes so long I may as well review this game while I wait for a match. I also can't seem to play with friends, or some friends at least. For some reason we're given a ‚ÄúThis game is full message‚Äù when we try to play in a room together, even if its just the two of us. 
Other than that and a few frame hiccups, the game is absolutely solid. 

Dragon Ball Fighterz is a [strike]raging[/strike]blast to play. It captures the fury, the scale, and the adrenaline of the series in a way we haven't seen since the Budokai Tenkaichi games. It doesn't hold back, it plays Dragon Ball straight and doesn't dilute it at all. If the more toned down games decided to let loose like DBF does then we'd probably have some kind of crazy Dragon Ball game renaissance on our hands.

DBF is in love with it's source material, and that's not something you can say for very many games. If you're looking for a new fighting game, a new Dragon Ball game, or just a new Dragon Ball story. At least give this a check out.

This game's multiplayer is definitely annoying, but you can still do most of the functions of the game by pressing Y (probably another key I don't know of if you're using keyboard) to go to an offline lobby.

Offline Gameplay:

[b]FINOMINAL[/b]. This is definitely worth getting, especially if you plan on playing a lot of single player. The story mode is an easy 10 hours for all 3 arcs if you defeat the least amount of enemies possible (but can get repetitive if you try to defeat everything), and a challenging arcade mode and loot system just ready for you to dig your hands into! There's plenty of gameplay to be had offline.

In addition, there's a practice mode where you can learn how to do the combat in this game, combo challenges, and more. There's a local battle as well for those who want to 1v1 friends, or create a tournament using the tournament feature, which is definitely finominal if you need to warm up, or just wanna go against random CPUs consecutively.

Online Gameplay:


I'm gonna split this up so you know where it's good and bad. [b]Note that this is the main problem in the game.[/b]

CONS:
There are about 12 lobbies on average for each region (based off North America). Each can hold up to 64 players, and is generally hogged pretty quickly, especially when those in your region aren't working/sleeping. The main problem with this, is that most people go onto the online lobbies, but don't participate in online activites, like Ring Matches, Arena Matches, and Casual and Ranked Matches (for more info, see pros). But what do they do then?

Instead, they do things like arcade and practice mode, while staying on the lobby, both of which can easily be done offline, and easily hogs up space for those who want to play online. The problem won't be completely hindered, but if they kicked you offline for using any of these modes, just like they [i]kind of[/i] do with story mode, the problem is majorly hindered.

[b]My main point is that they need to keep matches online, and keep all the other features offline to save space for those using online, and the game will be much better multiplayer wise.[/b]

PROS:
From Arena Matches to Ring Matches, there is definitely fun to be had in multiplayer, if you can get in and not get kicked out. Here's each of the modes:

Arena Matches: Have a match with someone else on the server quickly! Talk to the man right to the announcments to jump in, and go against others! (I recommend ring matches more, however)

Casual Matches: Jump into a casual match, and it's exactly like a ranked match, except there's no rank, and you can go against pretty much anyone, rather than a rank based choice. Speaking of which,

Ranked Match: A 1v1 with some random person on the internet also playing FighterZ that's most likely in the same region, but sometimes you end up with more, but it's based on your settings, really. Go against someone against your skill, or higher, [b]if you dare.[/b] This does count towards your win/loss ratio, and if you want to get rid of that Saibamen ranking on your player card, [b]play some ranked matches and rank up.[/b]

Ring Match: The most flexible online match making system in Fighterz. Set up mini tournaments, 1v1s with your friends, specific battles in specific orders, 3v3 with each player being one character, it's got it all! The only requirement is that you have to be on the same server as the person/people who are going to play, and they have to walk over to you to join. [b]Too much effort, if you ask me.[/b]


-----------

That being said, singleplayer gameplay, although the story can be a bit repetitive, is pretty great, and can help you get started in mastering the game/the characters you want to play. (9/10)

The multiplayer can be annoying, but it's not as hard as people give it out to be, [b]except during rush hour on weekends.[/b] But overall, the multiplayer gameplay is excellent. (7/10)

Although this wasn't a review of the actual game mechanics, I'll leave that to someone else; I'm clarifying the multiplayer and singleplayer situations. If I ever go into more detail, it'll most likely be game mechanics or DLC.

Enjoy the game if you buy!

Let me start off by saying that just like probably 80% of everyone, I also grew up with DBZ. I've always been a fan and played a lot of the old DBZ games, for example DBZ Budokai 3 for the PS2 which I will compare this game to a lot. 

DBZ Budokai 3 has the same 2D fighting style as FighterZ and the preview videos made it look like a new and better version of Budokai 3 (that's what I was expecting). However. I like to call this game an early access version of Budokai 3. I will list some things here that I find note worthy:

- You can't go super saiyan. Frieza can turn gold for a short time but other than that, you can't transform anything.
- There is very few characters to choose from. There are currently 24 characters available. I read that you can get 8 more characters if you're willing to pay $35 for the season pass. Since you can't transform anything except from Frieza, this is very disappointing.
- Every character that has the ability to turn super saiyan (storywise) is already super saiyan. For example, you can't play as normal Vegeta, only as Vegeta SSj1 or SSGSS which are 2 seperate characters to choose between. Same goes for Goku which also has Black Goku as seperate character, but characters like Trunks are always SSJ1.
- It feels like a huge insult that you're able to get lobby characters which you can only run around with, which you can't get as actual fighting characters. For example Cell's other forms, Frieza's other forms, Majin Vegeta and side characters like Saibaman etc.
- The combat system is super flawed. For example the other day I shot a beam at my friend and right before it hit, he did an attack aswell. We both watched as my beam clipped straight through his body without damaging him, while his attack continued at hit me. This happens A LOT. 
- There is very few defence mechanics in the game. So there really is not much you can do vs button mashers.
- The controls are very easy and bland. This combined with the flawed defence system make it so that your biggest chance at winning, is to look which character has the range/speed and spamming light/medium attack untill you win. 
- The story arcs are extremely boring. You're forced to fight countless clones of the same 3-4 character over and over while you play a different weird story 3 times which is about the same characters (?). 
- During the story cutscenes in the story arcs, the animations are garbage. The movement of the characters is often very stiff and laggy. I checked if my frames dropped because of the laggy characters, but it really is just the animation. The walking animations are also ridiculous. The feet move faster than they travel. The main lobby of the game has this same problem with the feet.
- The main lobby is boring and there really is not much to do there.
- If you're sick of the button mashers in online, and you've completed the 3 short story arcs, then too bad. There is nothing else to do except training or fighting an NPC. 
- There are a lot of issues with hitboxes in this game. For example, Goku reaching farther than his arm/leg and some attacks just failing to connect.

Now that I've listed some poor things about FighterZ, I will name some things that Budokai 3 has, and this game was made in 2004:
- There are 42 playable characters. You need to unlock most of them.
- The story mode consists of 11 characters, all with their own story and actual enemies to fight instead of the same clone again and again.
- During the story mode you can fly around over the Earth with various things to do like searching for items or searching for hidden stuff to unlock characters. 
- These 42 characters make for many more variations because of the tranformations. For example as Goku you can go all the way up to SSJ4 and even then you can fuse with Vegeta. 
- The combat system has more options since you can choose which attacks/items your chosen character has during a fight. You can even upgrade and unlock more skills from for example the shop.
- The fighting is way more balanced and broad. For example if both players both do a kamehameha at the same time, they will clash in which an event will start where you have to mash a button to win the clash. 
- There are items in-game that can be used during a fight or that simply boost your stats, for example as Vegeta you can equip a Majin thingy that transforms you into Majin Vegeta when you reach low hp.
- The in-game shop is a really fun way to gain new skills, items and costumes. 
- You can change how many HP bars both parties have. This makes it so that your fight doesn't end within 2 seconds and you can actually make it an epic battle with transforming etc. 

They made an HD rendered version called Dragon Ball Z: Budokai HD Collection which includes Budokai 1 and 3 for either the PS3 or the Xbox 360. I really recommend you buy that bundle instead of FighterZ. It will save you like $40 and gives you way more content to play with. I also really recommend Dragon Ball Z: Budokai Tenkaichi 3 which was made for the PS2 and the Wii. This game has 161 playable characters (yes I'm serious) including a lot of characters which were solely made for this game. For example the Saiyans' Great Ape forms. This game has a 3D fighting style which I also really enjoyed back in the day on the Wii. 

Conclusion:
Don't buy FighterZ. We have already seen with Xenoverse and Xenoverse 2 that the devs are really lazy and lacking their original creativity. The older games are cheaper and offer A LOT more content. FighterZ only has 3 things that are better than the old games: The game is new so it has the new characters in it (Hit, beerus, Goku&Vegeta SSGSS). The graphics are obviously better than the old games (I don't know how good the HD rendered version of the old games look). It's available on PC which is Master race. Honestly I don't know why this game has so many positive reviews, it lacks too much.

I'm gonna keep it short, the game is amazing.  It runs well, it is absolutely beautiful, and it is Dragon Ball but with MvC3 mehcanics.  It beats out UMvC3 and MvCI by a large margin (personally at least).  It's combos are simple, but once you understand how things flow, how characters work, and how to use the mechanics properly; it leads to one of the most intense and free will fighting game systems yet.  The only other game that does what FighterZ does is Guilty Gear Xrd -Rev- 2, and Arksys made that game.  It does have one thing that may put people off and that is the main menu is weird, and there is no way to directly make a loby for you and friends easily.  If you can look past that though, you get a faithful game to the DBZ franchise and a fighting game that anyone can play and have fun with.
Simply amazing

It's not only the fighting game of the year for me but also one of the best Dragonball games out there to date! For any dbz fan out there.

Pros
- amazing graphics
- great fighting game mechanics that feel fresh
- epic battles against your friends
- even when you are losing u have a chance to come back
- fun story mode
- great local versus play

Cons
- expensive with the fighterZ pass
- online lobbies are pretty shit and badly designed
- you will have connectivity issues if you don't set your steam region to the server you enter
- people in ranked like to disconnect from the internet and ragequit so they don't lose points
- i really wished the villain in this was a bit more original than a female looking buu...
- inviting a friend to fight you online isn't as simple as  "invite friend to match"

Overall most of the negative experiences have to do with the online multiplayer experience and trying to play with friends... if you're good playing with strangers all the time, then it's fine. I really wished they nailed the online experience as I really want  this game to do well.

Holy shit this game is awesome. I haven't had this much fun in not only a fighting game, but a Dragon Ball game in a long ass time. Not to mention the fact that I actually win online in this game. :O

Anyway imma list Pros and Cons to save anyone reading some time. 

NOTE: A common misconception is that this a game for DBZ fansm and while that is true, its a fighting game first, and a Dragon Ball game second. 

Pros:
+This game is ABSOLUTELY gorgeous, I almost splooged the first time I saw a super attack.
+ Combat is fun and simple, without feeling too repetitve.
+Net code is the best i've experienced. Frame delay is almost non-existent in most cases.
+3v3 is actually a cool and exciting concept.
+Story mode length and concept are really cool. (Finally a unique DBZ story lol)
+Modes are challenging and diverse
+Loot! But fair and no impact on gamplay, simply spend some Zeni (which is easily obtained) and hope you get something you want. You can unbox Lobby characters, colors, Z-stamps, etc. Feels rewarding
+Easter eggs/references. My god... if you're a diehard DBZ fan, play this game and figure out some of the Dramatic finishes... pls
+Stages are unique, fleshed out, even destructible enviornments.
+The music is incredible! Actually this game some of my favorite music in a DBZ I think.
+Story mode is hilarious.
+Linking with characters feels really rewarding, deepening connections with characters you sometimes don't even care about
+Android 21 is T H I C C

Cons:
-Story mode and its dialougue feel off. Sometimes it just doesn't mesh and I feel like characters lines are useless and only waste time, but can be funny.
-Fighting the clones in the story mode can feel really repetetive.
-Story mode animations 
-Artificial difficulty is annoying when climbing arcade (ie. the AI doing more damage just because, but still being brain dead)
-Android 21's voice actor in English is REALLY annoying.
-Getting into an Online Lobby can be a hassle if too many people are playing, especially Canada.
-The main lobby could use some "lively" attention. It feels stale pretty quickly.



Other than that this is one of the most fun games i've ever played.

Verdict:9/10
FUN

My fightstick wasn't compatible. I looked online and many others had noticed the same. Personally, I don't think it's reasonable to release a fighting game without arcade stick support so I've refunded it.

So first off I will say the story is pretty good, I mean you mainly fight clones, but the writing will give you a little laugh every now, and then, and its kind of interesting seeing characters ineract with one another. The gameplay is solid with great animation. Arcade mode is fun, and can get very challanging. Online works really well connection wise, and people don't tend to spam as much as they can't since energy stops them, but you can counter most spam attacks.

Overall it's a solid fighting game with great netcode, and I would suggest getting it if your a big fan of fighting games. Only downside is when you play the ai on hard they tend to spam the same move, and keep you in an endless combo.

Excellent game, but not perfect.

The pros:
-Awesome fighting mechanics, very marvel vs capcom style, with a bit of Guilty Gear formula.
-Excellent visuals, they are even betteer than the TV show. Best graphics ever for a DBZ game, by difference.
-All fighters have their moveset very well inspired on the manga and tvshow.
-Lots of stuff for online and offline mode (story mode took me about 15 hours to complete). The AI in arcade mode is soo hard to beat.
-24 different, unique and well balanced characters.

The cons:
-I don't like the fucking lobby oriented menus. Why, why they force you to enter the lobby, even if I don't have any intention to use online modes?? I would prefer a classic menu interface.
-Story mode is a bit unnecessarily large. Sometimes gets boring,. I think they could have made it in 8 hours, with less useless and repetyitive combats (the combats in story mode are very easy), and I think it would have been better to have a unique arc instead of having 3 differents arcs which sometimes have some incongruences between them.
-It would have been waaay better if arcade mode had some type of cinematic, credits, exclusive galleries when you beat it, you know, sime type of... story, like there has always been in fighters games.

In conclusion, this game:
-Is a dream come true if you're a fighting game enthusiast and a Dragon ball fan.
-Is a must have if you're a fighting game enthusiast.
-Is a must have if you're a Dragon Ball fan but never played a REAL fighting game (xenoverse, tenkaichis and other Dragon ball games are not fighting games sorry). The game offers gameplay mechanics so you can have fun from day 0 even if you're not familiar with the genre. You'll have to learn a lot to win in online battles of course, but that's another story...

I would give it a 9/10. Ultra recommended.

I don't get too hyped for games nowadays, too much bullshit. But this game is worth the hype. when I heard this game was being made I was skeptical; until I saw that Arc systems was making it, and immediately became hyped. If you want a masterful 2D fighting game than none come close to Arc. 10/10.

-Now that the line skimmers are out of the way, some issues. For one the player roster is a bit small in my opinion especially for the game mode which is a 3v3. if this game had a 1v1 than it wouldn't be so bad, but having 6 characters of a 21 character roster being used every battle makes the selection slim. what makes it even worse is the fact that this game comes after tenkaichi 3 which had every concievable character in it from the show. So the list was reduced on purpose and turned into bullshit "if you want more fighters get the season pass." In summary the list is small for the 3v3 battles; and if you don't think so go play Marvel v Capcom and just see the large roster.
-Another issue with this game is a problem that I found while playing. There are no combo breakers to my knowledge. This wouldn't be so bad in some fighting games, but a game like this where you can get a 30hit combo than switch to another character to get another without a respite for the opponent just seems like shit. Just for the haters I'm not bringing this up because I suffered this problem (which I did) but I bring it up because I have inflicted this same abuse on opponents and wiped entire teams without suffering any damage.
-Story mode is Eh. Maybe it's because I went straight into ranked, but the story mode had no challenge at all. I literally blew right through it. Not to mention it has the same problem that all fighting game stories have, it's just an excuse for characters to fight. which wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't Dragon Ball, the show made for characters to just fight.

Now some Positives

Everything.

really the game is a ton of fun and a great addition to fighting game enthusiasts libraries. There were just a few things that came off as odd to me.

This game is incredible. The lobby system allows you to meet tons of people, find your friends (with some navigation required), and practice while matchmaking. In addition, the game is great for newer players. Allowing basic inputs to work into combos. Now these basic inputs wont put on the top of the ladder, but it will make you feel good, look good, and actually beat people.
The story is lame, but Android 21 isn't.

Everyone already gushed on about Graphics, Sound, Story, Yada Yada so I won't bother.

Game is solid. Combos are easy to perform mechanically but the real trick is to know which ones to perform and when to use tags and assists to your advantage.

Matchmaking is a lot better since the patch today and Ring Matches finally work properly.

Let's talk about the online for now. Well, matchmaking is kinda wonky on ranked but then again game has been out for less than 5 days and I only played 3 ranked matches, and I'm in the Japan region. First ranked match, the guy bodied me so hard he did a false combo with Gohan and Hit till my first character died without landing a punch, like he was a lot better than me. Second and Third guy were so bad the abysmal AI from story mode could beat them.

Do you like Dragonball? Do you like fighter games? Then get this game for you.

[b]Kaaaaaa---![/b]

[u]Arc System Works[/u] has created a fighting masterpiece. Dragon Ball FighterZ may very well be the best fighting game on the market. 

From the gorgeous hand drawn artwork, to the extremely tight gameplay mechanics, all the way down to the fine details of the character banter. It is all spot on.

[b]Meeeeeeeeee---![/b]

However, there are a few minor annoyances. Nothing is perfect in this world, not even Cell. 
The way they handled the Lobby system and match making could be a little better. Disconnects are abundant and during the launch of the game there was no where near enough lobbies open for everyone to play online.

That being said, it is not game breaking. They've already fixed the lobby issue by adding more. 

[b]Haaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa---![/b]

I had to get that one negative aspect of the game out of the way, because this game is loaded with positive things to talk about.

I'll be real with you.. I am absolutely terrible at fighting games. I purchased Dragon Ball FighterZ simply because of my love for Dragon Ball and the artwork of the game looked exactly like the anime series. 

DBFZ has done for me, what no other fighting game has ever been able to do. It [i]makes[/i] me want to get better at the game, and it gives me every single tool I need to do so. The easy Story mode is a nice way to start off after you've practiced and practiced in training mode and after rewatching your fights over and over. You can also head over to Arcade Mode where things get a bit tougher, before you finally decide to take the plunge into online Casual and Ranked Matches.

[b]Meeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee---![/b]

I have a strong feeling this game will be around for a long time and celebrated among the Fighting community and loved on Twitch. The art style has me believing it will never age. As with other fighting games such as Tekken or Street Fighter, those pixelated games don't age very well visually. 

Seriously, if you are a Fighting Game fan, you should already own this. If you are a solid Dragon Ball Z fan, definitely check this out.  

+ The art style is very pleasing and almost identical to the actual anime
+ The mechanics of the game are so tight and smooth. Easy to play, but very, [i]very[/i] hard to master
+ You get a plethora of characters to choose from. Each with their own conversations and banter
+ There is a ton of customization as well. It's locked behind loot boxes, but these loot boxes are acquired from actually playing the game

- If you want to play with a couple friends online, it may be more troublesome to find each other then it needs to be. 


[b]HHHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA![/b]
AMAZING GAME BUY IT NOW!!!!!
A masterpiece of fun.
