Long Version:
 
Wow.... this is probably the best fighting game I've played in a long time. 

A bold statement, and there is a little bias because it features characters from my favorite anime Dragonball Z and Super. Yet, hear me out.

I've played and mastered most fighting games out there, MVC series, Street Fighter series, Virtua Fighter, DOA, Tekken, Smash Bros, you name it I most likely played it (hurts my wallet too). Honestly, I've become a little fatigued as nothing really feels fresh or new. Not to mention, paying more for DLC is a major killer for me as I've already spent full price for most the games that I mentioned. 

Dragonball Fighter Z takes me back to a time when I played guilty gear back in 2001, and said "wow, I wish Dragonball characters were in this." Now 17 years later, my wish came true and even though it comes off as a button masher it is much more than that.

What really makes this game is that each character is a blast to use, and while mashing a few buttons pulls off some of the coolest animations I've ever seen in a fighting game, you'll notice a much more rewarding experience by going farther  by mixung up combo's of your own. It's so rewarding to practice combo's in the training room, and then using them online against people or even the CPU on hard. The characters are quite balanced, and while it doesn't seem like that after playing your first online match and getting wrecked,  you'll come to find that every character can be countered. Example, while I was playing 3v3, this buu kept wrecking me and my friend. I realized that buu is a medium ranged character and he consistently used the same combo. So, I countered him with a solid projectile character like Trunks by damaging him with some ki blasts and following up with some solid combos to deal some damage. It's moments like that, that are so rewarding and keeps you at the edge of your seat. 

The animations, the character voices (japanese and english), the music, are all amazing and is everything I've wanted in a Dragonball fighting game! I have nothing but praise for this game and is a game that Dragonball fans have been waiting for and deserve!

In conclusion, if you love fast paced fighting games like marvel vs capcom 3 and anime like Dragonball, and are willing to put in the time to master the characters, you will find an excellent and rewarding game that is worth every penny!

FighterZ is still very much a multiplayer online classic fighting game though, and there's plenty of things to do, though I have been too impatient to start fights with players. you can train combos, go through an arcade mode, go through tournament style modes classic to Dragonball fighting games or just laze around in the game's online lobby. 
once you feel like taking the training wheels off, you'll find combos can be built from one button but there is an incredible amount of depth to getting past your opponent's block, forcing others to let their guard down and using teams effetively. 
I'm a massive dragonball fan, and you might have to be to know who the characters are, what special attacks they are likely to have and make sense of the relationships between characters in story mode, but if you've played games from this particular developer you'd be able to jump straight into the fighting without having to know too much about dragonball.

Let me start off by saying, ive been looking forward to this game for quite a few months. Now that i finally have it, from first day of launch to now, ive been getting failure to initialize network errors, so i havent been able to get online at all. I looked to the community and come to find out im not the only one having these issues, and there is currently no solution at the moment.  Now i just got another patch and i have to reissue the code from the support page, except its not taking the code because the finish button is grayed out.  Ive payed way too much to have these kind of issues for this long. I cannot recommend this to anyone until they get there stuff together.

Ok, when i closed the game, i got a weird message saying i have an untrusted file or something named "C:\Windows\System32\lavasofttcpservice.dll".  So i did some searching online and apparently it was stopping someone else from playing a game a while back, long story short, someone on microsoft site recommended adwcleaner to get rid of it, i used it and turns out that the file was considered malware i believe.  It got rid of it and now everything seems to be working fine. I was able to get online for the very first time, so now ill finally get to experience what this game is all about. Hopefully this helps anyone else with similar issues. Changing my recommendation since the game itself is actually pretty good.. its just the support that is kind of bad.

This review coming from someone with very MINIMAL experience in the fighting genre. You can say, entry level.

The lastest fighting game I've played was Street Fighter X Tekken, and although I enjoyed it, I couldn't find myself investing much time into the game. SFxT just didn't hook it for me in the end so I never got out of the button mashing habit.

Now being a DBZ fan, I decided to give this one a shot after following it for awhile before release. The art style is fantastic and gives that DBZ feel when you're playing. Game offers a variety of modes such as Story, Arcade, Ranked Match, Arena, etc etc. If you haven't figured it out, this title is 2 player 3v3 with tagging mechanics.

You can play locally with a friend if you like, and set up private "Ring" matches in the lobby (the lobby being a hub in a sense) with certain conditions.

Though I haven't tried it, apparently you can even have 6 players in a match with each controlling a single character which is pretty cool.

As mentioned before, I'm very entry level when it comes to fighting games, but unlike SFxT...this game seems to just settle in just right for me. So I've invested time in "Practice" and various combo challenges that each character has. With further help from the community on the forums...I have to say, I'm actually pulling off some pretty cool combos and its almost becoming second nature to me already.

This game does have built in "auto" combos which I feel is nice for newer players like myself, though I noticed veterans of this genre to be completely against this mechanic. I'm glad its there as it helps players stay somewhat competitive if they are newer. In the mean time, they can work out disciplining themselves out of the habit as I have to pull off some pretty cool combos.

As mentioned, the game offers a variety of things to do, though I feel $60 is a bit high from what I've experienced. Unless you're a die hard fan of DBZ and love fighting games then you should consider it. Everyone else should wait for a sale, I'm feeling $40 is a better price for what the game currently offers.

There are "lootboxes" in the form of capsules which is straight from the anime. Every thing is cosmetic ranging from lobby characters to customization options for your card...like titles, backgrounds, frames, etc. Currency is Zeni, which again, isn't a surprise...to buy these capsules and I've been getting a fair amount rather easily playing Arcade.  It keeps you engaged and doesn't feel like a grind while your playing the game and/or sharpening your skills.

If you're new to the genre, I can say that this is a good title to get your feet wet and it seems others agree. Stay away from the keyboard and get a controller, I use a plug in play Xbox 360 controller. 

The title offers a JAP dub for those who prefer that over ENG dub for the voices. The characters sound and feel legit in terms of their personality, though for some reason Bulma feels a tad bit off for me, but its fine. Sometimes characters will reference the other in combat which is a nice little touch, though it could be better to make it feel more alive.

The stages are "destructible", but its rather limited, nothing too amazing honestly.

Overall, its a solid title for what it is. No doubt new characters will be added. In the mean time the current roster is good enough and will take time for players to master them, and see who synergizes with who and make a good team of 3.

Great game for both veteran and  casual newcomer fans alike of traditional 2D fighting games. The game has an inbuilt (but sadly cannot disable) [i] Auto-Combo [/i] function in which you need only to press one button to pull off advanced combos. However, the game still highly rewards players who utilise a regular combo by achieving higher DPS which encourages players to overcome this steep learning curve in order to improve and take on harder opponents.

The game also features a Ranked Mode where players can test their might against one another without holding back in order to determine their rightful rank and to see how high they can climb within the community. [b] Not a fan of serious competition? No problem. [/b] The game has plenty of Casual Matchmaking modes which allow even the greenest novices to be matched up with their rightful counterpart whilst still able to retain a fighting chance in order to provide an overall fun experience for players of all skill levels.

Unlike the Xenoverse franchise, the game is aimed more towards the mechanical/competitive gaming community whilst still managing to appeal to casual players (all them button mashers who like to spam one button) with the Auto-Combo function. Each character has their own unique moveset and mastering them requires patience, practice and skill and is highly rewarding and satisfying especially if you manage to pull it off right. Plus, the feeling of pulling off a Manual combo is so satisfying in comparison to just spamming one button for an Auto-Combo which can get pretty boring.

The story mode is unique and original featuring familiar characters (both old and new) and an all new character developed by the original creator of the Dragon Ball series himself: [i] Akira Toriyama. [/i]

[b] Keyboard controls are supported and are able to be rebinded, however A CONTROLLER IS HIGHLY RECOMMENDED as this makes it much easier to play the game and pull off more advanced combos. [/b]

My own personal experience and opinions:
- No problems so far in terms of PC optimisation and graphical bugs. Stunning visuals on max settings!
- Appeals to hardcore fans of the Dragon Ball series.
- Sadly, limited amount of lobbies per server. (Up to 64 per lobby, however there is a worldwide matchmaking option, although keep in mind if one person has bad connection, the game will purposely utilise a frame delay in order to ensure one player does not have an advantage over the other).
- I don't think $59.99 USD is a justifiable price range, maybe more of a $25-$30. I'd recommend  either waiting for a sale or buying only if you are truly a hardcore fan of Dragon Ball.

I'm going to jump straight into it: This is the most fun I've had with a fighting game since Marvel Vs Capcom 3. It's welcoming to new players and even if you don't want to play multiplayer there's actually quite a bit to keep you entertained, especially if you are a completionist or Dragonball fan. 

Now the categories

Story: This is probably the weakest aspect of the game. While the story itself is fun and explains how all of these fighters can fight at the same level (a la Injustice), and even the cinematics are fun, the execution kills it. For one, you have to hit a button to go to the next piece of dialogue majority of the time, but sometimes doing so will interrupt the action and you will miss what happened (to be fair you can kind of tell which scenes you should wait on, but still). The second bad thing is that the fights are just booooooooooooooooooooring. As in the enemy will basically just sit there while you pummel him. At first my goal was to defeat everyone on a given map, but eventually got so bored with the fights almost wished there was an autoresult button. 

Gameplay: Simple to learn, somewhat easy to become amatuer, and not even that difficult to master once you have some practice. I guess the best way to say it is simplicity with depth. 

Production Values: AMAZING. That's really all I can say. You have both the Japanese and English subs, flashy effects straight from the show, and sound that was basically ripped straight from the anime as well. Not to mention the fan service thrown in such as Krillin replacing Android 17 if he's on your team for 18's ultra, or Goku's legendary scene of first going super saiyan, or even Gohan's one-handed Kamehameha against Cell. All of which can happen organically and in regular matches. 

Summary: A good solid game that you don't have to be a DBZ or fighting game fan to enjoy.

Ignore the haters. Ignore the whiners for a moment.

There are NO issues with joystick support, it's literally a setting you have to turn on. That's it. Simple as that.

Black screen story mode? Change V-sync to on. Bam. Instant fix.

Online play? Lagless unless someone is using wifi as their source of internet connection...which is bad for gaming in general and fighting games in particular. NO fighting game should ever be played with wifi.


Now that we've dealt with 99.9% of whiners, let's get down to the gameplay.

Perfection. And I'm not talking about Cell. (Though he's P.frickin' good.) I'm talking response times. Hell, the game even tells you the delay rate for online matches at the top of the screen so you can know EXACTLY how many MS the delay is. That's massive for fans of fighting games. It might not seem like much for casual or less intensive players, but for people who want to REALLY enjoy a fighting game and dig into the mechanics, frames, and combos? That's kind of nice. It's a quality of life improvement that I didn't really know I loved THAT much until I play other games that don't have it now.

Secondly, The graphics. GOD. DAMN. This game is good looking. Every single attack is torn straight out of a manga or anime frame. It's sex to the eyes and if you're a virgin, welcome to the big boy club. Get your jacket at the door because your visual cherry is about to be virtually popped. (All assuming you arn't running a potato. If you've got anything REASONABLY new (IE: Made within the last 3 years, maybe even 5) you should have no issue maxing this baby out. I'm running a GTX 970 and everything is maxed, and I'm sitting at a perfect 60 at all times. 

Third on our list? Music. It's great too. I can't find a track I don't like, though some of them are a little more...cinematic than I'd like. Some of them feel more like they'd be at home during cutscenes, but It's still a pretty massive roster of soundtracks considering there's one unique song for every character as well as one for each stage. If you're a fan of the music from the anime however, I'd suggest buying the collectors edition to get the soundtrack when it releases, as it will be adding in songs from the anime itself (Cross your fingers for Perfect Cell's theme. Doo doo doo wawa da doo ‚ô´)

Fourth, Balance. F**k balance, this is dragon ball Z. Every single character is overpowered. Even Yamcha. Yamacha will wreck your SSGSS rear and then grin at you like he's just been playing the long game and is secretly the true god of distruction. Beerus bows to Yamcha. There's no power level nonsense in this game. Every character is created with the intention of all being tournament worthy and it shows. There's not a character here that just feels lacking or even really a joke character of any kind. It's a fresh breath when you can finally play who you WANT rather than who has the cannonically higher power level in the series. I'm looking at you, Tenkaichi series/Xenoverse.

I'm very critical of games. If you look at most of my reviews, there's very few games I give the pass to. But I can't find anything in Dragon Ball FighterZ to complain about. 

The story mode is...a fighting game story mode, but with an original story that feels like it COULD have been a side movie, much like the Revenge of Cooler / Bio Broly films.

The Arcade mode has an interesting mechanic of making the fights harder or easier depending on how well you do, so it pushes you to play better and better until you S rank all of them which admittedly can be a LITTLE daunting, as losing ANY one of your characters or being heavily damaged on two can result in lower rankings.

Local Vs works fine for what it is. And even has PRESET TOURNAMENT MODES. It's like it's BEGGING you to get off your butt and go make ACTUAL REAL LIFE FRIENDS. Like what's up with THAT?!

Practice mode allows for normal practice and a objective based game mode that allows you to learn the basics of the game and even some of the more advanced aspects. It's great to run through and doesn't feel contrived or like it's babysitting you. It's a training mode that RESPECTS you, instead of treating you like you've never held a controller in your hand before.

Oh and Did I mention there's HECKA UNLOCKABLES?!?!?!?!??!!? *NANI!?* 

Yeah, every fight earns you Zenni, every arcade mode cleared? MORE ZENNI. ZENNI FOR DAYS. DISREGARD FEMALES, AQUIRE ZENNI. It unlocks colors, lobby characters, titles, backing cards, and it's all randomized. 

"BULLCRAP" i hear you scream, slightly peeing yourself a little. 

AHA, But here's the thing. Get a duplicate of an item you've already got? Get a Z coin for that instead! It allows you to pick an item you want. So once you've already got to the point of where you've got most of the stuff in the game, it actually gets EASIER to get those last few things you want. It's magical and makes it feel like Zenni has a worth even hours and hours in. 

This game is fantastic. It's a shining example of what a fighting game should be and it's the #1 played fighting game on steam right now, better than SFV and Tekken 7 Combined MULTIPLE times over. With 44 thousand peak players, 30-ish thousand peak per 24 hours and usually 20 thousand players online at any given time, you'll never be hurting to find a game. The lobby system makes finding matches easy, and when you run into ragequitters, you can mark them so that you don't have to fight them anymore, even in ranked! So you can avoid the heartache of that nonsense in as simple as three button presses. 

This game is a 10/10. A perfect fighting game. There could have been so many issues with this game that plagued other fighting games. Low playerbase on PC was a worry for some people, but no. It's the most played fighting game on steam, period. 

If you're a fan of fighting games, Dragon Ball Z, Videogames, life, air, dragons, or people that are blonde...you need to buy this game. Buy it even if you don't like any of those things. Shut up. Do it.
i am not a fighting game fan but i love this game, it can be played as a simpy button masher but once you understand the timeing of the attacks you can pull off some amazing chains

But the Netcode is absolutely awful right now. On Day One, there weren't enough lobbies to go around, so you'd be waiting 10 minutes just to connect into a lobby to play the game. However you can create an offline lobby to access story mode and the such.

This would not be too much of a problem, if online matches weren't inexplicably laggy and connection drops constantly. I can't tell you the amount of times I've been in an arena match, having a fantastic time, then all of a sudden I get kicked from the lobby.

Very solid gameplay.  This game is very accessible for people who have never played a fighter, as well as having enough depth to keep fgc veterans interested.  I've never watched the show and have been pretty entertained by the story, but let's get into the actual mechanics.

One of the coolest things about this game is how it can introduce new players to fighting games by easing them into it.  All characters have "auto combos," meaning you can sit there mashing the same button over and over and over and do some cool, flashy combos.  At this point, any experienced fighting game player is saying to themselves, "that's stupid, I'll get bored."  But wait, there are combos for you too!  Anyone familiar with fighting games will find more difficult, higher damage, unique combos for each of the characters.  You've been playing fighting games for two decades?  Chances are you won't have much use for most of the auto combos and will opt to use the more difficult combos that provide an extra 20-50% more damage.  It's a great way to introduce new players to the game while maintaining a competitive aspect that experienced players will enjoy.  Overall you're not going to see the fighter diversity that you do in games like BlazBlue or Guilty Gear, but the characters are different enough to stay interesting, even if they're a bit homogenized.

The game is also incredibly entertaining to watch.  Very flashy, big moves, big combos, big finishes.  The animation is top notch.  Super moves feel huge and punishing, super finishes in particular look amazing.  There's also not a ton of clutter on the screen, so the action is fairly easy to follow most of the time.  Again, this could be a plus or a minus depending on how much you enjoy other anime fighters like BlazBlue that can fill the screen with a daunting amount of clutter that can be incredibly difficult to follow for the uninitiated.

A possible negative for fgc vets is that three characters are locked to start and require completing arcade challenges for two characters and the entire story mode for the third.  I haven't completed the story yet, but it appears to be very long.  So far I'm about 3.5 hours into it and it has marked my progress at 22%, but I am doing all of the fights and listening to all of the dialogue so if you want to power through it you can do it much quicker.  Still, it's a sizeable time investment for those who would prefer to just hop into practice mode with all of the characters and start nailing down their combos for the competitive scene.  Alternatively, it does give a sense of progression for more casual players.  I personally would have preferred having access to all of the characters from the start and having some cool cosmetic unlocks for completing the story mode.

Overall, I'd say if you're at all on the fence about this game, it's an incredibly solid game and you won't be disappointed.

A solidly built combination of two of my favourite things - ARC fighters and the Dragonball universe.

Graphics: A good match for the series, a little bit stuttery at points in the menus, but it looks and plays beautifully during a fight. The cel shaded anime look isn't for everyone (if Overwatch is too colourful  for you, you'll never enjoy this), but the aesthetics are true to the game, entertainingly flashy, and generally don't outstay the welcome in already chaotic fights.

Audio: SFX are on point, the VAs are amazing, and the music kicks ass. Nuff said. 

Storyline: ARC has a habit of sticking entire series into their games lately (what a surprise Xrd's story mode was to me...) but the cutscenes aren't over the top long, and you'll be spending most of your time fighting the AI. 
The plot is as you'd expect, involving a new character named Android 21, and is reasonably lengthy across multiple arcs.
I get most of my enjoyment from the characters and their interactions, rather than the storyline itself. The wonderful performance by the VAs just makes the experience more enjoyable as a whole, especially Frieza and Cell (ALL HAIL BRITANNIA)

Characters: You get a good selection of characters in the standard edition, spanning the spectrum across all the main DBZ arcs as well as one or three entrants from Super. I'm uncertain which 8 characters the DLC unlocks and frankly don't feel the need to pick it up yet - the current variety is still plenty for me.

Controls: Tight and easy to learn, with plenty of tutorial, training and practice options. For the most part the special moves are easy to perform, the mastery comes in chaining them together for super combos, learning when to block, recovery and all the small things that end up winning a fight. The 3v3 system is interesting and adds a nice tactical touch to the game, as well as giving you a small breather when each character goes down. The pace is quite fast once you hit the hard mode arcades or multiplayer, but most CPU fights will give you plenty of time to experiment and make mistakes.

Singleplayer: Multiple branching arcade modes with unlockable hard difficulty. A story mode with significantly more (entertaining) content, if not challenge, than your average Call of Duty single player campaign. Various challenges and practice modes, as well as offline matches against the CPU with scalable difficulty. 

Multiplayer: Blegh. I can occasionally get a match, but if like me you're living somewhere without a regional server: you're mostly screwed for multiplayer. Haven't yet managed to get into a single arena or ring match, casual and ranked world matches take easily 10-15 minutes to find. Good thing you're allowed to use the arcade mode during the wait.
I do have to say, however, that when I finally get into a match it goes well in terms of connection. No noticable frame drops or latency. 

In game economy: There's no premium currency here, just in game currencies. There are two types of currency, one is Zeni which you earn via fights, quests, story missions, combo challenges, and particularly the Arcade. The other are Premium Z Tokens, which you get for each duplicate item dropped. Items are dropped from loot capsules, and take the form of lobby characters, stamps (stickers), character colours and character card customisation.  There are currently no in game real money purchases, SSGSS DLC aside, and all of these cosmetic items can be earned in game. Although I suspect more DLC will be incoming at a relatively high price. Just sell the soundtrack and you got my money guys. Simple.

Overall: As a fan of both the principle draws of this game (a fun ARC fighter and a Dragonball game), 9/10 due to potential issues for multiplayer fans. However, as a newbie to this style of fighter, you may want to first pick up something like Guilty Gear or Skullgirls before spending full price on this, just to test the waters.

While generally an excelent game, there are a few critical flaws that make this game hard to recommend at full price or before they are fixed.

Dragon Ball FIght Z is a great entry level game that has a deeper game play element for those that want it.  

This has been a great game to introduce 2D fighting games to my kids (9-11) since it can be visually stunning and exciting even when you are just mashing buttons.  The inputs are all easy to do, as well as a basic combo structure that transfers to most all the characters.  Once you get beyond mashing auto combos theres is a more complex system here of counters and combos.  I don't personally feel that it will ever have the technical demands that SFV or Tekken have, but I don't think it needs.

There is some design choices made around match making that I am not fond of, but it does work and I have had little trouble with getting matches.  I do hope that they make the system a little more streamlined in the future

Verdict: Great game for casual beat-em up action.
10/10 will play again

One of the best fighting games to date. Easy to get into, hard to master. At launch, they had a server problem. There was not enough lobbies for all the players. So you had to wait until you could get in. Unlike other games of the genre, this one has a story and an arcade mode along side other modes like 3v3, where each person picks a character and team, then fight together. All in all, a very good time for those who love dragonball and fighting games. Also a very good game to bust out at parties. Expect people to be in the lab for a long time before seeing some high level play.

-This review comes from a very casual DBZ and fighting games fan-

TLDR at bottom

THIS GAME IS DOPE
You ever think about a perfect game in your head and think it'll never happen because its to perfect? Yeah, this was that game for me. All the older DBZ games like Tenkiachi or Bodukai were good but WOO they can't lick this games toe. Firstly, the presentation OH BOY the presentation. The game looks ripped straight outta the anime. The art style is cell shaded, very similarly to the Naruto ninja storm games, and looks amazing. The particle effects look great, the impact from hits look great, the stages look great, THIS GAME LOOKS GREAT. The gameplay is very begginner friendly, but has much deeper layers under the surface for pros. It has a tag team mechanic very similar to Marvel Vs. Capcom 3. where you fight with 3 different characters swapping them out and calling them in for assists. They added possibly the smartest mechanic in a fighting game since combos, the chase mechanic. If RT is pressed (At least on xbone controller) You will do a dash straight to your opponent and can start attacking immediantly. This seems pretty simple but OH MAN this simple addition helps keep the high paced action DBZ is known for. The attack system uses a light, medium, and heavy punch system like most fighting games, and for control stick motions, if you can do a hadoken in Street Fighter, thats all you need. Just a quarter circle motion along with the button for the attack you want to use. The last face button activates a special attack, and if paired with a quarter circle motion you can use a signature move of the charcter (like kamehameha for Goku) which can be used to extend combos. If pairing a quarter circle motion with RB (again on xbone controller) you can launch a super move that does large damage, and can be paired with your teamates supers, but uses two ki meters. The Ki meter is charged up by taking or dishing out damage, or holding X and A (xbone). By pressing Y and B (xbone) you can do a suprise attack behind your opponent which is great for catching them off gaurd. And that only scratches the surface of the combat. Aight, lets look at some negatives. The game currently has a story mode, practice mode, arcade mode, ring matches with people in your lobby, and worldwide online matches (ranked and casual). And, thats it. (Currently) its kinda lacking in content. And the online conectivity is sorta unreliable at the moment (not bad, just shoddy) but that is probably becuase the servers are getting slammed with players at the moment, since as i write this, we are still in the launch window of the game. Thats it. Two cons that'll probably be ironed out soon. The game might not be worth $60 bucks at the moment, but xenoverse 2 is also 60, and this game craps on xenoverse, so take that for what you will.

TLDR- The game looks great, plays great, but slightly lacks in content at the moment, and the servers are shoddy at the moment, although that will probably be fixed soon.

Overall, this game is great, and worth your money for sure, in the state it is in now, I wouldn't say pay $60 for it unless you're REALLY HYPED like I was, its probably worth around $35-$45 dollars with the amount of content it has now. I have been very impressed by this game, and it blew my already high expectations out of the water.

The game is a simplistic take on the versus formula, but all it does, it does it excellently, my only complain is how the story mode is played, it really makes it slower and more tedious than what it should be, although the story itself makes up for it, the netcode is amazing, as long as the other player doesn't live in the middle of the woods, you're gonna find a pretty consistent connection, with barely any lag spikes, overall it's an amazing game 

9/10, would get my ass kicked again

Pros: Good gameplay mechanics and very interesting cooperative modes. You have the standard "swap" teams and one on one matches - but your team mates have to wait to be tagged in. It's pretty cool. 

Cons: Probabably the worst UI I've ever seen. You have to actually go into a server to get to a local combat match with a second player. Seriously. And it's not even a menu. There's this dumbass little town thing you have to walk through to find the right "menu" that's like finding the right shop keeper. And probably one of the worst cases of consolitis I've ever seen. You can't even get into the video options menu from most of the screens. I'd almost want a refund just for how bad the UI is. Unfortunately I overran the time for that...

Tip: DO NOT BUY WITHOUT OWNING A CONTROLLER - seriously... the main menu has you navigate using wasd as arrow keys... you can't even use the mouse... wtf...

Reflexes I no longer possess. Yes, I do understand that is an excuse and implies that I - the faceless voice on the internet - do anything more than reside indoors and play games, but you try to live with a tumor in your wrist that causes digital numbness and see where that getes you in a fighting game on a casual level.

I was led to expect, as some might have been, that this game would be a touch more complex than it is. Such is to say, more involved and by chance predictable combinations of attacks. The removal of differentiated punches and kicks compared to other fighting games is unwelcome for me, on the given that it is now very difficult - to a point where it destroys the fun of the game - to detect what block will apply and where. There are the obvious telegraphed attacks, but then there are the small combo-builders that I would previously have expected to have been blocked in other games of similar genre. This may not be a problem for some, but it is a problem for me.

This goes gently hand in hand with another issue I came to notice with controlling the game. Between my original Xbox One controller and the Pro/Elite/whatever variant (the one with the extra buttons on the back if you want them and such and palm grips), the game seems to have difficulties registering D-Pad input for me. The super-special-pro-woohoo version has a better switch as far as I'm concerned for the D-Pad, but still had the saem amount of success that the Xbox One regular-lameo-wimpy-boi version. Which is to say, about 60% of the time I would not fire off my super attack unless I was spamming the hell out of it, and then sometimes it would do the wrong one because it registered it going the wrong way. Inversely, I had roughly a 70% success rate with the actual control stick paddle, even if in my throes of Dragon Ball-ing I did lose one. They're magnetic and can be interchanged, what did you expect?

Frankly, this game might be nice with a fight-stick with all those fancy controller customizations that make them good for fighting games. But that's a big ol' chunk of change right there.

Fighting games are all about reading what will happen next. My matches thus far have been nothing but waiting for the other person to be impatient enough to instigate, and be heavily punished for it. If someone has spent a grand portion of their time in recent months learning and practicing the game at their every convenience, good on them, and perhaps they have a mote of skill that will carry on to perservere through what I have not been able to.

I suppose now is as opportune too say as any: I am not calling the game bad, nor do I think it is bad. I simply do not like how it plays and frankly somewhat regret my large purchase on it, having gotten the best edition while the game now rests uninstalled from my computer to spare me from temptation of upsetting myself with my own shortcomings.

My lasting complaints forever will ride upon the matchmaking system in the game. I will pardon that it's very soon after launch, but I will not pardon that I - while on a losing streak, and having not won a game out of my matches for a good fifteen minutes (in-fight time, not lobby time), and being pitted against someone who is either smurfing (somehow) or otherwise has won all of their games (or is on an 80%+ win rate) is unacceptable. When I am trying to pit myself against some onf "similar skill," I expect similar skill, not "they haven't put all their time into the ranked mode yet, but they're exceedingly knowledgable for what their combos and links are." Unacceptable.

The other - yeah, more bitching, I said "complaints," and I have to point this out - is that the MvC style switching of characters seemed janky at best. This is a consensus generally found within my circle of fighting game friends, each of which are rather big fans of the MvC series. The quick-switch would work here and there, and the deflect-switch would as well, but there's a repeated case of "it isn't as responsive as it should be." I've lost one of my three more times than I care to think because my switch-out didn't trigger. Naturally I hear the cries of "switch while on the offensive," but when you're in the middle of someone's infinitely chained combo because they have the reflexes of a fighter pilot, there's not much "offensive" going on, unless you mean offensive to your own self as some sort of self-deprecative thing.

Overall, if you understand the game, awesome, have fun. Enjoy yourself. Please, because I think the game is wonderful for what it is and I just can't get behind that. I'm far more acquainted with the Budokai and Budokai Tenkaichi games and their style of play, which I recognize is horribly flawed to begin with but was just as fun.

I'm some know-nothing on the internet, so no rating system. I hope that my gripes turn out to be just me being bad, but genuinely I think there needs to be some changes to how it functions before I'll be able to enjoy the $140+ CDN I spent on it.

Most people playing this game will be familiar with the source material, and most likely grew up with and/or has seen a lot of Dragon Ball. As someone who has never seen the show, outside of clips on the internet, I can safely say that the game is still very enjoyable even if you haven't seen a single episode of Dragon Ball. The game is very careful in including expositional dialogue to help fill in the newbies to who the characters are and what their relations are, and the main plot doesn't really require a major understanding of the show to follow along, although it greatly helps. Story aside, the game itself is a lot of fun and really well made. Arc System Works, the guys behind BlazBlue, did a great job creating an awesome and entertaining fighting game, and the visuals, made to feel like an episode from the show more like a 3D interpretation, are stunning. It feels like an Arc game, although things are simplified this time around, so it's good for beginners too. I'm not too far in the story at this point, but I do want to point out that a negative is it can get a bit repetative in the main quest. A lot of fighting the same clone enemies as filler between story pivots, and it feels more like grinding for EXP than saving the world. You can skip some battles and go straight to bosses, but you'll be at a disadvantage. Not that it matters, as the AI isn't very smart. If you don't move, it won't do much, and it's easy to corner and doesn't react well. I hope it gets harder after the hero arc. 

Lastly, and a huge complaint, is how ridiculous the lobby system is. Many people will tell you it sucks, and it does. It's not well designed, and isn't very stable. I kept getting kicked out the lobbies at first, and struggled to make it to the story mode. Once you leave the lobby, the game gets much better, but it makes a terrible first impression.

I hate numbering things, but I'd give the game an 8.5/10. It's not the most intuitive fighting game I've ever played, but it's fun enough to have me hooked for now. Worth the $60. Can't say if the FighterZ pass is worth it as i don't have it, but if you like the game and want more content, go for it.

If you played Ultimate Battle 22 on the PS1 as a kiddo until your thumbs and palms had collases trying your hardest to figure out the combos to do the craziest shit you could because the little game manual only had a few of the special moves. This game will be the breath of fresh air you've waited for for so long. Fantastic combat, not too technically difficult to learn like most other fighting game titles,  a few hours of practice in battle training can get you semi good with any given character that you enjoy, best tag team system I've ever seen as I'm not a huge fan of tag team, but I love DBZ so I had to give it a try and if you're like I was and on the fence about the tagging in and out bit, don't worry it is incredibly well optimized into the game with amazing synergies between your team as you perform combos even with super attacks. This is the first fighting game I personally have played in a long time that has completely swept me off my feet (Literally lol) The lobby system is okay, it could definitely be better, however there are so many different ways to fight another person nobody should really complain as you'll always find an opponent one way or another via Arena/Ring/Ranked/Casual etc. The loot box system is cool, no microtransactions yet, but I could see them implenting that eventually with the premium Hercule coins, however the loot is strictly cosmetics: Lobby Avatars/Titles/Headers/ Stamps nothing to boost you in battle or any of that nonsense. all in all its fantastic and you can clearly see the love the creators put into making it. HIGHLY recommend for any DBZ fan, if you're thinking about it, just buy it you won't regret.

I had to refund this game for two huge reasons

1) Can't play a game with my friend due to full lobbies and this weird overworld system, me and him tried to 'find' each other for about a hour, joning and re-joining servers.

2) It's a $60 dollar game with day-one DLC. This is big enough reason to not buy ANY game with this sort of business model regardless of how fun or great it is.

I'll repurchase the game once the steam invite a friend feature is implemented.

As it stands, I cannot click on a friend and invite or join via the steam interface. As @Lauchlan says, playing with friends is possible, though I haven't been able to figure it out (maybe i'm stupid or just trolling?) it's incredibly obfuscated.

Right, you're probably going to see a lot of positive reviews about this game floating around. That's because the game works for them. Great! Happy it works for you. At the time of this review I have about 4 hours of gameplay put into this. You're probably going to say "don't say anything if you haven't played it yet!" But I have played it. Well, at least I've tried playing it. For four hours, I have been troubleshooting this game trying to get the online to work. I have played a total of 2 Online matches. That's roughly 10 minutes of gameplay. I'm going to say it now, and depending on how the situation changes, I might change my opinion: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

I'll begin with the positives, because that's only appropriate for the effort put into making this game. it's gorgeous. Initally I thought it looked gimmicky after watching trailers and gameplay, but after playing it, it feels amazing! It plays really well and despite an easy combo system there's some levels of depth to execution. It's really really fun. And for those hardcore DBZ fans, I can't imagine this game disappointing. It's even prettier than GuiltyGear and Blazblue which are themselves absolutely beautiful. Execution feels great and you generally have a good idea of what you're doing as you're playing, and you're not hindered by lag very often. 

The story is really interesting and the characters you can play are some of the most popular loved characters so that's a real bonus. When the game works, playing with friends and strangers is fantastic. The experience is somewhat undescribable. It's easy enough that new players to fighting games are welcome in warmly. It's casual enough that it keeps you hooked to winning enough. It appears as if it's competitive in its gameplay such that there's depth to the combat system as well - though I'm definitely not at that level to start talking.

Right that's it, pros over. The cons will be addressed now, and boy are they some bad cons. Arcsys has had some serious trouble with online multiplayer in its previous games. Blazblue and GuiltyGear are riddled with issues and required me to either open my router to DMZ or use a VPN to play online. At least I could play online. I've tried everything from different regions, to VPN, to opening ports to make this game work. No dice. This game has JUST launched and already a sizeable portion of consumers are unable to play the game. A humorous thought popped into my mind last night. I remembered No Man's Sky and everyone asking where multiplayer was. That's exactly what I was asking when I was playing this game last night. Where's multiplayer Bandai Namco? Arcsys? Where is it?

There's 4 things that stand out at launch that have made this game somewhat unbearable.

1) A permanent lobby mode, where you're forced into chibi form to run around and figure out where you're going instead of using a good old menu. Why the social aspect? There's literally no reason to not use a menu. 

2) Connecting with friends. You CANNOT invite friends to any game or lobby. You need to coordinate with your friend, find the same room, in the same region, find each other in the little hub lobby they have, open a ring and pray to GOD it works. That leads on to the next point.

3) IT DOESN'T WORK. I'm super happy (seriously, not ironically) that this game works fantastically for many people. But also for many people they often find this error - "Cannot join because room is full" or "No rooms found". After trying to connect with a friend for an hour we just gave up and moved to Skullgirls because that works. When A 7 quid game outperforms a 60 quid game. I cannot express my disappointment when I could not find games. Alright, so maybe private matches don't work, how about ranked or casual matches? Surely those must work, after all that's the meat of the game!

4) IT DOES NOT WORK NICE TRY. Enjoy waiting 10 minutes for a game. I'm more than certain it's not the population that's lacking. Almost every server is filled. There MUST be at least ONE person who's matching at the same time. Turns out, it's apparent that there's no one! Sorry! Enjoy the single player fighting game!

I'm probably not going to bother playing this game until a patch comes out. I'll be able to provide a significantly more in depth review once I get to play >2 matches. As it stands, it is completely unplayable. I can't connect with my friend, who was the sole reason I bothered to buy the game at all. At this point, it seriously feels like you should just NOT buy the game and wait for a patch and/or buy it on sale. The worst part is, having tried EVERYTHING, I can't tell if it's the game's problem or my problem. Every other fighting game works online for me. Tekken, GuiltyGear, Street Fighter. You name it, it WORKS. it doesn't work for this game though. What's the problem Arcsys, Bandai? Please illuminate me.

I am not a very big fan of fighter games, but I do enjoy them every now and then. This game seems like a great fighter game that is easy to access, and has enough enough complexity behind it to keep you engaged. There are things like auto combos where you mash a button, but the real damage and flash is hidden behind combos that require practice and timing.

As for the Dragon Ball aspect to the game it is very nice to see the characters have amazing animations, voice work, and the game itself really does justice to the material. The characters portray their material counterparts very well, and the moves you know and love are here and ready for your use.

The game does have some bugs, but they aren't very important besides being annoying. The game will show you xbox prompts even when using a keyboard is an example. At least the combo challenge has an annoying "bug" where if you complete a challenge you aren't allowed to use the "reset challenge" button until you reselect the challenge you are already on. It could use some quality of life fixes is the main point here.

The online lobbies seem to be much better than the terrible mess that it was on launch. Back at launch I couldn't even get online due to the way it was setup. Now it seems to log me into a lobby as soon as I boot up the game without having to spam the option to join.

Overall I am enjoying the game even with the frustration of trying to perfect combo timing and train my hands to perform on a keyboard (the steam controller proved difficult to get any kind of consistency). I think this is a great game for fans of Dragon Ball that are willing to put in the work to get good at fighting games.

If you plan on getting through the game with just the simpler auto combos, then you would probably be better off waiting for a sale. It is overpriced to not want to make full use of the end game, which would be the online multiplayer. You could play online at any time, but it can be brutal against seasoned fighter game players.
Gameplay is smooth with a great character selection! Love the Story as well. 10 out of 10 would buy again.  xD

[b] I am posting this almost immediately after beating the last arc of the story mode [/b]
[h1] Pros [/h1]
I reccomend this game to both fighting game fans and dragon ball fans. 
For fighting game fans this is a good game to learn combos on your own, with the fighting as a team of 3 mechanic can lead to many different, interesting combos.
For Dragon Ball fans the story mode is very entertaining because of the variety of interactions that the characters have, although there is not a large array of characters, compared to games like Xenoverse 2.
The art style is gorgeous and very true to how the characters are portrayed in the anime.
[h1] Cons [/h1]
My main complain thus far is the gameplay of the story mode.
The story mode is divided into 3 different segments, and 2 of the three are tolerable, where you can grind levels if you feel like it. Although in the thrid segment, you a limited to two characters and forced to grind throughout 2/3 of the segment, which was aggravating to say the least.
The cutscene animation is also mediocre, but understandably so since this is a 2.5D fighting game, not a cinematic adventure.
[h1] Overall [/h1]
Solid 9/10, story is longer than expected for a fighting game, polished, story gameplay is weakest point

Really great game if you like the series.  I'm not a hardcore fighting game player so I cant really say how it stacks up to others but as far as im concerned its really fun.  It reminds me of the old SNES DBZ fighting games like Hyper Dimensions only WAY modernized.  The combos and the look of the game is really cool, almost like your watching an episode.
The bad in this game is pretty aweful in my opinion.  The cut scenes while looking like an episode of the show are visually pleasing, the need to hit a button to progress the cutscene after every sentence is just totally immersion breaking.  I would like to just sit back and watch the entire cut scene unfold rather than hit A after every line.  Otherwise you leave the characters in limbo waiting for you.  Another minor gripe is the need to switch to english from Japanese everytime you load up the game.  Not game breaking just bothersome that i cant make a change and it stick.  Itd be like having to change the resolution everytime you booted up.  The only other complaint is the servers!!  Prepare to try and try again in order to get into a server.  I hope that they can fix this soon as im not even bothering with online play until thats better.

Best game ever

ArcSys has somehow managed to make a fighting game that is simultaneously very accessable and still incredibly deep. I hardly ever play fighting games, largely because the barrier to entry is gigantic and tutorials are oftentimes very dense and unintuitive (seriously, a beginner's guide should not use abbreviations like j.131, SJC, and OTG, because a beginner will probably have no idea what the hell they're saying). FighterZ solves this by being very easy to pick up and play, with simple combos that let you at least fight straight away, while having a tremoundous amount of depth and playability under the surface. The graphical design and sound design is top notch too, just like the 3D Guilty Gears. Very reccomended, for complete neophytes and serious fighting game fans alike.

If you have read some other comments then you should know. The 8 DLC characters aren't out yet tho will be added. From that you also get and i quote "those new fighters also come with their respective stamp, set of alternative colors and Lobby Avatars." if you still don't get that part. It basically means you get those 8 characters playable AND as lobby avatars and ALTERNATIVE COLORS: Not to mention (maybe more then one) their stamp. If you are looking through the DLC's without having the game and thinking "What is a stamp used for?" well their used for in game chat as PICTURES that you can have fun with. You can also set a presetted message made by the game to a stamp for your choosing. If you ask me this is highly worth it for the main reason its 8 new characters, 8 new lobby avatars for a respective price, alt colors plus some stamps. Also the other DLC's is worth it if you ask me tho thats my opinion.

The other DLC's says themselves and explain on their own of what they give. Their will be more DLC's the game is new and i do hope there will be more. (at the time i am writing this that is)

One more thing before i end it. I know it is long so bare with me here. The game is HIGHLY based on skill and not characters. If you are really good you can make a a character like yamcha look like goku is nothing but an ant. So if you are a player that likes highly skill based games this is a game for you. Tho it is unique and very easy to grasp the controls of the game.

Also if you buy the game i recommend playing the practice mode before anything. Take your time there since it can actually help.

Hope this was helpful and if you bought the game have fun!

Fantasticly fun fighter that captures the look and feel of Dragonball. My favorite fighting game in the series since the SNES' Hyper Dimension. Once this problem is resolved I don't think I'll have a single issue with the game however. Ok, so after almost 22 hours over the span of 3 days, completing the story, unlocking all 3 extra characters, and playing a few matches online, this is what I have to say.

This may be the best fighting game you can buy on Steam right now, whether you be a newcomer to the FGC or a hardened veteran from games like Blazblue and Guilty Gear.

PROS:
-Easy to learn mechanics for those new to the genre
-Autocombos sacrifice damage for convenience, letting the player decide their playstyle
-The art is simply to die for, I mean look at this! A fighting game hasnt looked this good since Guilty Gear Xrd Revelator!
-An all star cast of characters from both Super and Z, with a few exceptions (I need me my movie characters and Gogeta!)
-THE SOUNDTRACK MAKES MY EARS NUT
-3v3 fighting a la Marvel and Skullgirls, with convenient ways to swap on the fly and neat assists.
-OH MY GOD THESE SPECIAL MOVES LOOK FRIGGIN AMAZING
-There are so many little easter eggs with the Dramatic Finishes (Yamcha's Revenge, the Trunks and Frieza scene)
-Lively community (as of writing this on 1/28/18) willing to teach and spar.

CONS
-Yeahhhhhh the online matchmaking kinda sucks
-Xenoverse noobs get salty, which won't be a problem in a few months
-Why do we have to join a massive online lobby to even play single player content? Menus work too you know.

Price Value: Amazing. I go off of a $2 per hour scale, and with 3 days on and already 21.2 hours as of writing this, I can see that this game will well exceed its value (even with the season pass added on!)

Score: 9/10

An excellent, but different kind of fighter.

The good: Amazing graphics, you will feel like you're in control of your favorite dbz character. Large roster feautring pretty much every character you would want to play (and some you don't). 

What sets DBZ apart is the frenetic pace of the combat along with the reduction in difficulty. Unlike other fighters (SF, GG) once you get "caught" in a combo, it's almost impossible to defend or escape. Since every character has single button strings, combos are incredibly easy to execute, so this tilts everything toward hyper agression. The Dragon Rush ability allows you to stick to your opponent so infinite loops are possible for some characters. This can make the game incredibly frustrating if you button spam. 

The balance between characters is decent (even Yamcha is viable (but you still won't use him)), but expect to see Black Goku and SSGSSs in almost every online match. If you're looking for Street Fighter in a DBZ skin, this isn't it. You won't get footsies or have high low strings to break guards. What you will get is a nuanced fighter with your favorite dbz characters.

If you are anything like me, then you just want a good Dragon Ball fighting game (without being a hybrid of something else...again). Well, this is it!
The game runs much better than I think even the devs realize (my specs are below minimum requirements but I get 60fps on max settings with a 670mx). Every character feels unique and every input feels smooth. The story starts out REALLY stupid but eventually gets the wheels rolling and starts feeling like a real DB arc, but without filler. The voice actors gave it their all as well, especially the new VA for Freeza, and 21's VA being in a new role. Everyone gets really in to their characters and it shows.
The controls are friendly for all types of players. Combo setups can be simple and executed decently easily, but there are still mixups that require more skill.
The combat feels great. Every input feels right, the sounds are all clear and match up perfectly, and pretty much all the moves are taken straight out of the anime. Clashing against an opponent who is hitting the same buttons as you is just awesome.

Some people say their stick isn't working, but I guess it depends on the stick compatability. Mine is a Qanba Q1 so it works great no matter the game. I don't think the game is worth 80 bucks, but there hasn't been a game yet that I think is worth that much. This is one of the few fighting games I think 60 bucks at least is worth it.
I highly recommend this to anyone who likes fighting games, and anyone who likes Dragon Ball. At least give it a shot at a friends house or something.

This game is really good....especially so if you are a DBZ fan.

The action is fast and furious, and runs as smooth as butter with no frame loss. The control scheme is simple enough for new players to pick up and play with, but deep enough for competitive players to really enjoy. Easy to play, hard to master.

They paid a lot of attention to the details, too. There are lots of cool chracter-specific interactions and one-liners that happen even in the middle of a fight that fans will really enjoy.

Characters all seem balanced so far, with no clear "must picks". It's really cool to be able to finally pick some of your favorite characters from the DBZ franchise, and have them be viable. Yamcha is totally on par with Goku Blue. It may sound off to fans of the lore, but they pull it off REALLY well. The 3-person team mechanic is also a lot of fun, with assists and swap outs similar to the Marvel vs Capcom series.

The multiplayer lobby set up is pretty neat, and handles a lot smoother than past iterations, like Xenoverse 2. It's not as large or complex, and I think that is what makes it work better. You can get into games VERY quickly, and have your choice of a lot of different options -There are different types of ring battles, which include you teaming up with 2 other players to fight another player team of 3, there are Arena battles which are kind of like a bear pit scenario, where a bunch of players are all in one place just fighting one opponent after another, and there is your standard ranked and casual play. 

The one downside of the multiplayer I feel I must note, is that on launch day, there were not enough servers. Even though there were a TON (that you can actually see in-game) they were all still filling up really fast. I give them some slack on that though....no one expected the game to be as big as it is, and I'm sure it will get cleared up. Even on day 1 I could get into lobbies within minutes, and since then it hasn't been an issue.

Single player options include a story mode that has a decent enough story and cutscenes, as well as a traditional arcade mode that sees you battling up a ladder. You can also play local multiplayer with a friend - I have tested this out a few times personally, and it runs as smooth as the rest of the game.

I highly recommend this game to any fighting game fans, or fans of DBZ.

Honestly, this is a wonderful game. Right now, I can not give it a thumbs down at all. I am still playing through the story and I must say I am quite impressed. So visually, this game steps up a little from Guilty Gear Xrd. Visually stunning. The sounds sound exactly like the show and the animations. Astounding. The combos are a little more simplified from Guilty Gear however, it still feels like the depth is there especially because of the tag in and tag out system with your allies. It is fun to find combos and try and replicate them with the best of  my trash abilities. I was honestly scared of the auto-combo system, but I'm glad to know that I was worrying for no reason. They translate well into this game and there are pros and cons of using the.

Characters are generally varied with some exceptions. There are characters that feel different and require a bit of different gameplay. Your teams is kind of like a mix match game of who do you want together depending on how they feel to you. They need to fit your style of play, and I find that fun.

Sadly, I have not gone into multiplayer yet. I have actually been too intrigued into the story (which was very surprising). I will be soon though, so I will be able to verify if Arcsys fixed the whole matchmaking system. The game has been getting quite a few updates (according to steamDB), so I am hoping it works.

Perhaps this will be updated, but most likely won't be unless asked or if I need to change it to a thumbs down (former much more likely than the latter)

Are you having resolution problems? Unable to change resolutions in full-screen?
Be sure to have Nvidia Control Panel installed, or the AMD equivalant!
Graphics stuttering or getting less than perfect performance without a cause? Be sure to have your device use your GPU, not your onboard graphics. (Some systems tend to default to onboard, for whatever reason)

For the best quality of graphics, turn resolution scaling to "200" with all other options set at medium.
Slowly increase the other options with anti-alising last to find your device's 'sweet-spot' in both performace and quality.

Using a controller? Be sure to use Big Picture mode!

The game is gorgeous, smooth and the combo system is quite enjoyable; the music adds depth and immersion.
Super attacks are fluid, and the satisfaction from a victory urges you onwards to continue!

While the movelist is limited, its the interaction, timing and using the other 2 characters makes it so there is a clear difference between people that like to try and spam basic combo's and block... and people who have the experience to know what they are doing (Spoiler.. meaning, not me)
It is not to difficult to come into and is decently noob-friendly but the mastering part can take up a while to say the least.
Unlike some other fighting games i did not like, this game at least does not have "well, this person played way to much and even though i am full health, because he hit me once.. i will be stunlocked 24/7 from now on and lose" ... there are alot more ways to avoid/get out of combo's which imo is a bit more fair.
Even though i am bad at the game, i still really enjoy it.

[b] Matchmaking 3/5 [/b]
As with any game starting off, the matchmaking is not to amazing.
However as said ... matchmaking is a thing that requires playerdata to improve, meaning there is 0 chance of matchmaking working well at release of any game.
Still need to give a point so gonna give it a "fine" because it hasnt been that bad.

[h1] Story 7/10 [/h1]
Story is decent. Some of the cutscenes are quite funny. Storymode itself is.. well.. it is what it is, not great, not bad either. It has fights, a gridbased system that makes you choose between becoming stronger by doing more fights/gathering more buffs (but also find more annoying enemies) or going through the story faster. Its fights.. and cutscenes ;D
Still decent enough for a fighting game.

[h1] Characters 7.5/10 [/h1]
Existing out of:

[b] Differences 4/5 [/b]
Roster is not to bad. A decent amount of characters to pick but most important.. do they feel different? Yes. Yes they do.
And thats what i am giving this game points for, for making characters that dont all feel like youre throwing out the same punches. All characters seem to have their prefered combo's, prefered gameplay and prefered teamcombinations.

[b] Character/Profile customisation 3.5/5 [/b]
Well. A few character cloth colors. Decent amount of lobby characters with colors/effects and enough profile card customisation.
As long as they dont add flashy unnessecary cosmetics into the fight itself, it works.

[h1]Technical aspects [/h1]
Not gonna grade this as this envelops way to many different configurations, setup and knowledge-differences per person.
Yes, there are error messages. Yes, those can be solved.
Can developers expect people to fix their own stuff? Yes and no. Yes as in.. they should. No as in ... people prefer to refund before trying nowadays. Players seem to think that PC's are like consoles as in, no technical knowledge required. Paying for stuff seems  to leave a bigger entitlement imprint than it sued to for sure.

Hereby my list of things i went through to get rid of all error messages for myself (havent had one since)
- Clean install of latest GPU update
- Exception of the Dragon Ball FighterZ folder in all anti-virus
- Use of controller on wire instead of through bluetooth (game had problems with the bluetooth driver)
- Running the game through big picture and on full-screen mode]
- Some people have also said there should be an U4Engine exe for requirementinstallations that you can run again to make sure all software is correctly installed

Can it solve disconnect errors? Not really nope. Can't say ive seen any disconnect messages in UK and Germany regions but i might be lucky and/or it might happen in other regions.

[h1] Total 7.5/10 [/h1]

Far from as bad as some people make it out, but still some stuff to improve through upcoming patches and/or dlc to.
Nonetheless in my eyes still better than most fighting games out right now.

menu system is an absolute mess. cant just play with firends online, have to join the right server and all. whats wrong with a good old fashioned text menu rather than this lobby stuff. other than that its real fun.

Honestly, one of the best fighting games I've played in quite some time. If you are coming into this expecting it to be like Mortal Kombat or Injustice 2, you'll be wrong. It has a more Marvel vs. Capcom 2 feel to it.

FighterZ is extremely easy to get into. The tutorials tell you how to do basic combos which still make you look badass while doing it. It's combat is beautiful, fluid, and is quite snazzy looking when you're able to combo a character chain right into an ultimate.

The story is an original story, not a rehash of you going through all the arcs through Dragonball Z and Super. They've even gone so far as to add a new character named Android 21 who is a Majiin android. Her creation was supervised by Akira Toriyama himself. She has quite a unique playstyle and is a great addition

My only gripe with the game is the Arcade. I hate artificial difficulty in games, and the arcade is a pretty good example of such. Hard modes of the arcade instead boost up the NPC difficulty rather than have them do some amazing combos. If one character is able to do one basic heavy combo, you lose half your health.

The lobby system is qutie annoying as well. It's hard to get into the same lobby with your friends to play against them, since you have to be in the same lobby to play with them. I wish they would add just a normal private match system so you are able to invite your friends rather than deal with the hassle of getting into the limited lobbys with only 64 player max slots. Quite annoying

All in all, this is definitely a pickup. If you love fighting games and love Dragonball, this is well worth the $60 pricetag.
Its basically MVC2 and 3 with DB characters. Really fun. This is what MVCI should have been.

This COULD be one of the best Dragon Ball fighting game.
But.. The always online mechanics are painfully bad, because of the poor server performances. Yes, you must be connected to the "lobby" even if you are playing practice matches against the CPU, or playing the story mode.

PROs:
Graphics are nice
Finally a "2d" Fighter

CONs:
Outrageous console port (Xbox controller buttons everywhere.)
Clunky tutorial (7 out of 10 times you do what it said and the game does not recognize the action done, despite the fact that your fighter did what the tutorial ask)
ALWAYS ONLINE WITH THE POOREST SERVER INFRASTRUCTURE EVER
I always got disconnected from the lobby match by match, so a 30min session usually contains 15 min waiting for "locating region, connecting to lobby". And I have a stable, gigabit cable connection.
The game does not save your settings (You switch the audio to english, next time you launch the game, it's on japanese again).

I hope they fix these, because right now the game is really annoying, and not because of the gameplay itself, but the clunky menu and servers.

Just don't buy it right now, wait for them to fix these issues.

I am going to address the few "No" vote reviews on here, first off they have been adding more lobbies to each region. Second after they did so I took a stab at Ranked matching (getting into a lobby is much easier than launch day with the extra lobbies) and ranked matches pop up very fast now on launch they were terrible.

It's not all unicorns and rainbows but in such a short time it has come a long way, the PC community is huge, growing and with it their ki and hunger for battle.

If you have any questions about the current state of the game, please reach out to me and I'll answer each one honestly.

:)

They did a great job with this game, I've never found a fighting game that is entry level friendly as well as complex enough to be viable for the competitive scene. They better not make this game a 1 off. They really fucked up by not allowing you to chat in lobbies like you could in GG Xrd. Can you imagine the staying power of the community for this game if you could chat again? A curse word filter and blocking feature would make it perfect. Because of this and the fact that I've sat in the arena with EIGHT other people stretching for 5 minutes and the amount of time I have to wait for a game sometimes is why I'd like to remove 2 stars....if there were any. So thumbs up and gret job guys.

Having seen a lot of issues relating to controllers and arcade sticks, I can say that I have my PS4 controller using no 3rd party software working just fine. 
Also my custom hitbox controller working with no changes required, though I am unable to rebind my hitbox inside the game, but have found the default layout to work just fine.
I am aware that this info is most likely useless as everyone elses setups are different but for what it's worth its fine for me.

The online net code seems to be doing the job in all the online games I have only had 2 stutters. That was against someone with a 2bar connection so I will just stick to 3 bars+. Can't help the existence of WiFi warriors or just dodgy internet!

The game looks stunning and feels super responsive which is a must in a fighting game. The screen can become cluttered which is something I hope I get used to, this coming from someone who prefers the less flashy tekken so maybe I just suck with my shit eyes.

The combo system seems to be an area of contention for a lot of people. The way I see it is that the auto combos exist to bridge the gap for newbies so that they get a reward for landing a successful hit. While the people that spend time learning proper combos and pressure strings are rewarded with more damage, better hit confirming, better pressure, building more meter etc.

If your game plan involves spamming Super Dash and mashing punch that will not get you that far. As it should be, every fighting game has its "cheap tactic", spamming shoryuken in street fighter, snake edges in tekken and punching in the nuts in real life. It is not to say that a cheap tactic isn't somewhat effective in early levels of play but that a solid strategy exists to almost completely nullify it (Down + heavy when you see your opponent do a super dash, free combo but it is hard to react to!). Those that seek a solution improve those that don't....don't.

Now I want to be clear that I am not claiming everything is balanced, or that no really strong "cheap tactic" exists. 
I haven't played nearly enough of the game to make that kind of call, in fact even after hundreds of hours I still probably couldn't. Just that the game is new, stuff is being discovered and as usual with fighting games a bit of research and practise will go a long way in helping you improve. 

All in all, what is reading like some kind of rant hides how much I am enjoying this game, it is fun, well polished for the most part. Limited online lobby space is dumb, they need to sort that out! Offline lobbies exist for playing solo but still it can be a pain when you want to online, though I may be missing something here. 

Why the need for this walk around lobby, what is wrong with menus!

Lots of content, not even touched story yet, solid practise mode, solid arcade, online ranked and unranked.

Big thumbs up.

Also my team is super sand virginia and kakka carrot cake and undecided on the last character. Maybe freezy pop.

Great game with interesting mechanics, but for ¬£45 I was left wanting way more, the lack of characters seems odd, having characters like nappa but not Zarbon or Dodoria is criminal, I get that more characters will be coming soon but these most likely will not be free, Jiren and UI Goku will probably burn a fat hole in your wallet when you buy the DLC. It is good dont get me wrong, in fact I would go as far to say that it feels better then the xenoverse series in terms of combat, but for ¬£45 this game isnt all there. The game has a story mode, a very lacking one but its there, it features mainly choppy animated cutscenes with some great lines between characters, these are great but not nearly great enough to make up for the stories emptyness. Fighting one new character aswell as 2 we have fought for years gets very boring very quickly, my favorite part of the story was the ability to play from both sides, both good and evil, this took me back to the lego batman days, if you know what I mean.

Maybe in a few months time, when the game has been flooded with new content and characters will I give it a higher rating, as of now the most I can give this game is a 7/10, great combat and very fast pased, just very dull after less than 3 days of playing, if you are looking for the full Dragon Ball fighting experiance then look no further, if you are looking for the full Dragon Ball Fighting experiance featuring a a full roster, you wont find it here for a while, but when you do, have your wallet handy.

Definitely worth buying IMO. Good value and a great feel. I feel rewarded just playing the single player...so yeah, it's like an interactive sequence of Dragon Ball Super episodes. DBFZ is simultaneously friendly and accessible to inexperienced players as well as full of complexity and depth for fighting game veterans. 

The controls are very simple, so don't worry if you are not good at directional motion inputs. But at the same time, the mechanics and simple fact that it is a 3v3 fighter make the skill ceiling very high, so there is unlimited potential for mastery.

The fighting itself is streamlined and fun. Don't be discouraged by the 'auto combos', they do not compare at all to the potential damage of manual combos, so they are not optimal. And yet, they actually have a ton of nuance and complexity built in, because you can use them partially during manual combos to lengthen and extend the combo itself in different ways. It's really interesting.

The visuals are completely unmatched for this style, and that really does enhance the overall experience.

Online play is very good, despite some early server issues which can be expected with any popular game during its release.

There is a ton of single player content, which is great for 'casual' players, but also functions as an entertaining way to just practice new characters even for experienced players. I've nearly finished the story and have been pleasantly surprised by really enjoying playing characters I never would have tried otherwise.

DBFZ is a blast for Dragon Ball fans and FGC players alike. It would be difficult to not find something to love about this game.

The only problem I honestly have is the limited roster. The Dragonball universe is filled with great characters, and it's a tragedy that many big name stars will not be in this. The quality of the game excels far beyond previous DBZ games, and that no doubt factors into the limited roster. 

60$ is a joke for many titles, most titles at that price point fail to earn it. I'd honestly say the same for this one. While the game is amazing, the content decent and what not, I'd just have to put it in the 40$ range.

I won't be purchasing the season pass, because 8 additional characters will go on sale eventually and it's no skin off my back till they do. The immediate lack of a big roster is what makes this appealing, but almost feels forced. I don't think it was the right call by the dev, because you open up the game with a fully unlocked roster aside from about 4 fighters, two of which are transformations of fighters in the game already. This is a kiddie pool sized game coming in at less than 5gig...couldn't they have forgone some of the mundane story cutscenes for a few extra fighters? 

Overall I give it a 8/10. Great game, tons of fun. However, I played/saw most everything there is to offer in just a wee 4 hours. (Story aside, but do any anime games ever have a really good story anyway? I might as well beat my head off a brick wall and hallucinate up a better story.)

Oh and the overworld is f**king awesome. Don't be fooled by reviews, because this overworld has me smiling from ear to ear.
