This game is great and if you are a DBZ fan you owe it to yourself to play this game. The roster is great with room for improvement thanks to DLC, the music is great, the english voice acting matches up with the character lips like a greasy chinese to western movie like kung pow enter the fist.

I'm digressing. I enjoy almost every aspect about the game. The only thing I don't really like is how some of the lobby is set up. I was trying to play with a buddy I knew from highschool and setting up thee match was a pain in the ass. That is until I figured out how to switch lobbies. A bit of a nooby mistake on our ends, but I'm used to text based menus, and while there is one in DBFZ it's not as straight forward as some of the older entries. UMvC3 did that pretty well I thought. I would like to be able to challenge friends to a match through steam (tab+shift) as well. Not a needed feature but could be a cool one. 

I hear arcade joystick support is rekt on PC. I don't use one so it doesn't matter to me, and either do my friends. This does matter for those who bought one before the release. I'm not sure if it's an issue with the game not detecting xinput from the device or whether the device was made for dinput where DBFZ may possibly use xinput only. Speculation but It's easily fixable so if you can be patient don't worry too much about it. It will come.

Conclusion: Recommended to anybody who loves dragonball. I'm excited for the new characters that are going to come. I would buy the pass, but I don't want to pay for characters I may not even like. So when the time comes I'll throw more of my sheckles at this glorious fucking game <3

By far one of my favorite games to date. The graphics are amazing and the in-game animations for everyones super are really well done. The combat system is easy to learn, so youu can pull off pretty great combos right off the bat, but hard to master. Being able to switch characters mid battle is probably my favorite part of the combat system because of how smooth it is. The campaign is great, my only complaint about the campaign is that to go through the cut scenes you have to click  A to advance through it instead of having the cutscene play through fluently, kind of like an episode in the anime. Either then that one small thing I could not recomend this game enough, everyone of my friends that I have shown it too agree that this is one of the best looking and best feeling fighting games yet, and becasue it s Dragon Ball is the cherry on top for me. I can max this game at 2K with V-Sync off and no frame drops. GTX 1070, Intel 6600k, 16Gb of RAM. 10/10 would recommend to any fan of fighting games and the anime.

Ok so this game has brought up my DBZ nostolgia real hard and I am enjoying every last minute of it Improving my combos and just feels amazing. The roster is good in my opinion and it feels completly fine to master at least one character you feel like it suits your playstyle and it will work. Although it feels like there is a good amount of characters it just feels like majority of them are missing (DLC). But overall I enjoy it.

Ok now for the Negatives:
Lobby System: Ok this is sorta mix. Its not BAD and its not Good either concerning we're all chibi characters walking around and I am guessing its for us to interact with each other WHICH I am Completly Fine with. BUT whenever you exit out an instance from the training area or story, You would have to go back to the server selection and find another server. Right now currently in the second day, Rooms are full and there are still a very good amount of slots open which is good.

Matchmaking: Ok so I am pretty sure this is going to get resolved BUT they need to fix this whole matchmaking that takes like 5 min to find  a normal match. Of course there are alot of people in lobbies that could instantly fight with each other which is fine. 
While in considerations these aren't realy big issues in my opinion but I am pretty sure (hopefully) they get resolved.

Overall I give it a 9/10 for a DBZ fighting game. This game can be good for non-experienced people who have never played a single fighting game in their life and would still be doing good. Veterans can improve on combos and fighting the perfect team. Other than that I say its worth it but if you still feel skeptical of buying full price you can just wait until the next sale.

good fighting game

This is after 17 hours in game, compleating the mainline story quest's all three arcs, of which I livestreamed and put up on youtube... feel free to view my channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ELPMCFlashFrame/videos

As for my take: I haven't taken a fighter this seriously since Super Street Fighter 2 back on Genesis... as far as a fighting game goes, it's accessable to new players, and has depth for people who love to deep dive into fighting game systems.

However, there ARE some problems currently... one of the main one's being Android 16's self destruct super, which will destroy an ENTIRE lifebar of a character... now it's easy to avoid, but if you get caught in it, I have a feeling people are going to bee seeing this as a huge problem [please note, I am NOT sure how much damage this move does in PVP, but in the story mode, it wrecks basically everything.]

So let me start by naming the negatives of the game:
Small roster of female characters... 2 exist, Android 21, and Android 18, that's it, if you're looking for waifu's, go play Skullgirls... because there's only two here [that being said, they are two good characters.]
Android 16's self destruct move for the reasons stated above.

Now for the positives:
Great optimization. 4k on a gtx 970 with everything set to MAX, the game looks AMAZING and at a butter smooth 60fps locked. [i've heard reports of it running just as well on a gtx 660 even]

Decent roster, compaired to something like, say, Xenoverse 2... or Tenkichi, the roster is SMALL, HOWEVER, that's nto really a bad thing when you consider this game is balanced as a fighting game first... each character feels unique, and has plenty of moves in their toolbox to get the job done.

great music, even better than Xenoverse 2 IMO, get's you pumped for every fight.

The game has Dinput support, so running with a gamepad, or a fightstick is easy as it comes, and full rebindable keys makes it easy to set the game up to play exactly how you want it to.

as of right now, I'd rate it 8/10, a solid, accessable fighting game, with a wonderful art style and tight controls.

A gorgeous game, absolutely recommend it for anyone who likes a fighting game in the 2.5D style. As I said the graphics look incredible, a faithful recreation of the anime style of the series. It plays great, with both accesibility to anyone who wants to start playing fighting games, or casual friends who come over (with auto combos wich sadly, can't be turned off online), and deep combo and assist mechanics for the seasoned players or competitive players. It also boasts a complete tutorial and combo challenges for ALL of the characters with the Play Demo option. The game doesn't feel unbalanced at all and it's fairly fast paced if you find people who know what they're doing, although not as fast as UMvC3.
Characters are really diverse (with the only "clones" being Goku & Vegeta with their upgraded Super Saiyan Blue forms, which also varies in some regards but not much) and play really different from one another and allow for a variety of team composition.

My experience with the game online so far has been flawless, with me being in the South American (Argentina) region, since Launch until now, I've seen all to most of the lobbies full and the connection has been excellent. Having 1-3 frame delay (Real Time with no perceptible delay) to the worst I had wich was 10 frames. But only once.

I've had no disconnects in Arena Matches, only when a Ring-Host disbanded the Ring.

All of this having a 50 MB Download Speed.

Absolutely recommend this game. I wouldn't recommend buying the Season Pass as of now, since we don't know what characters are included.

This is the best Dragon Ball game currently. The graphics, the soundtrack, the animations are all excellent! My only complaint and a downside is the fact that FighterZ has a small character roster, though I'm hoping that'll all change soon. There's so many characters they can bring, including some from Super!

But this gam eis definitely worth it 100%. If you're not a fan of fighting game and/or anime then it's not for you.

I will do my honest review of this game, as close as I can be to a neutral opinion of DB FighterZ (no spoilers so don¬¥t worry):

PROS:

-AMAZING gameplay and BREATHTAKING graphics, Arc System did an amazing job with this game.
-Very Smooth gameplay on PC.
-Fluid combos, easy to play but hard to master.
-Is VERY fun to play with friends.
-It have arcade mode, local matches, story mode, tournament, online with ranked and player matches... companies like Crapcom could learn a lot about how to make a complete game in 2018 with basic modes.
-The BEST DB related game available since DBZ Budokai Tenkaichi 3 in 2007.
-It looks very optimized on PC (I have a high end PC so don¬¥t know about the performance in general on other machines)
-Great Story mode (probably the best story mode in a decade, thanks God no more "Raditz arrival" story)
-Roasts everywhere on story mode, way better than DB Super¬¥s story.
-Great final boss and at last an original character.
-100% Controller compatible
-Is Dragon Ball on PC, and for the first time in a decade, a competitive fighting DB game, which I am very glad.
-So far, the online and the servers are working fine
-The avatars and customization unlockables are great
-The equivalent of loot crates (capsules) are free (well you use in game currency, but not real money) and you don¬¥t need to grind for it, zennie, pretty much comes from everything.
-Music, in general, is pretty decent.
-It have subtittles on several languajes and the japanese / english voices are pretty good.

CONS:

-Super expensive game and there is no localization of prices. (it will short the life span of the game)
-Day one DLC
-Laughable preorder incentive, as you can unlock SSJ Blue Goku and Vegeta in game.
-Be ready to pay $30 USD for classic music tracks that can be played for free on an Xbox for example.
-Expensive Season Pass with only 8 (unknown) characters (that can potentially end up being "Raditz" and "SSJ2 Goku" instead of characters people actually want). Do you want all characters? be ready to pay $100 USD
-The game has DENUVO, which is a "no buy" factor in many scenarios, be aware th egame needs perpetual internet connection to work, otherwise you are locked out of your legit purchased copy of the game. Also DENUVO games can¬¥t be modded, so forget the idea of downloading workshop mods or cool custom skins.
-BAMCO has no communication with it¬¥s consumers and were banning or deleting posts from users on FB or their boards all night about the PC release.
-PC specs were unknown for a long time, and then were set to a very high standard, scaring potential buyers of the game.
-No Beta on PC because we are second fiddle consumers it seems... except when it comes to pay full price.
-No midnight release of the game, or even pre-load, because again, PC consumers doesn¬¥t matter and apparently PS4 and Xbox One can download at midnight but PC in 2018, can¬¥t.
-Apparently the game is locked on India for no reason... but they do sell DLC. LMAO
-Characters has no alt costumes, only colors.
-Autocombos are a CANCER that will kill the game, but nobody cared to take them away at least on ranked.
-No spanish or LATAM dub. This is shameful taking in consideration the price and how they actually did it for g ames like Saint Seiya Soldier¬¥s Soul or Naruto.
-Servers are ok, but sometimes the connection is laggy even with Blue Bar-connection foes.
-An error make almost everyone unable to join matches on lobbies... which is killing the fun right now, and knowing BAMCO this error will be permanent, so be ready to play offline or arcade for good.
-The roster is too small and pathetic for a 3 vs 3 game. Remember Marvel vs Crapcom 3 in 2011 was made with way more characetrs and was also developed from zero, for 2 very different platforms, for $60 USD.
-Not all characters are very fleshed out, there are few characters that are VERY generic like Ultimate Gohan or Fat Buu, so remember, a small roster is not always equal to high quality.
-I want to kick whoever believed making us sign a Privacy Agreement with unskippable text was a good or reasonable idea. (I needed like 3 minutes scrolling down till I was able to Agree to it.)

FINAL SCORE:

9/10

Why? I gave it a high score (and a positive review even if I was tempted to give it a negative one) because the game is pretty good, it looks great and feels great to play, and is actually fun to play with other people, characters are very fleshed out in general (with few exceptions), and the original story mode is something I am grateful for it, even despise the pathetic small roster, the despicable attitude of BAMCO, the price, the plague of DLC, among other factors. 

if you are a fan of DB I advise to buy it now and support Arc System, you won¬¥t regret it if you are a true fan of t he franchise and like competitive fighting games, otherwise, wait for a sale because it is definitively NOT worthy $100 in it¬¥s current status with such a bare bone roster.

If you are not a huge fan of DB.... definitively wait for the sequel, this won¬¥t outperform DB Budokai Tenkaichi 3 in terms of content

As a fan of Dragon Ball since it came to the U.S back in the late 90's early 2000's, I gotta say, this game has it all. Great attention to detail in reference to it's source material and succeeding in being a good competitive fighting game for the franchise. You want fan service? Done. You want good online play and net code? Done. You want a good new story mode that doesn't rely on old DB material? Done. If you're a fan of fighting games, and/or Dragon Ball, this is the game for you.
Solid 9/10.

Marvel's back baby.

In all seriousness, the game is fantastic. The fights are fast, frenetic, and full of insane combos. It's got enough depth and variety that fighting game fans will find a lot of combo creativity, while also remaining accessible for those new to fighting games and just want to play casually with friends to wax nostalgic about DBZ, or to experience the story, which is exclusively made for the game and not just retelling the same arcs you've seen over and over again.

The game isn't without issues, though. The lobby system can be frustrating, especially to those who haven't played an Arcsys title before. It's meant to simulate the feeling of being in an arcade where anyone can come up and play you, but if you're just wanting to play with friends, it can be annoying to have to join an online lobby just to make a private game. Thankfully, they've added more lobbies so space isn't limited like it was at launch.

It looks and performs beautifully, with Arcsys making use of the shaders they made for GGXRD to make one of the most striking games I've ever seen. It LOOKS like you're playing the anime. Animations, music, and sound effects all evoke the spirit of DBZ, with close attention paid to get very minute details just right.

At the moment, I feel this is THE 2D fighter. The DBZ element should keep it relatively populated, which is an issue previous Arcsys games had. If you're a DBZ fan, there's SO much fun to be hard, with the game oozing fanservice and references and playing around with the cast. If you've never been into DBZ, the game is so fun it might just pique your interest.

I can easily state that this is one of the best fighting games both visually and in terms of gameplay.

I played the Open Beta on PS4 about two weeks prior to this game's release and legitmately either mentioned or thought about this game once a day since the launch trailer shown back last summer during Microsoft's E3. Here is the crazy thing: this game lives up to all of the overflowing hype I had for it and goes even further beyond. As I am a DrgaonBall fan but see a lot of problems with the series as a whole (I don't want to be considered an apologist to all of the nonsense, with Super currently airing as well), and can't say it enough that this is my favorite DragonBall game by far, as I previosuly was a huge fan of Budokai Tenkaichi 3 and Raging Blast 2's 3D-plane gameplay. I can't say it enough how beginner-friendly this game is yet has so much extra tech to it where the even the most extreme members of the FGC (Fighting Game Community) fell in love with this game so fast as it has been slated for an overwhelming amount of upcoming tournaments (rightfully so), and even if you don't prefer a 2D-style fighting game but are a huge DBZ fan, you can find enjoyment here as well with the amount of work dedicated to the visuals, with 98% of every move (including even the most basic of punches/kicks) have been taken by various panels of the manga and scenes from the anime, with dramatic finishes to allow you to feel what you may have always wanted in a DragonBall game. 

The upcoming plans of DLC is definitely something to not be wary of in my opinion considering how every character in the current roster (including Android #21 and both SSJ Blue Goku/Vegeta) feel as they should and even if you don't prefer a "heavy play-style" such as Majin Buu or Android 16, you can see where someone who does prefer that style would enjoy those characters, both feeling like how those characters are in the show yet feeling like unique character types in a more traditional fighting game such as Marvel vs Capcom. Every character is viable in their own way, even Nappa with his Saibamen to Yamcha with his insane rush-down moves regarding his Wolf Fang Fist. I am leaning more towards characters such as Piccolo, Hit, and SSJ Vegeta (with the true God of Destruction Tien sprinkled in there for more variety) but I constantly switch between every character as each one is easily an adreline-rush to play. 

I have been trying to push this to others and plan to help others see why this game, even from a standpoint of hating DragonBall AND fighting games, has an endless amount of love placed DragonBall FighterZ for each of the fans a game like this appeals to: fighting game fans, DragonBall fans, and fans of games that clearly went all-out with their project. I personally believe that DragonBall FighterZ can not be denied as a great game.

First and foremost, this is traditional 2D fighting game first and a Dragonball game second. To those coming from Xenoverse, this is NOT an arena fighter like that game

That said, Dragonball FighterZ is a great game with some minor nitpicks. The graphics are stylized to make the 3D models look like 2D sprites which makes look every character really crispy without losing that anime look.
The sound effects are straight from the show. No need to fix what isn't broken. The music is rocking good but I don't think it particularly memorable. Still puts you in a good fighting mood.

For gameplay, its made so that you can make a simple combo from mashing a single button so newbies of the genre dont get discouraged. Arc Systems has always had this on their games but as an option from separate from the technical style of inputs. The fact that its integrated by default into this game really takes away from that marvel of "Wow, that combo was pretty cool" Of course, the more seasoned fighting game players can still pull out a longer and more technically demanding combo just fine and deal with the auto-combos with relative ease. The game heavily rewards aggressive play, even giving you Ki just for walking forward. It feels a little unbalanced though compared with Guilty Gear Xrd which also heavily rewards aggressive play but also giving you quite a number of defensive tools. In this game, you only can rely on a good timed counter or a good timed Z-guard which basically a push back for the enemy.

Every character is similar to some degree, as in, they all share the same basic combo paths, do the same general type of attack with the same inputs (a sweep with low, medium. Anti-air with low, heavy, etc) So if you know one character, you basically can play the whole roster. That said, most of the cast has a diferent feel to each other and keeps things varied.

The story mode is cleverly designed and its definetly worth checking out. Lots of fighting with occasional dialog between the characters. Not to heavy on plot so its easy to enjoy.

If you are into 2D fighers, definetly pick this game. If you aren't sure you will like it, wait for a sale.

This game is worth all the money if you are a true Dragon Ball fan. Engaging single player story with a huge variety of cutscenes with each voice actor/actress (including Sean Schemmel, Christopher Sabat, Sonny Strait and Jason Douglas), beautiful graphics that truely make you appreciate that you don't need a guns blazing PC to even run it and addicting gameplay indeed. It's best with a controller, but thanks to it's simple and not so-complicated gameplay, a keyboard works fine for the time being if you do lack a controller.

Something extremaly convenient about the single player mode is that you get taught all the important techniques while fighting against the CPU opponents. In a lot of fighting games, the player would assume they'd have to pump up some iron a bit in a training mode against a dummy (which is still useful of course if you want to practice landing your combos), however in the story mode, you get taught all the basics, and advice tends to get repeated so it is quite unlikely you'll forget the neccassary moves in order to stand a chance against human opponents.

Speaking of which, as expected the online lobbies are simply stuffed with other eager to challenge warriors ready to duke out all of their ki energy on unsuspecting amateur clowns. However, it's far from impossible to find a room eventually (launch day should simply be excepted, it's something one should always prepare for, that little extra patience for expecting literally every single fresh new arrival at once), at times I did notice when trying to get into a casual match, I got random disconnections from the lobby, but it took little to no time to get back. Lobbies do fill up fast, but tend to lose players quickly at the same time, so just keep an eye out for numbers dropping.

With every character sporting their own unique movesets, you'll be putting in hours to gain knowledge just how each of them operate and obliterate. You can feel at ease knowing how easy it is to get the hang of just how the game plays, so much so that you can go in an online match instantly, study your opponent, and learn some methods out of him/her so you can improve yourself in the long term like a true Z fighter. Although of course as mentioned earlier, it's recommended you learn the controls in single player or training mode if you're in a rush to blast open some craters.

Who knew Marvel vs Capcom gameplay could transition so well into a Dragon Ball fighting game, perhaps M.U.G.E.N foretold the future, and even more excitingly, this means a crossover with another franchise would really work out.

Overall and very simply put, get this if you fancy fast-paced fighting. If you're skeptical over some negative reviews simply wait for a sale.

Dragon Ball FighterZ is the latest and greatest game from ArcSys, and dang it's pretty.

Pros:
-I have never seen an anime game capture the visual style of the actual anime so well. Everything in this game looks and sounds just like the anime, and the animations and super attacks are a treat to watch. On top of that, there's tons of visual touches such as opponents flying off into the terrain when defeated with a strong attack which make it even more intense to look at.

-The gameplay is incredibly fast paced and everything feels buttery smooth for a fighting game, and on top of that, despite the length and flashy-ness of combos, they're actually very easy to get into doing; the entirety of the game is, for that matter. Characters can perform simplistic combos by hitting the same buttons rapidly for people who just want to jump in and have fun, wheras they can also do much more complicated and damaging combos for those who want to invest the time to learn them. On top of that, all the game's specials are very easy to perform and remember, making it easy for players to switch up their team with different characters.

-The roster, while perhaps not exactly gigantic like other Dragon Ball titles, offers a great variety of unique characters to play with. Unlike other Dragon Ball games, everyone in this game feels very distinct from one another, from the simplistic all rounder gameplay of Goku, to the bizarre, projectile manipulating Beerus. 

-Unlike some modern fighting titles, this game released with a fair share of offline modes as well as online ones. For those who like to play offline, you've got access to your basic stuff like training modes, VS CPU and offline local play. Then, you have the Arcade Mode, which presents you multiple lines of battles against enemy CPU teams that vary in difficulty and character depending on how well you performed in the previous match. Then, there's a story mode, for those who're into the Dragon Ball story, where you can... Well, I suppose I'll leave that up to you to discover. It's your sort of standard fighting game story mode, but it's got some unique Dragon Ball flair to it and is surprisingly branching for a title in the series.

-Also worth a mention for being a personal favourite of mine; One of the online modes allows you to host a contest between 6 players, where rather than control an entire team yourself, each player controls a singular character on one side, and only controls the fight when they're tagged in. Though technically nothing mechanically changes about this mode, I found playing a match with two real allies against a team of 3 different opponents incredibly fun! It meant that each of my opponents was not only a different character, but also played differently, as were my partners. This does, however, bring us to the "Mehs" of the game.

Mehs:

-If you've heard people complaining about this game, it's probably about the online. The game is run on a lobby system, meaning from what I can tell, you only really match against the players who're in the same sort of hub world lobby as you. Theoretically this shouldn't be a problem, but there's about a 64 player limit on the lobbies, which means that it can be a little odd finding matches, and in populated countries, you might not actually find yourself able to get online. Personally, this isn't an issue for me, as the Oceanic servers have plenty of free slots, but it's worth considering.

-The online seems to vary in terms of quality. Though I've played several matches that felt absolutely seemless, I've also played matches where the game slows significantly and lags somewhat. Not unplayable, but it does feel a bit jarring compared to the blisteringly fast offline.

-For those seeking it, I do not believe that the game has an endless random CPU battle mode. You can fight endlessly in the offline battles, but the arcade ends after a set amount of matches depending on which one you select, and the teams seem to be pre-determined, though there's a great variety due to the way the battles change depending on your performance.


Overall however, Dragon Ball FighterZ is an absoluteley amazing fighting game. The gameplay is intense and epic, and offers a great balance of simplicity and complexity. The visuals are fantastic and the music has all kinds of great tracks. The roster is large enough to offer a good variety, and there are 8 DLC characters coming later to enlarge it further. The online is fun, but I suppose a little sketchy in terms of how frequently it works how you want it to. 

Should you get it? Heck yes. Despite a slightly flawed online, this is, in my opinion, the best fighting game to release in a long time. I've enjoyed it a ton so far, and I will continue to for a long time. It's been a while since a fighting game brought a real genuine smile to my face, as I played online in a 3v3 battle, tagging out to one of my partner's mid-combo and watching him seemlessly continue the combo into a super attack, accompanied by a little "Nice!!" message from the 3rd player watching. Truly, this is some of the most fun you're going to have with a fighting game or a Dragon Ball game.

A true spiritual successor to Marvel vs Capcom 2 and 3, and an excellent fighting game, as expected from Arc System Works. One of the easier fighting games to pick up and play, but not lacking in depth.

As in other Versus titles, there are surface similarities between the characters, but spending any amount of time with them reveals they are quite unique.

Currently without most of the stupid stuff that has historically plagued the Versus series.

All in all, easily the best Dragon Ball game of all time.

There are a few fairly minor issues currently, which I hope will be resolved in the near future: 

- Some people have to run the game from Big Picture for their controllers to work.

- Button icons in missions and the tutorial reflect the default configuration on an XB1 controller, rather than current binds or a generic L/M/H/S/A1/A2 or A/B/C/D/Z1/Z2.

A fantastic fighting game, horribly marred by some of the worst matchmaking design I have ever seen. THIS GAME DOES NOT WORK ONLINE. It is lobby based, with only a max of 10 lobbys for areas and as little as 4, with a max of 64 players in each lobby. Good luck logging into a lobby! That means there are ONLY 63 other people you can possibly match with at any given time, meaning you are rarely going to fight someone of your skill level. Hell, you are rarely going to fight anyone at all because they still need to be queued as well. Oh and you can't do anything else while queued for a match. Whoever designed this system should be fired immediately, and I will be petitioning for a refund for this reason. This review will stay negative until the server is fixed and this game is playable online, and in its current state I would not recommend this game for this atrotious failing and lack of care for PC.

A DragonBall fighting game that's easy to pick up, very fun to play, but hard to master and it has it's eyes on the competitive scene. Some might think this is a small character roster for a DragonBall fighting game, especially those used to the Budokai series. All I can say in response is quality over quantity. The developers should not be criticized for putting balance over fan service and have crafted an excellent fighting game with fun mechanics and frenetic fights.
The game looks gorgeous and emulates the anime's style near perfectly. I cannot speak of any performance issues whatsoever and online play is almost as snappy as local play. (Playing with a nearby friend had around 1-2 frames of delay).

Game has Denuvo anti-piracy, apparently. I have not personally checked this but I did not notice any issues with the game in this regard.

It's a shame the game released half a day later on PC than on console but ultimately wasn't a huge issue for me.

Also to those worried that they won't be able to play because the lobbies are full, it's blatant bullshit and it was only the case during the first hours of launch. (single player was unaffected)
The PC version of this game is probably a surprise hit compared to the console versions for ArcSys and they swiftly added more lobbies to the game.

Fun game. Bad online play. Instead of simple menus for matchmaking play, and serverlists for private/public rooms, they've designed some sort of bizarre overworld lobby that barely works and makes multiplayer frustrating to engage in.

I tried using their matchmaking and could not find a match at all in all my attempts. I waited 2+ minutes each time I tried. Never found a match.

Tried the arena mode which is supposed to be a communal fighting arena that you can spectate on, and that was a horrible experience as well. It's never clear what's going on, when you're going to get a match, and I couldn't get the observe a match function to work at all.

Tried using ring matches, which are lobbies that players create. It was an exercise in running around the overworld clicking on ring match circles to see an error message, then run to the next one for the same error message. I managed to get into 1 out of 15.

Also, no keyboard typing allowed, no voice chat allowed.

I did get in a few matches but the experience was frustrating enough for me to just refund and save myself the future trouble.

Came for the Plot.

Alright, this game is a VERY mixed bag... Firstly let me just say that this game is not worth $60. Ultimate edition is a total robbery for $110 and I was suckered into getting it for my birthday. I'd like to point out not even Arc System Works has the stones to charge full price for their games and the're at the top for fighting games on PC. 

Initial Issues...

-Not enough servers, there's like what... 20 US East servers for 64 people per server? They're all full. No servers left.

-Attacks not registering properly on gamepad. (The super/ultimate combos are total 50/50's)

-Story is even more stupid and cliche than Xenoverse...

-All animated segments are running in 30fps or lower and just make me ill to look at. (2560x1440, 144hz monitor)

-No functional tutorial, instead the game tries to hand hold you with tutorials for the first 10 levels of the story, enemies die while trying to learn new moves.

And at this point in time, I can't really tell how solid the gameplay ACTUALLY is. It feels very slow and janky, when you get up to the enemy and fight it's way too fast, you can't even effectively counter unless you anticipated it. A lot of skills and perks are locked until you level up...? I don't really know whats going on with this game and the typical Japanese hub/UI doesn't help. 

I'm just going to wait until they patch this thing, and based on how much of a wreck it already is, and how many bad reviews it's got, I'd say that it's coming soon. I am not going to be scammed out of $110, if this doesn't get resolved I WILL be refunding and buy it on mass sale later. I wonder if I'll keep the pre-order and Ultimate edition bonuses... Probably.

EDIT: Upon further review... The game has glaring issues. 

The tutorial hand holding crap continues the whole game. You have this nasty tutorial message across you screen in 50% of fights for the whole campaign.

As for the combat it's pretty shallow. Sure you can combo differently for every situation, but it's entirely character based. The game feels so static and repetitive. You have to switch chars all the time or you WILL get bored.

The AI is broken. It'll be full brain-dead and not even fight back or move for the first half of the fight, then just go full kill mode. They really should put in a difficulty option for the AI it's never consistent. It's really all over the place.

The campaign and fights are pretty boring overall. Imagine xenoverse with the copy paste missions fights, but in 2D format. That's what the "missions" are in this game. You're playing for 10 second slivers of unique audio/cinematics between chars.

I really don't get the point of zeni in this game all it does is get you lobby cudtomization crap, not even outfits or anything, just your standard cod player card...

Tag team char swaping spam is a thing... Everyone online just swaps their char out the second they get hurt so 90% of the damage you inflicted heals. They either need to decrease the amount of hp fighters regenerate, slow it down, or make the character swap cool down longer. Don't expect an honest fight on ranked. I know it sounds scummy but everyone swap spams.

I'd just like to mention how a neck beard came here to defend the game about my anticipation, unpredictable block complaint. Guy told me it's the genre and I know lmao. This game has a problem with it though when you can stunlock the other person in a combo, spam supers along with char swaps to get 2 supers in, taking out 50-100% hp of your fighters. It's very questionable... There should be more ways to break out of attacks (ie using a ki bar to escape like xenoverse)

The connection isn't horrible but it's not good... At least you can set what connection your other opponent is so you don't fight someone in China, that's nice. I've had a handful of laggy frames but nothing too noticeable. (I play with 4 bars of connection or higher. Laggy frames aren't acceptable.) I'm totally baffled why it takes 5min to find a match when all the online servers are full, despite there being virtually none. (Good luck getting into one to play online.)

Meh, there's just not much to this game. It can have it's fun little bits, and the voice actors are great (for the most part). If you dont love the core of this game it isn't for you. They put in all these gamemodes and stuff but in the end it's all just 2D fighting. I know that sounds silly but it's true. Campaign is just 100 AI skirmishes with cinematics over and over. Arcade mode is the exact same as campaign it just doesn't have cinematics... And online battles are online battles. Everyone I've played has been horribly bad and can only play Yamcha. Expect mega neck beards in the future though.

At the time of this review, I'm only 7 hours in... But thats after one session. I started playing and never wanted to stop.

It truly felt like the good old days of incredible Dragonball fighting games; I'm talking Budokai 2 and 3 vibes. Fighting with friends local, even online, it's so exhilirating! There may be some negative reviews about the current lobby system and I agree, they need to make more space for more players asap, however I'm reviewing the gameplay, and it feels amazing.

The fighting mechanics are so intricate, that I can see myself practising and training for weeks to get good. The combos you can pull off alone, and then having the option to bring in other characters to the fight for assists and even further combos just add a whole new level of wow. The game is beautifully presented and it's mechanics and feel show that a great deal of passion went into this project.

Pretty fun. I am not a fighting game guru, at least not these fighting games. I prefer smash bros and rivals of aether, but I found the combat in the last few dragon ball games to suck so I picked this one up.

The combat seems pretty good, to me at least. The combos don't seem to long or do to much damage since there is no break out of combo button. 

But like I said,  I don't play these kinds of games. I just know I enjoyed this one.

As for any other aspect of the game, it seems kind of cheap. Not like cheap in a bad way, but the hub world is kind of bland and it uses little chibi looking sprites for you to interact with. I think just a standard menu would have been fine, but that little bit of extra effort to allow you to walk around and emote at people is pretty neat I guess. The stamps are stupid. I never understood the point of "sprays" and these stamps. But some people enjoy using and collecting them, so there is that if you're one of those people.

I got a constant 60 fps on my laptop. I have not played on my PC yet, but if I get a constant 60 on my decent enough laptop, I think my PC will run it just as well. It seems to be optimized very well. 

The graphics themselves are just so pretty. I wish the cutscenes used different art though. The cutscenes seem to use art from the previous Dragon Ball game styles, if that makes sense. They just don't look as good. But it's not a big deal since I just skipped them since the story was kind of boring to be honest.

Also, Krillin is amazing in this, so that's cool.

If i had to describe this game in one word it would be: UNDERWHELMING.

Let me start by saying that gameplay-wise, it does deliver... kinda... it does scratch that good old "Dragon Ball Fighter Game" itch that every one of us have at some point in life... but its far from being the best DBZ game there is, it is VERY GOOD don't get me wrong... but Budokai and Budokai Tenkaichi on PS2 are both vastly superior, which brings us to the problems that make me sadly give this game (that I was really looking forward to) a BAD review.

Graphics are good, the game is GORGEOUS, it looks like a Dragon Ball game from 2018 should and for the most part the fidelity to source material was a huge selling point for me 
EDIT: I figured what had me running with poor performance, I admit, my bad, game is indeed NICELY optimized for PC, moving this to the positive side of my review.

Let's go in order... first thing the game prepares you for... takes FOREVER to find a lobby, first time I found one right away, then every time after I now realize how UNDERWHELMING this system is, you have 6 regions to chose from, all of them have several lobbys, USA having the most obviously, but even if we do basic math... the developer expected like... 1000 players at most to want to use the lobby at the same time?, sure every time you enter a new activity it takes you out of the lobby which helps for newcomers, but 1 This means you are always looking for lobby room and 2 It is still 99% of the time full so you end up going to the OFFLINE lobby, and if you are doing story mode or arcade thats fine but for an ONLINE fighting game you already lost access to major content.

Speaking of which, the story... boy is this story mediocre, now, obviously when having a Dragon Ball game for the story mode you have 2 options basically, either have us do the whole story of the original series (like Budokai and Tenkaichi did), or come up with underwhelming crap that justifies you battling everyone without breaking the lore or have it just be a tournament... this game sadly chose the second option... *Spoilers* you are... YOU, somehow linked to Goku's body (later you can link with everyone else as you unlock them), because thats who I want to be while playing dragon freaking ball... MYSELF... this in a convoluted way means that even though you are in the body of Goku, who already lorewise is at his strongest point you are technically weakest than every single dragon ball character ever... yaaay... well, no, Goku is your guardian spirit who cant fight, and the story treats YOU as if you have 1% of his power even though during fights you can use everything right away, oh and why or how are you fighting everyone else? theres an army of clones... so... Sonic Forces but with you and Goku sharing a body instead of being a new fighter which btw was a really cool feature from the Xenoverse series that would've been better for this game... but they had to force the gimmick of 3v3 by justifying it in so YOU can only inhabit 1 body at a time so... 3 v 3 battles taking turns! It doesn't even make any sense, if you can create any number of Gokus why would you ever fucking waste cloning resources on Yamcha, Tien, Krillin, etc!? Vegeta at least I would understand but for crying out loud, have every clone in your evil army be Goku! the villain already has intentional design flaws on its master plan and I havent even finished the first arc!!!

By the way... lip sync! what minor thing that we take for granted... yeah, during the "cutscenes" of the story mode no matter which language you chose, 50% of the lines are in proper sync with mouth movement (to an extent at least, you know... them not moving their mouths when they shut up and such), I understand that you cant lip sync 2 languages to generic mouth movement but at least sync it to ONE language! oh wait no, you actually can, like any big title that has multi language support has done since the era of the first cutscenes that had lip movement, otherwise I'd rather have the cutscenes be with standstills of the characters, it gets terribly distracting and now that I mentioned it you will be forced to press A to advance the lines as soon as they finish saying them so that you are not annoyed by it as much as I am. 

Edit: The hand holding is so terrible! no matter how far you are into the story, you will ocasionally have 30% of your screen covered by "Press A + X to charge your Ki" bitch I've recharged my Ki in DBZ games before you even existed!

Now, since you got bored of the painfully boring story, you force your way into a lobby and queue up for an arena match, or a casual match, or hell... anything! as long as you get to beat the shit out of someone else in awesome dragon ball fashion it doesnt matter!... well NO, even if the lobby is FULL as hell, queueing on anything takes forever to find a match, casual matches against people with any connection on any level... I couldnt find one in 30 minutes, arena matches I found 1 in 10 minutes of trying, directly challenging a player didnt work either HOW CAN YOU MESS THIS UP SO MUCH!? If I queue on a CASUAL unranked match just throw whoever's on the game, don't ask me to luck out on one of the people in the lobby to want to do the same activity as me and ACCEPT my match after waiting like 15 minutes to find it in the first place! (yes, you can DENY a match, why would you if it took you forever to find it I dont know... genius design... I obviously purchased DRAGON BALL to wait in imaginary lines and investigate and carefully decide if i want to fight the guy I've been waiting for hours).

Music is decent, the generic stuff you expect, supposedly there are some remixes of the original tracks from the anime, I have yet to find a single one, the new ones are underwhelming...

And honestly, I dont know what else to say, I had to stop playing to write this lengthy review, because when the action is so good, fast paced and awesome that obviously you have time to simply WANT to stop to instead write an essay on how much fun you could be having but are for some reason NOT having that is always a good sign right!?.

I bought DRAGON BALL and I am fighting using a freaking SUPER SAIYAN, HOW am I bored enough to want to write a fucking review instead!?

Speaking of which, character roster! underwhelming! as expected from a fighting game of 2018, you get like the most basic posible fighters out of a MEMORABLE cast, and everything else is going to come as DLC, if EVER, gone are the days when developers wanted to give you every single fighter that dragon ball has ever shown (Budokai Tenkaichi anyone?), why would I, on release, want to play as Tien Shinhan instead of... I dont know, literally anyone else? hell, male/female broly for instance is a BIG one that should be here, and sure, now we want to pretend that every movie ever released doesnt count, how convenient! its not that we are lazy, its that those interesting fighters are not canon! well then WHY are we missing the fighers from Dragon Ball Super? isnt this game a cashgrab for that anime!?

Right now I give this game a 4 out of 10 because the lobby is bullshit, the story is uninteresting, the music is generic, roster is lacking and unappealing and I havent even mentioned glitches, cause YEAH I already experienced some in my first 2 hours of playing the game (mostly related to music and audio and one instance where during gameplay it kept changing from fullscreen to windowed, nothing major).

If they ever fix glitches and somehow throw that useless lobby to replace it for a better matchmaking, I would raise it to a 7 out of 10, as it is you'd rather play Budokai on PS2 than waste any time on this mediocre thing... oh sorry, I was using the word "underwhelming" wasnt I?


Edit: Just to clarify, I am not saying the developers suck, I myself wouldnt make the gameplay as good as it is, but as a dragon ball game it does leave me wanting and the online aspect does need serious rework.

Arcsys has developed another quality fighting game experience with one major advantage -- the Dragon Ball IP.

With the major downside of games like Guilty Gear and BlazBlue having been their niche appeal, Dragon Ball FighterZ has drawn in a broad player base of seasoned fighting game veterans and casual newcomers alike.

This game delivers all of the mechanical polish that Arcsys is known for, including the fantastic net code, and couples it with an extremely approachable ‚Äúeasy to learn, difficult to master‚Äù playstyle that sits somewhere in between an ABC fighter such as Injustice and a technical anime fighting game such as Guilty Gear.

Further to this, Dragon Ball FighterZ manages to capture the fast paced battles that pop into our minds whenever we think Dragon Ball, without it becoming a cluttered mess like games such as Marvel (Think Star Wars Prequels).

All in all, this game has everything you could possibly want from a fighter including tactile/super fun mechanics, fantastic graphics/sounds, solid IP, net play and single player content for those seeking a more casual experience. It is a game that literally anyone can get into easily and one that is being embraced by a myriad of players from all walks of life.

If this game looks at all appealing to you ‚Äì give it a go, it really is fantastic. Another quality Arcsys release, but with mainstream appeal.

And this... Is a DBZ game that goes... even... FURTHER... BEYOOOOND!!!!!!!! (Proceeds to scream for 4 minutes)


In all seriousness though, it's a great game. No it isn't Budokai, or Xenoverse, or any other Dragon Ball game. Thank Kami. I like DBZ games, but none of them are great games. Some are pretty fun, yeah, but you can't really fairly say that you'd just want to sit down and play them for hours if they weren't Dragon Ball related. This one is different in that the core game is great, and the devs love Dragon Ball on top of that making it a fantastic adaptation. Every move is straight out of the series, character interactions that are all interesting and fun between characters you don't necessarily expect, and mechanics simple enough for a beginner such as myself to fighting games not to feel terribly intimidated by the game, yet deep enough to satisfy fans of the genre and make it quite competetive to boot. My only complaints so far are related to Bandai Namco's unfortunate troubles not releasing at midnight and allowing for enough servers to accomodate the millions of DBZ fans that will pick this game up. There are a few handful of servers capable of holding 64 players each, so you'll probably have to play offline. But that's fine with a story mode that has a boardgame look to it like some previous DBZ games and a fairly interesting story where most of Earth's defenders have been weakened by mysterious waves, with the only hope being you, the player, being able to "link" into other characters to fight a mysterious and somewhat familiar threat. Overall great, but the online issues definitely detract from the experience as of now. It'll probably solve itself over time, or be fixed by Bandai or ArcSys, who seem pretty determined to make this a great game.

An absolutely stellar game, both as a fighting game and as a Dragon Ball game. The plot isn't half-bad and the numerous dialogue between the various characters are extremely fun to listen to as a Dragon Ball fan. The music is awesome, if a little on the repetitive side since there are a lot of dialogue scenes in this game where you'll here one of a few tracks, but typically the action and the conversations are engaging enough for me to overlook it.

Goku and the entire DBZ cast look better than they ever have in any other video game, beating out even Xenoverse 2's graphics by a considerable margin in terms of proper homage to the designs within the franchise. The effects are gorgeous and there have to be dozens of little nods to the series within the roster, with most, if not all attacks, having appeared in the Dragon Ball manga/anime at one point or another.

The gameplay is super crisp and smooth. I don't have the chance to play fighting games often, FighterZ only being my second 'real' fighter, however, I still found much enjoyment in the game, even when I floundered around trying to figure out how to do some proper non-automatic combos. New players to the genre will have fun and will quickly pick up on the intricacies of the combat, whilst genre veterans will be able to pull off awesome combos where you can truly feel like you're a part of the Dragon Ball universe.

I have not tried the online component, so I will not comment on it quite yet.

Overall, 9.5/10. An absolutely amazing game that both fighting game fans and Dragon Ball fans will adore for a long time. Any fighting games coming out this year are going to have some seriously stiff competition from ArcSystem's Dragon Ball FighterZ. Don't pass this game up, or you will seriously be missing out.

I'm not usually a fan of fighting games, but games like DBZ Budokai always were an exception and had a special place in my heart growing up. When I heard there was a new fighting game in the DBZ universe coming out, I jumped at the chance to play it. 

The game seems relatively straightforward, the controls (while taking a while to get used to on a xbox controller) are relatively easy to pick up and understand. 

The biggest issue with the game is the amount of servers that are available. If you take a look, there's only around 40 or so servers in the US West and East regions, each. In smaller regions, there's maybe a handful of servers, and each server holds up to 64 players concurrently. Given the popularity of the game, there is no way to play it at the moment. In the time from when I bought the game to the hour after when I decided to return it, I spent most of that time disconnecting from a lobby after being the last person in, only to find all of the lobbies full after I got kicked. 

The only place where I was consistently able to connect were the UK and Japan servers, but that led to their own issues of poor connection quality. When I did fight someone, I was either able to watch as my team was helplessly defeated, with me being unable to really offer any input whatsoever, or I was just outright kicked from the match. 

I want to like this game, but since most of my time within that one hour was spent just trying to connect to the game, I have to say I'm a little disappointed, and a little worried that anyone wanting to spend any amount of time on this game is going to spend the majority of it waiting to connect to a full lobby, if at all.

From my 8 hours so far. I've beaten the main story (63% completeness)  and have about 40 fights against other players. What I can tell you is its very easy to pick up but very hard to master. If you're looking for a ground breaking DBZ story this game might not be for you. It's pretty good but if you will never touch the online then its not worth it. However once you get to online oh my god is it fun. They have a currency in-game. It's called zeni, which in the DBZ universe is their money. Basically you play matches or the story and you get zeni. You use this zeni to open up capsules and get avatars/emotes. Simple but honestly really enticing. For now I keep fighting people in the hopes I can get a super rare Gohan avatar. (that may or may not exist).

As I said at the start the real issue for us PC players is that they gave 40  servers across America (My country) with 14 for US East/West Coast and 4 for Mexico/Canada (East/west). With a total size of 64 players per server. So roughly 3k people can play at a given time and thats way to few. A lot of people are haten on this game because thats really the only bad things thats going on. That and being disconnected a few times (which I can confirm has happened to me) but it happens. 

Overall I think this game has a bright future. Has plenty to offer a new person or a veteran to fighting games and it will get better.

so, Ive been playing the game for 10 hours now, and heres my thoughts.
   
>Story-the story is really fun. great cutscenes that dont feel too choppy, great mapping system that mixes together RPG with 2d fighter. so far ive gotten up to the part where i save android 21 from cell, so i have a long way to go but so far i really enjoy it

>Gameplay-its absolutely amazing. no question there. as nice of the idea it is to have a 3d open fighter dragonball game, it just doesnt work. it cant work with how fast the reality of dragon ball is. thats why dragon ball is destined for 2D side scrolling. its able to balance speed and flow, and for that reason is able to make you feel fast af boi without getting too overwhelmed.

>Graphics-oh my god, this is probably the best part of the game. everything before ultimate tenkaichi=great graohics (especially for the limitations it had). ultime tenkaichi=stiff and awkward models. raging blast= semi stiff and awkward models. battle of Z- how do they talk with their mouths closed (thinking emoji). extreme budoten= 3ds limitations. xenoverse= how could you make the characters any more glossy and shiny, dear god its ugly. dokkan battle= lmao mobile players. now, fighterZ= LSD TRIP, WHAT A RIDE ONCE IN A LIFE TIME EXPIRENCE HOLY SHEET. (accurate representation). point is- naruto and one piece games found their perfect art style years ago. dragon ball just found theirs today. perfection.

>multiplayer- me personally, i have yet to expirence connectivity issues with opponents. im sure ive only gotten lucky though, as most games on release have awful connectivity issues. really fun, if youre playing with randoms that is. good luck trying to play with your friends, as well described in the next section

>servers- this is the worst part of the game. have fun trying to get into a server. 99% of the time the servers are ALL full. bandai decided "hey, we know EVERYONES hyped about this game, so lets make sure only around 2000 people of the 300 MILLION PEOPLE IN THE US be allowed to be in online servers at a time. lets put this into a perspective i like to call 'comparisons'. take a game such as, i dont know... black ops 2? the game is 5 years old and yet, the player base on average right now is about 10000-20000 people at a time. so now take fighter Z. a brand new game that has been preordered HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF TIMES by now. so lets just say 100,000 people are playing this game right now in the U.S alone. only 2000 of those people, aka 1/50 of those players are able to play online. the other 48/50 are stuck in offline mode, meaning they can only fight CPU's. WHO THOUGHT THIS WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA? on top of that, if you wanna play with a friend, you guys have to be in the same serve. considering its nearly impossible right now to get in a server, imagine trying to get you and your buddy in the same server.

>optimization- its not that bad for PC controls tbh. i have WASD for movement, and im using the number pad for my attacks. works nicely, feels comftoable. the only gripe i have is that theyre expecting you to play with an xbox contoller, instead of saying "use W A S D to move" it says "use UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT STICKS to move". so once you can get past that confusion, the controls are alright. as for graphics, i have the best of the best (ex. 1080 ti) so i have no problem with maxing out graphics. so the one thing i cant review this game on is how well it performs for less powerful computers.

>currency- yes, this game has lootboxes. yes, they are wonderful. I know, its usually weird hearing lootboxes and wonderful in the same sentence, but they made lootboxes how theyre supposed to be made; purely cosmetic. no boosts or passives to give you an extra hand in the battle, no character unlocks (imagine that, unlocking Beerus through RNG lmao). the lootboxes give you hub avatars, icons, banners, stickers, things like that. they dont change the outcome of the game, they simply give you a reason to keep playing, and thats why i love it.

>Hub world- i hear a lot of people complaining about this one. personally i like it. i think its neat that all the modes you can do can be accsesed in a tiny little hub. think of xenoverse. that hub world was HUGE. very hard to get to the shop when youre on the other side of the map, so there i could see why people would complain. but here? it takes 5 seconds to go from the shop to literally anywhere else in the map. so to those complaining that its making the game take forever to get from one mode to the other: calm down lmao.

>characters. finally, the fighterz in the game. and the answer is, theyre just eh. yes, the special moves they have are BEAUTIFUL and are the exact reason im not gonna totally and completely shit on this section, but lets be real, 80% of the time, youre not using a special move, youre just using normal moves, and unfourtunately, ALL the normal combos and moves are nearly identical for each character (with the exception of trunks, blaze that sword into battle baby). technically speaking, none of them have an exact reused moveset as another character, but relitavely speaking, god do they feel so similar. this usually happens with every fighting game though, its very hard to make a punch from one character feel completely different from a punch that another character has (expect for smash bros, love that unique shit).

SUMMARY
--------------------
so, youve made it this far into the review, ayy lmao thanks for reading. let me go ahead and sum it all up for you guys.

Story: 8/10 (so far)
Gameplay: 9/10
Graphics: 10/10
Multiplayer: 7/10
Servers: 0/10
Optimization: 6/10
Currency: 9/10
Hub world: 8/10
Characters: 5/10
Sexiness of my man Tien and his forehead viens: 10/10

Total: 72/100

Arc systems and Bandai have given full support to play FighterZ with a keyboard but there's no support in sight for fight sticks? 

 Hori literally made a new fightsick specifically for DBfighterz and the game has no support for them on PC? What a joke. The game itself is great but it's a real bummer when you practice and get used to using an arcade stick for this game during the betas only to be forced to use a game pad upon release. Very disappointing. Fight stick support needs to be added ASAP.

Edit: Im fully aware of the the different steps that can be taken To ensure fight stick functionality. The steam settings route did nothing for me but the x360 set up route was successful and I currently have full use of my TE2+ stick. 

My intention in leaving a negative review was not to slander the game itself but to bring attention to the devs about something that, in my eyes, is unacceptable for a 60$ game. The ratio of people that can‚Äôt get their sticks to work vs the people that have zero issues is exactly why the developers need to be made aware of the problem and fix this. I was lucky, some people aren‚Äôt. 

That being said, I am going to change my review to a thumbs up since it‚Äôs not entirely fair to steer people away from this game based on this single issue. Just want to make sure that this controller caveat is made clear to anyone who intends to buy this game. It‚Äôs awesome and fun, a 10/10 dragon ball game and a phenomenal fighting game at that. Just be warned that you may experience controller support issues until Arcsystems gets around to fixing it.

This game is fun, let me start with that. Despite any other greivances that I or anybody may have with this game it is almost certainly one of the most fun (for the non-fighting game player, which many people are) fighting games out at the moment and it's easy of access and low-skill requirement is sure to draw more people in.
Arc System works has done a great job making a Dragonball game here and make no mistake because that is what this is, it makes absolutely no attempt to be a reskined Guilty Gear(despite the graphical similarities), Blaze Blue, or any of their other projects. The effortless combos, rediculous power levels, and world shattering specticals make sure of it and it's fine that it isn't BB or GG because it makes no attempt to be.

Quick Pros:
-Fast Paced Fun
-Dragonball
-Made by a dev team who knows(more or less) what they're doing
-It's just fun

Quick Cons:
-Online is kind of terrible
-The UI is shit

The two cons above are really the only non-subjective downsides that I can offer but you should note they're pretty big. The online mode forces you to go into a 64 player max lobby, This *could* be fine if there were an unlimited amount of these and if there were other ways to play with people but there isn't. For any given region (in NA) that I've seen you have at most a dozen or so lobbies, meaning in the whole of North America there can be at most ~1000 people playing online. Now you might say "Well surely I could just play with my friends, I don't have to be in a lobby" No person reading this on steam, you can not. To play with ANYONE you and the other person have to be in the same lobby together.
Granted, however, playing online is very decent. I've only experienced lag once over the course of 40-ish games.

The UI isn't actually too bad itself it's just moderately annoying having to go into a lobby(there is an offline lobby) to do anything, even quite to title.

Ultimately I don't regret my purchase and I would/do recommend this game because the gameplay is just that good. It's still early on in the game's life (less than one full day on PC) so let's hope Arc Systems gets their shit together and fixes this godforsaken online.
5 servers in Oceania region? Only 64 players per server, 320 player slots, what the fuck? Shove this right up your ass. Refund!

NOICE

_Introduction_

I'm going to present the points that make me don't want to play the game and ask for a refund.

_Points_

The online multiplayer sucks (this is what kills the game for me):
Get your shits together ArkSys, is the same thing over and over with you. Why don't you listen to people and implement Rollback Netcode. You do NOT need NASA engineers to implement it. You have money, use it in the places you are lacking.

* There is a lot of input delay with people near and in the country (in this case Chile and Argentina).
* Lobbies are always full.
* The game isn't using rollback netcode (already mentioned)

The game feels like is in beta:
Looks half baked, is like you focused too much in the Gameplay (well, I can't blame, gameplay >> menus) and the pretty (in battle) assets.

* The ring's logic is dumb: Why there only can be two active battles peer ring if it can accept a lot of people (was 8? can't remember)? The only thing you cause with this is people jumping from ring to ring.
* The overworld is a waste of time: I still don't know why they are using this idea again (this came from GGXrd iirc, some people like it and others don't). Good lobby implementation are the simple ones, straight to the point (skull Girls, GGXX series, BB series, KI).
* The large EULA you need to "read" and accept to play the game (LMAO, to "skip" it you need to hold the down button for like 1 min... at least you only need to do it once... right?).

_Conclusion_

So, based on the previous points and IMHO this game isn't worth 59.99 USD + DLC. It feels like it should cost 19.99 to 29.99 USD... b-but you have to pay the creators of DB for the rights to use the franshise... na, isn't worth it. Pick this game in a sale or if you are a die-hard fan of Dragon Ball.

If you are a fan of the 2d fighting games: SSB4, Tekken etc. You will find that this game is very broken. Usually for a game type like this playing defense is a huge part; but with FighterZ, you can literlly instant trans behind them and get a cheap shot. Also the block breaker move is dumb. I am a huge fan of the DBZ saga and DBS but this just did not fit me. This is my opinion of course. Maybe this will help other people with super high expectations.

Calling the lobby system ill-conceived is an understatement, I rarely even manage to auto-join lobbies. The online lobbies are mostly people AFK or doing Arcade mode etc. and not using the online functionality. I'm in Texas (no Midwest, South, Central, w/e servers btw, you get to pick between East Coast and West Coast with no in-between) and in order to netplay with other friends from Texas we had to meet up on the Venezuela server or the Middle East servers.

That being said, online works on garbage. I'm running a GTX 1070 with an i5-6600k and 16GB ram, yet somehow this game destroys my machine on the recommended settings; something about online play makes Windows think it's malware or something and causes Windows Defender to eat up 20% of my CPU resources. This wouldn't be an issue but DBFZ will take up over 70% CPU randomly while (apparently) not fully utilizing my GPU. I'll be playing and randomly my FPS will drop down to 1-2. This only happens with online play, and while I'm willing to blame Windows, this never happens in other games, so I believe DBFZ is the culprit.

The game seems to have an active online so I'd love to play it, but I'm seriously considering refunding this game (if it's even possible at this point). I'm sure it's fun, but I can't even play.

The only thing I have to criticise is playing online against friends. To be able to fight against friends you have to be in the same lobby which are restricted to a maximum of 64 players. But if you manage to do so, the network is flawless.

1. graphics are amazing.

[b][h1]BAD STUFF:[/h1][/b]

1. connection problems (might be a release-day problem only, can't tell more right now. some disconnects etc....)
2. Combosystem feels not amazing - it feels like you could choose any character available, and the combo / super / whatever button-combo is always the same - only very few differences
3. Story - scroll down, i'll explain.
4. Price! 94 bucks for the game + a few characters (DLC later?) feels a bit too much for a fighting game tbh. 

----

yes there are kinda low amount of servers. they should have doubled or trippled the amount of servers in the beginning weekend for sure - just to be safe. so you CAN struggle to get on a server, or choose a server that is already filled up with some other guy. happens, not too annoying tbh.

losing connection is annoying, but happened like 4 times in like 9 hours of playtime, which is totally fine for me. (i played the Storyfor the most time so far)

to the Story mode - little SPOILER!!! - its kinda easy mode story-telling happening. You (the player) are the "Soul" that is linked to different fighters over the story-timeline. they call it "linked". the characters are not able to fight without these link. they are trying to get rid of it with the help of Bulma.

once you beat the first part of the "Story", with the good guys, you have to do the same story from the bad boy perspective, but actually its exactly the same story. bla bla .... soul.... bla bla ....link .... bla bla .... we must get rid of it.... which is kinda unspectactular and dismal.

Then there is a little bit of real story, when it comes to Android 21, but there is actually not much to say, and i dont want to spoiler this part for anyone who is interested in playing it. 

finishing this writing, i really hope this game doesnt get boring after a few days, so my 94 bucks wont hurt that much.
in general, great game, would recommend to any Dragon Ball fan out there, but not absolutely the 94 bucks version right now - but that will show the time and the announces of the "new" characters. 59 bucks for the game right now is a bit too much for a fighting game, but whatever.

The Game is amazing, only gripes are that Arcade diffuculty spikes tremedously after about 2 matches and if someone has bad framerates, it brings you down to their framerate, shits a slideshow.
This is a prime example of what a Dragon Ball game should be, flashy, over the top combos, beams flying everywhere. All done with just a few button presses.

It's alright, I'll probably pick it up again on sale or when my main gripes are fixed.

The Good

- It's easy to pick up and learn, you'll be able to do an optimal combo in no time
- It has a fully featured, reasonably fun story mode.
- It has a fully featured, fun Arcade Mode
- It has a reasonable lobby system when it works, the only issue right now would be trying to get in the same lobby as a few friends to make a party room or whatever it's called.

The Bad:

- Every lobby in my region is 64/64, either add a dynamic system that adds more lobbies as they fill up or give us an extra 10 per region (why does japan have 4 when china has 10?)

- The game runs as choppy as can be on an i7 7600k + 1070 with dropped frames everywhere.

- The combo trials show the default bindings instead of whatever you have your buttons bound to, and the combo trials are relatively weak and easy to execute compared to what is possible.

- A few characters are locked behind single player gameplay and require you to finish story mode arcs or arcade mode challenges to unlock them.

- Every cinematic is 24fps (including mid game) and is jarring to deal with when it's mid combat.

I definitely recommand this game. Didn't have any issue sor far for online matchmaking or in game. Runs very well too! 

So far, looks like it's the best fighting game I ever played. GG Arc System Works :)

Pros:
+Fantastic Visuals 
+Authentic Dragon Ball experience more than any of the other Dragon Ballfighters up until now
+Very balanced and very smooth performance
+Excellent presentation and a fine entry to the competetive fighter industry.

Neutral but noteworthy:
~Game is only 4.6 GB really, but it doesn't feel like a small game when you get into it at all. Probably just small because of the amount of 2D assets and basic textures.

Cons
-I tried 2 different fightsticks and neither of them worked; they are popular ones that work in literally every other fighter game out right now. No fightstick support really hurts this game.
-Online lobby mode is a mess. When you go to connect it's like there are only 4 servers of 64 players max for your area and they are always just constantly full.
-Game feels limited. Anyone familiar with dragonball games is going to expect a huge roster and all types of special moves and such....here you get a much more limited character selection; I expected this to mean the ones they focused on would be that much deeper but in reality they are just more balanced...their movelist has shrunken considerably.

I would pick this game up 100% absolutely...in the near future if possible; maybe not just right yet, give them a week and see if they fix the lobby and fightstick problems, if they do that; then it is certainly worth picking up.

Going to suggest no right now, but up this to a thumbs up probably in a few days if they get these issues resolved.

What can I say, I'm a Dragon Ball shill and this game is made by ArcSys. Accessible for super newbies and has a lot of depth for veterans. Attention to detail is immense.

Xenoverse this is not.  Nor is it a Tenkaichi.  The best way to describe this game is a dash of Budokai, a happy serving of DBZ: Hyper Dimension, a twist on Budokai 2's world map system (but better), and the visual style of DBZ Super.  I think, never watched Super.  I don't know if it's intentional, but cutscenes seem to be.... Halting?  Stuttering?  But not like my computer is struggling with it.  60 fps is pretty much the only number being reported so if it wasn't a stylistic choice, hopefully it'll be patched.

How's the story you ask?  It's there.  Luckily you can skip it.  The whole "everyone is roughly the same power" factor of a dbz fighting game is at least explained away in a fashion the other games miss, but it's a fighting game.  Story isn't going to be good.  

While character selection being dropped down to 21(I think) characters without including DLC and ones yet to be released, is a bit of a disapointment after coming from Xenoverse or Tenkaichi, the depth of each character and the unique interactions kinda makes up for it.

Overall, I'm liking this game a lot.  But if you want more xenoverse then go play the 2nd one.  This game may not be for you.

There's some weird things like the lobby system, and by extension the lack of lobby space (either make lobbies hold more players or add more players). There's not matchmaking for the 6 player mode either so it's really difficult to find a random game for that.

That aside, this is by far the best fighter I've ever played. It's easy to learn, hard to master, and the characters feel nicely varied despite using the same general attack commands. The game also pays homage to the anime very well with different intro/outros and in battle voice overs depending on who is fighting who. 

If you are into DBZ, fighters, or (even better) both then there's no reason not to get this game. The flaws pale in comparison to its overwhelming strengths.

Small roster is very noticable after a dozen rounds or so, especially with multiple copy characters. The DLC characters should have been included in the base but I still recommend.

The online lobbies are a nightmare and poorly designed. We don't need a carnival style display, just give us an old fashioned fighting game lobby FFS!

Not just an amazing Dragon Ball game, but an amazing fighting game.

Only DB fans and people who are bad at fighting games, but want to play them, will enjoy this. Dragon Ball FighterZ is a party game at best, with easy auto-combos and supers, the game desperately and unapologetically lowers the skill ceiling to appeal to more people, and it tries to make the player feel good by making everything look stylish and flashy even though all the player is doing is pressing X, Y and B with the occasional A over and over. As a fighting game player, I can see how more casual party gamers can enjoy this game for these reasons, but it's even easier to see why someone can hate the game for this. Oh yeah and the lobby system and menus for this game is far, far worse than anything Capcom could've ever created. When I started the game up I was surprised to see that not even 30 seconds in, it was trying to put me into an online lobby instead of say, a main menu where I could decide where I wanted to go from there. The exclusion of private online lobbies is also a huge problem for me, given I have friends I would like to enjoy this game with, but sadly can't because either they won't always be able to join the lobby I'm currently in or vice versa. Overall, this game feels like a HUGE work in progress and is definitely not worth the $60, I bought the game with low to no expectations and I was still disappointed, that's how awful this is. If this is what the future of ArcSys games looks like, then I want out.
