Dragonball FighterZ is hands down my favorite Dragonball game TO DATE and heres why.

The game has about 26 fighters to play as. sadly it is dissaponting that they have 2 versions of goku and vegeta and are basically seperate characters but they have the same move sets apart from their specials. but besides that hiccup the other problems with the game are very easy to fix. such as the lack of open servers from the U.S. which im sure Bandai Namco and Arc System Works are looking into fixing fairly soon. 

The Story:
The Story taking place between the Goku Black and Tornament of Power Arcs is perfect cause it adds to Supers canon and so far has a lot of potential. as well as the fact that the story is all about saving the other fighters and leveling them up which i find increadiably fun and it fits very well with the fighting game formula. basically in a nut shell it takes the fighting game genre and flips it on its head for the story mode.

The Gameplay:
Fighting in this game feels very Dragonaball. from the sounds to the hits and whenever Gohan says SHIEET i lose it. (if you dont know where thats from or havent heard Gohan say it go watch Team Four Star). i myself am terrible at fighting games. im much more accustom to shooters and other such genres but my love for dragonball and this game in general is making me give fighting games an actual chance and so far im not dissapointed. and its increadiably easy to pick up but hard as hell to master so if you into that then you might like the game's brand of mechanics.

Loot Box:
i decided to speak on this for a second, yes the game has loot boxes but not shitty greedy awful ones. in fact you cant even buy them with actual money. the game handles how it gives you Zeni and the Premium Z coins very well and its nice to have a sort of purpose to play all of the modes. to continously unlock new lobby avatars and Z stamps and such that im glad they have this system in and i hope you agree with me that Cosmetic Loot Boxes are always a nice thing if implemented properly (I.E. cant purchase them with actual money).

Conclusion: 
If you love fighting games, and Dragonball, Z, and Super, you will love this game. i urge you to purchase this if you can. otherwise wait for a price drop. but dont let this gem pass you by this year. thanks for reading my long ass review. have a great day!

An excellent fighter, let down by what is by far the most awful online system I have ever had the misfortune to experience. There are no private lobbies, you cannot host your own game. If you want to play with your friends, you need to arrange to meet in a public lobby. This might not be so bad if there were ample public lobbies, but Arc System Works has underestimated demand to a comical extreme. There are just 6 public lobbies for the UK, each which can take only 64 players. In a country of 63 million people, Arc System Works didn't consider the possibility that more than 384 people might buy their game.

Other countries have similarly low limits, and finding a public lobby becomes an exercise in trying out country after country until one with low player numbers can be found. Even when a lobby is found, your problems are only just beginning. Despite a player limit of just 64, the servers are laggy and error prone. Setting up a match was an exercise in frustration - either the player's avatars didn't show up, or when trying to join a room a mysterious "room full" error would occur, even when the room only had 2/8 occupants.

Even if there were sufficient servers, and the bugs in the servers fixed so that the game could actually be played, the interface Arc System Works has designed is a textbook example of how not to design a user interface. Instead of menus, players have to wander around a map with avatars and actually locate each other before they can play together. Functionally that would normally be reached through a menu, like going into practice mode, or changing the lobby, are instead hidden behind non-descript NPCs you have to talk to.

It's impossible to understate how terrible every aspect of this system is. Arc System Works have created an truly excellent multiplayer game, and then made it virtuallty impossible to play online. The excellence and the gameplay and visuals make the incompetance of the online experience all the most jarring.

God the game is so good. As a competitive fighter, Its so much fun and plays alot like Marvel Vs Capcom 2. It brings good memories of Dragon Ball as well. But of course Goku Black is OP AF.

"That lobby is full"

This is the message I got upon logging into the game the second time around. I couldn't find a single open lobby on the East Coast. Overall, it appeared there were only about 1,000 slots for online players.

Except, to play at all, you need to be online. So I couldn't even play the story mode.

The gameplay is excellent. It really, really is. As a low level fighting game palyer, I really was getting the hang of it and having a serious blast. But it seems the game is built with a low population in mind in the first place. I got into this because I thought I'd be able to play it as a relative novice in fighting games. I guess not, since I can't even log in.

The fighting mechanics are solid, and the tutorials are pretty good, but the lobby and "hub" that works as the main "menu" of the game is absolutely atrocious. They're a confusing and convoluted mess that result in a very poor experience and seem intent on doing their best to keep you from actually getting into fights with others.

To give an example, if you want to play with a friend, you have to:

1. Ensure you both pick the same Region to play in.
2. Ensure you both pick the same lobby to enter. At the time of writing, most lobbies are full and you have to just retry over and over until you get lucky. You cannot create your own.
3. Once you're both in the same lobby, you must create an "Arena" with rulesets and an optional password
4. Your friend must find you in the hub, enter this Arena, and challenge you

Want to pick another lobby? You have to exit to title, re-choose region, re-choose lobby, and go. At the time of writing you'll be randomly kicked from a lobby due to server strain. There is no other way to play with friends. What in the world were they thinking..?

You cannot see what lobby you're in once you're in. Since it remembers between game restarts, that's... not ideal.


While terrifically impressive graphically and a solid fighting game when you actually get to fight, I just cannot recommend this and have requested a refund. I play these games to play with friends, and this one just seems intent on not making that a possibility.

Should you buy it? Yes! Absolutely but you should know the pros and cons

Pros:
- Fantastic presentation
- Well developed roster with all your favorites
- Excellent in depth fight system that is better than the new Marvel VS Capcom
- Original story with a new villain
- Optimized
- Funny, characters roast each other often and joke around, story is at it's best when it doesn't take itself too seriously
- You don't have to be a fan of DB to enjoy it..
- Alot of content
- Characters are varied and unique.
- Music has alot of metal, rock, and other appropriate music.
- You have to unlock SSB Goku and Virgina, and it's challenging like it should BE!

Cons:
- Dialogue is occasionally cringy, usually when the characters are trying to be serious.
- No fightstick support, which I don't care about, but others might. Controller works just fine though.
- Just little weird nuances that might bother you.

For those of you with crappy PC's and are worried about whether or not you can run this game.
My specs are for the most part, hitting the required fields for this game to run. i7 intel core. 8 gb RAM. 64 bit processor. However, my pc is well under the minimum 1 gb vRAM requirement. for any 3D game, this would mean I'd have to sacrifice FPS in order to get this game playing, which for a fighting game would be unplayable. Despite this, Arc-Sys has done a lot of  optimizing as well as giving an absolutley huge range of supported graphical options. If your PC is like mine and isn't exactly a good gaming computer, you should be able to still hit that sweet 60fps without frame drops if your willing to lower the quality a tad.

That's not to say this game is perfect. The lobbys are unnecessarily small making online kinda not worth it at this point. Not to mention there is currently no way to invite friends to play online against you.
I've also seen the forums get flooded with "No Arcade stick support" rants. I'm currently using a Hori RAP V (Which is essentially the exact same as the RAP IV, but with Nintendo Switch Support) and I did'nt even know this was an issue until I hopped off and saw everyone complaining.

As far as gameplay goes, it's not exactly super in depth for a fighting game. Certain mechanics are dumbed down a bit. It's not as if it's a super simple game with no room for improvement (such as generic AAD fighting games), but its also not quite as in depth as BlazBlue and nowhere near as in depth as Guilty Gear (the two biggest Arc-Sys Fighing games). 

As a Dragon Ball game, you'll probably find this game a little more difficult than the standard fare. In most DB games, you've probably found yourself trying to go around enemy attacks and throwing out supers whenever you can. Since this a fighting game, there is also the requirment of understanding combos. There is the "Easy combo system" (Pressing light over and over), but that won't get you very far beyond the main story mode. It's nowhere near as hard to get into as other fighting games, but you probably won't be able to win online if you don't practice a lot.

If you are wondering about the roster size, keep in mind this is a real fighing game. Other DB games get by on their large rosters by reusing a lot of attacks over different characters. It's not hard (comparitively speaking) to copy over similar animations for different characters. For example, in XV2, a lot of characters have nearly identical animations for most attacks in order for them to save time and money on development. You won't be finding anything like that here (Even among characters like Blue Goku or Teen Gohan, a lot of moves are completely different, though there is SOME copy and paste animation)

Overall, I found this game to be amazing in most regards. As it is right now, if you're on the fence about it, don't worry. It's not going anywhere, and when you do pick it up, it'll likely be even better than it is now.

The game itself is very good, a very good DBZ game and a good fighter, the problem is that a lot of people (including me) like a open-world game more, this game gives a limit to the character movements and the battlestyle.

What's remarkable about this game is the balance between casual fun and competative level gameplay. It's very easy to pick up a controller and enjoy yourself right away, but if you feel that you want more depth there's endless room for improvement.

Good fun. Auto-combos almost ruin the skill gap, but theres always ways to counter them, and after a few hours you know what to expect from the most played characters if they keep spamming. 

Recommended, but I wouldn't pay full price again. Wait for a sale; its worth around ¬£25-30, ¬£45 is slightly steep for what you get imo.

Game is great and my stick works because I'm not an imbecile who doesn't know how to configure a controller on Steam.

Edit: If you still don't know how to configure your controller, go to Settings, Controller, then General Controller Settings. Plug it in and define the layout, save it and it should be recognized by every Steam game from now on (as an Xbox controller, so if you have a Playstation or some other controller, you'll still see Xbox-style prompts).

Some legitimate grievances I have with the game so far.

- No traditional menu. The overworld idea is cute, but it just gets in the way of the game.
- Not nearly enough lobbies.
- No ability to invite a player for a match directly from your friends list, as far as I can tell. This was present in Guilty Gear XrD. If there is a way and you know how to, please leave a comment.
- No ability to change the button prompts to generic ones, forced to see Xbox-style inputs (A, B, X and Y, instead of L, M, H and S). Very confusing, especially if not using the default layout.

Yet, the game looks and plays great, so I still recommend it.

There are a few problems (arcade sticks not natively working - bunch of easy workaround available, even using steam settings for dinput controllers), but outside of that, you've got a superbly optimised and slick fighting game that captures the essence of the franchise perfectly. 

It's quick, visual and easy to get into, but has a clear level of depth and tactical play to appease the hardcore fighting purists too. And it's Dragon Ball, so, that's always a bonus. 

There's a lot of love that's gone into this game - that much is clear. From the small character interactions to the faithfully renditioned super attacks, they got the style down to a tee. Would highly recommend.
